
                               1 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                 Aswat Masriya

                            November 10, 2014 Monday

Student protests take the lead in October - Democracy Index

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 331  words


CAIRO, Nov 10 (Aswat Masriya) - October witnessed a rise in the rate of
protests, as 643 protests were held during the month, the majority of which were
organised by students, said Democracy Index.

The Cairo-based index released on Monday a report on the rate of protests in
October, noting a rise in the number of protests held during the month by 130
protests, compared to September.

Students took the lead with 209 protests held in October, making up 32.5 percent
of the protests held during the month. Students' top demand was releasing
detainees, a demand which 256 protests called for.

Muslim Brotherhood protests ranked second, with 204 protests held (31.7
percent). Residents' protests made up 17 percent of October's protests (108
protests), while labourers held 94 protests.

Political demands made up 66 percent of October's protests, while social demands
were called for in 34 percent of the protests. Some of the top demands called
for during the protests included: "ending the military rule" (69 protests),
condemning "terrorist" acts (54 protests) and condemning the police's
"repressive practices" (14 protests).

Protesters used 25 different types of protests, eight of which were of a violent
nature, Democracy Index said. Violent protests included: blocking roads (46
protests), disrupting officials' processions (nine protests), breaking into
institutions and blocking them (6 protests), torching public and private
properties (four protests), as well as one case of suicide and another of
attempted suicide.

The majority of October's protests were held in Cairo (151 protests), followed
by Giza (66 protests). The index owed this to the "return of the centralist
nature of the decision-making process."

The border-governorates of South Sinai and Marsa Matrouh witnessed the smallest
number of protests; one protest was held in each governorate.

Democracy Index is a research project issued by the Cairo-based International
Development Centre to monitor protests rate in Egypt.

                               Miadhu (Maldives)

                             June 11, 2015 Thursday

Police launchestwo forms of notices for protests

LENGTH: 228  words


Maldives Police Service (MPS) has launched two forms of notices for protests to
be filed 36 hours before any protest.

An announcement made in the Police website stated that Police have to be
informed of any protest 36 hours prior to the protest. The announcement added
that protest organizers have to be present in a meeting arranged by the Police
to discuss the issues regarding the protest.

Police stated that protest leaders should inform the Police of the protest via a
form and sms. In the form, details of the protest such as corresponding Police
office, full information of the protest leaders and the date, time and duration
of the protest. Additionally, the routes on which protests will take place have
to be mentioned in the form. If the protest is one that is organized by a
political party, a copy of the decision of the Party regarding the protest has
to be filed with the form.

In addition to the form, protest organizers can inform Police via sms sent to
9888899. All information in the forms must be sent in the sms.

Freedom of Assembly Act states that Police have to be notified of the protests
36 hours before the protest. The principles of the notice will be published by
the Police.

The new principles on the notice have been issued at a time when a mass rally
for this Friday had been announced. The protest is to be a sit-ing protest on
MajeedheeMagu.

LOAD-DATE: June 11, 2015

                               Egypt Independent

                          December 31, 2014 Wednesday

Report: 2,274 labor protests staged in 2014

BYLINE: Nehal Mostafa

LENGTH: 359  words


Egypt saw 2,274 labor protests in 2014, according to the Mahrousa Forum for
Researches and Public Policy Studies.A report issued by the forum, affiliated to
El-Mahrousa Center for Socioeconomic Development (MCSD), showed that the first
quarter of the year including January, February and March witnessed the highest
number of protests reaching 1,420. The last quarter including October, November
and December came in second place with 318 protests. The third quarter including
July, August and September followed with 305 protests, whereas the second
quarter including April, May and June came in the last place with 231 protests.
Cairo had highest number of protests, reaching 429. Alexandria came next with
185 protests, followed by Sharqiya with 150 protests. Luxor saw the lowest
number of protests reaching 16, the report said.Factory workers staged the
highest number of demonstrations reaching 558 (25% of the total). Civil servants
came in the second place with 426 protests (19%), followed by the medical sector
with 323 protests (14%), the educational sector with 137 protests (6%) and the
textile sector with 117 protests (5%). Drivers staged 110 protests, the security
sector 94 protests, the trade and investment sector 67 protests, the agriculture
sector 64 protests, the petroleum sector 63 protests, the cleaning sector 59
protests, media professionals 47 protests, the fertilizers sector staging 45
protests, the tourism sector with 42 protests, holders of masters and PhD and
graduates staging 35 protests, lawyers holding 29, the disabled with 24, sailors
with 19 and businessmen staging 15 protests.The report showed many forms for
protesting including strikes, vigils, marches, demonstrations, sit-ins, closure
of establishments, hunger strikes, filing reports, blocking roads, detaining
officials, gathering signatures and committing suicide.Social and economic
reasons topped the demands behind the protests, the report said, mentioning
reasons like disbursing financial dues, applying minimum wage, enhancing
financial and working conditions, layoffs, increasing investments to boost the
economy and releasing detained colleagues.

                                 Aswat Masriya

                           October 15, 2014 Wednesday

Decline in protest rate in September - Democracy Index

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 306  words


CAIRO, Oct 15 (Aswat Masriya) - The rate of protesting declined in September,
standing at 513 protests during the month against 647 protests during August,
the Cairo-based Democracy Index said on Wednesday.

Democracy Index noted a decline in the number of protests staged by the Muslim
Brotherhood. The group, listed as a terrorist organisation last December, staged
203 (39.5 percent) protests in September, compared to 414 (64 percent) in
August; almost half the number of protests.

Most of the Muslim Brotherhood's protests were held on Friday, making up 75
percent of the group's protests throughout the month. Fridays witnessed the
largest number of protests held during the month; 153 protests were held on the
four Fridays of last September.

The number of social and economic protests meanwhile rose in September, making
up 54 percent of the protests held during the month, compared to 35 percent last
month. This came at the expense of protests calling for civil and political
rights, which made up 46 percent of the protests, as opposed to 65 percent in
August.

The most frequent form of protests in September was hunger striking. Democracy
Index reported at least 1000 cases of hunger strikes, in solidarity with a
nation-wide campaign launched in late August in protest over last year's protest
law and calling for the release of all those detained due to the law.

Cairo hosted the highest number of protests in September; 118 protests making up
23 percent of the protests held nationwide. Alexandria ranked second with 56
protests while Giza ranked third with 45 protests. The Sinai Peninsula witnessed
the smallest number of protests; one protest was held in North Sinai and another
in South Sinai.

Democracy Index is a research project issued by the Cairo-based International
Development Centre to monitor protests rate in Egypt.

Following attempts by striking AUC students to lock the gates of the campus to
prevent people from entering, the university's administration elected to
completely remove the gates to allow free traffic. Later on, it closed its
campus and subsequently announced the university would suspend all operations
until further notice.

                           Cape Argus (South Africa)

                            February 20, 2015 Friday
                                   E1 Edition

More violent protests in 2014 than any previous year - study

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 297 words


South Africa's violent protests reached an all-time high in 2014, according to a
report by the Multilevel Government Initiative at the Community Law Centre,
released yesterday.

"Both the number of civic protests and the prevalence of violence increased in
2014," the centre said.

"In 2007 just less than half the protests were associated with some violence,
but in 2014 almost 80 percent of protests involved violence."

This was according to the Civic Protest Barometer which measures various trends
in protest action in South Africa.

"The number of protests in 2014 reached an all-time-high of 218. The previous
maximum was 204 in 2009 (which was also an election year)," the centre said.
"The increase in 2014 is only partly due to the election held on May 7. Although
April and May saw 25 and 30 protests, respectively, almost as many protests (28)
took place in August."

Between 2012 and 2014, Gauteng had more protests than any other province. Since
2007 Gauteng's share of protests had been rising more rapidly than any other
province.

Cape Town was the most protest-prone municipality, with 84 protests, followed by
Johannesburg, eThekwini, Tshwane and Ekurhuleni. These five municipalities
accounted for half of all protests recorded.

"Issues relating to municipal services and the administration of municipalities
were cited more often as the cause of protests than all other grievances put
together," it said.

"The barometer tests one hypothesis about the causes of protests, namely that it
signals a 'rebellion of the poor', against the empirical data." The barometer
covers the trends in the number of protests, geographical spread, trends in
violent civil protests and the grievances behind protests.

The Community Law Centre is based at the University of the Western Cape. - Sapa

                                The Irish Times

                             March 17, 2014 Monday

Irish language is for all, not just for the fluent

BYLINE: Una Mullally

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 839 words


The Irish-speaking community needs to pull itself out of the Gaeltacht, and it
is doing so at the moment. Everyone says "the Irish don't protest" as if it's a
truism. We don't really riot, but we do protest. Students protest, elderly
people protest, people protest about rights for those with disabilities, the
LGBT community protests, there have been austerity and Occupy protests, water
charge and property tax protests. Nurses protest and junior doctors protest. And
Irish speakers protest in large numbers. Last month, 10,000 people marched on
the D^oil expressing their concerns about the perceived failure of Government to
protect their linguistic rights. Unfortunately, Fine Gael has belittled the
Irish language by having spokespeople for Gaeltacht affairs who weren't even
fluent, with Dinny McGinley (whose ministerial responsibilities for Irish are
now junior ones, not senior) operating almost as an interpreter.

ConcernsThe problem that the leaders of the Irish-speaking demographic also face
is an inability to articulate their concerns in a clear manner. The resignation
of coimisinir teanga Se^on ^" Cuirre^oin, and the perceived weakening of the
Official Language Act, as well as Fine Gael's occasional kite-flying about
ending Irish as an obligatory Leaving Certificate subject, all illustrate an
apathy at Government level towards the importance of our native language. The
20-year strategy to increase the number of Irish speakers from 83,000 to 250,000
is both rudderless and toothless.

Irish speakers talk about second-class status, but there are also tiered
statuses among speakers themselves. In my experience, there has never been a
gr^o shared between the Gaeltacht and the Irish-speaking environs of Dublin,
even though Dublin has the potential to hold the key to the language's future.
Given the massive population of young people attending all-Irish speaking
schools in the greater Dublin area, there's an argument for Dublin eventually
even being the largest Gaeltacht in the State.

That said, the Gaeltacht areas aren't just about the language, but neither is
the language just about Gaeltacht areas. Yet if you want to "keep up" your Irish
in the capital, you're pretty much on your own. As someone who only became
fluent at 12 upon entering secondary school, "keeping up" my Irish is something
I have done in isolation, although such dedication has led to becoming a
presenter on TG4, an entity that has done an incredible amount to modernise,
celebrate and make visible the diversity of Irish-speaking voices in the
country.

But I remember as a teenager visiting my cousins in Spiddal and being shocked at
the students pouring out of their school speaking English. In my Irish-speaking
environment in Col^oiste ^osag^oin, between Stillorgan and Booterstown in
Dublin, if you were caught speaking English in uniform anywhere in the city
you'd be reprimanded by senior pupils, or by the hypothetical Stasi  that was
conjured up by the teaching staff, resulting in the dreaded bileog bu^K, or
"yellow sheet", signifying a meeting about your discrepancy, and a stint in
detention scraping chewing gum off the tables. Everyone spoke Irish. It became
an every-day language, a language you dreamt in. It became the subject and
product of brd, pride. We were outsiders embracing it. Whereas the insiders -
the children in Spiddal - appeared to reject it. To me that seemed to indicate a
complacency in the Gaeltacht, the paradox of the new speakers in Dublin being
more active about the language than the establishment.

My Irish isn't the best, but I try. Still, that isn't good enough. I've had
snide comments about "46A Irish", and have been in group situations where Irish
speakers switched from speaking Irish to those they were conversing with, to
speaking English to me. It's hurtful and exclusionary. And guess what? It makes
you not want to speak it.

Snobbery towards Irish is real, and so is snobbery within it. The language is
not a museum exhibit in a glass case that needs to be polished to perfection. It
is a working, living, breathing thing. And in terms of levels of fluency, the
intent to speak it - even if that means grasping for words or "Barlachas" - is
as valid as the poetic prose that flows from a native speaker.Not 'good enough'
The idea that one's Irish isn't "good enough" unless it's fluent, is unfair.
Instead of celebrating the "cpla focal" people might have, fluent Irish speakers
have a tendency to make people feel inadequate if that's all they have. There is
no sense of social acceptance if you have broken Irish, and therefore little
impetus to use what Irish you have. And if you don't use it, you lose it.

Preserving the Irish language is not just about the boundaries of Gaeltacht
areas being drawn on linguistic criteria. Our language is the foundation on
which all of our historical, cultural and traditional output has been based.
It's our language. It belongs as much to the first generation Irish-Nigerian kid
as it does to the bean an t^K in Gaoth Dobhair.

LOAD-DATE: March 17, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2014 The Irish Times
                              All Rights Reserved


                               8 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                               Egypt Independent

                              April 1, 2013 Monday

Report: In March, Egypt had highest rate of protest worldwide

BYLINE: Egypt Independent

LENGTH: 315 words


In a March report titled "Democracy Indicator," an Egyptian rights center said
Egypt has one of the highest rates of protest, having witnessed 1,354 protests
in March, up from 864 in February.

According to the report issued by the International Development Center, Egypt
has never seen such a high rate of protest before, not even at the peak of the
25 January revolution. In March, Egypt had 1.8 protests every hour, 7.2 protests
every four hours, 44 protests a day and 306 protests a week.

Forty different categories of people staged protests. People with no political
affiliations staged 309 protests, while activists came in second, with 190
protests. The security sector occupied the third rank, with 173 protests
throughout the month.

Demonstrations over labor rights accounted for the most protests, while the fuel
crisis triggered 112 protests. Seventy-three protests were staged to call for
bringing down the regime, and 25 to oppose the "Brotherhoodization" of state
institutions.

Six protests called for civil disobedience, three opposed visits conducted by
the president or Freedom and Justice Party members, and three called for the
army to intervene in politics over dissatisfaction with the management of
political affairs.

Concerning the geography of protests, Cairo, Gharbiya, Sharqiya, Alexandria and
Kafr al-Sheikh staged the most. The report also cites an increasing number of
demonstrations in Upper Egyptian and Bedouin governorates.

The report states that the rate of violent protests has increased. Regular
protests account for slightly more than a quarter of all protests staged, while
road blocking was the second most used form of protest, accounting for 18.24
percent of all protests.

The report says it "is a disgrace that the security apparatus used the most
violence against establishments in protests, closing police stations, damaging
buildings and blocking roads."

                               Egypt Independent

                            April 23, 2015 Thursday

Democracy Index: Detentions by Egyptian authorities, terrorist incidents
increased in the first quarter of 2015

BYLINE: Egypt Independent,Mai Mohsen

LENGTH: 357  words


According to the report issued on Saturday by Democracy Index, affiliated with
the Cairo-based International Development Center (IDC), both the the amount of
detentions by Egyprian authorities and the number of terrorist incidents have
increased in the first quarter of 2015. The report also mentioned a rise in
labor protests, as well as violent incidents at colleges and schools.According
to the report, 1,353 protests took place in the first three months of 2015, 40
percent of which were related to economic and social demands.526 protests
occurred in January, 401 in March, and 390 in February, the report
mentioned.Muslim Brotherhood supporters staged 552 protests, whereas laborers,
business owners and craftsmen staged 323 protests. At the same time, school and
university students staged 183 protests .Labourers organized 81 protests,
followed by teachers with 36 protests, medical workers with 35 protests, drivers
with 27 protests, bread distrutors with 17 protests, university staff with 15
protests, farmers with 12 protests, lawyers with 12 protests, Endowments
Ministry workers with 9 protests, journalists with 8 protests, the security
sector with 4 protests, and finally the judges with one protest regiustered, by
the end of March.University graduates and job applicants staged 29 protests,
while 22 demonstrations were organized by political activists. In addition, 29
protests have been staged by people with disabilities, and 8 gatherings by
representatives of the Coptic community.The most prominent demands included
Muslim Brotherhood's calls to release prisoners, as well as demands to abolish
military tribunals for civilians, and protests against restricting freedoms and
against violence against civilians, such as the Air Defense Stadium incident or
toture at police stations.Social demands included job opportunities, improving
work conditions, demands to provide gas cylinders and housing, and protests
against raising tuition fees.The report pointed out that the rate of social and
economic demands was higher compared to 2014, where those demands represented
between 20 and 30 percent of the protester's calls..

                                Daily News Egypt

                            December 31, 2012 Monday

A Year in Review: Strikes and civil disobedience

BYLINE: Liliana Mihaila

LENGTH: 164 words


There have been over 100 incidents of industrial action in January, 2012. That
includes protests, sit-ins and strikes, held mainly by farmers and labourers.

The count for February was 92. This month also witnessed an attempt at civil
disobedience.

In March, there were around 70 protests, strikes or sit-ins.

A reported number of 270 protests in April.  This includes political protests,
industrial action and student protests.

There was a total number of protests held in May was 206.

In June  157 protests were reported.

In July, numbers exceeded 500 with 566 protests.

In August the number dropped to 410.

The number of protests rose again in September, with the start of the new
academic year, to 615.

There were a total of 507 protests in October.

November witnessed over 300 protests.

There have been at least seven protests in December in addition to another
attempt at civil disobedience.

Figures provided by Egyptian Centre for Economic and Social Rights (ECESR) and
Revolutionary Socialists.

                               Egypt Independent

                            July 22, 2015 Wednesday

Report: Factory, public sector workers at forefront of labor protests

BYLINE: Al-Masry Al-Youm

LENGTH: 250  words


The El-Mahrousa Center for Socioeconomic Development has monitored 385 labor
protests in the second quarter of 2015, with protests of workers of private
factories and public sector companies at the forefront.In a report issued on
Wednesday, the center said the companies that have witnessed the most protests
were Hassan Allam Contracting, Simo Paper Mills, The Egyptian-Indian Company,
Kiriazi, Bishay Steel, The Crescent and Star Company, Ezz Steel, Verdi Ceramics
and Arab Contractors.It said there were 68 protests by public sector workers,
including workers of the Endowments Ministry in Sharqiya and Alexandria, The
National Council on Disability and the AgricultureMinistry.The medical sector of
hospitals, health centers, the ambulance service, pharmacists, doctors and
nurses came in third place with 30 protests, followed by the education sector
and private universities with 20 protests and the media and journalists with 19
protests, including the Al-Shorouk newspaper, the CBC channel, the Radio and
Television Union and the Media Production City.Temporary laborers of different
sectors staged 15 protests, followed by the agricultural sector with 13
protests, the public transport sector with 11 protests, the sports sector with
10 protests, the textile sector with nine protests, mosque imams with eight
protests, holders of M.A. and Ph.D. degrees with seven protests, NGOs and
lawyers with six protests and the tourism sector with five protests.Edited
translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm

                              12 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                   Bikya News

                              April 1, 2013 Monday

Egypt tops countries in protest

LENGTH: 209  words


CAIRO: An Egyptian rights center issued a report on Monday stating that Egypt
has become the top country in the world in terms of the number of protests.

The "Democracy Index" monthly report issued by the International Center for
Development states that there were 1,345 protests in March compared to 864
protests in February.

"This is an unprecedented number of protests that did not occur even during the
January uprising as March witnessed an average of 1.8 demonstration every hour,
7.2 on a daily basis and 306 protests per week," said the report.

The report added that more than 40 percent of Egyptians from diverse backgrounds
contribute to protests, mostly citizens with no political affiliations.

Violation of workers' rights stood as the main reason behind protesting, whereas
the fuel crisis caused 112 protests and 73 protests were against Egypt's
government.

Twenty-five protests were staged against the "Brotherhoodization" of state
institutions and six protests called for civil disobedience.

The report monitored that protests are growing in number in Upper Egypt and
Bedouin governorates.

"Violence in protests rose up by 25.41 percent," the report said, noting that
cutting off roads is the second largest means of protest used during this month.

BN

                               Egypt Independent

                            November 10, 2014 Monday

Democracy Index: 643 protests in October

BYLINE: Nehal Mostafa

LENGTH: 426  words


The latest report by the Egypt-based International Development Center's
Democracy Index revealed that 643 protests, with average of 21 protests daily
and one protest every hour, have took place in October, marking an increase of
130 demonstrations in September, which saw 513 protests.August saw 647 protests,
according to Democracy Index's earlier report.Released on Monday, the index's
report showed that students topped the protesting categories with 209 protests
(32.5 percent of the total demonstrations in October). Supporters of the Muslim
Brotherhood came next with 204 protests (31.7 percent). Protests from the
general public followed with 108 protests (17 percent). Twelve other categories
followed, with 94 protests for work rights, then political activists with ten
protests, pensioners with four protests and finally three protests demanding
rights for disabled people.Sixty-six percent of the protests voiced civilian and
political demands, 256 protests, mainly staged by students, demanded release of
the detainees. Sixty-nine protests focused on ending military rule. Another 54
protests condemned terrorist operations.

Citizens also staged 14 protests against police practices, 12 of which were
against killing of a student and citizen by police.Social and economic demands
made up 34 percent of October's protests. The demands included the workplace
atmosphere, rights to education and rights to housing, facilities and services.
The demands also reflected problems of farmers and the physically-disabled.
Protests between January 2013 and October 2014, according to the Index report,
showed that absence of the transitional justice in Egypt has come in the first
place during the post-January 2011 period.Demonstrations were staged in 25
forms, 17 of which were peaceful, while eight were violent. The protest means
included vigils, protests, strikes and human shields. The most developed form of
protesting was the 'Their feast in prison' campaign staged by activists
demanding release of the detainees. The campaign was the most effective in 2014,
reflecting activists fear actions against them.However, the violent form
included blocking roads, intercepting an official's procession, breaking into
government buildings, setting fire to public and private properties and suicide.
Protests occurred in 26 governorates. Cairo came the first in number of
protests, then Giza, then Alexandria, Sharqiya, Daqahliya, Menoufia and Kafr
al-Sheikh. The lowest number of protests was seen in South Sinai and Marsa
Matrouh with one protest in each.

                              15 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                             Sowetan (South Africa)

                            June 15, 2016 Wednesday

Labour issues top reason for protests

BYLINE: Poppy Louw

SECTION: LABOUR

LENGTH: 298 words


NEARLY half of protests that took place in South Africa between 1997 and 2013
were labour-related.
 This is according to a report based on police data, launched by the University
of Johannesburg's social change research unit yesterday.


 The report, Counting Police-Recorded Protests, estimates there were about 70
000 police-recorded protests over the past 17 years - equating to an average of
11 protests per day.
 Labour protests were the most common (46%), followed by community-based
protests including service delivery (22.1%) - a higher portion of which were
categorised as disorderly.
 Xenophobia-related protests occurred the least (less than 1%).
 Gauteng had the highest number of protests (14 229), followed by Eastern Cape
(10251), North West (8 881) and Western Cape (8 796).
 Protests were categorised as violent when a person was injured or property was
damaged, while disruptive protests were those where there was only disruption
with no injury or damage to property.
 However, the Institute for Security Studies' Lizette Lancester said the
likelihood of events erupting from "pure order to absolute chaos" were very
rare.
 A large portion (80%) of protests in the period were considered peaceful, with
violent and disruptive protests each being 10%.
 "Our communities are increasingly frustrated by a lack of service delivery and
other issues," Lancester added.
 There was a peak in overall protests in 2012 (an average 15 per day), compared
to 2004, which had the lowest number (an average of seven per day).
 Professor Peter Alexander said the lack of democracy and service delivery was a
cause for concern. "Those in power have to do more listening to help avoid
protests. When people say they are short of electricity, then provide
electricity - and provide the right service."

LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: Sowetan

                              16 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                 Aswat Masriya

                              April 1, 2013 Monday

Egypt ranks as top country in protests - rights center

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 209  words


An Egyptian rights center issued a report on Monday stating that Egypt has
become the top country in the world in terms of the number of protests.

The "Democracy Index" monthly report issued by International Center for
Development states that there were 1345 protests in March compared to 864
protests in February.

"This is an unprecedented number of protests that did not occur even during the
January uprising as March witnessed an average of 1.8 demonstration every hour,
7.2 on a daily basis and 306 protests per week," said the report.

The reported added that more than 40 percent of Egyptians from diverse
backgrounds contribute to protests, mostly citizens with no political
affiliations.

Violation of workers' rights stood as the main reason behind protesting, whereas
the fuel crisis caused 112 protests and 73 protests were against Egypt's ruling
authorities.

Twenty-five protests were staged against the "Brotherhoodization" of state
institutions and six protests called for civil disobedience.

The report monitored that protests are growing in number in Upper Egypt and
Bedouin governorates.

"Violence in protests rose up by 25.41 percent," the reported said, noting that
cutting off roads is the second largest means of protest used during this month.

                            The Times (South Africa)

                            June 15, 2016 Wednesday

Strikes are kings of protest

BYLINE: Poppy Louw

SECTION: LABOUR

LENGTH: 419 words


Country has had 11 incidents a day over past 17 years
  Those in power have to do more listening to help dispel the anger
 NEARLY half of the protests that took place in South Africa between 1997 and
2013 were labour-related.


 This is according to a report released by the University of Johannesburg's
social change research unit yesterday.
 The report estimates there have been about 70000 police-reportedprotests over
the past 17 years - equalling an average of 11 protests per day.
 Data collected in the research are supposed to be the largest amount of police
information collected in the world.
 Labour protests were found to be the most common (46%), followed by
community-based protests, including service delivery protests (22.1%) - a higher
portion of which were categorised as disorderly.
 Although there was evidence suggesting xenophobia-related protests were
becoming an increasing problem, these occurred the least, at less than 1%.
 Gauteng had the highest number of protests (14229), followed by the Eastern
Cape (10251), North West (8881) and Western Cape (8796).
  Northern Cape had the highest number of labour and community protests per
capita, whereas KwaZulu-Natal had the lowest incidence of labour protests and
Limpopo the lowest rate of community protests.
 The rate of community protests has been higher than other kinds of protests
since 2005 and higher numbers of violent community protests were recorded
between 2005 and 2011 than disruptive ones.
 Protests were categorised as violent when a person was injured or property was
damaged. Disruptive protests were those that resulted in no injury or damage to
property.
 Lizette Lancester, of the Institute for Security Studies, said the likelihood
of events erupting from "pure order to absolute chaos" was very rare.
 A large portion (80%) of protests in the period were considered peaceful, with
violent and disruptive protests each scoring 10%.
 "Our communities are incredibly patient, but are increasingly frustrated by a
lack of service delivery and other issues of marginalisation," Lancester added.
 There was a peak in overall protests in 2012 (an average 15 per day) compared
with 2004, which had the lowest number of protests (an average seven per day).
 Professor Peter Alexander said the lack of democracy and service delivery in
South Africa was a cause for concern.
 "Those in power have to do more listening to help avoid protests. When people
say they are short of electricity, then provide electricity - and provide the
right service."

                              18 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                             June 24, 2008 Tuesday
                                  1 - Edition

TTN

SECTION: LEARNING; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 408 words


WHAT'S MAKING NEWS

Today at 11.30am on digital station TDT.

Types of protests

WHEN we watch or read news we sometimes witness violent protests or campaigns
taking place around the world. People taking part in such protests are often
called activists. They are protesting to draw attention to an issue and to have
their voice heard.

Activism is taking action to bring about social or political change. It's often
associated with protest, but activism can take many forms. A protest may involve
letter writing, donating money, boycotting an organisation, blogging, or
activism, a form of online activism.

We live in a democracy and we have a right to protest and have our voice heard
-- such as student protests, political protests or animal rights protests. Right
to protest is protected by the Australian Constitution. Activist groups may take
direct action to influence public opinion or political policy. Greenpeace has
used this method in its protests against whaling. ttn takes a looks at some
recent protests from around the world including South Korea and the US.

DISCUSSION: Choose five causes and outline the most effective way to protest for
each. Give reasons for your answers.

ACTIVITY: Get involved with blogging and have your say online.

Handy hydrogen

STUDENTS around the globe have joined international experts in learning about
alternative energy. They've been creating clean green energy from hydrogen.
Hydrogen is the most common element in the universe. It's found in plants, food
and even our bodies -- 70 per cent of the human body is made up of water, which
is produced from hydrogen and oxygen.

Every molecule of water has two atoms of hydrogen for every atom of oxygen --
which is why it's called H2O. On its own, hydrogen is highly flammable.

The gas has been in the spotlight this month at the World Hydrogen Energy
Conference in Brisbane. Students around the world have learnt to create Hydrogen
energy using a process called electrolysis. An electric current is put into the
water to separate the hydrogen and oxygen molecules. Then the two gases are put
back together again -- creating energy and water. This called an exothermic
reaction -- which means a reaction that produces energy.

DISCUSSION: What alternate energy sources do you use in your life?

ACTIVITY: Identify three reasons why hydrogen run cars could be better for the
environment.V

isit www.news.com.au/ttn for more activities and catch ttn updates in Totally
Wild on TDT.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               Egypt Independent

                            December 12, 2014 Friday

Democracy Index: 226 student protests occurred in November

BYLINE: Mai Mohsen

LENGTH: 384  words


As anti-regime protests by university students continued on campuses, the
Democracy Index, affiliatedo the Cairo-based organisation the International
Development Center (IDC), reported Friday that 226 student protests occurred in
November, with Al-Azhar students in the foreground. More than 270 students were
arrested in November, and 280 were referred to prosecution.

There have been 70 violent incidents on campuses, 34 of which were for violent
dispersal of protests by the security forces. Eighteen clashes took place
between the security and protesting students, according to Democracy Index.

There were 6 court rulings against protesting students and one in their favor in
November.

November students protests recorded an increase compared to October where 209
protests took place.

Al-Azhar University students came in the lead with 52 protests, followed by
Alexandria University students with 33 protests.

Forms of protests varied between peaceful and that which turned to violence.
Students staged 78 marches, 98 protests and demonstrations, and 7 human chains.

Twelve cases of blocking roads were recorded and 5 cases of strike.

Some students expressed their political views through art exhibitions and
theatrical performances.

One and forty eight protests demanded the release of detained students. Twenty
seven protests deprecated former President Hosni Mubarak acquittal, and 15
protests were commemorating the victims of Mohamed Mahmoud Street clashes.

Two hundred and eighty students were referred to interrogation and 265 were
dismissed from college.

About 140 students were sacked last year and reinstated to Al-Azhar University
upon a court order in November.

More than 270 students were arrested in November. The strangest incidents were
for a student who was arrested at Cairo University while possessing a novel
about despotic military regimes, and another who possessed a pin that read
"Tomorrow your triumph shall be," according to Democracy Index.

Eleven faculty members were suspended from work, 6 were referred to
interrogation, and 10 others were arrested in different universities over
charges of belonging to the Muslim Brotherhood.

Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Zagazig Tarek al-Berembly
was among those sacked over belonging to the Muslim Brotherhood organization.

                              20 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                            BBC Monitoring Kiev Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            March 20, 2013 Wednesday

Protest mood in Ukraine rises, research shows

LENGTH: 283 words


Text of report by Interfax-Ukraine news agency

Kiev, 20 March: The Centre for Research into Society NGO has said that 2012 saw
a record high of protests (3,636), according to the data of monitoring since
2009.

"The number of protests rose by 60 per cent compared with 2011. The peaks of
protests were in July (407) and October (446) last year. However, in some months
the number of protests also exceeded the peaks of past years," the head of the
department for research into social protests at the Centre for Research into
Society, Volodymyr Ishchenko, told a news conference in Kiev on Wednesday [20
March].

According to him, the protest mood of Ukrainians remained rather high in
January-February 2013. Twice as many protests were registered in February 2012
than in 2011 and 2012.

At the same time, the absolute number of protests rose in almost all Ukrainian
regions. The growth in 2012 protests was mainly due to political rallies linked
to the parliamentary election. At the same time, socio-economic issues were
often raised during the protests for the third year in a row (43 per cent of
protests in 2012).

In 2012 the Centre for Research into Society registered a rise in the turnout of
parties and individual politicians (up to 35 per cent) at the protests. At the
same time, they increasingly ignored the socio-economic problems of Ukrainians.

In 2012 every one in 10 protests was held by "unknown groups". In addition, they
registered a rise in confrontation (18 per cent) and violent protests (10 per
cent). One in 10 protests was violent. But the overwhelming majority of protests
remained peaceful (72 per cent in 2012).

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kiev, in Russian 1212 gmt 20 Mar 13

                             The Examiner Newspaper

                           September 3, 2015 Thursday
                         Examiner First Edition Edition

Protests to provide inspiration

BYLINE: MARY MACHEN Arts reporter

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 375 words


THE history of protest in Tasmania is the basis for a collaborative dance and
sound project taking shape now with expectation of it being performed when
Junction Arts Festival comes around again next year.

During Junction this week, the artists involved are seeking contact with anyone
on either side of a protest to share their story.

Devised by choreographer Liesel Zink, of Brisbane, in collaboration with sound
artist Mike Willmett, The Stance will explore the history of protest in Tasmania
and "collective action through observing crowd movement, behaviour, gesture and
form and formation".

Zink and Willmett are in Tasmania researching protests and seeking to record
personal stories in relation to each protest they select for performance
purposes.

"We're also looking at the relevance of protest now and how effectively protest
can create change," Zink said.

"This week we have been talking to activists involved in protest, and not all
from the same side, with a focus on the physicality of protest, group behaviour
and also the power of peaceful protest."

Zink envisages their findings will inspire a series of podcasts and audio bites
that will be developed into a full performance to be presented in a public space
in Launceston next September with the assistance of Tasmania's Mature Artist
Dance Ensemble.

The podcasts will be broadcast live at QVMAG Royal Park as part of Junction this
Saturday, September 5, at 11am. Entry is free.

" MADE, which is based in Hobart, is in Launceston also this week to present its
own work, Abandoned Dances, as a Junction highlight on September 4 and 5 at 7pm.

This work explores how memory influences and manages our existence. The
45-minute work promises to unravel the "insular reality of a woman caught in a
perpetual cycle of her own actions".

It will be at the round house, entry via showgrounds gate 1, Forster Street,
Invermay. Tickets are $15.

FACT FILE

For a full festival program and to buy tickets, visit
www.junctionartsfestival.com.au. Tickets can also be bought from the Junction
ticket HQ, 63A Brisbane Street, open daily until September 5, from 9am until
6pm, and September 6, 9am to noon. Tickets will be available to buy (cash only)
at show venues 45 minutes before start time unless sold out.

                                Daily News Egypt

                           December 31, 2013 Tuesday

Year in review 2013 - Workers hold 2,486 protests

BYLINE: Fady Ashraf

LENGTH: 337 words


//

Workers of the National company "Delta for Sugar" protest in front of the
journalists syndicate .
(Photo by: Hassan Ibrahim)

Egyptian workers held 2,486 protests in 2013, 2,243 of which took place during
the reign of ousted former President Mohamed Morsi. A total of 243 protests were
held under the military-backed interim government.

An average of 6.1 worker protests took place each day during the year. This was
down from the total in 2012 when the number of demonstrations reached 3,300. The
overall number of protests in 2013 topped that of 2011 when 1,300 protests took
place.

January, February and March saw 278, 424 and 396 protests, respectively.

April registered the highest number of demonstrations for the year with 448.

During Morsi's last month in office 288 protests took place. That total dropped
sharply to 46 immediately after his removal from power.

The number of protests rose slightly in August to 55, but declined in September
to only 45.

A sharp decline was witnessed in October, with only 25 protests held.

November registered the highest number of protests after Morsi's ousting with 61
taking place during the month. Only 11 protests were recorded in December.

Workers held 912 demonstrations and marches in their protests, 36.6% of those
recorded in 2013.

Strikes were the second most common with 558 strikes, or 22.4% of the total.

Workers held 373 sit-ins, accounting for 14.9% of the year's protests, while 85
cases of hunger strikes were recorded in 2013.

There was a total of 10 protest-related suicide attempts during the year, only
one of which was successful. A worker in the customs department of Port Said
killed himself while demonstrating for increasing wages.

*Figures were provided by the Egyptian Center for Social and Economic Rights
(ECESR)

Interior revamp

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            July 16, 2014 Wednesday

'Labour protests drop by 49% in first six months of 2014'

LENGTH: 398  words


The number of labour protests in the Kingdom witnessed a 49 per cent drop in the
first half of this year compared to the same period last year, according to a
report released this week.


A total of 302 labour protests were organised in the first six months of this
year, compared with 597 protests in the first half of 2013.
The report, issued by the Phenix Centre for Economic and Informatics Studies and
prepared in cooperation with the German Friedrich-Ebert Stiftung (FES), said 134
protests (44.3 per cent of the total) were organised by private sector
employees, after public sector employees had dominated protests in the past
three years.
Strikes comprised 61.3 per cent of the total number of labour protests; sit-ins
followed with 24.5 per cent. Threats to organise protests were 11.2 per cent of
the total, according to the report.
Meanwhile, self-harm, suicide and suicide threats for reasons related to work
stood at 3 per cent.
Phenix Centre Director Ahmad Awad said the drop in the number of protests this
year is due to many factors, including not achieving the targets and objectives
of the protests organised in the previous years.
Another reason for the drop is related to "government pressure" on labour unions
and leadership, he added, noting that several protests were dispersed by
security forces.
Low wages topped the reasons for organising protests in the January-June period,
with 116 (38 per cent) protests organised to call for higher salaries.
Protests against laws and regulations governing work-related issues came second
(24.8 per cent), while (13.6 per cent) of the protests were held to demand job
opportunities.
Awad said it is normal to have the majority of protests organised to demand
higher salaries as low wages are among the main challenges the local labour
market suffers from. He noted that salaries of approximately two-thirds of
labourers in Jordan are under the poverty line.
In its recommendations, the report called for reviewing wage levels in both the
private and public sectors and linking them to the inflation rate.
It also suggested revisiting the minimum wage, currently set at JD190.
The report called for amending Article 31 of the Labour Law, which allows
employers to implement collective layoffs, with the labour minister's approval,
in the case of economic or technical difficulties or changes at the company.
 2014 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

                              24 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            March 9, 2011 Wednesday

Liberal arts college team is "shadow leader" of protests in Croatia - daily

LENGTH: 274 words


Text of report by Bosnian edition of Croatian daily Vecernji list, on 8 March

[Report by pmz/VLM: "Government Toppling Continues - Kapovic: If Pernar Cares
About Protests, He Should Withdraw"]

The message on protest banners "We Do Not Need Leaders To Make Decisions" has
become the main idea of the current anti-government protests

As [anti-government] protests continue, it has become clear that its
protagonists can no longer be called the Facebookers and that Ivan Pernar, the
self-proclaimed leader of the protests, cannot be considered leader. The latest
two out of the total of seven protests held in Zagreb have shown that the banner
"We Do Not Need Leaders To Make Decisions" has become the main idea of the
disgruntled crowd. And the authors of the banners - an experienced team from the
Liberal Arts College - have actually become the "shadow leaders" of the current
protests in spite of their reiteration that they are not and do not want to be
leaders.

Mate Kapovic, assistant professor at the Liberal Arts College and active
protester, says that it is true that students have experience and that they are
capable of actively participating in the protests. However, not as leaders
because these protests are the people's protests, as he put it.

"They tried to recruit me but I refused. I neither want to be a leader nor do
these protests require one. Pernar should also withdraw if he cares about the
protests. This way, he is only doing harm," Kapovic says.

Furthermore, it is his contention that the protests would be even more
successful if they were shorter.

Source: Vecernji list (Bosnia-Hercegovina edition), Zagreb, in Croatian 8 Mar 11

                              25 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Essex Chronicle

                            February 6, 2015 Friday

Protesters march in defence of Baldock

BYLINE: Michael Havis michael.havis@hertsessexnews.co.uk

SECTION: NEWS:POLITICS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 378  words


HUNDREDS turned out to protest during a march opposing council plans for
thousands of homes in the green belt.

The demonstration on Saturday, organised by campaign group Save Rural Baldock,
left Simpson Drive at noon led by  North East Hertfordshire MP Sir Oliver Heald.

Preferred sites for housing have been identified in a draft district plan by
North Herts District Council (NHDC), with Baldock set to take 3,500 homes.

An estimate from the organisers suggested at least 500 people joined the march,
with many marchers chanting "Save rural Baldock" as they proceeded.

Albert Sillwood, of Save Rural Baldock, said: "This is a nice small community.
It's a country town and if you start bringing in all the extra houses, that will
spoil it. It would be horrendous at the Whitehorse traffic lights because of all
of the traffic.

"It will be back to the days before the bypass was built. Also, with extra
houses, the doctors' surgeries won't be able to cope and the sewage system,
which is overloaded at the moment, will have to be improved."

Speaking to the Mercury, Sir Oliver said the district should approach housing in
two phases, using existing brownfield sites in the first ten years and building
a new garden city in the second.

He said: "I'm against the proposal for the north east of Baldock, it is too big
and in the wrong place.  The purpose of green belt   is to avoid urban sprawl,
this   plan would mean another settlement the size of Baldock, right next to
Baldock.

"In our area we are the home of the world's first garden city and our plan
should have a bit of vision. People come from all over the world to see how to
really build a garden city well. Why can't we build one?"

Councillor David Levett, portfolio holder for planning and enterprise at NHDC,
said: "We appreciate residents' concerns about the preferred options plan and
the sensitivity of building   on green belt.

"We do, however, need to plan for additional homes to meet the needs of local
families.

"We would like to reassure residents that if this particular potential
development goes ahead it would have a masterplan in place, which would include
all the appropriate infrastructure."

A consultation on the plan - which allocates sites for 14,200 homes between 2011
and 2031 - ends on Friday.

                                 EKantipur.com

                           September 30, 2012 Sunday

NC won't protest for PM's berth, says Sujata

LENGTH: 295 words

DATELINE: BIRATNAGAR


BIRATNAGAR, Sept. 30 -- Nepali Congress central member Sujata Koirala has said
that her party will not stage protest s for the prime minister's post.

"I don't think that people will participate in the protest s simply to make some
a prime minister," said Sujata talking to reporters in Biratnagar on Sunday.

She said the announcement of protest alone will not make any difference. She
added that the protest s called at time when the parties should strive to forge
consensus will rather become unsuccessful.

Sujata remarked that the NC's collaboration with the Mohan Baidhya-led
CPN-Maoist for the protest is shameful.

She was of the view that party cadres and citizens were also not in favor of
staging protest s at the moment. "Staging protest at this stage of the country
will not give a good message to the country," she said. She said that the issue
of staging protest was also not raised in the party's CC meeting.

"CC meeting should discuss first. I have no idea about such protest programmes.
As it is not the official decision of the party, let's forge agreement and not
the protest ," said the NC CC member.

Sujata said that NC should put forth the name of PM candidate instead of staging
protest against the government. "I guarantee that Prime Minister Baburam
Bhattarai will tender his resignation once the NC decides the candidate. Not
only NC but also the CPN-UML will not be unable to forward the name of the PM
candidate," said the NC leader.

She further said that the president should take step to pick a prime ministerial
candidate for the consensus government. Published by HT Syndication with
permission from EKantipur.com. For any query with respect to this article or any
other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              27 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          What the Papers Say (Russia)

                           November 11, 2014 Tuesday

FORGET PROTESTS;
Only 12% Russians are prepared to put forth economic demands

BYLINE: Maxim Ivanov, Sergei Goryashko

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 1207

LENGTH: 273 words



HIGHLIGHT: POLLSTERS: MORE RUSSIANS ARE PREPARED TO PROTEST AGAINST
DETERIORATING LIVING STANDARDS THAN TO PUT FORTH POLITICAL DEMANDS; Results of
opinion polls indicate...


According to the Levada-Center, the Russians prepared to protest against
deteriorating living standards outnumber those ready to put forth political
demands. Even the former are a minority. Opinion polls show that only 12%
Russians are prepared to participate in economic protests. Experts point out
that there are no "proliferation of protests" traditions in Russia... and that
deterioration of relations with the international community makes it harder for
the Russians to seek within Russia itself those guilty of the existence of
social problems.

Levada-Center pollsters discovered that 12% respondents view protest rallies
with political demands a distinct possibility these days. Eight percent are
"probably" ready to join these protests.

"People lack the desire to join protests at this point. They say almost
invariably that the time is wrong for protests," Levada-Center Assistant
Director Alexei Grashdankin said. "In fact, the Maidan in Kiev changed the
Russians' attitude towards protests. The Russians are mostly worried about the
armed conflict in Ukraine these days. Fear of war drives away all other fears."

As for protests with socioeconomic demands, 17% Russians consider them possible
and 12% are ready to participate.

"Few people see those guilty of the deteriorating situation right here, in
Russia. In fact, few people even try to look for them here. The Russians do not
know who to protest against. Organizing protests to condemn [U.S. President
Barack Obama is nonsense, isn't it?" to quote Alexander Shershukov, Secretary of
the Federation of Independent Trade Unions.

Source: Kommersant, No 203, November 11, 2014, p. 2

LOAD-DATE: November 11, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                              32 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                 Aswat Masriya

                          September 13, 2014 Saturday

Almost one protest per hour in August: Democracy Index

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 457  words


CAIRO, Sept 13 (Aswat Masriya) - August witnessed 647 protests, at the rate of
one protest per hour, according to a report released by Democracy Index on
Saturday.

The highest rate of protests was reported on August 14, which marks the first
anniversary of the deadly dispersal of two pro-Mohamed Mursi camps last August,
said Democracy Index. Eighty-three protests were reported on that day, as well
as 61 protests on Friday, August 15.

The dispersals left hundreds killed and were described by international watchdog
Human Rights Watch as "the most serious incident of mass unlawful killings in
modern Egyptian history."

Political and civilian demands ranked highest as the cause for protest in
August, representing 65 percent of the protests held.

The Muslim Brotherhood organised the highest number of protests; 414 protests,
making up 63.98 percent of the protests held throughout the month.Three-hundred
and seventy protests were held against "military rule" and calling for Mursi's
reinstatement, according to the report. The Brotherhood also organised 12
protests condemning Israel's latest aggression on the Gaza strip, as well as
protesting the power outages and price hikes.

Thirty-five percent of the protests held in August called for economic and
social rights. Residents held 70 protests, while activists organised seven
protests. The month saw 43 protests calling for financial rights, 34
demonstrations protesting power cuts and 10 protesting price hikes.

Student activity returned to Egypt's streets with 19 student protests held in
August, Democracy Index said. Four protests called for reversing the expulsion
of university students.

The majority of the protests, 17 percent, were held in the capital. The
governorate of Sharqiya ranked second with 12 percent and Giza ranked third with
9 percent. The lowest number of protests was recorded in the border governorates
of Marsa Matrouh, North Sinai and South Sinai.

August saw 269 protest marches, 33 strikes and 15 sit-ins, Democracy Index
reported. The most frequent violent form of protest was blocking roads, with 94
cases reported. The Cairo-based index also reported 12 cases of hunger strikes
and 10 cases of torching public and private properties.

The Freedom for the Brave, a movement calling for the release of those detained
pending politically-motivated charges, announced on Sunday a gradual hunger
strike campaign demanding the release of detainees held under protest law
charges.

The announcement comes amid an ongoing hunger strike campaign, gaining momentum
by the day, with over 100 already on hunger strike inside and outside prisons.

Democracy Index is a research project issued by the Cairo-based International
Development Centre to monitor protests rate in Egypt.

LOAD-DATE: September 13, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

JOURNAL-CODE: 1026


                          Copyright 2014 Aswat Masriya
                Provided by Syndigate Media Inc.(Syndigate.info)
                              All Rights Reserved


                              33 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                               Egypt Independent

                           December 16, 2014 Tuesday

Democracy Index: protests surged by 10 percent in November

BYLINE: Egypt Independent

LENGTH: 314  words


Egypt witnessed 714 protests in November up from 643 in October, a surge of 10
percent from the previous month, said a report by the Cairo-based International
Development Center.Out of that number, 64 of those protests were triggered by
the acquittal of former president Hosni Mubarak and his regime figures of
charges of murder and financial corruption, according to the center's Democracy
Index.Fridays were the most active protest days, said the report. Friday the
28th saw the highest number of demonstrations of that month with 92 protests.
Sunday the 30th, one day following Mubarak's exoneration, saw 42 protests.
Students staged most protests in November with 226 events, according to the
index.

They were followed by members of the Muslim Brotherhood with 225 protests.
Students as well as Brotherhood backers, therefore, make up 63 percent of
November's protest activities, the index revealed.Labor protests stood at 111
during that month.Cairo came on top of the governorates with the highest number
of protests, 175, followed by Alexandria, 87, and Giza 75. Port Said came at the
bottom with seven protests.Forms of protest were mainly peaceful, with only 36
cases of road-blocking, sieges and suicides detected.Political and civilian
rights topped the demands of protesters in November in 462 protests. Economic
and social demands were voiced in 252 events.The report said executive
authorities still adhere to the "flawed" protest law, adding that while the
government apolitically confronts its opponents disregarding their affiliations,
"citizens backing Mubarak or the current regime enjoy full freedom of
expression."The report called upon the government to release all detainees
confined for practicing the freedom to protest and expression, warning that the
continuation of freedoms restriction would lead to the weakening and collapse of
the current administration.

                             June 11, 2013 Tuesday

PM: Protests directed against Turkey's economy and policy

BYLINE: R. Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 255 words


June 11--The Turkish protests are directed against the economy and politics of
the country, Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan was quoted today by TRT
Haber TV channel as saying.

Erdogan said four people were killed during the riots. One of them was a
policeman.

He added that the protesters do not realise the amount of the damage made to the
country's economy and tourism as a result of the protests.

According to Erdogan, about 80 per cent of reservations were cancelled due to
the protests in Turkey.

"The government must not remain silent when the radical groups are damaging the
country's economy," Erdogan said. He also urged that the protests cease.

Protests against the reconstruction of Gezi Park on Taksim Square in Istanbul
have lasted for more than 10 days. Istanbul police blocked the roads leading to
the Taksim Square this morning where several groups of people continued
protesting.

Earlier, Istanbul's governor Huseyin Avni Mutlu said the police will not use
force against protesters on Taksim Square

He added that the purpose of the police is to clean the area from the
anti-government posters and remove the barricades.

Earlier, it was reported that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan will meet with
representatives of the Taksim Square protesters on June 12.

                               Right Vision News

                          September 29, 2012 Saturday

Pakistan: Protests against sectarian killings today

LENGTH: 251 words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Sept. 29 -- The Majlis-i-Wahdat-i-Muslimeen (MWM) and the Ahl-i-Sunnat
Wal Jamaat (ASWJ) announced on Thursday that they would stage separate protest
demonstrations on Friday against targeted killings on sectarian grounds.

Speaking to journalists on Mehfil-i-Shah-i-Khorasan Road, Allama Hassan Zafar
Naqvi of the MWM said that his party would observe Friday as a day of protest
against the targeted killings and murders of Shias.

"In the first phase, protests will be held outside mosques after Friday
prayers," he said.

"This is the beginning of our protest campaign and if the government does not
move, the protests will be expanded to throughout the country and in the final
decisive phase, protest demonstrations will be staged outside the key government
buildings and the US embassy."

He said that the killings on sectarian grounds had increased following the
recent peaceful protest staged outside the US consulate against the anti-Islam
film made in the US.

A spokesperson for the ASWJ also came up with almost the same viewpoint and
condemned the killings on sectarian grounds.

He said that their organisation would also observe Friday as a protest day.

"A protest demonstration would be held outside the Markaz-i-Ahl-i-Sunnat on the
main Nagan traffic intersection after Friday prayers," he said Published by HT

                                Mail & Guardian

                                 April 11, 2011

Planned Swazi protest banned

BYLINE: Mandy Rossouw

SECTION: AFRICA

LENGTH: 204 words

DATELINE: Johannesburg, South Africa



HIGHLIGHT: Swaziland government has banned the much-anticipated protest planned
for April 12, claiming the protest organisers didn't follow correct procedures.>



The Swaziland government has banned the much-anticipated protest planned for
April 12, claiming the protest organisers did not follow correct procedures.

Swazi Prime Minister Sibusiso Dlamini said on Thursday such protests need to
have the government's approval. "Government has now learned that the formations
in question have not complied with the procedures and notices prescribed by the
relevant legislation," he said.

"This then renders the protest action illegal. We do not, therefore, expect any
individual to participate in any such proposed protest action."

Anyone who went ahead with the protests would be "dealt with in accordance with
the laws of the country", the prime minister's statement said.

The Swazi foreign minister, Lutfo Dlamini, visited South Africa this week and
downplayed the protest. "There is more talk about it here than in my country,"
he said.

He discussed with International Relations Minister Maite Nkoana-Mashabane the
economic problems facing the landlocked kingdom.

Lucky Lukhele of the Swaziland Solidarity Network said in a statement on
Thursday that the government was scrambling to put its best foot forward with
South Africa and the world to gain support and get rid of its economic woes.>

                           November 28, 2015 Saturday

Police halt protest after participants move protest to the streets

LENGTH: 146  words


The opposition MDP led Minjuvaan protests have been halted by thePolice after
participants moved the protests from Artificial Beach to the streets

The protests began Friday evening, with MDP pledging to carry out the protests
for 73 hours.

Police had halted some of the participants after they had moved along Majeedhee
Magu. The protesters were halted near H. Shabnam and Police pushed them back to
Artificial Beach. After that Police entered Artificial Beach area and stopped
the protest that was on going in the area.

Police said that they had informed MDP that the protest can only be carried out
in Artificial Beach area up until midnight. However, MDP had challenged the
order, stating they will continue their protest until the Government fulfill
their demands.

Even though, the protests were halted by the Police, no scuffles had erupted
between the protesters and the Police.

                               Egypt Independent

                          December 10, 2014 Wednesday

Democracy Index: 111 protests in November

BYLINE: Nehal Mostafa

LENGTH: 684  words


Worker protests increased by 17 in November from the previous month, raising the
total number to 111 worker protests, according to the Democracy Index,
affiliated to the Cairo-based organisation the International Development Center
(IDC).In a report on Tuesday, the Index showed that workers of factories and
companies staged 36 protests, while the medical sector staged 12 protests, the
educational sector staged 12 protests, journalists staged nine protests, lawyers
staged eight protests, Agriculture Ministry workers staged six protests, drivers
staged six protests, traders and owners of stores, bakeries and factories staged
six protests, civil servants of municipalities staged three protests, security
sector staged three protests, workers of mosques and bakery project staged two
protests each, Industry Ministry's vocational education teachers, workers of
Suez Canal Authority clubs, mines, farmers, street cleaners and university
security personnel staged a protest each.Demonstrations took many forms in
November including strikes, vigils, demos, sit-ins, filing complaints, detaining
officials, issuing statements, withdrawal from conferences, marches and other
forms, the Index said.Twenty-two protests were staged in Cairo, then came
Alexandria with 10 protests, then Gharbiya with nine protests, then Sharqiya and
Giza with eight protests for each, six in Suez, five in each of Menoufia,
Daqahliya and Kafr al-Sheikh, four protests in Minya, three protests in each of
Ismailia, Beheira and Qalyubia, two protests in each of Luxor, Damietta,
Fayyoum, Marsa Matrouh and Sohag, and one protest in each of North Sinai, New
Valley, Assiut, Qena, South Sinai and Port Said.The main demand behind the
protests, according to the Index, was on financial dues including disbursement
of salaries, bonuses and profits (27 percent of the protests). Twelve protests
voiced demands of getting permanent contracts.

Rice mills workers staged 12 protests demanding stable price for rice and
rescuing the company against bankruptcy. Five protests were staged against
selling of companies as well as layoffs. Lawyers staged four protests for being
insulted by police and judges. Three protests were staged against assaults on
civil servants while performing duties and two protests against arbitrary
transferral. Journalists staged two demonstrations over newspapers closing and
demanded being divided among state-run newspapers. Two protests were staged
against being forced to sign down contracts without counting the past years of
work.Workers also staged protests not related to work rights. Employees in the
Red Sea governorate protested against the decision on the new demarcation of the
governorate. Faculty members of Kafr al-Sheikh demonstrated against calls for
protesting on 28 November. Security also banned peaceful protest by workers of
Petrotrade for petroleum services despite giving a notification in advance.The
report concluded recommending reconsidering the work nature of companies that
send Egyptian workers abroad for being a main reason behind loss of migrating
workers' rights. Out of 1,147 companies,252 were closed over violations.It urged
authorities in question to investigate corruption, noting that corrupt policies
are the reason behind destruction of the national industry. The report also
indicated ambivalence in applying the protest law as many workers were
transferred to prosecution, suspended, dismissed or detained, while none of
police personnel were questioned over the protests or allowing demonstrations
denouncing 28 November calls for protests. The report stressed the necessity to
hold dialogue over the situation of independent trade unions, describing them as
the biggest profit gained by workers under rule of ousted President Hosni
Mubarak. It also highlighted unified executive, trade union and civil efforts to
resolve problems of workers related to layoffs and dismissal as result of
selling, changing activity, privatization of a company or corruption to protect
rights of hundreds of thousands of Egyptian workers.Edited translation from
Al-Masry Al-Youm

                               Irish Independent

                          December 11, 2013 Wednesday
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

EU protests;
LETTERS to the EDITOR

SECTION: LETTERS; Pg. 42

LENGTH: 203 words


How ironic that less than two weeks after the Spanish government announced plans
to crack down on protests through the imposition of massive fines, we now have
pro-EU protests in Ukraine.

The prospect of fines up to (EURO)600,000 for unauthorised protests in Spain was
no doubt precipitated by the increased frequency of strikes and protests against
the measures implemented by the Spanish government, and endorsed by the EU.

Yet now that the democratically elected government of Ukraine has decided to
step back from a treaty with the EU, and pro-EU protests and strikes have
erupted, the EU is encouraging the Ukrainian government to engage with the
protesters. Where is the conciliatory stance when it comes to the antiausterity
protests in Spain, Greece, etc? This two-faced approach to the right to protest
- and the validity of such protests - demonstrates the double standards and lack
of fairness that lie at the heart of the European Union. Strikes and protests,
it would appear, are fine, just so long as the people are protesting on behalf
of the EU. However, those that oppose the austerity being foisted upon them are
subject to swingeing fines and the tender mercies of the riot police. Simon
O'Connor Dublin 12

LOAD-DATE: December 11, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IIN

                              All Rights Reserved

BRIEF: MFA: Organisation of protest rallies in Azerbaijan by National Democratic

BYLINE: E. Mehdiev, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

March 15--Organisation of protest rallies in Azerbaijan by the National
Democratic Institute of the U.S. is under investigation and the public will be
informed of the outcome, Foreign Minister Elmar Mammadyarov said at a joint news
conference with Secretary General of OSCE on Friday.

Power of Baku, and the dispersion of the latest protest was due to its illegal
nature.

According to several media and social networks, the National Democratic
Institute of the U.S. has allocated $2 million to hold protests in Azerbaijan.

"Previously all protest rallies were held in designated areas and faced no
interference. If protest rallies are illegal, the police will suppress them," he
said.
