                          Columbus Telegram (Nebraska)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            June 16, 2010 Wednesday

Supervisors set valuation protest dates

BYLINE: Eric Freeman, Columbus Telegram, Neb.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 728 words


Jun. 16--COLUMBUS -- The Platte County Board of Supervisors set the 2009 real
property valuation protest hearings to begin at 1 p.m. Tuesday, July 20, and 9
a.m. Wednesday and Thursday, July 21-22.

If needed, hearings will continue on Friday, July 23. As of Tuesday a total of
55 protest forms had been submitted at the Platte County Clerk's office.

The deadline to file a protest with the county clerk's office is Wednesday, June
30.

A total of 195 protests were scheduled last year in time for the June 30 protest
filing deadline.

Those considering a protest are encouraged to contact the assessor's office for
an explanation of the changes before filing a protest. The information can also
be accessed online by completing a property search at
www.plattecounty.net/assessor.htm.

The required valuation protest Form 422 can be obtained at the Platte County
Clerk's office at the Platte County Courthouse, 2610 14th St. or online at
www.plattecounty.net/protest.htm.

The supervisors voted no to an offer to settle a freedom of information act
court action between the Platte County Assessor's office and County Records
Inc., an Oklahoma based firm.

Supervisor Holly Olk had made a motion to accept a settlement offer brought
forward by Platte County Attorney Carl Hart which would have provided County
Records, Inc. a monthly report in electronic format detailing property
assessment records at a fee of $20 per month with the company providing a
portable data drive for the information. The company would also have received
GIS mapping data, sketches and photographs on a semi-annual basis at a fee of
$20 twice per year.

County Records Inc. is a for profit company that uses the information to provide
plat maps and assessment products for sale to individuals and, potentially,
other for profit organizations.

"If the board approves this settlement today, the company has agreed to drop the
law suit and we can all go on our way," Hart said.

Hart had assured the board that Platte County Assessor Vanora Mulligan had
worked diligently to arrive at the $20 fee as being a reasonable fee for the raw
data requested which is public information.

Supervisor Myron Franzen insisted the request for public information should have
to be made by the company each month and that in his opinion the $20 fee was not
enough to cover the expense to the county and the assessor's office in providing
the information.

"There was, at the beginning of this situation no process for extracting the
data the company wanted and so at that time there was significant time spent in
finding a reasonable way to provide the data," Hart said. "Now there is a way to
do it and the process is as simple as plugging in a flash drive , starting the
process and in about 30 minutes have what is needed and requested."

Hart explained that if the board chose to deny the settlement and the case goes
poorly for Platte County that the county could be liable for the attorneys fees
of County Records Inc.

The supervisors were concerned that the company was using the public information
for profit and most agreed the $20 fee was not enough.

"Under current law why they use the information can not be considered when
determining what is a reasonable cost for the information," Hart said.

In the end Hart was directed to return to negotiations with County Records Inc.
and secure a higher fee for the information and mechanisms in any agreement
reached to re-evaluate or assess the cost of providing the information on at
least an annual basis.

In other business, the board of supervisors approved support of CASA (Court
Appointed Special Advocates) in the amount of $15,000, which will be more fully
addressed in the upcoming budget cycle. The board approved the amount to cover a
budget deficit of $15,145.66 reported from the Platte County Treasurer. A
permissive tax exemption for Rainbow Inc. a non-profit organization that
provides residential services to mentally ill clients also was approved.

To see more of the Columbus Telegram, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.columbustelegram.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Columbus Telegram, Neb.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: June 16, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20100616-CU-HLT-Supervisors-set-valuation-protest-dates-0616

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: CU


                        Copyright 2010 Columbus Telegram


                              84 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                              June 19, 2009 Friday

Avoid those futile protests

BYLINE: Samuel Yesuiah

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 390 words


I REFER to your report ("Minister warns foreign students" - NST, June 17) on the
staging of demonstrations.

A group of 700 Iranian university students had demonstrated on Monday over the
results of the Iranian presidential elections. The police had to fire tear gas
to disperse the unruly crowd.

Foreign students and workers should never abuse their stay in this country. If
they have come here to study or work, then they should do just that. This rule
should also apply to local students and Malaysians as a whole.

The staging of protests and demonstrations outside embassy buildings, places of
worship and public places should not be encouraged with or without police
permits. .

Such protests and demonstrations prevent the people from going about their daily
duties.

There is also the feeling of tension and fear of things getting out of hand with
such boisterous crowds.

However peaceful these assemblies are, it takes only a small misunderstanding or
scuffle for the gathering to turn into chaos. Therefore, it is important that
the government views such protests and demonstrations by locals and foreigners
seriously.

The recent staging of the protest against the alleged killing of Tamils in Sri
Lanka at Batu Caves temple by hundreds of people and Tamil members of parliament
is a case in point.

However noble the intentions are in staging a protest or demonstration, it
should be avoided at all costs for the peace and security of the nation.

As the letter "Not the place for a protest" (NST, May 27) has clearly indicated,
a protest of this nature should never have been staged in the temple grounds.
The organisers of the protest had little regard for the sentiments of devotees
and the sanctity of the temple grounds.

As the letter suggested, it would be ideal to hold such protests and
demonstrations in an indoor stadium as it would be easier to keep the protesters
under control and it would not inconvenience others. It has become the norm the
world over for people to stage protests and demonstrate in their home countries
against incidents in other countries.

The alleged killing of Tamils in Sri Lanka has fuelled protests by Tamils in
England, Australia and Europe against the Sri Lankan government.

However widespread these protests are, they would not have any bearing on what
the Sri Lankan government does.

SAMUEL YESUIAH

Seremban

LOAD-DATE: June 18, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

                              85 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            January 25, 2005 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Council hears proposals for changes to bid appeals

BYLINE: DEENA WINTER, Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: B; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 512 words


To try to prevent frivolous protests from being filed when businesses are vying
for contracts with Lincoln, city officials proposed increasing the protest
filing fee from $50 to $500 during a public hearing Monday night.

The Lincoln City Council held a public hearing on the proposal, part of a
package of ordinance changes proposed by city officials at the direction of
Mayor Coleen Seng. The mayor requested the changes after three protests recently
prolonged the awarding of a bid to build up to seven new fire trucks.

The current appeals process was created in 1993, and since then protests have
been filed on seven different bids, according to city Finance Director Don Herz.

The proposed amendment clarifies the deadlines for filing protests, increases
the protest filing fee from $50 to $500 and clarifies who may file a protest. It
also allows the city to award a contract while a protest is underway.

Councilman Jon Camp questioned the need for changes when the city has averaged
less han one protest per year 1993.

"Really, to say there's been frivolous protests would be an overstatement,"
Camp said. "I think maybe we're overreacting here."

He said increasing the filing fee might be enough to prevent frivolous protests.

Currently, a protest stops the bidding process in its tracks. The changes would
let the city proceed.

In other business, the council listened to a request by Talent Plus to assign
the address "One Talent Plus Way? to a driveway near its headquarters, at 65th
Street and Pioneers Boulevard. Talent Plus is a human resources consulting firm.

Talent Plus Chairman Doug Rath said the simple address helps brand and market
the company and helps them compete internationally. The address would be
assigned to the building, not on a street sign. The company already uses the One
Talent Plus Way address in the Alltel phone directory and on a sign in front of
the Talent Plus building.

Mark Hunzeker, an attorney representing Talent Plus, said granting the address
designation would be a ?very small token? of appreciation from the city to the
business for keeping its headquarters in Lincoln.

But the U.S. Postal Service and police chief opposed the address, saying the
city should not set a precedent of allowing ?vanity addresses? rather than legal
addresses that more accurately reflect the locations of businesses.

Lincoln Police Chief Tom Casady said emergency responders wouldn't have trouble
finding the building, since it's a large landmark, but the departure from
previous addressing protocol could open the door to ?weird addresses? that
aren't so easy to find.

Council members expressed appreciation that the company is located in Lincoln,
but worried that the unusual address could set a precedent.

But Hunzeker said the action would not likely ?bring down a torrent of these
kinds of applications."

"I don't understand why this is all that difficult," he said.

The council will decide on both the bidding changes and Talent Plus address at
its next meeting.

Reach Deena Winter at 473-2642 or dwinter@journalstar.com.

LOAD-DATE: January 28, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2005 Lincoln Journal Star,
                              All Rights Reserved

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          December 25, 2013 Wednesday

BRIEF: Mass protests participants in Turkey to stand trial

BYLINE: Rufiz Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: NATIONAL POLITICAL NEWS

LENGTH: 166 words


Dec. 25--Some 255 participants of mass protests in Turkey will stand trial,
Anadolu agency reported on Dec. 25.

They are accused of holding illegal protests, damaging public and private
property, as well as marauding, according to the report.

The accused persons also included seven foreign nationals. Their nationality was
not specified.

Anti-government protests took place in Turkey for nearly three weeks beginning
in late May. Turkish oppositional parties accused Turkish police of using
excessive force against protestors. In total, around 2.5 million people from 79
Turkish provinces participated in protests during the three weeks, the Turkish
Interior Ministry said.

As a result of the unrests in Turkey nearly 4,000 people were injured with
varying severity, 4,900 were detained by the police.

Translated by E.A.

                                 Aswat Masriya

                          November 27, 2013 Wednesday

Egypt security forces disperse protest in Alexandria

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 162  words


CAIRO, Nov 27 (Aswat Masriya) - Egyptian security forces fired teargas to
disperse a protest staged in support of 21 detained Islamist women in Alexandria
on Wednesday.

The women were arrested by security forces earlier in November as they attempted
to stage a protest to back deposed President Mohamed Mursi before his trial.

The detained women, aged 15 to 25, stand trial on Wednesday on charges of
disrupting traffic and vandalizing public property during their protests.

Nasser al-Abd, a senior security official in Alexandria, said that the
defendants did not have permits to protest and they stood outside a vital
installation which is the court.

Their protests took place before the new protest law, which largerly restricts
protests, was ratified. The new law requires that protesters notify the
authorities of demonstrations three days prior to it.

                              The Financial Daily

                            August 27, 2013 Tuesday

ECP takes notice of PTI by-polls rigging protest

LENGTH: 150  words


The Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP) has taken notice of the protest of the
Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) against rigging during the by-election in PP-150.
The ECP has decided to hear the PTI's petition seeking a recount in PP-150 and
summoned all candidates who contested for the seat on August 28.

The PTI continues its protest against alleged rigging and party leaders and
workers are staging a sit-in outside the Punjab Assembly. According to reports,
PTI workers assaulted members of the press during the protest.

On Saturday, several party leaders and workers had been arrested during a police
crackdown on their protest camp on Mall Road. The police claimed protests could
not be held in the area due to the imposition of Section 144. Later, those
arrested were released and they continued their protest on Mall Road. The
protest ended when party leadership decided to continue it from Monday.

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           August 22, 2007 Wednesday

Burma: Mass protests against fuel oil price increases continue in Rangoon

LENGTH: 302 words


Excerpt from report by Norway-based Burmese Democratic Voice of Burma on 21
August

Protests against the military regime increasing fuel oil prices continued in
Rangoon today and democracy activists warned that protests would be staged
nationwide tomorrow.

Protests were reported in at least four locations of Rangoon. People who are
organizing the mass protests tomorrow informed Democratic Voice of Burma that
the first protest was led by members of the National League for Democracy (NLD)
with about 50 people walking from Yankin to the NLD Headquarters. The second
protest march was by 88 Generation Students and NLD youths who walked from Tamwe
to the NLD headquarters. The third protest took place near Theingyi Market but
no details are available yet. The fourth protest was staged by students of Dagon
University, Rangoon East University, and Tarwa University, who walked in
procession without riding buses.

Although there were attempts by the Union Solidarity and Development Association
and [its affiliated] Swan-Arr-Shin ["People with Power"] members to stop these
protest marches, no instances of arrest or physical assault were reported.

The organizers also said that the monks and the workers were also initiating
their own protests.

These protests started because the military regime raised fuel oil prices by 100
to 500 per cent last Wednesday [ 15 August].

On Sunday, the 88 Generation Students and about 500 people staged a peaceful
march in Rangoon and the other forces started joining the protest today.

Ko Htin Kyaw and his group members who have been leading the campaign against
high commodity prices have publicly announced that protests will be staged in
Rangoon as well as other places nationwide tomorrow. [Passage omitted]

Source: Democratic Voice of Burma, Oslo, in Burmese 1430 gmt 21 Aug 07

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            June 12, 2013 Wednesday

BRIEF: President: Comparing protests in Turkey with unrest in Middle East is
wrong

BYLINE: R. Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 157 words


June 12--It is wrong to compare the protests in Turkey with the unrest in the
Middle East, Turkish President Abdullah Gul said during his visit to the Rize
province, TRT Haber TV channel reported today.

Gul said that every citizen has the right to protest in Turkey, but it must be
within the democracy.

He added that the countries, criticising Turkey, incorrectly assess the
situation. Such protests also occur in those countries.

Protests have been taking place in various Turkish cities for more than two
weeks. According to the authorities, the protests are of an anti-government
character.

Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is expected to meet with a
delegation of Taksim Square protesters.

Do you have any feedback? Contact our journalist at agency@trend.az

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

                             August 27, 2010 Friday

PTCL employees protest continues for salary raise

LENGTH: 167  words

DATELINE: LAHORE


LAHORE, Aug. 27 -- Employees of Pakistan Telecommunications Corporation Limited
(PTCL) are continuing their protest in Lahore for the second day; they have also
indicated a country wide strike.

Yesterday they staged a protest for a salary raise in front of the Lahore Press
Club. One employee tried to burn himself in protest, but others foiled his
attempt.

PTCL employees started their protest on Egerton Road and took the protest rally
up to the Lahore Press Club.

Furious PTCL employees brought out a ceremonial funeral of the management; upon
reaching the Press Club, they burnt it.

the management and beating his chest in protest. In between, he suddenly tried

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

               February 20, 2000, Sunday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

OVER 150,000 IN AUSTRIA PROTEST FAR-RIGHT PARTY'S RULE;
DEMONSTRATORS IN VIENNA SHOUT SLOGANS CRITICAL OF RIGHT-WING LEADER

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A5

LENGTH: 395 words

DATELINE: VIENNA, AUSTRIA


More than 150,000 flag-waving demonstrators crammed a historic Vienna square on
a cold, rainy Saturday evening in the largest protest yet against a far-right
party's inclusion in the Austrian government.

Throughout the day, tens of thousands of protesters gathered for smaller rallies
at different spots throughout the city. Others marched through the streets,
blowing whistles and shouting slogans critical of the government and Joerg
Haider, leader of the right-wing Freedom Party.

Later, they converged on the Heldenplatz, or Heroes' Square, where thousands of
Austrians welcomed Adolf Hitler as Nazi German troops arrived in 1938.

"We have to prevent right-wing nationalism from creeping into Austria again,"
Hans Marschalek, head of the inmates association from Austria's Mauthausen
concentration camp, told a cheering crowd of 30,000 gathered in front of the
ornate neo-Grecian Parliament Building.

A banner that was hung from police barricades around the building read: "Haider
is Hitler."

Vienna police and state television estimated the crowd at 150,000 by evening.
Austrian state television estimated that 1,000 more people continued to stream
into the plaza each minute an hour after the rally began.

Overall, the demonstrations were peaceful. The atmosphere varied throughout the
city, from festive in downtown Vienna, where artists decorated the sidewalks of
the city's posh shopping district with anti-Nazi symbols, to that of an earnest
political rally outside Parliament.

The Ringstrasse, the main road around Vienna, was a sea of mostly hand-painted,
colorful banners: "Being ruled by the Freedom Party hurts our souls"; "Join in
to help in the retention of human dignity"; "Austria, you mournful country,
being ruined by black and blue hands." The last slogan referred to the political
colors of the Freedom Party and its coalition partner, the mainstream
conservative People's Party.

Anti-government rallies have become a near-daily practice in Vienna since the
new government coalition took office Feb. 4. The European Union, Israel and the
United States have taken measures to isolate Austria diplomatically.

The outrage stems from Haider's opposition to immigration and rapid European
Union expansion, as well as previous statements praising some Nazi policies and
excoriating immigrants. He has since apologized.

LOAD-DATE: February 20, 2000

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: PHOTO AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE Photo - Demonstrators crowd Vienna's
Heldenplatz on Saturday to protest the inclusion of Joerg Haider's Freedom Party
in the Austrian government. Protests occurred throughout the city.

                  Copyright 2000 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              95 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Daily News Egypt

                             April 11, 2016 Monday

733 protests in the first quarter of 2016: observatory report

BYLINE: Daily News Egypt

LENGTH: 418 words


Independent observatory Democracy Index said in its periodic report that 733
protests took place over the first quarter of 2016 with an average of 245
protests per month and 6 daily across Egyptian cities.

Democracy Index based the quarterly report on media reports from five local
newspapers, an independent fact checking unit, field reporting, official reports
and previously published statistics, and figures on movements by organisations
and groups critical of the regime in Egypt.

The latest figure indicates a similar pace of protesting compared to the latest
quarter of 2015, during which there were 730 protests with an average of 244
protests per month.

The reasons behind the protests were attributed to economic and social demands
for 74% of the total number of protests monitored in the report, whereas
politically motivated protests represented only 26% of the protests.

The economic demands were brought about by delay in payment of salaries for
workers, not receiving incentives, and arbitrary expulsion among other issues.

In early April, dozens of workers in the Nile Cotton Ginning Company went on an
open strike inside the company's headquarters in Mahalla, demanding the payment
of late salaries.

Earlier in 2016, Egypt witnessed more protests from taxi drivers who protested
against the emerging Uber and Careem services.

Meanwhile, the past few months were marked by a wave of protests demanding civil
and political rights. The release of political detainees topped the list of
those demands. According to the report, 63 protests took to the streets
demanding the immediate release of detainees with 45 protests on the fifth
anniversary of 25 January Revolution.

On the anniversary of the revolution, protesters affiliated with the Muslim
Brotherhood took to the streets in small groups in several governorates. All
over the country minor protests took place, leading to clashes with riot police,
and leaving dozens arrested. Although the official number of arrests has not
been confirmed, lawyers estimated that 60 protesters were detained.

Following the ouster of the Muslim Brotherhood regime in 2013, the interim
cabinet issued a new law to regulate protests--the controversial Protest Law--in
November 2013 amid bloody clashes between Brotherhood supporters and security
forces.

Since the law was enacted, it has been used to build several cases against
students and activists, on charges of "illegal assembly". Thousands have been
arrested in Egypt since then, according to Amnesty International.

LOAD-DATE: April 11, 2016

                             The Advocate (Burnie)

                           November 28, 2013 Thursday

Rylah slams peaceful protests

BYLINE: JASON THOMAS

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 208 words


A PEACEFUL protest against logging has been labelled as a job- destroying
campaign by Braddon Liberal candidate Joan Rylah.

Fearless Summer is holding protests across Australia this summer, including
Tasmania in January, to voice its concerns about logging.

Ms Rylah compared the planned protests to what she called the "anti-everything"
protests of last year, while defending the counter pro-mining and logging
demonstrations.

Holding a peaceful protest about an important issue would not hurt anyone,
Fearless Summer spokesperson Miranda Gibson said.

"Such events support the community to take safe and effective actions in
expressing their concerns and highlighting the destruction of native forests,"
Ms Gibson said.

Ms Gibson said inciting hatred towards one world view, while praising another,
meant Joan Rylah was ill-suited for state parliament. Rather than seek to
destroy jobs, the peaceful protests would be a chance for Tasmanians to make a
statement, Ms

Gibson said.

Ms Rylah said it would be a new round of conflict for business.

Before the protests, the group will hold training days about conducting peaceful
protests.

The Fearless Summer group has not confirmed the details of the protest in early
January, but said details were on its website.

                              97 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           Cape Times (South Africa)

                           September 20, 2013 Friday
                                   E1 Edition

Public order units may be needed to cope with protests

BYLINE:  Xolani Koyana

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 359 words


POLICE Minister Nathi and police commissioner Riah Phiyegahave alluded to the
re-establishment of specialised public order units as an increase in the number
of violent protests in the country contributed to a rise in other serious
crimes.

The country saw an increase, with police responding to 12 399 protests between
April 2012 and March 2013 nationally, Mthethwa said at the release of the latest
crime statistics yesterday.

The Western Cape experienced 1 243 incidents of protests. KwaZulu-Natal recorded
the most number of protests - 2 609.

Between September and January, the Western Cape was hit with a wave of protests
in De Doorns, Robertson, Ceres, Wolseley, Swellendam and other farming towns in
the Boland with workers demanding better wages. There were also strikes by bus
drivers and Metrorail security guards.

Phiyega said protests nationally were a challenge and taking up resources meant
for visible policing.

"We need to deal with these visible policing constraints upfront. In this
regard, we are looking into beefing up our public order policing resources.

The public order police unit was disbanded in 2006.

Of the 12 399 national protests, 10 517 were peaceful and 1 882 were violent
public protests.

Police opened 693 various criminal cases as a result of the protests. Mthethwa
said the surge in violent protests contributed to an increase in the number of
arson attacks reported, damage to property and common robbery.

"There are some instances where these have led to criminal elements being able
to make use of public gatherings and protests to pursue criminal acts.

"You will also realise that some of these protests result in murder... ,"
Mthethwa said.

Community Safety MEC Dan Plato said he was encouraged by Mthethwa and Phiyega's
statements. He said the units would prevent the increasing number of violent and
illegal protests.

"While the public have a right to take part in peaceful protests in our
democracy, there is no excuse to resort to violence, and I look forward to
Minister Mthethwa ensuring that the SAPS are adequately trained and resourced to
deal effectively with illegal protesters," Plato said.

xolani.koyana@inl.co.za

                                 Aswat Masriya

                               May 3, 2013 Friday

Rights centre: 1462 protests in Egypt during April

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 101  words


Egypt witnessed 1462 protests during April, making it the top country worldwide
in number of protests during that month, a report for the International
Development Centre (IDC) has said.

April's record number compares with 1354 protests in March and 864 in February.

Forty-seven categories of Egyptians staged the protests.

Economic and social demands were the major drive for 62.4 percent of the
protests.

The main demands of these protests included releasing detainees and toppling the
regime.

The protests also included demonstrations to supportthe Copts' religious beliefs
and condemnassaults on the judiciary.

                            The Statesman (AsiaNet)

                              May 10, 2010 Monday

Teachers plan protest drive for acceptance of demands

BYLINE:  Statesman Report

SECTION: Vol. 9 No. 728

LENGTH: 243  words


The Muttahida Mahaz-i-Asteza (MMA) has decided to launch a protest movement
across the province from May 20 to mark their protest against federal and
provincial governments for failing to meet their demands regarding 100 per cent
raise in salaries.

The decision was made during a meeting with president of MMA Khairullah Khan
Hawari in the chair here on Sunday.

The meeting decided to hold protest camps from May 20 in the first phase of the
protest drive followed by protests in the districts.

In the second phase the MMA will hold a protest camp in front of the Parliament.

The president said that the protest movement includes rallies, demonstrations
and meetings besides pen-down strike in government institutions.

He said that the government endeavours are nothing but total disgrace and insult
to the teaching community.

He also expressed his resentment and anguish over spending billions of rupees on
enforcement of English medium school system in Urdu medium institutions and
holding of training courses for schoolteachers.

The meeting said that besides announcing additional educational allowance, the
government should introduce a health insurance policy for teachers instead of
giving them meagre medical allowance in their salaries.

The participants of the meeting further said that teachers and other staff
cannot wait any longer and the recommendations of Pay and Pension Committee
should be implemented in the budget for the fiscal year 2010-2011.

                              103 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                            South China Morning Post

                             August 3, 2008 Sunday

Beijing spells out the rules for protesters during the Games

BYLINE: Josephine Ma in Beijing

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 447 words


Beijing has issued a detailed list of  procedures to follow for those wanting to
hold public protests during the Olympic Games.

The move comes after   an activist was detained and sent home while  trying to
lodge  an application to stage a demonstration in one of three designated
protest zones.

Protest organisers will have to submit an application to the relevant public
security bureau five days before they want to hold their protest, together with
their ID cards, according to a notice posted on the official Bocog website.

Organisers  are also asked to assign people to help the police maintain  order
during the protest and wear badges for easy identification,   Liu Shaowu,
director of the Beijing Organising Committee for the Olympic Games'  security
department, said on the website.

The removed activist    was sent home on Friday. She had been representing some
100 homeowners from Suzhou and was at  the Beijing Municipal Public Security
Bureau to hand in an application to protest in a designated protest zone.

Anti-Japanese activists have also been  told they will not be given permission
to stage protests.

According to the website,  foreign applicants have been  asked to provide a
Chinese translation of their application documents.  State agencies, private
companies and NGOs have to  chop the document with their official seal  as well
as getting it signed by   the head of the organisation.

The relevant public security agencies will  decide on whether to allow the
protest  two days before the planned protest date and will notify applicants in
writing,  Mr Liu said.

If applicants have not received any feedback two days before the planned
protest,  they should assume their application has been turned down.

The three protest parks would remain open to the public even if protests took
place, although security measures would be implemented,  he said.

"Parks are recreational venues for the public and they will open as usual. Of
course, if there are any  protests or demonstrations, Beijing police and the
park authorities  will take appropriate measures  to ensure the protests go
smoothly.   Visitors will be informed about these measures in advance," he said.

The public  would be told when approved protests would  take place in the
designated zones.

He also reiterated that protests should not jeopardise the interests of the
country, although  he did not explain what constituted  national interests.

Beijing announced 10 days ago that it had designated areas in three  parks for
protests  during the Olympics.

The parks are in the Beijing districts of Fengtai, Haidian and Chaoyang,   areas
of the sprawling capital a long way from the Olympic Green.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              104 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                           The New Age (South Africa)

                             July 21, 2016 Thursday

\c\SPage 3 FS Lead

BYLINE: TSHIMOLOGO LEEUW

LENGTH: 370 words


TSHIMOLOGO LEEUW

LEADING civil society organisations in the country have formed an alliance to
promote the peaceful resolution of public protests.

The Coalition Against Violence (CAV) is made up of organisations working to
prevent violent protests and is coordinated by the Centre for the Study of
Violence and Reconciliation (CSVR) and the Institute for Security Studies (ISS).

CSVR executive director Nomfundo Mogapi said that they were very concerned at
the increasing number of violent protests ahead of the local government
elections. "The coalition will draw attention to the trends and put pressure on
the government and political parties to act appropriately."

The coalition was formed following a meeting to review the state of violent
protests in the country.

"Municipalities must take applications to hold a protest seriously, the right to
protest, demonstrate or strike is entrenched in Section 17 of South Africa's
Constitution and this needs to be respected," ISS researcher Lizette Lancaster
said.

CAV will focus on addressing the triggers that increase the risk of protests
turning violent.

"The causes of violent protests in South Africa are complex, but this doesn't
mean that protest action should be discouraged or that appropriate responses
can't be taken to minimise the impact of violence in the weeks ahead," Mogapi
said. Research by ISS and CSVR shows that a range of factors can influence
whether or not protests become violent and these include the conduct of leaders,
law enforcement agencies, government departments or private companies that may
be the target of protests.

According to Lancaster, the key question is why many communities feel peaceful
protests are not working to resolve their grievances.

"We know people often resort to violence after other avenues have been
exhausted. Violence is a desperate expression of dissatisfaction. Underlying
issues such as socioeconomic exclusion, inequality, poverty, unemployment and
unresolved trauma related to our past all come into play. Communities feel
stripped of their dignity and mistrust those in authority," Lancaster said.

The coalition aims to promote human dignity in how the government engages with
communities.

tshimol@ann7.com

                              105 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                           Agency Tunis Afrique Press

                              June 17, 2016 Friday

Social protests down 46% in May 2016

LENGTH: 156 words


(TAP) - Social protests have decreased by 46% in May 2016 compared to April,
2016.

During a press briefing held Friday in Tunis, Abdessatar Sahbani, member of the
Tunisian Forum for Economic and Social Rights (FTDES) said 529 social protests
were recorded in May, against 987 in April 2016.

Presenting the results of the report on social protests for May 2016 prepared by
the Tunisian Social Observatory under the FTDES, Sahbani added that the region
of Kairouan has occupied the first place in protest movements with 80, followed
by the region of Gafsa with 60 protests and Greater Tunis (50) and Kasserine
(42), pointing to a decrease in social protests in education and also
politically and socially driven ones, against rising sporting and economic
protests.

Sahbani said social movements will further decrease in the coming months as they
coincide with the summer period and Ramadan.

                     Oroville Mercury Register (California)

                             April 9, 2015 Thursday

Too few protests to halt plan

BYLINE: By Ryan Olson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 514 words


Oroville >> A preliminary review of submitted protests indicates there are too
few to outright halt the annexation of the first area of Southside Oroville into
the city.

Local officials were still verifying protests from registered voters to
determine if there are enough to call a mail election over the annexation of the
neighborhood of 2,392 residents east of Lincoln Boulevard and south of Wyandotte
Avenue.

State law required the Butte Local Agency Formation Commission to hold a protest
process after it approved the city of Oroville's application to annex the
203-acre area Feb. 5. The period to submit written protests began March 12 and
ended with a hearing Monday.

Under the protest process, annexation is halted if more than 50 percent of
either registered voters or landowners protest. A mail election is called if
between 25 to 50 percent of either group protests.

Annexation continues if less than 25 percent of either group protests.

LAFCO executive officer Steve Lucas said Wednesday the number of landowner
protests was insufficient to cancel annexation or call for a vote. Protesting
landowners needed to represent about $19 million of land value to halt
annexation or $9.5 million to force an election.

Regarding registered voters, Lucas said the 408 submitted registered voter
protests fell short of the 438 needed to stop the process.

Some protests invalid

LAFCO staff spent the day verifying the written protests to determine if there
were enough to

Annex Â» Page 5

meet the 219-vote threshold to force an election. Lucas said a preliminary
review showed a large number of protests would be invalid, but didn't have more
detailed figures by the end of the day.

He said protests may be disqualified for any number of reasons, including
residents who aren't registered voters or whose information didn't match voter
rolls.

Lucas said protests also needed to be completed by the person who signed the
document. Some protests were partially written in different colored inks or
different handwriting.

The final tally would be presented to the LAFCO board during its May 7 meeting.

One Faunce Way landowner told this publication that she didn't receive the mail
notice of the protest period. She had wanted to contact neighbors to submit
protests, but it was too late.

Lucas said it was possible some didn't receive a mail notice and it was
unfortunate some were missed. LAFCO mailed notices based on information from the
Assessor's Office.

Case law calls for commissions like LAFCO to make a good faith effort to contact
people. Lucas said LAFCO sends out mail notices in addition to a required public
notice in the newspaper.

After LAFCO completes its protest review of the first Southside annexation, it
will schedule the protest period for the second annexation east of the Lincoln
Boulevard area.

On March 5, the LAFCO board approved the city's annexation of the 201-acre area
generally south of Lower Wyandotte Road, east of Oro Bangor Highway and north of
both V-7 and Oroville Garden Ranch roads.

Reach reporter Ryan Olson at facebook.com/NorCalJustice and 896-7763.

Annex

From Page 1

                            National Herald Tribune

                           December 5, 2013 Thursday

JI Balochistan to launch protest demonstrations from Dec 13

LENGTH: 302  words


Jamaat Islami (JI) Balochistan has announced to launch protest demonstrations
from December 13 to 29, 2013 across the province against NATO supply and
continued lawlessness, price hike and unemployment in the country.

Provincial Ameer JI Abdul Mateen, Secretary General Bashir Ahmed Khundai along
with other leaders said during a press conference Quetta press club that protest
demonstrations will be held on national avenues and different areas of the
province.

Provincial Ameer said, in first phase of protest demonstration, JI will arrange
APC and Tribal Councils, while will launch the movement from December 13, 2013
by holding protest on Chamman After that protest demonstration will be held in
Quetta on December 20, while on Dec 29 public protests will be arranged in
Naseerabad on the route of NATO supply. Protest will be staged on 4 main avenues
of the province, he added.

Abdul Mateen said that nation is being dragged into economic crises from the day
when Pakistan became ally of US in war against terror, and because of this,
lawlessness has spread in country.

He said, rulers seems being failed in resolving the issues of public because,
they have closed the doors of employment on youth by increasing the tax to
fulfill their own resources, while it is the responsibility of government to
provide employment to youth. Abdul Mateen said, Prime Minister (PM) Nawaz Sharif
has not worked on the hope that he had given to people before the general polls
of May 11, while he has also not taken any lesson from his past experiences.

"Matters are becoming worst due to delay in decisions because, Pervez Musharraf
went against our culture, religion and faith by supporting US in war against
terror, while it has been confirmed in Wiki Leaks that US had already planned
the attack on Afghanistan," he added.

                   Globes [online] - Israel's Business Arena

                             August 9, 2011 Tuesday

Tent protesters to head from Tel Aviv to periphery;
The tent protesters today announced that this Saturday night's main protest will
be held in Beersheva.

BYLINE: Ori Chudy

LENGTH: 295 words


The tent protesters today announced that this Saturday night's main protest will
be held in Beersheva, rather than in Tel Aviv. A second protest march is planned
to take place in the north. The organizers said that the objective was to move
the center of power to the periphery.

Yesterday, the protesters published their vision for Israeli society, and Prime
Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced the make-up of his team for socioeconomic
change.

Judea and Samaria Council chairman Danny Dayan visited the tent protest on
Rothschild Boulevard in Tel Aviv today. Although the Judea and Samaria Council
has not officially joined the protest, Dayan said that it was a worthy protest
that brings the entire nation together.

Dayan said, "There are a lot of settlers among the tents here. The whole people
of Israel are here. For years, I've been saying that Israeli society should be
engaged, and from this perspective, the tent camps across the country have now
created a grace period. This is the time to engage to deal with the ills of
Israeli society. This protest puts real distress on the agenda."

Dayan said that the social protest should not turn into a protest that will tear
society apart, and that this was the time to focus on solutions. As for the
issue of government spending on the settlements and whether this contradicted
social justice, he said, "There are no special incentives for the settlements
now. Not in housing nor for education, nor for anything else. We have the same
problems as everyone else. Home prices in the settlements have also soared and
their residents are middle class people par excellence."

Published by Globes [online], Israel business news - www.globes-online.com - on
August 9, 2011

© Copyright of Globes Publisher Itonut (1983) Ltd. 2011

                          Sunday Telegraph (Australia)

                            February 6, 2011 Sunday
                               1 - State Edition

Protests reach Jordan

BYLINE: DALE GAVLAK

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 42

LENGTH: 284  words


AMMAN

HUNDREDS of Jordanians inspired by Egypt's uprising staged a protest against
Jordan's prime minister, installed just days earlier in response to
anti-government marches.

However, Jordan's main Muslim opposition group said it wants to give the new
leader a chance to carry out promised political reforms, and Friday's turnout
was much smaller than in previous protests against rising prices.

The scenes of mass protests in Egypt have riveted the Arab world, and unrest has
spread to other countries, most recently Yemen where tens of thousands on
Thursday called on their long-time president to step down.

However, expectations of large-scale protests in Arab countries after Friday's
noon prayers, the highlight of the Muslim religious week, did not materialise.

In Syria, where authoritarian President Bashar Assad has resisted calls for
political freedoms, an online campaign calling for protests in the capital,
Damascus, fizzled.

In Iraq, residents seizing on the Egypt protests staged two small demonstrations
to protest corruption in their own security forces, rampant unemployment and
scant electricity and water supply.

Even the march in the Jordanian capital of Amman on Friday was far smaller than
previous anti-government protests. Jordan's King Abdullah II has tried to
pre-empt further unrest by sacking his Cabinet earlier this week and installing
a new prime minister, Marouf al-Bakhit, amid promises of political reform.

The Islamic Action Front, the political arm of Jordan's Muslim Brotherhood, said
it is confident about change after meeting with the king and Mr al-Bakhit, a
leader of the group, Nimer al-Assaf, said.

Egypt's protesters also found support from people in Malaysia and Turkey.

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             August 3, 2008 Sunday

China lays out rules for protesters during Olympics

LENGTH: 480 words


Text of report by Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post website on 3
August

[Report by Josephine Ma in Beijing: "Beijing Spells Out the Rules for Protesters
During the Games"]

Beijing has issued a detailed list of procedures to follow for those wanting to
hold public protests during the Olympic Games.

The move comes after an activist was detained and sent home while trying to
lodge an application to stage a demonstration in one of three designated protest
zones.

Protest organizers will have to submit an application to the relevant public
security bureau five days before they want to hold their protest, together with
their ID cards, according to a notice posted on the official Bocog website.

Organizers are also asked to assign people to help the police maintain order
during the protest and wear badges for easy identification, Liu Shaowu, director
of the Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games' security department,
said on the website.

The removed activist was sent home on Friday. She had been representing some 100
homeowners from Suzhou and was at the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau
to hand in an application to protest in a designated protest zone.

Anti-Japanese activists have also been told they will not be given permission to
stage protests.

According to the website, foreign applicants have been asked to provide a
Chinese translation of their application documents. State agencies, private
companies and NGOs have to chop the document with their official seal as well as
getting it signed by the head of the organization.

The relevant public security agencies will decide on whether to allow the
protest two days before the planned protest date and will notify applicants in
writing, Mr Liu said.

If applicants have not received any feedback two days before the planned
protest, they should assume their application has been turned down.

The three protest parks would remain open to the public even if protests took
place, although security measures would be implemented, he said.

"Parks are recreational venues for the public and they will open as usual. Of
course, if there are any protests or demonstrations, Beijing police and the park
authorities will take appropriate measures to ensure the protests go smoothly.
Visitors will be informed about these measures in advance," he said.

The public would be told when approved protests would take place in the
designated zones.

He also reiterated that protests should not jeopardise the interests of the
country, although he did not explain what constituted national interests.

Beijing announced 10 days ago that it had designated areas in three parks for
protests during the Olympics.

The parks are in the Beijing districts of Fengtai, Haidian and Chaoyang, areas
of the sprawling capital a long way from the Olympic Green.

Source: South China Morning Post website, Hong Kong, in English 3 Aug 08

                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                            February 4, 2007 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

LETTERS

BYLINE: AUSTIN AMERICAN-STATESMAN

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G02

LENGTH: 979 words


SPEAKING OUT

Misleading coverage

Re: Jan. 18 article "Decrying abortion, war."

Your coverage of the protests in Austin was misleading and failed to accurately
convey the scope of the day's events. The article attempted to equate the
anti-abortion protest, attended by only a few hundred, with the larger anti-war
protest that gathered more than 1,000 citizens.

Anti-war Austin residents stopped traffic to march up Congress Avenue, chanting
to end the occupation of Iraq. The protest began with a large rally that
blanketed the plaza in front of City Hall and concluded on a stage constructed
in front of the Capitol. Speakers included prominent political figures and a
University of Texas professor, both of whom spoke out against this horrible and
illegal war. All of these facts were absent from your article.

It strikes me as ironic that a protest against women's rights should receive
more emphasis in your paper than an anti-war protest.

KATHERINE HAENSCHEN

Austin

Protests endanger troops

Re: Jan. 28 article "Thousands join D.C. war protest."

I'm offended by the absurd suggestion that war protesters like Nick Travis are
"troop-supporting." Quite the contrary, their efforts embolden our enemy and
make tougher an already difficult situation.

Claiming to be troop-supporting may make Travis feel good about himself, but the
fact is; he's no help to our troops.

Don't like the war? Fine, write your congressman, support a like-minded
candidate or run for office yourself. But as long as we're fighting this war,
you can better support our troops if you'd keep yourself from being part of the
enemy's propaganda machine.

BILL WELCH

wowelch@aol.com

Austin

SPECIAL PRIVILEGES?

KIM-POSSIBLE

Who does she think she is?

Re: Jan. 27 article "Kim seeks special airport access."

I understand that Saturdays are typically slow news days, and that is the only
reason I can muster as to why Austin City Council 3ember Jennifer Kim's demand
for special airport privileges commanded front-page news.

I find it terribly ironic when bureaucrats such as Kim and our venerable
representatives in Washinton believe they can and should circumvent those very
rules and regulations they are responsible for creating in the name of the
public good.

Don't like the laws? Fine. Change them the old-fashioned way - by utilizing the
very same legislative process they were elected to impart.

DIANE LeBLEU

Austin

*

When I read the article, I was relieved such a critical issue had been resolved.
Austinites everywhere can breath a sigh of relief knowing Kim doesn't "own" our
airport and must go through the hoops just like the rest of us.

Whew! Now we can move on.

DON STRATMANN

Austin

*

Bravo for the American-Statesman publishing that story on Page 1.

What unmitigated chutzpah, when the mayor and the city manager have not
requested such an exemption. And to top it off, Kim is peeved that she didn't
get what she asked for.

We need people with maturity to run our City Council, so I will not be voting
for Kim if she runs for reelection.

HENRY R. HUG

Austin

*

Welcome to the world of us common folk, Ms. Kim, those of us who hired you and
can fire you. Since we common folk are paying your salary, you can stand in line
like the rest of us.

JOE MEADOWS

Austin

Leave her alone

Kim's misunderstanding about airport security procedures seems to have been a
short-lived, minor incident that does not merit full-length, front-page
coverage.

Why isn't the Statesman reporting on the minor misunderstandings of the white or
male City Council members?

Texas has a long tradition of denying Asian Americans political participation.
That's one tradition the Statesman should not be seeking to revive.

Leave Kim alone or publish something positive about her for a change.

ARTHUR SAKAMOTO

Austin

Webb set up for failure

Re: "District saw few answers for Webb's problems."

So Superintendent Pat Forgione's recommendation is to move failing students to
another low-performing school and pray (surely not in public school) that they
miraculously improve.

Webb Middle School has one of the state's highest teacher turnover rates;
inexperienced teachers who actually fail certification exams; and its students
have been failing for three years. Now, everyone pretend those teachers were at
Westlake High or Anderson High and consider whether students there would have
any chance of passing with that caliber of instruction.

Trust me, the parents are not blameless, either, and they should be held
accountable, but if those are the types of teachers the state is sending, then
Webb was set up for failure.

SHARON ARMSTEAD

Cedar Park

Watch your step, parents

A law is under consideration in California to put parents in jail for spanking
their children because it is a form of child abuse.

Let's go one step further. Let's put the parents of obese children in jail
because the parents are abusing the children by overfeeding them and putting
them in bad health. Or the parents who won't go to sports events or to dance
recitals or music recitals because that is a form of child neglect. Or the
parents who smoke or drink or use drugs in front of their children because they
are setting a bad example. Let's put parents in jail for correcting their
children, such as scolding, when their child does something wrong.

Let's put parents in jail for raising their own children as they see fit.

Solution: Let's turn our kids, at birth, over to the government and let the
government raise them according to their laws so that our kids will be
well-trained and disciplined.

TOM WALSH

Buda

Coal plants' effects

Even if TXU Corp. does get approval to build the coal plants, the public will
soon turn against the company when everyone realizes the impact global warming
is going to have on flooding the Texas Coastal Plains areas. I hope it's not
already too late to stop the eventual ocean rise. Some scientists think it is
already too late.

EUGENE PRESTON

http://egpreston.com

Austin

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                             June 20, 2005, Monday

CALL FOR BAN ON PROTESTS AT MARCHES

SECTION: Ulster Edition; NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 212 words


STRANGFORD assemblyman David McNarry is issuing a call today to the Parades
Commission for a total ban on protests at parades. The Ulster Unionist MLA said
he firmly believes an across-the-board ban could go a long way to ensuring that
the marching season will pass off peacefully. "Unfortunately, it seems there is
no such thing as a peaceful protest," said Mr McNarry. "Protests cannot be
controlled and there is no option other than for the Parades Commission to ban
all parade protests. "This is because republicans are intent on abusing the
right to peaceful protest," said the MLA. "What we have is that the Parades
Commission readily determines bans on legal parades, but never have they banned
a protest. "The PSNI can police law-abiding people involved in parades, but they
cannot police protests without violence erupting. "Subsequently, the Parades
Commission have caved-in to a protests' charter as evidenced by the orchestrated
republican attacks over the weekend." Speaking to the News Letter yesterday, the
Strangford MLA said he would be firmly putting his view to the Commission today.
"I have no doubt that parades would pass through peacefully if people don't
protest," said Mr McNarry. "The law is there to ban them and it should be used."

LOAD-DATE: June 21, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-TYPE: PAPER

                   Copyright 2005 Century Newspapers Limited

                     Belfast News Letter (Northern Ireland)

                             June 20, 2005, Monday

CALL FOR BAN ON PROTESTS AT MARCHES

SECTION: Ulster Edition; NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 217 words


STRANGFORD assemblyman David McNarry is issuing a call today to the Parades
Commission for a total ban on protests at parades.

The Ulster Unionist MLA said he firmly believes an across-the-board ban could go
a long way to ensuring that the marching season will pass off peacefully.

"Unfortunately, it seems there is no such thing as a peaceful protest," said Mr
McNarry.

"Protests cannot be controlled and there is no option other than for the Parades
Commission to ban all parade protests.

"This is because republicans are intent on abusing the right to peaceful
protest," said the MLA.

"What we have is that the Parades Commission readily determines bans on legal
parades, but never have they banned a protest.

"The PSNI can police law-abiding people involved in parades, but they cannot
police protests without violence erupting.

"Subsequently, the Parades Commission have caved-in to a protests' charter as
evidenced by the orchestrated republican attacks over the weekend."

Speaking to the News Letter yesterday, the Strangford MLA said he would be
firmly putting his view to the Commission today.

"I have no doubt that parades would pass through peacefully if people don't
protest," said Mr McNarry.

"The law is there to ban them and it should be used."

                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                            June 15, 2016 Wednesday
                                   E1 Edition

13 protests a day rock SA, says research

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 445 words


WAGES, service provision, crime, dismissals, unemployment and housing are what
South Africans complain about daily - in at least 67â[#x20ac]¯750 protests over
the past 17 years.

And those protests are continuing, at a rate of about 13 a day at the last
count, mainly peacefully.

"Protests seem to be the measure that the majority of the poor use to access
democracy," said University of Johannesburg researcher Boitumelo Maruping.

Why are so many still protesting across the country?

"Those in power have to do more listening, as well as more implementing," said
sociology professor Peter Alexander, also of UJ. "One way of avoiding protests
over electric lights is by providing electric lights."

They are part of the team of researchers from UJ's Social Change Research Unit
which analysed the SAPS's counts of protests.

Yesterday the team released its report, "Counting Police-recorded Protests:
Based on South African Police Service Data".

Recorded

It looked at incident data collected by the police through their incident
registration information system from 1997 to 2013.

Those 67â[#x20ac]...750 incidents were police-recorded protests, not general
crowd-related incidents. They were about 43% of the 156â[#x20ac]...230 crowd
incidents logged by police over that period, and were probably under-reported,
said the researchers.

Police count protests by the day, so if a group protested over three days, it
would be logged as three incidents.

Researchers said about 80% of protests were orderly, 10% disruptive and 10%
â[#x20ac]¨violent (with injuries or damage).

Labour-related protests were more orderly - about 86% of them - than
community-related protests (68%).

There was a "steady rise" in the proportion of both labour and community
â[#x20ac]¨protests that were disorderly, said the report.

Researcher Boikanyo Mo-

loto said her assessment of the incident reports indicated that violence often
flared after police intervened, for example by shooting rubber bullets.

Labour issues topped protesters' concerns, with about 46% of protests attributed
to this by police. Community protests were the second-biggest issue, with about
22%.

Xenophobia was listed as the main cause of just 0.2% of protests.

The most protests were in 2012 with 5â[#x20ac]¯589; the least in 2004, with less
than half â[#x20ac]¨that.

Gauteng had the most protests and the Northern Cape the least, but looking at
protests per 100â[#x20ac]...000 people, the Northern Cape and North West had the
most.

"It's not just about this elusive concept of service delivery," said Institute
for Security Studies researcher Lizette Lancaster.

She welcomed the study, saying it showed how communities were under siege over a
range of issues, including violent crime.

louise.flanagan@inl.co.za

LOAD-DATE: June 16, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The Frontier Post

                            December 18, 2015 Friday

Karachiites suffer as protests become order of day

SECTION: Vol. XXX No. 346

LENGTH: 364  words


Commuters have to go through great hardship almost every day due to protests and
rallies on the streets of Karachi, as these have become order the day.It appears
as if protesters are at liberty to take to any street and block it for traffic,
ruining the plans of thousands of commuters who are trying to reach from point A
to B. Ambulances also get stuck in the traffic mess and the distance that should
take minutes to cover gets stretched over hours, delaying the provision of much
needed medical care to the patient.

Here is the list protests and rallies on Karachi streets during the past few
days: protest over killings of Muslims by Israel-backed forces in Nigeria on
December 16; protest by PIA on December 15 employees over proposed privatization
of the national flag carrier; protest by sugarcane growers on December 13;
protest by family members of a youth killed in an alleged police encounter and;
protest demonstration on December 11 calling for declaring local bodies
elections null and void and then holding re-elections.No matter if the number of
demonstrators is huge or thin, blocking roads is considered the most essential
part of any protest. The aim, obviously, is to draw attention of the government
by making the people suffer.Traffic jam is just one problem caused by these
protests.

The availability of a large number of people stuck in jams becomes a perfect
place for the criminal elements to come out and deprive the citizens of their
cash, jewelry, cell phones, laptops and other valuable belongings.What is even
more irritating for the commuters is how police reacts to the protests.
Sometimes the protesters don't have any intention to block a road but then
police jumps to action and does what protesters don't.Protests are also held in
other civilized countries where people do take to streets to raise their voice.
But unlike the protesters of our country, these demonstrators never try to
disrupt the system. The citizens of Karachi who contribute billions of rupees in
taxes question for how long they will have to put up with this ordeal on a day
to day basis. Don't the administration and traffic police have any solution to
this significant issue?

                                 Jerusalem Post

                              May 19, 2013 Sunday

Social justice protests held in TA, J'lem for 2nd week

BYLINE: BEN HARTMAN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 206 words


A few hundred people marched in central Tel Aviv on Saturday night to protest
the current government's economic policies, in the second-straight week of
"social justice" protests in the city.

The protest in Tel Aviv was held at the same time that hundreds gathered in
Jerusalem as well as in Beersheba.

Other protests included a few hundred people who gathered outside the house of
Israeli businessman Yitzhak Tshuva in Netanya, and a few dozen outside of Prime
Minister Binyamin Netanyahu's house in Caesarea. At the protest in Netanya,
demonstrators called for a greater share of the offshore gas profits to go into
the public coffers, while in Caesarea, protesters rallied against the budget and
lampooned recent revelations about the expenditures at the prime minister's
house.

At the protest in Tel Aviv, the crowd called out chants like "there is no future
with [finance minister] Lapid and Bibi [Netanyahu]" as well as "the people
demand social justice," a chant from the 2011 protests.

Saturday night's protests were far smaller than last weekend's, when several
thousand people marched through central Tel Aviv in what was billed as the
reignition of the 2011 social justice protests, in response to the announcement
of the new budget.

                            The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             October 7, 2011 Friday

EDITORIAL: The "Occupy" protests: After the bellowing, get to achievable targets

BYLINE: The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 401 words


Oct. 07--The protests

Street protests can be inane. Recall the image of Medicare beneficiaries
bellowing (during Congressional debates over health care reform) that government
should keep its mitts out of health care. Another case: Several months ago a
woman protesting the planned construction of a mosque in a Tennessee town found
particular meaning in screaming into a radio microphone "Islam is not a
religion!"

The current protests being carried out under the banner of "Occupy Wall Street"
have similarly tenuous components that, at times, convey impressions of a
complaintfest; what else to make of the latest iteration in the form of "Occupy
College" walkouts to protest student debt loads and the shortage of jobs for
graduates?

But there is something legitimate beneath some of these "occupy" protests, just
as the tea party movement ultimately gave voice to genuine dismay over the
direction of government.

The tea partiers started in a confusing way, and a few of their early champions
were laughably inarticulate. But ultimately some of them got beyond caricature
fulmination to insist on specific actions. Some of those actions have been
downright damaging, the debt ceiling fiasco being an example, but the ultimate
blame for that falls not on the tea partiers but on the elected policymakers who
did their bidding.

With luck, the "occupy" movement will take a lesson and come up with achievable
targeted steps to guide policymakers in wiser directions. Doubling the minimum
wage and arresting unnamed Wall Street "criminals" don't pass the achievable
test. Here's one that does: Call for the return of banking controls that were
written during the Depression in 1933 and that were later swept away. The
restoration of so-called Glassâ[#x20ac]"Steagall restrictions, which tea
partiers might also favor, would do more to heal and protect the economy than
countless other corporation-bashing initiatives by keeping Wall Street cowboys
in check.

The test here is whether the "occupy" crowd -- or crowds -- can get beyond the
shouting to the practical stage. That includes not just spelling out pragmatic
prescriptions, as wonky as some might sound, but also turning up at the voting
booth. That's ultimately how many important things get done in a democracy.

___ (c)2011 The Keene Sentinel (Keene, N.H.) Visit The Keene Sentinel (Keene,
N.H.) at www.sentinelsource.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

LOAD-DATE: October 7, 2011

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                            January 29, 2008 Tuesday
                                  ALL EDITION

THE ESSENTIALS How to start and organize a protest

SECTION: XTREME; Jennifer Glass; Pg. B04

LENGTH: 297 words


Having a voice as a teen is important, because we are the future of our nation.
One way to get your voice heard is by protesting.

Here are tips on how to start and organize a protest from Mecca and Okonlawon
Smith, who have participated in a protest demonstration; Shama S. Cartwright, a
local musician who writes protest music; and Richmond County Marshal's Sgt.
Bryan Patterson:

* When organizing a protest, first and foremost, have a reason.

* Find people that support your cause: Draft a petition and go out to find
people who believe the same way you.

* Protest by the rules: While protesting, you can't block a sidewalk, but you
can be on a sidewalk. You cannot impede the flow of traffic.

* Protest no-no's: Never take your clothes off in public, never throw stuff, and
never make terrorist threats, such as, "I'm going to follow you home and burn
your house down." Use common sense: You know what not to do.

* Laws change. Generally, you need to have a permit to demonstrate for groups of
four or more, but recent laws in Augusta state that you no longer need a permit
unless the protest is held in the street.

* Keep your options open. Protest doesn't mean just marching and carrying picket
signs. You can express your concerns with the clothes you wear, the music you
play or a simple act of silence.

* Sometimes, you don't need to protest. "Learn who you are and there's no need
of protest," Mecca Smith said. "When you know who you are there is no need to
protest because the knowledge of self is the protest."

* Protester words of wisdom: "Knowing who your history is, knowing your
grandmother, knowing your ancestors, knowing your goals and objectives allows
you to know where you need to be today," Okonlawon Smith said.

Jennifer Glass is a senior at North Augusta High School.

                                   Irish News

                            July 11, 2007 Wednesday

Commission permits loyalist counter demo

BYLINE: Barry McCaffrey

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 359 words


The Parades Commission last night ruled that nationalists and loyalists can hold
counter-protests within metres of each other at a flashpoint interface in west
Belfast tomorrow morning.

Loyalists will be allowed to hold counter-protests on the Springfield Road as
nationalist residents protest against an Orange Order march.

The decision, which has angered nationalist residents, will allow 10 loyalist
protesters to stand on a traffic island outside the disused Mackies Factory site
while a second loyalist protest will be allowed to take place on an upper
section of the Springfield Road up to within 10 metres of the nationalist
protest.

It is believed to be the first time that loyalists have been allowed to counter-
protest in this way.

Defending its decision, the commission said: "Protests and counter-protests are
important civil and human rights and should be facilitated where possible
without restriction.

"However, there is no doubt that these protests demonstrate a degree of
community disharmony which clearly is in need of redress."

Springfield Road residents spokesman Sean Murray criticised the commission
decision to allow the loyalist counter-protests.

"The Parades Commission decision defies logic as they are now allowing loyalists
to protest directly outside nationalist homes on the Springfield Road," he said.

"This counter-demonstration has been orchestrated by two senior figures from the
NWBPCF (North and West Belfast Parades and Cultural Forum).

"The NWBPCF is trying to disrupt the nationalist protest but we are appealing
for people to remain calm and not to be provoked."

Mr Murray rejected NWBPCF claims that nationalists had intimidated loyalist
residents on the Springfield Road and attacked the home of a Protestant
pensioner at the weekend.

NWBPFC spokesman Tommy Cheevers said that nationalist intimidation had forced
loyalists to apply for a counter-protest, however.

"This is the first time this has happened and only came about because our people
were being intimidated and decided to speak out against these attacks," he said.

"Our community is not looking for confrontation, but we insist that our voice is
properly heard."

                                 Aswat Masriya

                            October 17, 2014 Friday

Almost one "act of violence" every five hours in September: Democracy Index

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 542  words


CAIRO, Oct 17 (Aswat Masriya) - Egypt has witnessed 138 acts of violence and
"political terrorism" in September, led by clashes between Muslim Brotherhood
supporters and security forces, the Cairo-baseddemocracy index reported Friday.

Explosions and violence in Cairo and other cities have surged since the ouster
of Former President Mohamed Mursi, resulting in 1500 deaths of mainly Mursi
supporters and hundreds of security personnel.

The month of September witnessed 25 killings, 43 injuries, and 138 cases of
violence and political terrorism, the report stated, estimating five accidents
per day, and almost one accident every five hours.

The report identified perpetrators in three groups; the Muslim Brotherhood,
security forces, and supporters of the current state administration.

Armed clashes between the Brotherhood supporters, security forces, and the
people amounted to 57, all of which were sparked by pro-Brotherhood protests and
ended in confrontations with either security forces or the supporters of the
current administration, in reference to the supporters of President Abdel Fattah
al-Sisi.

Bombings carried out using improvised explosive devices (IEDs) amounted to 32
cases, while 20 more attempts were foiled, four of which targeted electricity
transformers.

These accidents occurred in 17 governorates, most of which took place in North
Sinai which witnessed 23 accidents (17 percent), followed by Cairo where 20
accidents took place (15 percent).

On Wednesday, the index reported a decline in the rate of protesting in
September, standing at 513 protests during the month against 647 protests during
August.

Democracy Index noted a decline in the number of protests staged by the Muslim
Brotherhood. The group, listed as a terrorist organisation last December, staged
203 (39.5 percent) protests in September, compared to 414 (64 percent) in
August; almost half the number of protests.

Most of the Muslim Brotherhood's protests were held on Friday, making up 75
percent of the group's protests throughout the month. Fridays witnessed the
largest number of protests held during the month; 153 protests were held on the
four Fridays of last September.

The number of social and economic protests meanwhile rose in September, making
up 54 percent of the protests held during the month, compared to 35 percent last
month. This came at the expense of protests calling for civil and political
rights, which made up 46 percent of the protests, as opposed to 65 percent in
August.

The most frequent form of protests in September was hunger striking. Democracy
Index reported at least 1000 cases of hunger strikes, in solidarity with a
nation-wide campaign launched in late August in protest over last year's protest
law and calling for the release of all those detained due to the law.

Cairo hosted the highest number of protests in September; 118 protests making up
23 percent of the protests held nationwide. Alexandria ranked second with 56
protests while Giza ranked third with 45 protests. The Sinai Peninsula witnessed
the smallest number of protests; one protest was held in North Sinai and another
in South Sinai.

Democracy Index is a research project issued by the Cairo-based International
Development Centre to monitor protests rate in Egypt.

LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Magazine

JOURNAL-CODE: 1026

                Provided by Syndigate Media Inc.(Syndigate.info)
