                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                           December 5, 2013 Thursday

NATO supply, lawlessness: JI Balochistan to launch protest demonstration from
Dec 13

SECTION: Vol. XXXVII No. 333

LENGTH: 448  words


Jamaat Islami (JI) Balochistan has announced to launch protest demonstrations
from December 13 to 29, 2013 all across the province against NATO supply and
continued lawlessness, price hike and unemployment in the country.

Provincial Ameer JI Abdul Mateen, Secretary General Bashir Ahmed Khundai along
with other leaders said during a press conference Quetta press club that protest
demonstrations will be held on national avenues and different areas of the
province.

Provincial Ameer said, in first phase of protest demonstration, JI will arrange
APC and Tribal Councils, while will launch the movement from December 13, 2013
by holding protest on Chaman

After that protest demonstration will be held in Quetta on December 20, while on
Dec 29 public protests will be arranged in Naseerabad on the route of NATO
supply. Protest will be staged on 4 main avenues of the province, he added.

Abdul Mateen said that nation is being dragged into economic crises from the day
when Pakistan became ally of US in war against terror, and because of this,
lawlessness has spread in country.

He said, rulers seems being failed in resolving the issues of public because,
they have closed the doors of employment on youth by increasing the tax to
fulfil their own resources, while it is the responsibility of government to
provide employment to youth.

Abdul Mateen said, Prime Minister (PM) Nawaz Sharif has not worked on the hope
that he had given to people before the general polls of May 11, while he has
also not taken any lesson from his past experiences.

"Matters are becoming worst due to delay in decisions because, Pervez Musharraf
went against our culture, religion and faith by supporting US in war against
terror, while it has been confirmed in Wiki Leaks that US had already planned
the attack on Afghanistan," he added.

JI Provincial leader more said that all parties have advised the current
government that Pakistan should take itself out from this war but, Nawaz Sharif
government is also continuing the policies of its predecessors.

He said all parties have forwarded this opinion in All Parties Conference (APC)
that Pakistan should come out of war on terror by changing its foreign policy
because this war is creating problems for country.

"No one in the society is feeling secure, kidnapping and target killing is
ongoing even Ulema, political and religious leaders are being targeted," he
added.

Replying to a query he said, Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM) has fake mandate and
Altaf Hussain is not a political leader he has made Karachi hostage for 20
years.

"US should leave this land and we by blocking the NATO supply should pressurize
US to stop drone attacks on our country," he concluded.

                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            January 27, 2013 Sunday

AHBP teachers to launch protest move

SECTION: Vol. XXXVII No. 26

LENGTH: 201  words


The teachers recruited under the Aghaz Haqooq Balochistan Package (AHBP) have
decided to launch protest movement in favour of their demand of making them
permanent. The protest movement is being launched under the umbrella of Haqooq
Teachers Association.

In this regard, a protest rally would be taken out in Quetta on January 28
(today). A hunger strike camp would also be set up in front of the Press Club
after the protest rally. The male as well as female teachers would also take
part in the hunger strike.

If then the demand of the teachers were not met, then the circle of protest
would be expanded to the entire province where protest demonstrations would be
held. If the concerned authorities did not agree to their demand, a protest
demonstration and sit-in would be staged in front of the parliament, said the
teachers.

According to them, the authorities including the ministers had assured to them
to make them permanent within 15 days, at the parliament house, but nothing was
done despite lapse of several months.

It is high time for the government to regularize their services making them
permanent against the same posts of teachers, otherwise, the protest would be
intensified further, they vowed.

                              141 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                   The Star Phoenix (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan)

                            January 18, 2013 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Protests part of healthy democracy

BYLINE: Nathalie Des Rosiers, The StarPhoenix

SECTION: FORUM; Pg. A9

LENGTH: 454 words


Des Rosiers is general counsel of Canadian Civil Liberties Association.

The right to protest disturbs and disrupts. It is meant to.

It disturbs ordinary people who may be delayed, inconvenienced or unable to do
business as usual. It disturbs businesses for whom changes to scheduling may
mean additional costs. It should disturb the government whose job it is to
facilitate our life in a democracy and offer us a prosperous place to live.

When protests disturb and paralyze traffic, what should be done?

During the protests last spring in Quebec, we witnessed a variety of responses.
The government initially ignored the protests and these grew larger. Some people
took their anger to the courts and sought injunctions, which led to arrests,
violent interaction between police and protesters, more court challenges, more
arrests, more tear gas and broken shop windows.

Then the government enacted a special law that would have significantly
curtailed the right to protest, which was met by a broadening of support for the
protest movement and eventually to an election, which saw the newly elected
Parti Quebecois "revoke" the legislation.

There are lessons to be learned here. Finance Minister Jim Flaherty worries that
continuous indigenous blockades threaten economic recovery. He may be right.

The government has choices: It can ignore the protest and hope that, over time,
protesters will tire, their numbers decrease and their public support wanes. It
can criminalize the protest, seeking injunctions to stop blockades and have
police arrest people. Or it can opt to attempt to remedy the problem at the root
of the protest, and commit to a resolution.

The job of police is to enforce the law and they must protect the right to
protest. Their primary aim is often to de-escalate the potential for violent
interruption. A decision not to intervene is often the smartest. Charges can be
laid later, if there has been criminal behaviour.

But people ask: How long can a protest go on? How long can the patience of
ordinary people be taxed? The answer is as long as the political struggle gains
enough supporters to keep the action going, or as long as the government takes
to resolve the issue.

Certainly, there are limits to the right to protest. There is no constitutional
right to violence or to endanger someone's life. Protests let emergency vehicles
go through. Occasionally, other essential services can also be negotiated with
the protesters.

It must be remembered that protests are legitimate forms of political
expression, and they do disturb. But so do elections, road construction and
closing the streets for parades and fundraising races. All are part of living in
a democracy. It is messy, but better than the alternative.

LOAD-DATE: January 18, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Opinion

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                      Inc.

                 BBC Monitoring Former Soviet Union - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            August 23, 2012 Thursday

Russians' protest potential steady over summer months, polls show

LENGTH: 274 words


Text of report by corporate-owned Russian news agency Interfax

Moscow, 23 August: Over the summer months of 2012, the index of public protest
potential among Russians has narrowly fluctuated around 34 points, while the
personal level [of protest potential] has stayed between 25 and 27 points,
VTsIOM [All-Russian Public Opinion Research Centre] sociologists told Interfax,
citing the results of their research.

The index of public protest potential shows the extent to which Russians
consider mass protests possible, while the index of personal protest potential
measures people's readiness to take part in protests. The greater the indices,
the more conviction among respondents that protests are possible and the greater
the declared readiness to take part.

At present, 28 per cent of Russians consider certain protest manifestations
possible in the country, while 68 per cent suppose that such events are
unlikely, the VTsIOM poll, carried out on 18-19 August among 1,600 people in 138
settlements in 46 Russian regions, showed.

According to regular sociological research, 27-28 per cent of respondents did
not rule out mass protests in their settlements in June-July, while 68-29 [as
received, presumed to be 69] per cent considered them unlikely.

As regards personal involvement in rallies against falling living standards and
in support of their rights, 17 per cent said they were ready to take part in
June and 19 per cent in July-August. Most people - 77 to 79 per cent - showed an
indifference towards such events throughout the summer months, the VTsIOM
research has shown.

Source: Interfax news agency, Moscow, in Russian 0806 gmt 23 Aug 12

                               Belfast Telegraph

                           December 1, 2010 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Queen's students join nationwide protests

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 307 words


STUDENTS from Queen's University Belfast were among thousands across the UK to
protest against plans to increase tuition fees.

Up to 60 students were involved in the demonstration outside the
vice-Chancellor's office at the south Belfast campus yesterday.

The protest organised by the pressure group FEE (Free Education for Everybody)
began at around 1pm and ended peacefully after three hours.

The students were seeking a meeting with vice-Chancellor Peter Gregson to
discuss fears about proposals to raise student fees to £9,000 a year.

Chris Donnelly (21), a first-year history student from Dungannon, was among the
protesters.

"We had a meeting on Monday night and decided to go down the protest route
against the vice-Chancellor Peter Gregson," he said. "We are totally opposed to
the Browne Review, which is the proposals to raise the tuition fees up to
£9,000.

"We came down to highlight that students at Queen's are resolutely opposed to
the rise in tuition fees.

"It was a peaceful protest, there has been no vandalism.

"It is a stewarded protest. Security guards are not allowing people outside the
building in."

QUB Students' Union president Gareth McGreevy, however, said it was an
independent protest.

"The Students' Union acknowledges the right for peaceful protest and the choice
to do so. "The protest was independent to any action currently ongoing by
QUBSU."

A spokesman for QUB said the protest ended quickly.

"There was small protest by a number of young people," he said.

"Professor Tony Gallagher, pro-vice-Chancellor, addressed the students, listened
to their concerns, and promised to report them back to the university's
management board."

CAPTION: Students unfurl a banner outside the vice-Chancellor's office at
Queen's University yesterday during their demonstration against cuts ARTHUR
ALLISON/PACEMAKERPeter Gregson: meeting sought

                              147 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          The Courier Mail (Australia)

                            December 21, 2015 Monday
                              CourierMail Edition

Protest was not simply just about the judiciary

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 812  words


TREVOR LaBrooy rightly points out (Letters, Dec 19) that Richard Chesterman
misses the whole point, as does the legal profession generally.

The protests about the Baden-Clay case are threefold: a protest against the
court overruling a properly instructed jury; a protest against a law that allows
this to happen; and a protest against inactivity on domestic violence generally.

Some people subscribe to one, two or all of these.

The protest should not be against the judiciary if, as they say, they only
interpret the law.

The protest against the law itself must be directed at government. The protest
against domestic violence is against the perpetrators.

The Queensland judiciary rightly defends its right to make judgments without
interference.

However, the people also make judgments through the jury. The appropriate body
to fix this is the people, through their government.

Ross Clark, Woody Point I READ with disbelief the statements of the Queensland
judiciary, who tried to state that the community protest against the decision in
Baden-Clay's appeal was an attack on the separation of powers (executive,
legislature and judiciary).

This is disingenuous in that the community (like the jury in the original trial)
believes that the evidence has proved that Baden-Clay killed his wife, lied
about the circumstances of her death in any number of formal venues, and has
been found guilty by a jury of his peers.

There is no attack on the separation of powers, it is a direct rebuff to the
decision of the Court of Appeal to downgrade his conviction for murder to
manslaughter.

It is the community that elects members of Parliament who raise legislation, the
executive is selected from these members of Parliament, and the judiciary is
appointed by the executive.

I suggest that there should be a mechanism whereby judicial decisions and the
judiciary itself are evaluated to ensure these decisions and the holders of
these judicial appointments are safe, acceptable and meet community standards
and expectations.

Garry Volk, Brisbane

THE sad demise of Allison Baden-Clay has shown the new order under which we now
must live.

This conclusion has been reached due to the legal fraternity's decision that we
have no right to ever question them.

1. Legal Fraternity. No dissent must ever be shown.

2. God. You may criticise slightly.

3. Politicians. Nothing must be shown as being their fault.

4. Us, the public. We must shut up, pay all our bills and never question the
legal fraternity or politicians.

Robert Lillington, Sheldon

I KNOW things are a bit unbridled at the moment but the spokesman for the Law
Society has flummoxed me. This present position has been brought about because,
in his opinion, "the prosecution was unable to prove that murder was the
intention".

If evidence was presented to the court by both the prosecution and defence, and
the jury, after hearing the evidence, brought in a verdict of guilty of murder
where does the problem lie? Are the jury to blame here? They believed the
prosecution was able to prove that murder was the intention. What is afoot?

Patrick McNevin, Macgregor

THE law makes much about what the "man in the street" or a "reasonable person"
would think about an issue.

A petition has been signed and a rally has been held by such people regarding
the Gerard Baden-Clay verdict reversal.

This is the feedback the judiciary should heed.

Ordinary people, evidently, are perplexed and distressed by this decision and
call into question the judicial system.

Patricia Paige, Nobby

IN DOWNGRADING the charge against Gerard Baden-Clay from murder to manslaughter,
the Court of Appeal has made two huge assumptions.

First, it has assumed that Allison's death was an accident during a fight.
Second, it has assumed Allison was dead when her body was dumped in the creek.
Surely Baden-Clay would have called an ambulance if he had accidentally
seriously injured or maybe even killed his wife in a fight and thus given her
perhaps some chance at life.

Instead he dumped her in a creek when she may not have been completely dead.
Surely this proves that he wanted her dead one way or the other.

The dumping in the creek may well have been the thing that finally killed
Allison.

To assume that she was killed in an accident and that Gerard "forgot" to call an
ambulance to try to save her, but instead innocently dumped her in a creek,
represents to me the greatest miscarriage of justice I have seen in my 77 years.

Robin Barke, Daisy Hill

AT THE rally on Friday, one of the speakers said that the law had to move with
the times.

I found myself questioning this until later that day I heard Bill Potts saying
that in Allison Baden-Clay's case, there were "no witnesses to a domestic
incident".

So yes, the law does have to move with the times.

Let Allison's death be evidence that surely violence can be fatal no matter who
is the perpetrator.Carol da Costa-Roque, Annerley

                              148 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                            The Times of India (TOI)

                            December 4, 2015 Friday

A protest spot in college campus? In UP, it's a norm: Students

BYLINE: Abhimanyu Mathur

SECTION: NOIDA

LENGTH: 763 words


Last week, Bareilly College announced its plan to build a designated protest
spot for its students inside the campus. Universities and colleges in the state
are certainly not alien to student protests. The fact that many of them are now
trying to come up with policies to regulate protests shows how deeply ingrained
student protests are in Uttar Pradesh's academic culture. But students in UP say
that to some extent, this has always been the case, with most institutions
having their own unofficial protest spots. The only difference is that what was
earlier a norm is now being given an official sanction.

Bareilly College to have a dedicated 'dharna spot' for students

Bareilly College recently sent out a circular proposing the construction of a
'high park' near the administrative block, which will act as an earmarked
location for student protests, or a de facto dharna sthal within the college.
Dev Murti, the secretary of the college's management committee, says, "The idea
behind this high park is to provide students space near the principal's office
to protest so that they do not disturb the evening classes or affect the
functioning of the administrative wing. If the students have a dedicated protest
spot, they will stay there and not disrupt the college proceedings. Lucknow has
its own protest spot opposite Council House, Delhi has Jantar Mantar, and so we
thought, why can't Bareilly have the same?"

Most UP varsities have unofficial protest spots

The idea of having a designated protest spot in campus is not new to UP. Aligarh
Muslim University has the reputation of being one of the most politically
charged varsities in the state, so it does not come as a surprise that the
administration there has made many attempts to regulate protests. Aman*, an
engineering student from the university, says, "The main entrance gate to the
university - Bab-e-Syed - is unofficially the protest spot for students in
Aligarh. There is an understanding between the administration and the students
that all protests will take place there only. In fact, in the past, the
administration has even tried to regulate the timings of the protests in an
attempt to restrict them to specific times during the day."

The situation in other major varsities in the state is quite similar. Ayush
Panwar, a student leader from Meerut, says, "Meerut's Chaudhary Charan Singh
University (CCSU) has a big tree inside the campus, which is known as the
protest spot. If you want to protest, that is where you go, almost like an
unwritten rule. Of course, there have been protests outside VC residence and
near the administrative block as well, but those are few in number. There was a
plan to limit protests inside the university and to move it to a park opposite
the library, but that never worked out."

UP students protest for the sake of protesting

Students say that this is because the educational institutions here are known
for their proactive and charged-up political atmosphere and student protests are
a regular feature in most of these institutions. A senior police official from
Lucknow, who did not wish to be named, says, "In Delhi and other places,
students protest for some issue. In UP, they protest for the sake of protesting.
Here, they say that if you haven't been a part of half a dozen big protests in
your first year of college, you are not a student leader. So, it's no wonder
that colleges have now started coming up with some rules and regulations for
protests."

Even cities like Noida that do not see a lot of dharnas have had colleges coming
up with protest-related regulations. Animesh*, a student of a private institute
in Noida, tells us, "Even though private colleges do not see protests because
here the authority is stricter and the punishment is severe, colleges in Noida
have come up with protest rules. That includes the area where one can stage a
dharna to the time limit. This is obviously done to discourage protests and to
ensure that such activities don't disrupt studies."

Only in UP you can have a protest over another protest

Sometimes, rules formulated on protests can become a reason for a whole new
protest. Rajneesh Thakur, a former student politician from Muzaffarnagar, tells
us, "I remember that the colleges here had introduced a rule some years ago that
students will not protest after lunch time because it disturbed the hostellers.
The funny part is that this led to a protest over the time schedule of protests.
It is clear that this region loves to protest, particularly the students!"

(*Names changed on request)

For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                   defenceWeb

                            November 2, 2015 Monday

54 protests recorded in SA last week

LENGTH: 349 words


The Police Ministry says 54 incidents of protests were recorded by police in the
last week, with most being peaceful.


"It is because most of the leaders of the protesting communities decided to be
at the centre of these protests and they have helped to ensure that they went
off peacefully most of the time," said Police Minister Nkosinathi Nhleko on
Saturday.



The Minister commended the leaders for their hand in ensuring that most protests
were conducted within the law.

"In the event that the protests were not peaceful, they were quickly brought
under control by the combined action of police and leaders," he said.

Student protests were recorded in eight of the country's provinces with
KwaZulu-Natal recording the most at 15 and Mpumalanga recording the least with
two protests. Protests were also recorded in the following provinces:

-          Gauteng with 13 protests

-          North West with 4 protests

-          Free State with 5 protests

-          Western Cape with 9

-          Eastern Cape with 11

-          Limpopo with 3

In all, students estimated at just over 30 000 protested in various forms with
most higher learning institutes being barricaded by angry students.

An estimated 40 000 Economic Freedom Fighters also took to the streets in
Johannesburg and Sandton in a march that largely went off peacefully.

On Friday, an estimated 1000 members of the African National Congress Women's
League also undertook a march to Pretoria.

Public order police were deployed in all the recorded protests. A few arrests
were made although most of these had to do with trespassing and defying court
orders.

"Again, men and women in blue have been on hand to ensure that protesters
exercise their rights peacefully - the rights that are enshrined in the
Constitution. They also ensured that those who were not part of the protests
were given the necessary protection and space to go about their lives without
least possible inconvenience," said Minister Nhleko.

The Minister said police will continue to discharge their duty of protecting all
South Africans as they exercise their rights.

                              150 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Daily News Egypt

                            August 18, 2015 Tuesday

599 labour protests in H1 of 2015: Democracy Meter

BYLINE: Daily News Egypt

LENGTH: 300 words


Egyptian NGO Democracy Meter issued a report Tuesday on Egypt's labour movement
in the first half of 2015, marking steadiness in the labour protest movement
size since 2014.

The report tracked the labour movement in the broader sense of the term, that
includes every wageworker whether for a public or private institution, small
businesses or handicrafts. The report tracked 48 categories of labourers who
demanded rights related to their work.

The categories included lawyers, journalists, university staff, security
workers, butchers, engineers, pharmacists and pilots.

A total of 599 protests were recorded between January and June of 2015, with an
average of three protests a day. These numbers are consistent with the 433
protests in the last four months of 2014, according to the report.

However, the Democracy Meter figures conflict with government officials'
statements. Minister of Manpower Nahed Al-Ashry stated last Tuesday that the
number of labour protests in 2015 were approximately 100 protests in comparison
to 200 protests in 2014.

The organisation added that the difference in figures could be referred to
either a deviation in the official statistics and the governments tracking of
labour issues, or "an attempt to create imaginary gains and draw an unreal image
of labour reality in Egypt".

The report highlighted that the industrial sector led the labour protests in
2015 with 169 protests, followed by the educational sector with 89 protests. The
main demands of the protests according to the report included: higher wages,
salaries and/or allowances and protesting arbitrary dismissals.

The report showed concerns on Al-Ashry's reactions to labour protest, saying
they lacked systemised solutions. Instead, instead they were mainly directly
attempts to solve every dispute on its own.

                              152 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                                 Jerusalem Post

                              March 9, 2015 Monday

Municipality clears out protest encampment on Tel Aviv's Rothschild

BYLINE: BEN HARTMAN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 258 words


A protest encampment set up on Rothschild Boulevard in Tel Aviv was cleared out
Sunday morning less than a week after it was set up as a continuation of sorts
of the Summer 2011 housing protests.

The man who launched the demonstration, Shay Cohen, said Sunday he and his
associates would look for other protest efforts in the coming days and that he
believes other protest camps could start sprouting up in other cities beginning
Monday.

"Our message was heard in the media and on social networks and helped get the
issues that really matter to the public back into the discussion," Cohen told
The Jerusalem Post Sunday afternoon.

Like the 2011 protests, the week-long protest on Rothschild began with a
Facebook post. About two weeks ago, Cohen, one of the founders and leaders of
the organization "Koach L'Ovdim" called on supporters to pitch tents in a show
of protest against the high cost of housing in Israel.

That may be where the similarities end though. While the 2011 demonstrations
swept the country and brought hundreds of thousands of people to protests in
cities across Israel, at most there were only about two dozen tents at the camp
launched by Cohen, and the protest only remained in the news cycle for around 24
hours.

The Tel Aviv municipality said Sunday that it had informed the protesters last
week that by Wednesday it would begin removing the tents. It added that those
who received permission to set up the encampment last week had left by Friday
and just a few late arrivals had remained when the evacuation was completed on
Sunday

LOAD-DATE: March 23, 2015

BRIEF: PM: Protest organizers include terrorist organizations members

BYLINE: R. Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 159 words


June 06--Among the organizers of the protests in Turkey, there are
representatives of terrorist groups who organized the attack on the U.S. embassy
in Ankara, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said during a press conference in
Tunis, TRT Haber TV channel reported on Thursday.

Erdogan added that among those detained during the protests in Istanbul there
are foreign nationals, but they are not officers of the diplomatic missions
accredited in Turkey.

It is ninth day that protests against the reconstruction of the park Gezi in
Taksim Square in Istanbul are continuing in different cities of Turkey.

Earlier, Erdogan said that the protests have ideological nature and are directed
against the government.

                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                             August 7, 2012 Tuesday

Non-recovery of senior doctor: Doctors on city roads lodging protest, stage
sit-in --Condemn govt. apathy

SECTION: Vol. XXXVI No. 219

LENGTH: 249  words


Doctors took out a protest rally and staged a protest demonstration near GPO
chowk here in the provincial metropolis on Monday.

The protest rally under the aegis of Pakistan Medical Association (PMA)
Balochistan was started from the Sandman Provincial Headquarter Hospital and
reached at the GPO chowk. The President PMA Balochistan, Dr. Sultan Khan Tareen
and others were leading the protest rally.

The participants of the rally carrying banners inscribed with slogans for early
recovery of Dr. Ghulam Rasool wanted to go to the Governor House and Chief
Minister Secretariat to record their protest. However, they were stopped by the
police personnel deployed there. Barricades were also erected there to prevent
entry of the doctors into the VIP area.

Addressing on the occasion, Dr. Sultan Tareen strongly condemned the government
for delay in recovery of the kidnapped psychiatrist. He also lashed out at the
government for its apathy towards the issue regretting that it has not bothered
even to say few words of sympathy to doctors.

Dr. Tareen also said that doctors' protest and strike would remain continued
till recovery of Dr. Ghulam Rasool. He said that doctors' protest is also aimed
at lodging protest against increasing incidents of kidnappings for ransom in
Quetta and other parts of the province.

He said that as the government has failed to protect the life and property of
the masses so it must quit.

Later, the doctors ended their protest demonstration and were dispersed
peacefully.

                    Appeal-Democrat (Marysville, California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 21, 2008 Thursday

Hillcrest vote is too close to call: But city's surface plan may be going under

BYLINE: John Dickey, Appeal-Democrat, Marysville, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 442 words


Aug. 21--Unofficial counts of Hillcrest water protests show the proposed Yuba
City surcharge will be a close call and could go down in defeat.

"It's real close," said City Clerk Terrel Locke.

Locke and other city staffers spent Wednesday checking whether the protests were
valid, and inputting the substantiated ones on to a computer spreadsheet.

Locke is hoping to have the count finished by the end of today.

By late Wednesday, unofficial and uncompleted counts showed 2,222 verified
protests, 461 more protests that still need to be verified, and another 436
unverified protest withdrawals that might go against the protest totals if they
check out.

Just over half of the 4,000 Hillcrest area homeowners or city water customers
would have to protest the nearly $20-per-month surcharge to shoot it down.

The fee would pay to switch residents from their current groundwater system to
the city's surface water facility.

Official numbers will be certified by City Council on Aug. 26.

Members of Murky Waters, opponents of the city's plan, were observing the public
count at City Hal, but declined comment on process.

They had gathered many of the protests filed, but generated a backlash from
people who wanted the city's surface water because it was better than the
Hillcrest groundwater.

Anti-protesters started their own campaign of hanging flyers on doorknobs
telling residents they can take back their protest. They also put a video on
YouTube.

Mayor Rory Ramirez joined in the anti-protest campaign with a mailing to
residents claiming misinformation was given out, and telling them they could
take back their protests or file a protest.

A 45-day Proposition 218 protest period ended Monday at a stormy Yuba City City
Council meeting marked by accusations of lies and complaints regarding the
city's handling of the issue.

High arsenic readings in Hillcrest groundwater last year sparked a city campaign
to connect Hillcrest residents to the main city plant which takes its water from
the Feather River.

But some have complained about a $3,570 per-home surcharge, or $19.80 monthly,
to pay for a 30-inch pipe, a water tank and other equipment.

Contact Appeal-Democrat re-porter John Dickey at 749-4711 or
jdickey@appealdemocrat.com

To see more of the Appeal-Democrat, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.appeal-democrat.com. Copyright (c) 2008, Appeal-Democrat, Marysville,
Calif. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints,
email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send
a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee
Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                               The Jerusalem Post

                           October 16, 2001, Tuesday

Settler leaders to renew protests vs government

BYLINE: Margot Dudkevitch

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 515 words


Leaders of the Council of Jewish Communities in Judea, Samaria, and the Gaza
Strip informed Prime Minister Ariel Sharon in a meeting last night of their
plans to renew protest activities and fight the government's recognition of the
establishment of a Palestinian state.

The leaders expressed deep disappointment in Sharon's overall policy, especially
his decision to pull out IDF troops from the Abu Sneineh and Hareth a-Sheikh
neighborhoods in Hebron and leave the security of Jewish civilians in the hands
of West Bank Preventive Security chief Jibril Rajoub.

Prior to the meeting at Sharon's office, the Council convened an emergency
meeting to discuss the issues and vote on whether to cancel their meeting with
the prime minister, but decided to go ahead with it and express their concerns..

Council chairman Benny Kashriel said: We are deeply disappointed with Sharon's
performance and will point out to him that the withdrawal of IDF troops from Abu
Sneineh will only lead to the renewal of violence and an escalation in terror.
The easing up of restrictions and the lifting of blockades will only endanger
the lives of Jewish residents in our communities even further and greatly harms
the IDF's deterrence capability Kashriel said that the leaders will also demand
that Sharon dismantle the coalition and form a right wing government.

The council will also go ahead with plans to stage a protest rally in Jerusalem
next Monday to protest the current government policy. Uri Ariel of Beit El said
community leaders will tell Sharon that they will fight the establishment of a
Palestinian state and do everything to prevent it from happening.

It is absolutely inconceivable and we will remind Sharon that he is responsible
for the security of all Israeli civilians Ariel said. The current war we are
waging against the terrorists has taken the heaviest toll in civilian lives more
than any other war the country has fought."

Noam Arnon spokesman for the Hebron Jewish community who refused to accompany
the leaders to meet Sharon due to the decision to withdraw the troops noted that
despite Sharon's statements if one shot is fired in the Hebron area troops would
reoccupy the Palestinian neighborhoods.

Meanwhile Binyamin police yesterday began investigating reports by Palestinians
that residents of Shilo and Shvut Rachel torched two of their vehicles and
damaged others and fired shots at a group of Palestinians harvesting olives in a
grove two kilometers from the community yesterday morning.

Judea and Samaria police spokesman Rafi Yafe said Palestinians from Turmus Aya
informed soldiers that Jewish residents shot at them as they harvested the
olives. Police who arrived at the scene were taken by Palestinians to the grove
and showed them the two torched cars.

The Palestinians whose cars were torched were identified as Rebhi Salama and
Mahmoud Araj and they told Palestinian reporters that when they sought to
prevent the Jewish residents from setting their cars on fire they were told to
leave and weapons were pointed at them.

                                      DNA

                           January 13, 2016 Wednesday

Patidar students bunk school to support leaders

BYLINE: dna correspondent

LENGTH: 306  words


More than 200 students from the community skip classes and stage protest outside
school in Surat

Surat: Students from Patidar community staged a protest in Surat on Tuesday, by
skipping school at Ambatalavdi in Katargam area of the city. Students boycotted
school demanding the release of Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS) leaders and
continued the demand for reservation in education and jobs.

More than 200 students of Ankur Vidyabhavan and Yogi Pravutti Vidyalaya in
Ambatalavdi area boycotted classes in school. At 6 am, students gathered at
school gates and staged protest. They chanted slogans and showed banners in
support of Hardik Patel and other PAAS leaders.

The student's protest resulted in chaos in the area and administrators of both
schools promptly informed police. Cops rushed to the spot and asked students to
end protest. Majority of students protesting at the gates skipped school, while
few students attended classes.

"Students have decided to stage protest against bias state administration, which
is making all efforts to crush the protest initiated by Patidars. The student's
protest was planned by them and PAAS has no role in it. Tuesday's incident is
result of anger within community due to delay in giving reservation," said
Dharmik Malaviya, convener of PAAS in Surat.

Parth Navadia, a class XII student said, "We will continue protests on
Wednesday."

Students allege school authorities of using force

Students alleged school administration of using force to prevent them staging
protest. They alleged that the school security personnel beat some of them to
force them into calling of protests and return to respective classrooms. One of
the trustees of Ankur Vidyalaya threatened students with arrests, if they didn't
enter into class-rooms, said a class XI student.

                                  Oxford Mail

                             May 28, 2015 Thursday

Anti-fossil fuel protesters plan protest at Didcot Power Station

BYLINE: Alex Wynick

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 249 words


A PROTEST at Didcot Power Station at the weekend will be monitored, police said.

Officers said the No Dash For Gas group is planning a demonstration, called
Reclaim the Power, between tomorrow and Tuesday.

Anti-fossil fuel protesters may establish a camp within a few miles of the power
station, police said.

Supt Jim O'Ryan said: "We will be working closely with its partners, including
the RWE Energy Trading Ltd and those wishing to protest, in order to minimise
the impact of the protest on the local communities and fulfil our legal
responsibility to facilitate peaceful protest.

"We respect everyone's right to protest in a way which is non-violent protest
against people or property. However, should activity go beyond peaceful, those
breaking the law will be dealt with proportionately.

"Measures are in place to notify local residents and those who might be affected
by the protests, and our aim is to ensure that there is minimal disruption
caused to them and the wider community of Didcot, and the surrounding areas,
while facilitating protest.

"However, it is highly likely that there will be some disruption to the area.

People should remain vigilant and take appropriate measures to secure access to
open land."

The No Dash for Gas website said the camp was part of a "global weekend of
action on corporate power" ahead of UN climate talks in December.

There will be activities, talks, activist speed dating, workshops on alternative
energy sources and sessions on how to effectively campaign.

                              Mirror Publications

                             March 7, 2015 Saturday
                                Bangalore Mirror

'FIRs were needed, but no one will be arrested'

BYLINE: Praveen Kumar

SECTION: CRIME

LENGTH: 336 words


Reacting to Bangalore Mirror's article titled After peaceful protests, the
police state strikes back, additional commissioner of police (law and order)
Alok Kumar defended his men for filing the FIRs against principals of the two
colleges, its students as well as others, for protesting over the death of a
woman in an accident at Hebbal recently. The IPS officer explained the need for
registering the FIRs against those who blocked the KIA road on February 27, in
an interview with the newspaper.

What do you have to say about the FIRs?

The FIRs have not been registered against all students who protested on that
day. It was against some students who kept inciting other students to come on
the road and stage a protest. Even a lecturer was seen encouraging students to
protest.

Why was there a need for FIRs?

Inconvenience was caused to so many people as a result of the protest. Traffic
was stranded for up to 7 km. People going to KIA as well as the movement of
ambulances were affected. Yes, the police definitely understand the need for
protests. This protest was extremely emotional, but no force was used against
anybody.

Was there any other way without protests?

The students on their part should have carried out a symbolic protest for about
10 to 15 minutes, but it went on for two hours. There are various other ways to
voice grievances against civic authorities. A protest is not the only option. So
many people were affected because of the protests. Somebody might have been late
to attend an interview, while another may have been rushing to attend to an
emergency, while somebody may have had to catch a flight. This protest has
definitely caused problems to so many people.

Were the FIRs a last resort?

Yes, the registration of FIRs was much needed, failing which it would be like
encouraging somebody to keep protesting and block all major roads, leading to
public disorder.

Will there be any arrests?

The police will not arrest anybody.

Related Story: After peaceful protests, the police state strikes back

                                   Azer News

                            October 14, 2013 Monday

Protests against Russia's actions in de-facto border held in Georgia

BYLINE:  Nazrin Gadimova

LENGTH: 281  words


Georgian students held peaceful protests with the slogan "Stop the annexation"
in seven cities across the country on October 13. Participants of the protests
accused Russia in the occupation of Georgian territories.

About 500 students who lined up in a "human chains" gathered in Tbilisi,
Rustavi, Telavi, Gori, Batumi, Kutaisi and Zugdidi during the protest actions.

One of the protesters said that the protest actions were planned in social
networks and similar protests will be held in the future, and it is desirable
that the wider population joined it it.

The main goal of the protests is to show the international community that the
majority of the country protest over the occupation by Russia.

The situation at the administrative border of Tskhinvali region (the so-called
South Ossetia) with the rest territory of Georgia has been in the spotlight of
the Georgian authorities and the international community for several months.

Russian border guard officers have begun establishing barbwire along the
de-facto border shortly after the conflict. The Georgian side claims that these
actions violate the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Georgia, as well as
the principles of international law and the ceasefire agreement between Georgia
and Russia dated August 12, 2008.

Georgia and Russia, its giant northern neighbor, have maintained no diplomatic
relations since a brief war in 2008. Tbilisi broke off relations with Moscow in
August 2008 when Moscow crushed a Georgian assault to reassert control over two
rebel regions -- South Ossetia and Abkhazia -- and later recognized the regions.
Georgia announced the two unrecognized republics as occupied territories in
September 2008.

LOAD-DATE: October 14, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2013 Azer News Newspaper
                              All Rights Reserved

                            October 14, 2013 Monday

Protests against Russia's actions in de-facto border held in Georgia

BYLINE:  Nazrin Gadimova

LENGTH: 281  words

in seven cities across the country on October 13. Participants of the protests
accused Russia in the occupation of Georgian territories.

Rustavi, Telavi, Gori, Batumi, Kutaisi and Zugdidi during the protest actions.

One of the protesters said that the protest actions were planned in social
networks and similar protests will be held in the future, and it is desirable
that the wider population joined it it.

The main goal of the protests is to show the international community that the

                              163 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                            Cihan News Agency (CNA)

                             June 5, 2013 Wednesday

Davutoglu reacts to consecutive US statements on Turkey protests

LENGTH: 590  words


ISTANBUL (CIHAN)- Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu has reacted to the
consecutive statements issued by the United States expressing concern over the
ongoing protests in Turkey during a phone conversation with US Secretary of
State John Kerry on Wednesday.



Describing the protests against the demolition of Gezi Park as "tests of
democracies," Davutoglu told his American counterpart that similar protests have
taken place in Europe and the US such as the "Occupy Wall Street" movement.

Davutoglu also said that while similar protests in other democratic countries
are seen as normal, the protests in Turkey are reflected differently. The
Turkish foreign minister underlined that the way that the protests are reflected
in the media depict Turkey as a "second class democracy."

Noting that Turkey respects people's right to protest, Davutoglu stressed that
there are marginal groups who want to hijack the environmental protests. He
added that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is able to distinguish between
peaceful protests and those by marginal groups.

Turkey's allies as well as international bodies have voiced concerns over the
protests, particularly the police violence reported during the clashes.

A new round of concern was expressed by US Vice President Joe Biden on Tuesday,
who urged Turkey's government to respect the rights of its political opponents.


Biden, speaking to the American-Turkish Council, said Turkey stood a chance to
reach its goal of becoming one of the world's 10 largest economies by 2023, but
that it should not stray from democracy.

"Turkey's future belongs to the people of Turkey and no one else. But the United
States does not pretend to be indifferent to the outcome," Biden said.

The protests that started as an objection to the demolition of Gezi Park in
Istanbul's Taksim Square evolved into anti-government demonstrations when
marginal groups and foreign agents reportedly hijacked the campaign. More than a
thousand protesters and hundreds of policemen have been injured in
demonstrations that have turned into the most violent rioting that Turkey has
seen for decades.

As opposed to the defiant tone used by Prime Minister Erdogan who accused
"thugs" and the country's main opposition, Republican People's Party (CHP), for
the violence, deputy Prime Minster Bülent Arinç and President Abdullah Gül sent
more conciliatory messages to the protestors. On Tuesday, Arinç apologized for
the undue and disproportionate police force against an initially peaceful group
of protestors in Gezi Park, while Gül said that they "got the message" of
protestors.

According to the US vice president, countries with open societies, political
systems and economies; democratic institutions; and a firm commitment to
universal human rights are the countries that will thrive and be the most
powerful nations of the 21st century.

"Today's Turkey has a chance to demonstrate that there's no need to choose
between economic advancement and democracy, the system that empowers the winners
of elections and yet protects those who are in the opposition," Biden said.

Separately, White House spokesman Jay Carney noted Arinç's apology and added:
"We hope that ... the Turkish government will handle this in a way that respects
the rights of free speech and assembly that are elemental to democracies. And we
welcome the deputy prime minister's comments apologizing for excessive force and
we continue to welcome calls for these events to be investigated," Carney stated
at a briefing.

(Cihan/Today's Zaman) CIHAN

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              164 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Daily News Egypt

                               May 3, 2013 Friday

EIPR rejects limitations on right to protest

BYLINE: Hend Kortam

LENGTH: 423 words


//

EIPR: Protests need protection, not legal limitations
(AFP File Photo of the 25 Jan 2011 protests)

The Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights (EIPR) has announced its rejection
of the Ministry of Justice's draft of the protest law.

In a Thursday statement, the human rights organisation said it rejected in form
and substance as well as the philosophy behind the law which places restrictions
on the right to assemble and protest.

Article 4 of the draft law allows the right to protest in a way that does not
breach security or public order, impede citizens' day to day activities, block
roads or transportation, or disrupt traffic, or property or the right to work,
or pose as a serious threat to any of the aforementioned.

EIPR described this as a "loose definition" that includes a set of unacceptable
restrictions that can be used to limit protests.

"Protests need protection, not legal limitations. What needs regulation and
legal limitations is the authority's intervention in peaceful gatherings," EIPR
said.

In addition, Article 5 of the draft law states that those wishing to organise a
protest must provide a written notification to the police, three days before the
protest. EIPR described this as a text isolated from reality and impossible to
apply citing that most protests in Egypt are spontaneous and not pre-planned.

"Even in countries that require a notification, the authority has no right to
ask those organising the protest to sign any papers or hold them legally
responsible for everyone who took part in the protest," the human rights group
added. It added that in most protests, there usually isn't one person who can
speak on behalf of the protest or bear responsibility for it and the actions and
events that may come with it.

The draft law limits police's ability to break up protests then gives an
exception, in cases allowed by the Penal Code and Police Corps Act. "The current
Police Corps Act allows the police to fire live bullets to disperse a protest,"
EIPR said.

EIPR took part in the discussion of the draft law by two committees in a joint
session between them in the Shura Council. It announced its rejection of the law
and decided not to join next discussions.

"The priorities of legislative amendments have to focus on the Police Corps
law... and the Egyptian legislative body has to fully review its legislative
priorities," EIPR added.

Related posts:

Several protests prevent constituent assembly from meeting

US concerned NGO draft law will weaken civil society

Shura Council committee discusses protest law

                                Vanguard (Lagos)

                           January 25, 2012 Wednesday

Why I Shunned Fuel Subsidy Protest - Terry G

BYLINE: Opeoluwani Akintayo

LENGTH: 172 words


At a time when fellow artistes were all out to protest against the removal of
Fuel Subsidy by the Jonathan adminstration, House of Ginger master, Terry G
never stepped a foot at the protests.

Terry G gave reasons why he didn't show up at the protest in an interview he
recently granted an online magazine, saying he didn't see any reason to be at
the protests.

According to Terry, the protest as a waste of time because instead of artistes
protesting against the removal of Subsidy, the protest became a means to perform
their songs.

...I don't get it, I saw artistes performing their songs and forgetting what the
protests really meant. What's the point in that? I'm not looking for that kind
of attention, he commented.

Instead of being at the protests, Terry G took out time to share already packed
food prepared by his mother, to hungry street children and area boys, claiming
that they needed his help more than his presence at the protests.

My people have found it hard to eat so I just brought some food for the hungry
kids, he said.

                            December 11, 2005 Sunday

Bosnian Serbs would not eagerly protest over Hague arrests, poll indicates

LENGTH: 217 words


Text of report by Belgrade-based B-92 TV on 11 December

[Presenter] Citizens of Banja Luka are not quite sure that they would join
street protests if [Bosnian Serb wartime leaders, now Hague indictees] Radovan
Karadzic and Ratko Mladic were arrested.

Some of them, nevertheless, support today's protests in Croatia [following the
extradition of indictee Ante Gotovina to The Hague].

[Reporter] Would you join protests if Karadzic and Mladic were arrested?

[Citizen 1] I would join protests only if people protested about low wages, bad
living standards, lack of heating, etc.

[Citizen 2] I support them [referring to protests in Croatia].

[Reporter] Would you join protests if Karadzic and Mladic were arrested?

[Citizen 2] I would.

[Citizen 3] Of course, any time, why not? If they can, why can we not [probably
referring to protests in Croatia]?

[Citizen 4] It is all the same to me.

[Reporter] Would you join protests if Karadzic and Mladic were arrested?

[Citizen 4] I would not.

[Reporter] Why?

[Citizen 4] I mind my own business, let them mind theirs.

[Citizen 5] Why would I support them [the protests in Croatia]? In my opinion,
the whole Gotovina thing serves to pull the wool over Serbs' eyes. Gotovina was
arrested so that Serbs would calm down. Come on.

Source: B92 TV, Belgrade, in Serbian 1730 gmt 11 Dec 05

                                 EKantipur.com

                              May 30, 2016 Monday

Sanghiya gathabandhan contemplates further protests

LENGTH: 357 words

DATELINE: Kathmandu


Kathmandu, May 30 -- Madhesi and Janajati parties have begun fresh discussion on
ways to take the anti-government and constitution protest ahead once the ongoing
mass campaign comes to an end on Monday. The first round of extended programmes
of protest is expected to conclude amid a formal programme in Pokhara--the
second largest city

Leaders affiliated to Sanghiya Gathabandhan, a joint alliance of ethnic and
Madhesi groups, said that the protest would continue.

But the parties are still undecided over the form, length and target of the
upcoming protest.

"The protest would continue but its length and nature would be decided only
after a meeting of the top leaders," said Rajendra Mahato, chairman of the
Sadbhawana Party. Gathabandhan's second rung leaders had held a meeting on
Friday to review the protest and discuss further moves.

While Gathabandhan allies are determined to continue the protest, some disputes
remain over its form and length. The Sanghiya Samajwadi Forum Nepal and most of
the ethnic parties in the alliance have insisted on more protest programmes
targeting large cities including Kathmandu. They have also argued on behalf of
confining the ongoing protest to an awareness campaign.

But Madhesi parties, including the Tarai Madhes Loktantrik Party and the
Sadbhawana Party, have stood in favour of resuming protest at the grassroots
level in the Tarai citing lack of expected support in the hills.

Meanwhile, talks to end the Tarai crisis stare at further delays, with the
government and the agitating parties blaming each other of being insincere over
talks.

The Gathabandan have sought another formal invitation from the government
addressing the Madhesi-Janajati alliance instead of the Samyukta Loktantrika
Madhesi Morcha.

"We are ready to sit for negotiation anytime if the government is serious about
finding a solution," said Ashok Rai, senior leader of the Sanghiya Samajwadi
Forum-Nepal.

                              Daily Pakistan Today

                              July 28, 2014 Monday

Sindh protests against power outages

LENGTH: 374  words

DATELINE: KARACHI


Staging a protest against power outages in Sindh, Pakistan People's Party on
Sunday gave a one month ultimatum to the federal government to end the power
crises in Pakistan.

The PPP protest was staged outside K-Electric head office, as several people
from different areas of Sindh also staged protests and sit-ins against frequent
power outages.

Addressing the protest, Senator Raza Rabbani said that "circular debt was paid
so that the power crises could end soon" but the situation is still the same. He
said that the privatisation of state institutions will not be allowed in any
situation.

The senator also announced his support for laborers after calling Prime Minister
Nawaz "a representative of capitalists".

MPs Nauman Islam Shaikh and Nafeesa Shah led a protest at Regional Office of
Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA). PPP workers also staged protests
at Dadu Press Club against power outages.

It should be noted that protests against power outages are underway in many
parts of Sindh as Hyderabad, Thatta, Badin, Mirpurkhas, Sukkur, Larkana and
Jacobabad are facing power cuts of upto 18 hours.

A protest was held at Hyderabad in which citizens and PPP workers were present.

The angry citizens blocked the National Highway to protest against prolonged
power load shedding at Mirpur Mathelo.

The protesters demanded that Sindh be given its due share of electricity.

Earlier, Sindh Information Minister Sharjeel Inam Memon said the massive power
breakdown on Friday hampered industrial production in the port city and that
citizens also suffered in the process.

Sindh Governor Dr Ishratul Ibad Khan directed K-electric, WAPDA and Water Board
to ensure regular electricity and water supply to the people of Sindh.

Friday's power breakdown across Karachi as well as in several parts of
Hyderabad, Jamshoro and other districts of the southern province had occurred
reportedly due to the tripping of production units in the National Grid Line.

The breakdown had come at a time when exporters were busy in meeting shipment
deadlines ahead of Eidul Fitr holidays.

Earlier, the Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM)'s coordination committee had also
condemned the power outages, saying it is imperative that both cities had
uninterrupted power supply.

                                  The Patriot

                             June 24, 2014 Tuesday

PAT protest adversely affected business activities

SECTION: Vol. 13 No. 174

LENGTH: 137  words


The traders community in twin cities of Islamabad and Rawalpindi on Monday said
that Pakistan Awami Tehreek protest on the arrival of its patron-in-chief
adversely affected their business activities.

The traders community said that these kinds of issues can aggravate problems,
demanding that there should be some specific places for protest demonstrations.

They said that people are busy in shopping for Ramazan ul Mubarak, but due to
protest of PAT, their business activities have been affected badly.

They claimed that due to these unnecessary protest demonstrations the traders
are suffering losses worth millions of rupees.

Gul Nawaz, a shopkeeper said that PAT protest has no sense, adding that  earlier
also these people was created mess in capital city and now again they are trying
to create problems for the common man.

                                Daily News Egypt

                              May 19, 2014 Monday

Democracy Index releases report on 2013 protests

BYLINE: Ali Omar

LENGTH: 587 words


Egyptian Islamist groups led by the ruling Muslim Brotherhood took part in a
demonstration to mark  anniversary since President Mohamed Morsi (portrait) was
elected, on June 21, 2013 in Cairo.
(AFP File Photo)

Democracy Index released Monday its comprehensive report on 2013's protests,
breaking down the 14,270 individual protests based on demands of the protesters.
The report is split into two, first detailing protests for social and economic
rights and lastly detailing civil and political demands.

According to the report, 70% of the protests that took place pre-30 June were
organised to demand social and economic rights, whereas post-ouster, only 20-30%
of protests were concerned with said rights.

A total of 3,212 protests were organised to demand labour rights, "especially
the right to work or the rights relating to appropriate pay" for workers.

A total of 1,052 protests were organised to claim wages, back pay, or promised
demands. Of the protests, the report says: "Workers, who lie between the hammer
of the low scarcity of wages and salaries and the anvil of price rises, have
[been given] no practical solution to the issue of minimum and maximum incomes."

2014 has already seen crippling strikes at factories such as the Mahalla
Spinning and Weaving company, although workers from seven companies later joined
the strikes.

Workers also gathered to protest corruption and nepotism, which, according to
the report, "were the main engine of uprising of the Egyptian people in January
[2011] and June [2013]".

2013 witnessed more than 2,000 protests pertaining to the education environment
in Egypt, although only 591 dealt with administrative issues. The report noted
that present conditions on college campuses are "worse than before 2011," and
that the educational environment is "something that requires the immediate
intervention of the state to protect the Egyptian education system from sliding
into a quagmire".

The health sector only witnessed two protests in 2013, but the Index noted that
"patients do not protest, they only suffer. This is what the Egyptian state must
be aware of ... only two demonstrations of their systems of patients do not
express the size of the face of violations of [patients'] rights in hospitals".

A total of 67% of 2013's protests, or 8,999, were political. According to the
report, "the fall of the regime and the beginning of the transitional phase
outlining a new regime amid political infighting" further encouraged protests.

According to the report, the first half of 2013 witnessed 1,312 anti-Muslim
Brotherhood protests, whereas post 3-July witnessed 2,679 protests against
interim authorities, who many accused of staging a coup.

A total of 1,149 protests were organised to express solidarity with detainees,
whose numbers swelled after Morsi's ouster and during the subsequent crackdown
on Muslim Brotherhood supporters.

Another 153 protests were organised to mobilise citizens against 2013's Protest
Law, which essentially outlaws public gatherings and marches unless permission
is granted by the Ministry of Interior.

The report, which intermittently questions future authorities' abilities to
control constant and ongoing protests, ends with "five basic tools" used to
suppress freedom in Egypt: restrictive legislation (the Protest Law);
suppressive security; political trials for demonstrators; encouragement of
citizens loyal to the regime to protest in favour of present authorities
themselves; and disinformation.

Provided by SyndiGate Media Inc. (Syndigate.info).

                               Egypt Independent

                              June 3, 2013 Monday

Report: Egypt averaged two protests an hour in May

BYLINE: Egypt Independent

LENGTH: 293  words


With 5,544, Egypt witnessed the most protests in the world during the period
from 1 January to 31 May, according to a report released Sunday by an
Egypt-based research center.



According to the democracy index published by the International Development
Center (IDC), the month of May saw 1,300 protests, an average of two protests an
hour, 42 a day, and 325 a week.

The report said that 39 different Egyptian social groups staged in May 390
demonstrations, related to work conditions and workers' rights.

Economic and social demands, spurred by violations of workers' rights and
deteriorating services, triggered 63.7 percent of the protests, according to the
report.

Common citizens, the report outlines, were the second most disruptive segment of
society, accounting for 28.4 percent of all demonstrations in May. With 210
protests, activists and politicians staged 16.2 percent of all protests.

Pilots were the latest group to join the wave of protests last month.

Cairo, accounting for 18 percent of all protests, was the most rebellious
governorate, followed by Alexandria, Sharqiya, and Gharbiya. The rates in other
provinces in the Delta, Upper Egypt, and the border regions were similar.

The wave of protests, as the report explains, reflect in the Egyptian street
indignation at the ruling regime and a return to the habit of pressuring state
institutions and major corporations in order to retrieve lost rights.

Protests in May were more violent than in the preceding months, according to the
report. It stated that demonstrators managed to shut down institutions in 56
separate incidents, stormed facilities in 23, and besieged other buildings in
14. The number of protests featuring marches dropped to 57 in May, down from 120
in April, the report indicated.

                      The Argus (Newsquest Regional Press)

                          September 5, 2012 Wednesday

Sussex Police launch specialist protest team

BYLINE: Peter Truman

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS (GENERAL NEWS)

LENGTH: 360 words


Police have unveiled a new tactic as they try to deal with an increase in
protests in Sussex.

With the number of protests in the county increasing in recent years,
particularly in Brighton and Hove, Sussex Police has announced that two
dedicated Protest Liaison Officers will shortly be introducing themselves to
protest groups.

Sergeant Mark Redbourn and PC Stephanie Franks will be making the visits over
the coming weeks.

According to Sussex Police, this is to 'develop its approach to enable greater
communication, understanding and facilitation of peaceful protests'.

Chief Inspector Paul Betts said: "Everyone has the democratic right to protest
and as we know the city of Brighton and Hove has always attracted diverse
communities and welcomed freedom of speech.

"It is therefore one of our core functions as a police service to facilitate
these protests whilst balancing this with the needs of the rest of the
community.

"While we have used officers in a protest liaison capacity in the city for a
number of years, we are now changing how these officers operate and, for the
first time, investing in a specialist team to build and maintain relationships
on a permanent basis.

"Sergeant Redbourn and PC Franks are working within our communities on a daily
basis. Over the coming weeks, they will be contacting protest groups directly,
offering information about their role and explaining ways of contacting them
before, during and after a protest.

"During protests they will be easily recognisable and visible by their light
blue police liaison officer tabards.

"Their primary role will be to increase engagement with protest groups by
supporting an open and honest two-way dialogue with them, before during and
after events.

"By doing this we hope to better facilitate peaceful protest, and provide a safe
environment for the protesters and others in the city."

He added: "We accept that some groups will not want to engage with us initially
and some may choose not to at all, which we will respect. But we owe it to the
many communities of Brighton and Hove, including those who engage in protest, to
try."

Will the new police scheme work? Tell us what you think.

                               Right Vision News

                            March 28, 2012 Wednesday

Pakistan: PML-N plans nationwide protest against power cuts

LENGTH: 143 words

DATELINE: LAHORE


LAHORE, March 28 -- The Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) has announced a
plan to hold nationwide protests against ongoing power cuts and high electricity
bills.

According to the schedule, PML-N will stage protests in Lahore, Karachi,
Peshawar and Quetta on March 31. It will then hold protests in Abbottabad,
Sialkot, Hyderabad and Sahiwal on April 2.

On March 3, protests will be held in Multan, Kasur, Sheikhupura and Dera Ismail
Khan while Rawalpindi, Bahawalpur, Kurk and Sargodha will witness protests on
April 4.

The schedule further said that there would be protests in Dera Ghazi Khan,
Gujrat and Okara on April 5.

The protests will be led by the parliamentarians and senior leadership.

Traders, students, laborers and local organizations will be contacted to
organize the protest plan Published by HT Syndication with permission from Right

                             March 29, 2010 Monday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

BYLINE:  Youni Chandio & jani Khaskheli

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1481

LENGTH: 296  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club on
Sunday. According to details, the members of the Pakistan Trade Union under the
leadership of Ghulam Rasool Memon, Pir Muhammad and others staged a protest
demonstration against the prolonged power outages and surge in electricity
tariff.

The members of the Solangi Social Welfare Association (SSWA) under the
leadership of Muhammad Waryam Solangi, Khadim Hussain Solangi and others staged
a protest demonstration against the open sale of narcotics in Hyderabad .

The workers of the Bangle Glass Industries under the banner of the Mehran
Mazdoor Union and under the leadership of Ashiq Ali, Muhammad Rehan and others
staged a protest demonstration in favor of their demands. The candidates, who
had passed IBA Test under the leadership of Azam Siddiqui, Nauman Shah and
others staged a protest demonstration for the reinstatement of their services
and issuance of their withheld salaries.

The members of the All Hindu Shagird Association under the leadership of Ram
Sigh, Molchand and others staged a protest demonstration for the arrest of the
accused rapists of Kasturi Kolhi. A youth namely Muhammad Rehan Khan, resident
of Latifabad No-8 staged a protest demonstration for the provision of a job. The
PPP workers of Tando Jam chapter under the leadership of Altaf Hussain Unar and
others continued their protest demonstration against the local party leadership.

The members of the Left Unity Hyderabad chapter staged a protest demonstration
against rampant inflation. The Palestinian students of the University of Sindh
Jamshoro under the leadership of Muhammad Oaz, Saleman Baqir, Fahad and others
staged a protest demonstration against the Israeli aggressions and attack on the
Masjid-e-Aqsa.

                            Business World (Digest)

                          February 25, 2009 Wednesday

Off duty gardai to protest today on levy;
Gardai Protest

LENGTH: 123 words



HIGHLIGHT: Off duty gardai are to hold a protest in Dublin today in protest at
the public sector pension levy which is currently going through the Dail.


Off duty gardai are to hold a protest in Dublin today in protest at the public
sector pension levy which is currently going through the Dail.

The demonstration is being organised by the Garda Representative Associaiton,
which has asked members to gather at Parnell Square at lunchtime for a march to
Government Buildings.

The association says the introduction of another levy on earnings is causing
"extreme concern" to its members.

In a statement announcing today's march, it said: "This protest is significant
in that a new generation of gardai will be protesting against government plans.
"Many of these gardai were in school during the pay protest of 1998. It is among
this new generation that the proposed levy will have the most effect."

                               Egypt Independent

                            October 18, 2015 Sunday

Protests escalated in last three months: report

BYLINE: Al-Masry Al-Youm

LENGTH: 192  words


Protests in Egypt have escalated in the past three months, according to a report
issued Saturday by the Arab Foundation for Civil Society and Human Rights
Support.According to the report, 67 protests, sit-ins and strikes occurred
between July and September.Eight protests occurred at the Education Ministry,
six at the Journalists' Syndicate and five at the Cabinet headquarters. Six
protests were organized against the new Civil Service Law.Fourteen protests
occurred in July, including four by doctors, pharmacists, and teachers, three by
high school and university students, two by residents against water cuts, one by
public employees against the Civil Service Law, one by policemen, one by
laborers and two by the Muslim Brotherhood, said the report.Twenty-eight
protests occured in August, including eight protests by workers at the
Endowments Ministry department in Giza, workers at the Rock Ceramic factory,
workers at the General Authority for Industrial Development, workers at the
Integrated Oil Company and high school students and students of the Faculty of
Specific Education at Ain Shams University.

                                 Derry Journal

                           October 17, 2015 Saturday

PSNI recruitment event protest passes peacefully

BYLINE: Andrew Quinn

LENGTH: 491  words


A protest held outside a PSNI recruitment event in Derry has passed off
peacefully.

At around 3:30p.m. on Saturday afternoon approximately 60 protesters carrying
banners, Irish tricolours and placards made their way from Pilot's Row in the
Bogside, across the Peace Bridge and through St. Columb's Park where they were
stopped by police from entering the venue where the recruitment event took
place.

Independent Derry City and Strabane District Council councillor Gary Donnelly
was amongst the protesters.

Speaking to Journal' at the protest Colr. Donnelly said

"This is a protest led by the people of Derry against British policing.

"Over the last number of days there have been a number of homes ransacked by the
PSNI and there has been a dramatic increase in the number of stop and searches.
People have come here today to show their anger and opposition to British
policing," said Colr. Donnelly.

The PSNI maintained a heavy police presence throughout the protest.

The protesters eventually made their way from Browning Drive, through St.
Columb's Park to the entrance of St. Columb's Park House.

PSNI officers in high visibility jackets maintained a barrier across the
entrance during the protest.

Several PSNI land rovers observed the protest from less than 50 yards away.

There was no violence and no one was arrested. The protest lasted over an hour
and passed off without incident.

Elected members of the DUP, including Gregory Campbell and MLA for Foyle, Gary
Middleton, attended the protest.

Mr. Middleton described the protest as "disgraceful" and said he did not think
it was peaceful.

"I am disgusted at this protest because again, individuals have taken it upon
themselves to disrupt what is an employment opportunity for many.

"I think it's disgraceful that people who have come to this recruitment event
today have been denied that opportunity. I am all for peaceful protest and I
support the right of people to protest peacefully but what we have here today is
completely unacceptable."

The PSNI recruitment event was due to take place in Waterfoot Hotel on Saturday
October 10 but the police postponed the session as they feared a planned
Republican Network for Unity (R.N.U.) protest had the potential to interfere
with a wedding due to take place at the hotel at the same time.

Police then carried out a search after they received reports that a suspect
device had been planted near the hotel on October 9.

After a thorough search of the area a viable device was discovered in the
grounds of the hotel.

The event was then due to take place in the hotel on Saturday October 17 but
hotel owner Garvan O'Doherty decided against it because he feared for the safety
of customers and staff.

The PSNI then announced on Wednesday that an alternative venue had been found on
the event went ahead as planned on Saturday afternoon.

The PSNI held two information sessions at St. Columb's Park House and Justice
Minister, David Ford MLA, was in attendance.
