                                   The Hindu

                           February 16, 2016 Tuesday

TNGEA steps up protest as strike enters sixth day

LENGTH: 273  words

DATELINE: MADURAI


MADURAI, Feb. 16 -- More than 1,000 government employees from various unions
affiliated to Tamil Nadu Government Employees Association (TNGEA), staged a
protest near the premises of the Collector's office on Monday in a show of
strength as their State-wide indefinite strike entered the sixth day.


 M. Gnanathambi, State Treasurer of TNGEA, said that from Monday, Tamil Nadu
Primary Teachers' Association had joined the protest and more associations were
expected to join the protest in the coming days.
 He denied rumours about some of the associations withdrawing from the protest.
"A particular association of Anganwadi workers with affiliation to the ruling
party was asked by TNGEA to withdraw from the protest. All other associations
are still involved in the strike. Other Anganwadi association members are
planning to participate in protests along with their families from tomorrow," he
said.
 TNGEA office bearers said that, from Tuesday, non-teaching staff associations
of government aided colleges were also joining the protest. They said the
ministerial staff associations in Police Department may also join the protest in
coming days.
 Hopeful
 The protesters said that they are hopeful of a favourable announcement from the
Tamil Nadu government during the release of interim budget on Tuesday.
 TNGEA has begun the indefinite strike demanding the fulfilment of their
20-point charter of demands, which include the removal of new pension scheme,
regularising the contract employees in various departments and putting an end to
outsourcing of government jobs and recruitment of employees on contractual and
consolidated pay basis.

                           The New Age (South Africa)

                            October 14, 2014 Tuesday

'The protest capital of the world'

BYLINE: RUSSEL MOLEFE

LENGTH: 401 words


DAMAGE done to infrastructure as a result of violent service delivery protests,
estimated to be more than R10bn  a year, impacts negatively on the economy,
analysts have warned.

Researchers, economists and the police, among others, point out that the 1907
violent protests recorded in the past financial year were a major cause of
concern because of the destruction to infrastructure and the disruption to
services and policing.

Police Minister Nkosinathi Nhleko revealed in Parliament recently, that a total
of 13575 protests occurred in the past year alone.

Violent protests went up from 1887 in the 2012/13 financial year to 1907 in the
past year.

Economist Chris Hart said that the impact of the violent protests was alarming.

"The consequences are in the short, medium and long term. In the short term, the
damage is already done and how do we fix that," Hart asked.

Violent protests that erupted in Gauteng in February, resulted in more than R65m
in infrastructure damage.

Infrastructure and property worth R40m was damaged in Mpumalanga in 2010.

Hart said smaller municipalities, in terms of their budget, would feel the most
negative economic impact.

This would be exacerbated by the lack of investment in those areas, he said.

A research conducted by the University of Johannesburg painted a disturbing
picture of how the increasing number of protests have earned the country the
title, "the protest capital of the world".

Prof Peter Alexander, who led the research into community protests, also agreed
that further violent protests would continue to undermine economic expansion. He
said in some instances, the protests have become part of a broader rebellion of
the poor.

"I have not found any other country where there is a similar level of ongoing
urban unrest. South Africa can reasonably be described as the 'protest capital
of the world'," he said.

National police spokesperson Lt-Gen Solomon Makgale said violent protests have
stretched the resources of the police as they have to be diverted from
day-to-day crime prevention policing.

"It is the violence and acts of criminality by elements piggybacking on the
legitimate demands of the people that often create unnecessary confrontations
between the police and protesters," Makgale said. The ANC said that the violent
protests across the country undermined the gains of the democracy and undermined
its successes.

russelm@thenewage.co.za

LOAD-DATE: October 16, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2014 TNA Media (Pty.) Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              237 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Daily News Egypt

                          November 27, 2013 Wednesday

Thousands demonstrate against Protest Law

BYLINE: Mostafa Salem

LENGTH: 482 words


//

Egyptian Activists and members of the 6th of April movement shout slogans
against the Egyptian Military on November 27, 2013, in Cairo.
(AFP PHOTO/GIANLUIGI GUERCIA)

Thousands protested in downtown Cairo Wednesday in defiance of the recently
issued Protest Law and in response to the dispersal of the No Military Trials
demonstration Tuesday.

The protest started in Talaat Harb Square at 5pm and marched through downtown.
At the time of print, the march was heading towards the Shura Council building
where Tuesday's clashes occurred.

A number of revolutionary forces were present, including 6 April, the
Revolutionary Socialists, Revolutionary Front and a number of independent
groups.

"We will never agree on the Protest Law and will continue protesting until it's
gone," said Basma El Hosseiny, a founding member of the Revolutionary Front. "We
the people don't accept it."

Revolutionary Front members said they had marched downtown to intentionally
violate the Protest Law, which says that the locations of protests must be
declared in advance.

The Revolutionary Front called for the protest in response to the forcible
arrests and detention of several activists after the forcible dispersal of
yesterday's protest in front of the Shura Council.

The front's Wednesday protest demanded the release of these detainees, the
abolishment of the Protest Law, and a ban on military trials in the
constitution.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Interior announced that a request was made for the
Wednesday march by a party the ministry refused to identify. The law stipulates
that a three day notice to the Ministry of Interior is required prior to any
protest, and the notice will be reduced two 24 hours if the protest concerns
elections. Renowned human rights advocate Hossam Bahgat issued a statement
denying that any party had requested a permit.

The released protesters from Tuesday's demonstration also announced that they
had filed three complaints against the ministry of Interior

Amr Adel, one of the detainees, said that, "the three complaints are against
[the detainees'] kidnapping and being dumped on the desert road, violence and
beatings during the arrest and the third is a complaint against the sexual
harassment experienced by the detained women."

Tuesday's violent dispersal of a peaceful protest generated local and
international criticism of the current government. The protest marked the first
to take place without the required permit demanded by the law.

The Protest Law was ratified by interim President Adly Mansour earlier this week
after its draft that was suggested by the Ministry of Justice had stirred
controversy in the political sphere.

Related posts:

NoMilTrials protest dispersed; prominent activists detained

Opposition to draft Protest Law mounts

Government wavers on Protest Law

                              Anadolu Agency (AA)

                            November 25, 2013 Monday

Activists to lodge 1st demo request under Egypt's new protest law

LENGTH: 417 words


Activists say that the planned protest - to be held, if approved, in Cairo's
Tahrir Square - would target the new law itself CAIRO   Egyptian activists are
planning to submit the first formal petition to stage a demonstration in Cairo
under the nation's new protest law, which came into effect on Monday. Activists
say that the planned protest - to be held, if approved, in Cairo's Tahrir Square
- would target the new law itself. "We will submit a notification to stage a
protest against the protest law itself," Mohamed Adel, a founder of the April 6
protest movement, said in a statement.

The move comes one day after interim President Adly Mansour approved the
controversial law, which the government says is needed to restore public order
amid Egypt's deteriorating security situation. The law makes it necessary for
protest organizers to obtain Interior Ministry approval the three days prior to
any planned protest. Violators will be fined and in some cases imprisoned. The
new law has sent shockwaves across Egypt's political scene, with some of parties
warning that it would curb civil liberties and restore the Egyptian government's
traditional "police mentality." In a statement, Adel declared his intention to
go to a police station in downtown Cairo on Monday to submit a petition to stage
a protest on December 1. Applicants must pay a fee of 32 Egyptian pounds
(roughly $4) to submit a petition at a police station. Adel said he would pay
the fee, adding that the planned protest would carry the sarcastic slogan "Eat
Popcorn" - a phrase, usually said in ridicule, that has become popular among
local youths after appearing in a television commercial. "We're serious about
staging the protest," Adel told Anadolu Agency. "But we're adopting this
satirical slogan to poke fun at the notion of submitting a petition to stage
protests." He added: "This law trims the right to protest." He said
demonstrators would demand the prosecution of the interior minister and the
dismissal of the interim prime minister and Defense Minister Abdel-Fattah
al-Sisi due to what he described as their failure to restore public security
following the army's July 3 ouster of elected president Mohamed Morsi. Adel
added that demonstrators would set out towards Tahrir Square from several
starting points, including eastern Cairo's iconic Rabaa al-Adawiya Square. By
Hussein Qabani englishnews@aa.com.tr

                          Sunday Times (South Africa)

                            November 17, 2013 Sunday
                              Natal Metro Edition

Walk marks protest centenary

BYLINE: SIPHILISELWE MAKHANYA

SECTION: HUMAN INTEREST

LENGTH: 248  words


Walk marks protest centenary

MORE than 3 000 people are expected to take part in a re-enactment at the end of
the month of anti-government protests 100 years ago.

The Volksrust commemorative walk on November 30 will mark the anniversaries of
several significant protests. They include the 1913 pass law defiance campaign
led by Charlotte Maxeke in the Free State and a protest the same year led by
Kasturba Gandhi, wife of Mahatma Gandhi, against a court ruling that nullified
Hindu and Muslim marriages.

The walk will also commemorate resistance to restrictive travel laws and to a £3
tax imposed on Indians who refused to sign up for fresh periods of indentured
service.

Ela Gandhi, granddaughter of Mahatma Gandhi, said the walk would celebrate the
role of women in the peaceful protests of that era.

One of them was Valliama Mudliar, who led one of the key protests of that year,
mobilising coal miners to join a protest over taxes and the marriage issue.

"Valliama was 16 at the time - she was one of the youngest people to participate
and she was instrumental in organising the workers," said Gandhi.

"At a young age, she displayed so much courage and resilience.

The walk is being organised by, among others, the Gandhi Development Trust and
the Department of Correctional Services.

Those interested in participating in the walk may e-mail sm@gdt.org.za with
their contact details and the number of people they will be attending with by
November 26.

RESISTANCE: Ela Gandhi

Pakistan: JI to hold protest rally against blasphemous movie

LENGTH: 264 words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Sept. 15 -- To condemn the blasphemous movie, made in the United
States, Jamaat e Islami Karachi has announced to hold a protest rally and
demonstration on Friday (today).

In this regard a protest rally would be taken out at 2:00 pm from Jamia Masjid
Alfalah North Nazimabad to Matric board office, where JI Pakistan Amir Munawar
Hassan would address the protest demonstration.

Meanwhile, in a statement, JI Karachi Amir Muhammad Hussain Mehnati appealed
masses to join the protest demonstration so as to record their protest.

Condemning the hatred and sentiments provoking measure, Mehnati has said that
those powers blame Muslims for extremism and terrorism, were sowing extremism
through such type of measures. He said that the US and a part of West were
continuously revealing the anti Islamic policies.

He said that any religion of the world doesn't allow to insult of any
personality particularly a prophet. He further said that those attempt to insult
the prophet (PBUH) were provoking inter-religion harmony.

He further said that sentiments of Muslims had been provoking under a designed
conspiracy to destabilize inter faith peace and harmony. He added that a Muslim
can never tolerate any attempt to abuse the personality or image of the holy
prophet (PBUH). He further said that through such type of nefarious attempts,

                         The Middle East Reporter (MER)

                            October 8, 2011 Saturday

JORDAN-PROTESTS

LENGTH: 414  words


JORDAN-PROTESTS

Anti-government Protests in Jordan Send 'Firm' Messages to the Head of Authority


Jordan witnessed "heated" anti-government protests on Friday during which
demonstrators chanted slogans 'firmly' calling on the head of the Jordanian
authority King Abdullah II to speed up reforms, the Beirut daily AN NAHAR
reported Saturday.

The protests kicked off in the capital Amman and other provinces. Some
demonstrators were attacked by what the daily called "thugs" urging the security
forces to intervene using teargas to control the situation. However, it failed
to prevent the "thugs" from hurling stones at protestors, the daily said.  In
Irbid, 80 kilometers north of the capital, police used teargas to end clashes
between pro-reform demonstrators and government loyalists, witnesses said.
Protesters were demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Marouf Bakhit's
government, accusing it of failing to curb corruption and introduce political
reforms. More than 2,000 people demonstrated outside the Grand Husseini Mosque
in central Amman under the slogan "Political Reform Our Path for Eradication of
Corruption." They chanted, "No to protecting the corruption of the government,"
on the march from Al-Hussein mosque in central Amman to the town hall, one
kilometer (less than a mile) away. The demonstrators carried banners reading:
"Political reform is the path to wiping out corruption... Corruption is the
cause of poverty and unemployment."

The demonstration was led by former Prime Minister Ahmed Obeidat, who chairs the
opposition National Front for Reform (NFR), and prominent members of the Muslim
Brotherhood movement and its political arm, the Islamic Action Front (IAF).
Obeidat told AFP the protesters demanded "an end to corruption in all its forms:
political, administrative, legislative and financial." It was the first public
action by the NFR, which is a partnership formed in May by the Muslim
Brotherhood, leftist parties, trade union leaders and independent figures.
Constitutional amendments recently adopted by parliament and approved by King
Abdullah II 'did not live up to the aspirations of the people,' Obeidat said,
addressing the protesters. "We want reforms that ensure fairness of the election
process and prevent all forms of interventions," he added, referring to charges
that the security authorities in the country sought to obstruct reform.  Similar
demonstrations were reported in the cities of Karka, Tafileh, Maan, Jerash and
Salt.

                           February 24, 2011 Thursday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

SECTION: Vol. IV No. 114

LENGTH: 375  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged by people in favor of their demands
outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Wednesday.  According to details, the
members of the Pakistan WAPDA Hydroelectric Central Labour Union under the
leadership of Abdul Latif Nizamani and others staged a protest demonstration
against the proposed privatization of WAPDA and its units. The women residents
of Husri staged a protest demonstration for the recovery of an abducted girl.

The people of the Khoso Community, residents of Tharparkar under the leadership
of Zulekhan Khoso and others staged a protest demonstration for the recovery of
their community men Jalal Khoso. A woman along with her children, residents of
Noonari Bast staged a protest demonstration against the torture of her husband
and in-laws. A social worker Comrade Anwar Mallah, resident of district Dadu
staged protest demonstration against the open sale of drugs in his area. The
residents of village Molidino Shoro Qasimabad under the leadership of Manthar
Shoro and others staged a protest demonstration against the Arif Builders. The
members of the Peoples Labour Bureau Sindh University Jamshoro Chapter under the
leadership of Ghulam Hussain Joyo others staged a protest demonstration for the
acceptance of their demands.

The members of the Save Forest Action Committee Khipro under the leadership of
Hussain Mari, Daim Ali others staged a protest demonstration in favor of their
demands. The members of the Pukar Welfare Association Tando Adam under the
leadership of Sultan Khaskheli and others staged a protest demonstration against
the administration of Power loom factories Tando Adam for the rights of
labourers. A flood affected woman namely Bilqees along with her 3 disabled
daughters including Rasheeda, Aneela and Sameena staged a protest demonstration
against the non issuance of Watan Card and other facilities.

The members of the Flood Affectees Rehabilitation Movement Sindh under the
leadership of Ali Gohar Chandio and others staged a protest demonstration for
the rehabilitation of IDPs of Sindh. The members of the Hyderabad Action
Committee under the leadership of Ashraf Noonari, Akhtar Sindhi and others
continued their protest demonstration against the Habib Group.

                            October 30, 2009 Friday

Students protest against council's decision

LENGTH: 209  words

DATELINE: Srinagar


Srinagar, Oct. 30 -- The students of HNB Garhwal Central University have termed
the decision of the Education Council as one sided and in protest against it
enforced a lockout of the university's Birla campus.

Climbing atop the roof of the faculty building student union leaders raised
slogans against the decision of the Education Council and declared their
decision to undertake relay protest demonstration against the decision.

The student union leaders warned that unless the demands of the students union
were accepted the protest demonstration by the students would be intensified in
to an agitation movement.

Students of the Garhwal Central University continued their protest at the Birla
campus of the university on the second day against the decision of the EC
committee. As part of their protest the student union members also submitted
their memorandum to the SDM VK Mishra which was addressed to the Human Resource
Development ministry. Student union leaders Sanjay Singh Bisht and Sanjay
Rauthan initiated relay protest by sitting for protest demonstration at the dean
of faculty office. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For

                          November 19, 2008 Wednesday

Kosovo opposition leader backs protest rally against UN's EULEX deployment plan

LENGTH: 176 words


Text of report in English by Pristina-based independent internet news agency
KosovaLive

["AAK Supports Protest" -- KosovaLive headline]

Pristina, 19 Nov (KosovaLive) -- The Alliance for the Future of Kosovo (AAK)
supports today's protests, which is organized by nongovernmental organizations,
thus reconfirming the stance of the AAK against the UN plan, whereas other
political parties have not stated their stance regarding today's protest.

A press release of the AAK reads that this political party, based on their
analyses, evaluated the protests as right.

"By supporting the protest, the AAK reconfirms its strong position against the
six points and especially against plans and compromises for functional partition
of Kosovo," reads the press release.

Kosovo Assembly Speaker Jakup Krasniqi has also made comments yesterday
regarding today's protests. Krasniqi said that it is citizens' right to protest,
but said that there is no reason to protest because the institutions have
rejected the UN plan.

Source: KosovaLive website, Pristina, in English 19 Nov 08

                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                              May 27, 2016 Friday

'Peaceful' protests now a crime in capital

BYLINE: MUNAWER AZEEM

SECTION: Vol. 70 No. 148

LENGTH: 342  words


The right to protest for their due rights is an inherent freedom enjoyed by all
citizens in a democratic set up, but police in the federal capital are looking
to clamp down on all protests, even ones that do not cause damage to public
property.

On Thursday, police registered an FIR in response to a protest involving 25 to
30 people at Islamabad Chowk, near Golra Mor.

According to the FIR, a protester who addressed the group had drawn attention to
the dilapidated state of roads in sectors G-13 and G-14, as well as the lack of
proper systems for drinking water, sewerage and street lights in the area.

The FIR stated that the protesters blocked Kashmir Highway, stopping vehicles
from entering Islamabad.

The case against the protestors was registered in response to a complaint by
Assistant Sub-Inspector Turabul Hassan, under Section 341 of the Pakistan Penal
Code, which deals with the punishment for wrongful restraint.

A senior police official, however, admitted that blocking a road during a
protest was a minor matter, and it was normally the responsibility of local and
traffic police to facilitate both motorists and protesters. It is a right of the
people to be able to stage a peaceful protest, he said. The official added that
it was not common for Islamabad police to register a case over a peaceful
protest.

Zohra Yusuf of the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan said that protests by
vulnerable groups or people calling for their rights were often met with
violence, while violent protests by religious groups were permitted. Freedom to
protest is a democratic right, as long as they do not infringe on the rights of
others, she maintained.

Golra Station House Officer Chaudhry Mohammad Aslam admitted that the protest
was a peaceful one, adding that the protesters were asked to vacate the road and
protest by the roadside, but they refused.

When asked about policies or SOPs regarding peaceful protests, a spokesperson
for the Islamabad inspector general said a case was registered against the
protesters because they had blocked the road.

                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                              June 29, 2015 Monday

117 protests held in first half of June against ECP

SECTION: Vol. LXIX No. 179

LENGTH: 375  words


Political temperature remained high in the first half of the current month
because of the local government elections in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa where 117
protests and rallies were taken out against the Election Commission of Pakistan.

Strategy and Analysis Wing of the provincial home and tribal affairs department
said in its report that a record number of protests and road blocks were
observed in the first half of June which showed 59 per cent increase compared to
incidents occurred in the second fortnight of May.

The report comprising 53 pages said that 18,036 people took part in protest
rallies and public meetings held across the province and public registered their
grievances against the government.

The document said that the main reason for the strikes and protests was the
local government elections held on May 30. Political parties and unsuccessful
candidates held protest demonstrations against alleged rigging and were
demanding re-elections.

The document, however, does not mention killing of people in elections.
Election-related violence had claimed 20 lives and left 200 wounded across the
province.

Tripartite alliance comprising Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam-Fazl, Awami National Party
and Pakistan Peoples Party held protest rallies in many districts against
rigging in the election and demanded re-poll in the presence of interim setup in
117 protests held in first half of June against ECP the province, said the
report.

It said that 117 of total 201 demonstrations, rallies and road blockades were
polling related in which 9,316 people took part, while 22 issues which caused
protests were related with the establishment department. Also, 19 protests were
held against the Peshawar Electric Supply Company for power outages.

Regarding law and order situation, the report said that multiple protests were
taken out against rise in extortion cases in Peshawar. It said that internally
displaced persons held a protest for early return to their homes.

Tribesmen also held a protest demonstration in Peshawar, demanding introduction
of local government system in Fata and end to corrupt practices of political
administration of Khyber Agency. Employees of various associations, including
paramedics, also took out rallies in favour of their demands.

                        Armenpress News Agency (English)

                              July 12, 2013 Friday

Turkish journalists to hold protest action in Taksim Square

LENGTH: 362  words


"We, the journalists, protest against the force, violence, tension, threats,
arrests,
detentions and dismisses carried out against us during the disorders in the Gezi
Park".

YEREVAN, JULY 12, ARMENPRESS: The Turkish journalists, suffered from the actions
of the police during the anti-governmental demonstrations, will hold a protest
action in the Taksim Square of Istanbul. As reported by Armenpress, this was
published by the Turkish Demokrathaber.net.


The protest rally is intended to be held on July 12, at 19:00 by the local time
under the heading "Let me do my work". The message, spread by the journalists,
says in particular: "We, the journalists, protest against the force, violence,
tension, threats, arrests, detentions and dismisses carried out against us
during the disorders in the Gezi Park".
The disorders in Turkey began when on May 28 2013 the plans of replacing Taksim
Gezi Park with a reconstruction of the historic Taksim Military Barracks
(demolished in 1940) with the possibility of housing a shopping mall became
known. The protests developed into riots when a group occupying the park was
attacked by police. The subjects of the protests have since broadened beyond the
development of Taksim Gezi Park, developing into wider anti-government
demonstrations. The protests have also spread to other cities in Turkey, and
protests have been seen in other countries with significant Turkish communities.
On May 31 2013, police suppressed the protesters with tear gas, arrested at
least 60 people and injured hundreds. The police action received wide attention
online. 5 men died in the clashes between the police and the protesters, more
than 7,500 people were injured and about 5,000 of people were arrested. By the
data provided by the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Turkey, about 2,5 million
people from 79 regions took part in the anti-government demonstrations held in
Turkey.
The Turkish authorities were appealed by the White House, the UN
Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, the EU foreign policy commissioner Catherine
Ashton, the US Vice President Joe Biden and the President of the Russian
Federation Vladimir Putin to settle the issue via a dialogue.

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              July 12, 2013 Friday

Another wave of arrests in connection with Gezi Park protests occurs in Turkey

BYLINE: A. Taghiyeva, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 239 words


July 12--Another wave of arrests in connection with the protests, which were
held in support of the demonstrations in Istanbul Gezi Park occurred in the
Turkish cities of Izmir, Bursa, Manisa and Balikesir, Sabah newspaper said on
Friday.

As a result of the country's security forces' operations, which were held at 16
locations, around 15 people suspected of organizing the riots and attacking the
buildings of public and private organizations were detained.

The Turkish security forces claim that there are representatives of the
left-wing terrorist organizations among the detained.

Earlier it was reported that around 944 people were detained during the protests
in Turkey.

The protests have been held in Turkey for three weeks. According to the
representatives of the authorities, the protests had anti-government character.

Turkey's opposition parties accuse the police of using excessive force against
protesters.

Earlier, the Turkish Interior Ministry reported that around 2.5 million people
were involved in the protests in 79 Turkish provinces for three weeks.

Around 4,000 people were injured, 5 people were killed and 4,900 people were
detained by the police as a result of the riots in Turkey.

                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                            June 12, 2013 Wednesday

Lawyers rail at police response to Turkey protests;
Turkish lawyers join anger over police response as government seeks end protests
with meeting

BYLINE: JAMEY KEATEN SUZAN FRASER Associated PressAssociated Press

SECTION: A; Pg.2

LENGTH: 112  words


ANKARA, Turkey (AP) - Thousands of black-robed lawyers are storming out of their
courthouses in Turkey, shouting about the rough treatment police dished out to
their colleagues amid Turkey's biggest anti-government protest in years.

The rallies Wednesday by clapping, chanting jurists added a new twist to the
nearly two weeks of protests that started in Istanbul and spread to dozens of
other Turkish cities.

The protests have shaped up as the biggest test yet in the 10-year rule of Prime
Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Islamic-rooted government.

After fierce overnight clashes in Istanbul's Taksim Square, Erdogan was to host
talks with some protesters later in the day.

                              253 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          Business Day (South Africa)

                              May 22, 2012 Tuesday
                              Business Day Edition

Service delivery protests and their patterns

BYLINE: KAREN HEESEand KEVIN ALLAN

SECTION: OPINION & EDITORIAL

LENGTH: 768  words


Service delivery protests and their patterns

KAREN HEESE nd KEVIN ALLAN

IT IS a relief that the aggregate number of service delivery protests for last
year fell off the highs of 2009 and 2010, but will this trend be sustained?
Recent trends in service delivery protests send mixed messages.

One of the encouraging features of last year's protests was a lull around local
government elections. The lull suggests that political engagement with
communities can channel frustrations, and that protest action is often a last
resort. In fact, protests often follow failed engagements in which memorandums
and petitions are ignored or inadequately dealt with.

Even more encouraging than last year's lull is that protests have not rapidly
accelerated since politicians took office a year ago - but they have by no means
disappeared. Municipal IQ's Hotspots Monitor, which logs major protests related
to service delivery, shows that service delivery protests for the year so far
account for 8% of protests recorded since 2004; if they continue at the same
rate, not only will they outstrip last year's aggregate number but, more
worrying, also 2009's - thanks to a busy first quarter. March saw a 22-month
peak in protests, but it is far off those of 2009 and 2010 and growth in the
number of protests decelerated last month. It should be noted, however, that
almost all of last month's protests were squeezed into 10 days.

The problem with analysing protests is that they tend to be lumpy. In trying to
discern whether the first quarter's spike will be sustained for the rest of the
year, it is interesting to consider the recent past. Both 2009 and last year
both saw a rise in the second quarter, but both years also had quieter first
quarters than this year. The busier first quarter of 2010, by contrast, saw a
tailing off in the second quarter, which makes a trend hard to surmise. It is
perhaps more useful to understand the driving forces behind this year's
protests, which have a markedly different provincial breakdown from previous
years. Many protests this year have had complex motivations, with some -
including those in the racially tense Western Cape's Theewaterskloof and
politically unsettled Bitou and Nelson Mandela Bay - having political
undercurrents that, if not catalysing protests, may have added to their fury.

Others, including those in Mpumalanga, have surrounded the delivery of basic
services, in particular water. The Free State, a worrying site given its seminal
flare-up in 2004, is again a province typified by service delivery protests.

Conspicuously quiet is Gauteng.

Sustained protest activity in the Free State and Mpumalanga this year put these
provinces, along with the Eastern Cape and Western Cape, ahead of Gauteng as the
most protest-ridden provinces - a major achievement for Gauteng in its attempts
to mitigate protest activity, considering its former dominance as the most
protest-afflicted province.

Between 2004 and this year, Gauteng accounted for almost one-third of protests
on the Hotspots Monitor, but this year it has fallen to a mere 11%, whereas the
Western Cape has risen to 25% from a more modest 17% since 2004.

What, then, is Gauteng's apparent secret? While protests such as those in
Ratanda and Kya Sands continue to hit headlines, most of the metros are acutely
aware of protests and the need to respond, with the provincial MEC often the
first on the scene. There is a balancing act too; politicians cannot appear to
be at the mercy of violent protests, and while the official line has been to
condemn such actions, swift political responses appear to have mitigated protest
activity.

Of course, a rapid response is easier to achieve in metropolitan areas, and it
is noteworthy that almost two-thirds of this year's protests have taken place in
nonmetro areas; until this year, there has been a 50:50 mix between 2004's and
2011's aggregate protest breakdown. This profile has policing implications too,
often with riot units far from the site of protests and local police
ill-equipped to deal with large-scale protest activity.

Is this year set for another record?

If protests in Gauteng heat up, almost certainly. But if the trends of this year
are sustained, it is the Western Cape, Nelson Mandela Bay, the Free State and
water-scarce Mpumalanga municipalities that need to be watched.

With winter approaching, with its electricity and other service hikes, the
impatience shown by those who felt e-tolling was an unaccountable service should
be heeded. With no time for complacency, communities must be heard.

& 8226;Heese is Municipal IQ's economist; Allan is its MD.

LOAD-DATE: May 25, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2012 BDFM Publishers PTY Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              256 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                             The Financial Express

                            October 17, 2011 Monday

Popular protests

BYLINE: The Financial Express

LENGTH: 319  words


The Occupy Wall Street protests, now more than a month old, are showing no signs
of stopping-in fact, they've even spread to London, Rome and Melbourne. The
feeling behind the protests-that the bankers of the world have earned their
supernormal profits at the expense of the common man-is a pretty common one in
this economic climate, but it seems that the drive to take to the streets is
also becoming equally common. The Arab Spring protests, and the worldwide
coverage they got through the media and social networks, have almost made it
fashionable to protest against the established order.

But a protest needs direction and, more importantly, a mission. The Arab Spring
protests were political, with the aim to overthrow dictatorial regimes; the Anna
Hazare-led movement in India was equally targeted, towards the passing of a
strong anti-corruption Bill. The spate of protests in the West, in contrast,
have been singularly chaotic and directionless. Take the London riots, for
example. Ostensibly started over an alleged firing by the police on a civilian,
the protests quickly took on a nasty character, with rioting, looting and
burning ruining the livelihoods of many small business men. The Occupy Wall
Street protests, too, are in a similar state, although they haven't really
turned violent, except in Rome. The point of the protest is in the protest
itself, not in what the demands are. The people involved want their displeasure
at the existing economic scenario to be known, but then what? The lack of a goal
almost condemns the movement to peter out.

The simple truth is that radical reactionary measures against Wall Street will
not help. Just doing away with the bankers will

only worsen the problem manifold. There is no simple solution to this. The
protests have made their point-people are unhappy with the excesses of Wall
Street and are angry enough to show it-but maybe it's now time to go home?

LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                     The Russian Business Monitor (Russia)

                            March 11, 2009 Wednesday

LEVADA CENTER POLL SHOWS 60% SUPPORT FOR PROTESTS

SECTION: HUMAN RESOURCES; No. 24

LENGTH: 390 words


"What do you think of the people participating in rallies and manifestations
against the falling living standards and therefore trying to defend their
rights?" Levada Center sociologists asked 1,600 respondents between February 20
and 23. Nineteen percent admitted feeling respect for the protesters and 41%
said they fully understood them. Seven percents admitted interest. Not a single
respondent said that street protests were an affront to be put an end to.
Twenty-six percent admitted indifference.

Answers to an analogous question concerning street actions in support of the
government were different: 31% declared support, 11% sneered, and 41% were
indifferent.

Protest expectations greatly increased over the last couple of months.
Possibility of protests was recognized by 18% of respondents in November, 20% in
December, and 39% in February. Readiness to join protests was declared by 20% in
December and 23% nowadays.

Expectations of these protests are particularly considerable in cities with the
population between 100,000 and 500,000 or more but not in Moscow. Readiness to
protest was mostly admitted by residents of small townships (27-28%) where
sympathy with street protests was particularly strong (66%).

"That's potential energy rather than actual willingness to protest," Levada
Center Assistant Director Alexei Grazhdankin said. "There were even more
sympathizers in the 1990s but actual participation in the protests then was
nothing to write home about. I'd rather say that results of the opinion poll
indicate the general mood of society and its attitude toward anti-crisis policy
of the government and splendiferous actions in its support."

Ilya Yashin of the Solidarity Movement, one of the most active protesters, said
the next wave of protests was expected in the regions (as opposed to the
capitals) in April and May. Protests would probably take place in the Far East,
Nizhny Novgorod, Yaroslavl, and Sochi. "It is absence of legitimate opposition
and genuine trade unions that makes street protests the only option," Yashin
said.

Vadim Soloviov of the CPRF Central Committee said a nationwide protest campaign
is planned for late March. The CPRF's last nationwide protests drew 2-2.5
million people in cities across Russia. The CPRF is counting on 7-8 million
protesters in late March.

Source: Vedomosti, March 6, 2009

                          Sunday World (South Africa)

                                 August 7, 2016

Protests a nest for criminals

SECTION: OPINION & EDITORIAL

LENGTH: 156 words


IT seems service delivery protests are becoming a nest for criminals to hide
before they prey on innocent people.
  A recent protest near Leratong Hospital, towards Tshepisong on the West Rand,
was clouded by acts of criminality when young people saw it as an opportunity to
extort money from motorists by blockading the main road.


 It was sad to observe that these protests had turned what could have been a
valid protest into a criminal act during peak hour traffic.
  A group of young men approached a woman motorist and promised to escort her
through the protest without being harmed if she could just give them a tip of
R10. Their protest was a failure because cops acted swiftly and stopped what
could have been a nightmare for motorists.

 These criminal elements deviate from the genuine concerns facing communities,
because opportunists use these protest marches to exhort money from desperate
motorists.
  Sithembiso Mkhize
  By e-mail

                               Miadhu (Maldives)

                           December 15, 2015 Tuesday

MDP, AP fined for 27th November mass protest

LENGTH: 151  words


Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP) and Adhaalath Party (AP) has been fined by MVR
75,000 each, in connection to the mass protest carried out on the 27th of
November.

Elections Commission (EC) stated that the Commission had passed to fine the two
parties for the inclusion of minors and the use of UN logo in the protest.

MDP has stated that the Party did not include minors in the protest and that the
Party cannot be held responsible for the actions carried out by individuals.

The guidelines on protests say that protest organizers should be responsible for
all the events that take place during the protest.

The UN Office had raised concerns on the use of their logo in the protest to the
ACC and had issued tweets that the logo cannot be used in such a manner.

EC had said that if the parties did not pay the amount, then the amount will be
deducted from the funds released to the parties from the state budget.

                                      DNA

                            August 29, 2015 Saturday

Bhagat roars like a lion, runs away like a rat;
Congress leader reduces alt145dhamaka' agitation to a mere photo-op

BYLINE: Amit Srivastava

LENGTH: 376  words


Congress leader reduces alt145dhamaka' agitation to a mere photo-op

Vashi: They called journalists from all over Navi Mumbai to witness a 'dhamaka'
of a protest and by the end of the fiasco, it turned out to be a whimper.

City Congress chief Dashrath Bhagat and his cronies summoned the media to
witness a stormy protest against Cidco at an ongoing meet between its managing
director Sanjay Bhatia and project-affected persons. Far from storming the
venue, Bhagat tamely held a banner outside the gate and sheepishly got away from
the venue.

The confused Congress workers, who sought media attention outside Cidco
exhibition centre in Vashi, were equally clueless. They claimed that there were
carrying out a peaceful protest against Cidco. However, with a bunch of hardly
20 party workers, the protest ended in a couple of minutes.

Several people crossing the stretch could not stop themselves by asking whether
it was a protest or a photo shoot to seek media attention.

Bhagat, known to roar during a protest, was not even able to give an exact
reason what prompted them to stage a protest and what are their demands.
Meanwhile, the mediapersons kept asking the reason of their protest. However,
instead of giving reason of their protest they quietly asked mediapersons to
come outside the centre, who were attending the Cidco's investment and banking
seminar for NMIA PAPs, as they would protest.

Even it was learnt that a few mediapersons were reportedly informed over the
phone by party workers that there would be a stormy protest at the centre in
Vashi.

Eventually, after bringing the media outside the centre, around 20 party
workers, along with Bhagat, just posed for photographs.

Sources claimed that Vashi police reportedly prevented the outfit from carrying
out any protest, following which the party dropped the idea of protest and just
posed for photographs. However, Bhagat refused the claim that he was under any
pressure from police.

"I had never carried out any protest under fear," he said, adding, "I wanted to
make the PAPs aware that they need to be cautious as they would land in trouble
in future. Cidco did nothing after taking lands of the poor villagers. I need
media support to raise the issue."

                             March 14, 2014 Friday

Over 20 polling stations attacked in Turkey

BYLINE: Rufiz Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: NATIONAL POLITICAL NEWS

LENGTH: 232 words


March 14--Over 20 polling stations in Turkey were attacked during yesterday's
protests, Turkish Deputy Prime Minister Bulent Arinc said, TRT Haber TV channel
reported on March 13.

Arinc said the protests that took place yesterday, were directed against the
government.

"No force can change the government with protests," Arinc said.

He also said that the policy changes should be made in a democratic way.

On March 11 there were mass protests in 32 Turkish cities with regard to the
death of the 15-year-old Elvan Berkin. He suffered a head injury during a rally
in May last year and died recently.

The largest protests were observed in Istanbul and Ankara.

Mass protests were also held on March 12 during Elvan Berkin's funeral.

Anti-government protests took place in Turkey for nearly three weeks beginning
in late May.

Turkish oppositional parties accused the police of using excessive force against
protestors.

In total, around 2.5 million people from 79 Turkish provinces participated in
protests during the three weeks, the Turkish Interior Ministry said.

As a result of the unrests in Turkey nearly 4,000 people were injured with
varying severity, 4,900 were detained by the police.

                           The New Age (South Africa)

                            December 2, 2013 Monday

Service delivery protests politicised

BYLINE: Siyabonga Mkhwanazi

LENGTH: 378 words


THABO Manyoni, the chairperson of the SA Local Government Association (Salga)
chairperson Thabo Manyoni, has blamed some violent service delivery protests on
infighting in political parties.

Manyoni told The New Age Business Briefing in Cape Town on Friday that while
people were allowed to protest, he questioned the violence behind some of the
protests.

Service delivery protests have been hitting the country over the last few years,
with Cooperative Governance and Traditional Affairs Minister Lechesa Tsenoli
revealing in a written parliamentary reply to a question two weeks ago that
Gauteng was the hot spot for these protest.

He said between 2011 and 2013 there had been a total of 46 public protests in
Gauteng, resulting in 546 people being arrested for destroying property, theft
and assault.

Manyoni, who is also the mayor of Mangaung, said local government was trying to
keep pace with the level of service delivery demands.

"Citizens should own municipalities. That is why we are talking about inclusive
cities. The problem is that we don't talk with one another, we talk across each
other. In South Africa we are chasing a moving target," he said.

Tsenoli said the auditor-general, Terence Nombembe, had found that there were no
systems in place, making it difficult to meet service delivery objectives by
municipalities.

Replying to a question on the protests Manyoni said there was a need to contain
these protests.

"What I am stressing is that before you protest let's engage. You can't explain
why someone should burn a library, but these things are happening. You find that
in most cases these protests are politically motivated," he said.

Parties must rein in their members and not bicker in public, resulting in the
violent service delivery protests, he said.

Senior ANC leaders, including ministers in Parliament, have warned against
factionalism and infighting causing violent protests.

Some people are said to be exploiting the frustrations of communities over the
lack of service delivery to advance their political agenda by waging protests to
oust their rivals.

The public protests have been escalating over the last few years.

Tsenoli said he could not quantify the damage caused to property during the
protests.

siyabongam@thenewage.co.za

                                Daily News Egypt

                            December 21, 2012 Friday

New law governing protests

BYLINE: Laurence Underhill

LENGTH: 299 words


Protests in Egypt could soon be regulated by a new law (File photo)
Mohamed Omar

A new law governing protests is expected to be issued soon, amid concern over a
possible crack-down on freedom of protests.

In a press conference held at the presidential palace Thursday night, the
president's official spokesperson Yasser Aly denied that the new protests law
would resemble the notorious emergency law which governed Egypt throughout
Mubarak's 30-year reign. Aly stated that the law would guarantee the
preservation of democratic mechanisms and the protection of public as well as
private properties, reported state-owned Al-Ahram.

"We do not intend to bring back a state of emergency," Aly was quoted by
Al-Ahram as saying, "if we intended to take any exceptional decisions, we would
have done so during the more severe circumstances we've faced recently."

Aly stated that the new law would determine the bodies holding protests, as well
as the time and place for such protests. He added that such a mechanism is being
used worldwide.

"The process of protesting needs further organisation," Aly said, adding that
the forms of violence which took over several recent protests have caused alarm.
Aly stated that everybody should unite to stop all forms of violence.

Emergency law, which Egypt adopts whenever a state of emergency is declared,
puts restrictions on people's rights of association, in effect it could ban
protests or marches.

The protest law was earlier proposed by Essam Sharaf's cabinet in March 2011.
Sharaf's law criminalised protests, sit-ins and gatherings. The cabinet
justified the proposed law saying that such protests stall work in public and
private institutions. The law was criticised by several human rights
organisations, including Amnesty International. It was never implemented.

                                  My Republica

                          September 26, 2012 Wednesday

CPN-M to join hands with oppn parties in anti govt protests

LENGTH: 327 words

DATELINE: Nepal


Nepal, Sept. 26 -- KATHMANDU, Sept 25: The ongoing politburo meeting of
CPN-Maoist has decided to adopt all possible means to intensify the protest
against the current government.

The meeting at the party headquarters in Buddhanagar, also concluded that the
earlier protest programs of the party were a great success. "We decided to
intensify the street protests against the government and prominently raise the
issues of national sovereignty and people's livelihood," Secretary Netra Bikram
Chand told .

Chand said that they would discuss ways to make the joint protest program with
other opposition parties including Nepali Congress and CPN-UML more effective.

CPN-Maoist had earlier launched street protests against the government terming
it 'anti-national'. "The target of fresh protest will be to exert pressure on
Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai to step down. The protest will create ground
for forming a joint national government," added Politburo member Kul Prasad KC.

KC said the street protest will also be targeted against price hikes and
hoarding of various daily necessities. "After privatization of all institutions
of government, our country is going to hands of the bureaucratic compradors. So,
we are going to form a joint front of the all patriotic forced," claimed KC.

Among other things, the meeting also decided to form around 90 district
organizing committees including 75 geographical and 15 non-geographical district
committees.

The newly formed party has already announced mass meetings in the major cities
across the country. While the party general secretary Ram Bahadur Thapa and
Secretary Chand will address the gathering in the capital and in Pokhara,
respectively, the party bureau in-charges will address other mass gatherings of
the party. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Republica. For any

                             Sowetan (South Africa)

                             August 24, 2012 Friday

Protests close Howard College

BYLINE: Tebogo Monama Education Reporter

SECTION: EDUCATION

LENGTH: 304 words


CLASSES at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Howard College have been suspended
until Monday following violent protests by students.


 The protests at this college and the Pietermaritzburg campus started on
Tuesday.
 On Wednesday police dispersed the protesters and also arrested five students.
The students were released yesterday.
 Students are protesting over security at off-campus residences.

  University spokeswoman Nomonde Mbadi said students were continuing the protest
action at Howard College.
 "A group of students gathered at Shepstone Building Level 6 this morning. Risk
management services are monitoring the protest and the SAPS is on campus. The
SAPS were informed that the protest action is illegal.
  "Management is committed to reaching an agreement with the protesting students
in a professional and peaceful manner," Mbadi said.
 Classes have been suspended indefinitely and examinations were moved to the
Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) after protests over financial exclusion.

  Violent protests at TUT started at the Soshanguve, GaRankuwa and Pretoria West
campuses and this week affected other provinces, forcing management to shut down
the premises.
  The students are complaining about the allocation of funds from the National
Student Financial Aid Scheme. They are also demanding that all catering
contracts be cancelled.
  Students were evicted from the residences and university spokeswoman Willa de
Ruyter said the campuses have been closed to ensure the safety of students,
staff and property. Staff have been back at the institution from Tuesday.
  Students will be notified by text message when the institution will be open
again.
 Higher education and training spokeswoman Vuyelwa Qinga said a team had been
selected to deal with the issues at TUT on a regular basis. -

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                             August 20, 2012 Monday

Jaago Mangalore Association calls off protest campaign following police advisory

BYLINE: Jaideep Shenoy

SECTION: MANGALORE

LENGTH: 306 words


MANGALORE: Jaago Mangalore Association has called off its planned protest march
and protest meet on August 21 planned as part of the week-long protest campaign
against attacks on young birthday party revellers at Morning Mist Home Stay at
Padil on July 28. This follows move by Mangalore City Police to deny them
permission citing potential law and order disturbances that the protest march
and meet could trigger in the present day situation.

Vijaynath Shetty, chief coordinator, Jaago Mangalore Association stated that
following the recent developments regarding the protest campaign, he met City
Police Chief Seemant Kumar and again sought clearance for planned protest march
and meet on Tuesday. However Seemant expressed his unwillingness to grant
permission stating that the issue was getting hot and it might lead to untoward
law and order situation that might arise during the protest.

The movement was meant to be a civilized and peaceful protest with the main
objective being to express strong disapproval against violence, especially
violence against women. As Jaago Mangalore Association has no intention to break
the law or create public nuisance in order to voice its protest, Vijaynath said
that as of now, the protest planned for Tuesday stands cancelled. He urged
everyone to shun violence and help create a better 'Mangalore to Live'.

Incidentally, City Police on Thursday had arrested Vijaynath Shetty, along with
Gurudath Kamath and Vijay Kumar, two among the male victims of Padil attack and
others when they attempted to hold a protest meeting in front of the DCs office
here. Seemant had justified the action against JMA stating the association
office bearers did not obtain prior permission nor intimate the jurisdictional
police about their protest forcing police to arrest them.

                           The Advertiser (Australia)

                           February 17, 2011 Thursday
                               1 - State Edition

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 85

LENGTH: 472  words


Egyptian unrest part of a bigger picture around the world

I understand that the Egyptian protests are linked to other protests around
Africa and the Middle East. Could you please tell me in which countries
demonstrations or protests have occurred? - M.B. (Lockleys)

The first of the protests, in Tunisia on December 18 last year, has since been
referred to as a revolution.

The government was overthrown and president Zine El Abidine Ben Ali fled.

The governing party, the Constitutional Democratic Rally, was subsequently
disbanded, removed from government and suspended. Major street protests were
held in Tunisia, resulting in 219 deaths and many injuries.

In Algeria, major demonstrations were also held from December 28. President
Abdelaziz Bouteflika promised an end to the 19-year state of emergency in the
near future but no date was announced.

From January 13 to 21, smaller-scale protests were held in many countries
including Libya, Jordan, Mauritania, Oman, Sudan, Yemen and Saudi Arabia.
However, the death tolls for these protests was minimal to none. The next major
protest was the Egyptian revolution in which more than 300 people died. The
protests began on January 25 and president Hosni Mubarak handed power to the
military on February 11.

The Armed Forces Supreme Council subsequently announced the suspension of the
constitution, the dissolution of both houses of parliament and a general
election within six months.

After the start of the Egypt demonstrations, there were several more in Syria,
Morocco, Djibouti, Iraq and Bahrain.

Roebucks not related

Two simple unrelated sporting questions. 1: Was Ayrton Senna left or
right-handed? 2: Is cricket journalist and ABC commentator Peter Roebuck related
to famous motor racing journalist Nigel Roebuck? - P.B. (Port Elliot)

Brazilian racing driver Ayrton Senna was left-handed. Peter and Nigel Roebuck
are not known to be directly related.

Don't forget this one

I am trying to remember the word that describes the state of not being able to
remember the word you want to use. The irony is that I can never remember the
word that describes this state of not remembering. Can you please help? - S.B.
(Mt Barker)

The word you are trying to remember is lethologica. It is not in all
dictionaries but is defined by dictionary.com as ``the inability to remember a
word or put your finger on the right word''.

Where to write

Questions should be addressed to What's Your Problem? The Advertiser, GPO Box
339, Adelaide, 5001, or email to problems@adv.newsltd.com.au Please include name
and address, not necessarily for publication.Need more information? Contact the
State Library of SA inquiry service on 82077250/7252 or country (freecall)
1800182013.WWW home page: http://www.slsa.sa.gov.au/goto/askus

Please note that answers published are not necessarily supplied by the State
Library.

                       The News Courier (Athens, Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 28, 2009 Tuesday

Tea party organizers taking protest to D.C.

BYLINE: Karen Middleton, The News Courier, Athens, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 353 words


Jul. 28--One of the organizers of the local Tea Party tax protest said Monday
she is encouraging her group and any other supporters to hop aboard the Tea
Party Express and take the protest to Washington.

Deborah King said the Tea Party Express is a wave of tax and "reckless
government spending" protests that is sweeping across the nation and will
culminate Sept. 12 in a march on Washington.

The local group held a Tea Party protest in Athens on April 18 and joined the
Decatur group on July 4.

Supporters have already registered 14,000 nationwide and hope to attract at
least 100,000 to their cause, according to the Web site:
http://shoals2dc.webs.com.

"When I saw this information about the march throughout the United States I
thought Alabama should be in those numbers," said King. "Citizens who are tired
of reckless government spending and bailouts should not sit silently while this
administration spends this government into bankruptcy.

"The reasons I got involved are I'm against socialized health care, the
government taking over industries, socialism, and spreading the wealth. What I
am for -- and from what I've seen this government is against -- is the
Constitution, limited government, gun rights and God."

Organizers have set an Aug. 14 deadline to register to join the March on
Washington. Call King at (256) 559-0980 for answers to questions about motel or
bus accommodations. If you plan to go by train, call Karen Krutch at (256)
764-2230 to make reservations.

The limit is four persons to a room and no rollaway beds or sleeping bags are
allowed. Room reservations will only be assured after your check is received.

"We will leave by bus on Sept. 11 and return Sept. 13," said King.

To see more of The News Courier or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.enewscourier.com/. Copyright (c) 2009, The News Courier, Athens, Ala.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                             The Gazette (Montreal)

                            February 2, 2009 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Right to protest is at heart of democracy

BYLINE: The Gazette

SECTION: EDITORIAL / OP-ED; Pg. A11

LENGTH: 195  words


That letter-writer Ed Brown ("Ban masked protest," Jan. 28) equates protests
with riots, while Gary Ikeman ("No masks," Jan. 26) argues that demonstrators
"disrupt our society with impunity" betrays a complete misunderstanding of the
rights and freedoms enshrined in our charter.

Protests can be messy affairs, but they are at the root of democratic government
and protected under our right to freedom of speech and of assembly. Any move to
clamp down on the ability and inclination of citizens to protest against
policies they find unjust is a step down the slippery road to injustice and
oppression. One need only look at the critical role of mass protest in assuring
civil rights for blacks and women to see how integral these rights have been,
and continue to be, in shaping our society.

I, for example, consider Ikeman's charming assertion that immigrants who wish to
protest should "stay home and protest in their own country" both racist and
xenophobic. But the Charter of Rights and Freedoms protects his right to make
such a statement, as it does mine to call it racist. It also protects the right
to protest of every resident of Canada, citizen or not.

Ethan Cox

Rigaud

LOAD-DATE: February 2, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                    February 18, 2003 Tuesday Final Edition

Naive protests

SOURCE: The Ottawa Citizen

BYLINE: Peter A. Beeftink

SECTION: News; Pg. A13

LENGTH: 90 words

I am amazed at all the protests against a war with Iraq. When Iraq used poisoned
gas against Iran and against its own citizens, killing many tens of thousands,
there was nobody protesting in the streets, or anywhere else.

Has everybody such a short memory? Are these protesters assuming that Iraq has
been so nice that it has either neatly used up all its poisoned gas, or
conscientiously cleaned up all its remaining stocks?

If protesters believe this, maybe the tooth fairy will come to them soon.

Peter A. Beeftink,

Ottawa

                              274 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                  News Letter

                            October 18, 2015 Sunday

WATCH: Republicans protest at PSNI recruitment event

LENGTH: 453  words


A protest held outside a PSNI recruitment event in Londonderry has passed off
peacefully.

Around 3.30pm on Saturday afternoon approximately 60 protesters carrying
banners, Irish tricolours and placards made their way from Pilot's Row in the
Bogside, across the Peace Bridge and through St. Columb's Park where they were
stopped by police from entering the venue where the recruitment event took
place.

Independent Derry City and Strabane District Council councillor Gary Donnelly
was amongst the protesters.

"This is a protest led by the people of Derry against British policing,"
Councillor Donnelly said.

"Over the last number of days there have been a number of homes ransacked by the
PSNI and there has been a dramatic increase in the number of stop and searches.
People have come here today to show their anger and opposition to British
policing," he added.

PSNI officers in high visibility jackets maintained a barrier across the
entrance during the protest.

Several PSNI land rovers observed the protest from less than 50 yards away.

There was no violence and no one was arrested. The protest lasted over an hour
and passed off without incident.

Elected members of the DUP, including Gregory Campbell and MLA for Foyle, Gary
Middleton, attended the protest.

Mr Middleton described the protest as "disgraceful" and said he did not think it
was peaceful.

"I am disgusted at this protest because again, individuals have taken it upon
themselves to disrupt what is an employment opportunity for many," he said.

"I think it's disgraceful that people who have come to this recruitment event
today have been denied that opportunity. I am all for peaceful protest and I
support the right of people to protest peacefully but what we have here today is
completely unacceptable."

The PSNI recruitment event was due to take place in Waterfoot Hotel on Saturday
October 10 but the police postponed the session as they feared a planned
Republican Network for Unity (R.N.U.) protest had the potential to interfere
with a wedding due to take place at the hotel at the same time.

Police then carried out a search after they received reports that a suspect
device had been planted near the hotel on October 9.

After a thorough search of the area a viable device was discovered in the
grounds of the hotel.

The event was then due to take place in the hotel on Saturday October 17 but
hotel owner Garvan O'Doherty decided against it because he feared for the safety
of customers and staff.

The PSNI then announced on Wednesday that an alternative venue had been found on
the event went ahead as planned on Saturday afternoon.

The PSNI held two information sessions at St. Columb's Park House and Justice
Minister, David Ford MLA, was in attendance.

                              Early Times (India)

                              July 3, 2015 Friday

Dirty deals: For a few leaders, 'protest' is tool for blackmailing

LENGTH: 413 words

DATELINE: JAMMU


JAMMU, July 3 -- The protests, which are a strong medium of communicating with
the government on vital issues of public importance, may gradually lose their
flavour in Jammu given the inputs that a few small-time leaders have been doing
so to blackmail government officers.

They need a reason to protest, howsoever irrelevant it may be. Some protest 30
days a month over virtually "no" issues, discrediting this important form of
democratic expression.

The frequently held demonstrations are anti-Pakistan, anti-Geelani and against
the government over dilapidated roads, broken electric poles, choked drains and
other such issues. Their acts are solely aimed at drawing the attention of
authorities concerned towards them and they succeed in it.

A few days back, a government engineer was found enquiring about the address of
a "protester" at New Plots. Asked why he wanted to meet him, he said, "Sahib ne
bheja hai us-se milne ke liye taaki voh hmare department ke khilaf protest na
kare (My boss has asked me to meet him so that he does not protest against our
department)."

For these leaders, protests are a "tool" for blackmailing. They have found out
this new way to mint money. They would hold protests and then resort to
blackmailing of the authorities concerned to keep their mouth shut in future.

There is another leader, who would protest outside Press Club against a
particular department once or twice a month. Later, he could be seen frequently
visiting this department and exchanging "pleasantries" with its officers.

There is another set of leaders who would hold protests to get favours from the
state administration but most of them have now been sidelined by their parties.

The "protest industry" is flourishing well for them. People's issues are
important for them only to make money and carve out some political space for
them.

Apart from these protesters, there are others for whom politics is a means of
making a fortune. A small-time contractor did not have much work to do but after
he joined Congress, he developed close relations with a former PCC president
which, in turn, helped him to extract huge contracts from engineers of different
government departments. He is now a rich person. Like him, there are some others
too who have joined politics only to make money.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Early Times. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              Daily Regional Times

                              June 7, 2015 Sunday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Pres Club

SECTION: Vol. VIII No. 875

LENGTH: 299  words


Different protest demonstrations were recorded by the people in favor of their
demands outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Saturday. According to details, the
members of the Property Dealers Association Qasimabad recorded a protest
demonstration against the builder of the Memon Housing Scheme. The property
dealers accused the builder Ghaffar Dada of selling one plot to several people
in Memon Housing Scheme. On the occasion, they demanded of the concerned
authorities to take action against the accused builder. A man namely Lutifullah
Jamali, resident of Ganjo Takar recorded a protest demonstration for the arrest
of his brothers accused murderers. The protesting man said that his brother was
killed six years ago but the police have still not arrested his accused
murderers.

On the occasion, he demanded of the higher authorities to ensure the arrest of
his brothers murderers. Another man namely Premo Kolhi, resident of Hussainabad
staged a protest demonstration for the recovery of his abducted wife. He
demanded of the concerned authorities to take steps for the recovery of his
abducted wife, otherwise he has threatened to accelerate his protest circle.

A man namely Khair Mohammad Chohan, resident of Kotri continued his protest
demonstration for the arrest of his son Sadiq Chohans accused murderers. The
employees of the Sindh Small Industries also continued their protest
demonstration for the issuance of their withheld salaries. The local
transporters of Hyderabad staged a protest demonstration for the release of a
driver namely Ramzan Brohi, who has been arrested in India. The activists of the
Jeay Sindh Tehreek staged a protest demonstration against the registration of
cases on their party leaders including Shafi Mohammad Karnani, Sohail Abro,
Sooriah Sindhi and others.

                  Carroll County Times (Westminster, Maryland)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            April 30, 2015 Thursday

McDaniel hosts discussion of Freddie Gray, protests, police brutality

BYLINE: Jacob deNobel, Carroll County Times, Westminster, Md.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 635 words


April 30--Amid ongoing protests in Baltimore contesting police brutality, more
than 100 students at McDaniel College gathered in the Baker Memorial Hall on
Wednesday night to discuss the death of Freddie Gray, minority communities'
relationship with the police and the politics of nonviolent protest.

The event, Believe: Bigger Than Baltimore, was spearheaded by students on campus
who wished to have a platform to discuss these issues. After a performance of
"Amazing Grace' by students Malcolm Jones and Briahna Harris, McDaniel
professors and students took the stage to give short speeches on a variety of
aspects of the protests in Baltimore.

Pam Zappardino, co-director of the Zepp Center for Nonviolence and Peace
Education, spoke about the history of nonviolent protest and the ways it is
often misunderstood. Zappardino said nonviolent protest doesn't simply mean
turning the other cheek or walking peacefully down a road before dispersing.

She described protest as seeking change through disruption of the status quo and
demanding justice. She also quoted Martin Luther King, Jr's 1968 speech in which
he describes riots as the language of the unheard.

"And what is it that America has failed to hear? It has failed to hear that the
plight of the Negro poor has worsened over the last few years," Zappardino said,
quoting King. "It has failed to hear that the promises of freedom and justice
have not been met. And it has failed to hear that large segments of white
society are more concerned about tranquility and the status quo than about
justice, equality, and humanity."

Senior Jelae McNeil, of Philadelphia, who spoke immediately after Zappardino,
said it shouldn't take a death to be publicized for the campus to come together
to discuss issues of racism and injustice.

"If you want to step up, it starts from the top. It starts with our president.
Then it goes from our president to our faculty and staff. And from there it goes
down to the students and across the whole campus," McNeil said. "If we can't fix
McDaniel, then we can't fix other places."

The final student to speak was Elijah Jones, a sophomore from Baltimore. Jones
said when he watches the news and sees teenagers in the streets, he's reminded
of himself.

"If I was 15 again, that would be me. And I say that because I was lost. I feel
like everybody at that age is lost," Jones said. "You feel like you're
suffocating. You feel like you're slowly but surely dying. So when I see images
of Freddie Gray and I see video, I realize that I am Freddie Gray. We went to
the same schools and lived in the same neighborhoods. What's the difference
between him and I?"

Freshman Joseph Ferguson said he was born and raised in Baltimore, and wanted to
attend the event to hear other peoples' perspectives on what was going on in his
hometown. He said over the past few days, he's relied mainly on social media to
keep him up to date with the news.

Attendee Melanie Ojwang, a junior from Columbia, said the discussions about
Baltimore have been taking place across campus over the past week.

"That's why I think an event like this is so important. It provides people a
space to talk about these things safely and comfortably, and get their feelings
out in a positive manner."

At the end of the evening, organizers held a candle lighting and a moment of
silence and remembrance for the victims of police brutality. On their way out,
students were invited to write messages on banners labeled "Solidarity," "Heal"
and "Come Together," which are planned to be hung in the hall of the Decker
College Center.

Jacob.deNobel@carrollcountytimes.com

410-857-7890

Twitter.com/Jacob_deNobel
