                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 3, 2014 Wednesday

Macedonian analysts view reasons for "unsuccessful" civil protests

LENGTH: 836 words


Text of report by Macedonian newspaper Nova Makedonija on 2 December

[Report by Marta Tanevska: "All Protests Are Political, but Not Partisan"]

Although civil protests, in which the Macedonian youth most often takes part,
have been staged for several years now, they eventually rarely ever affect civic
activism. After a while, the protests abate, while the demands of those who go
out on the streets and seek changes are libeled as partisan, after which the
protests acquire a different dimension. Some of their demands may be fulfilled
or reach an institution, after which the protesters retreat, as they think that
their job has been done and that the institutions have taken them seriously.

This is the analysis of state political analysts, who believe that persistence
is crucial for a successful protest, as well as that it is important that the
arguments for the protest are justified and that the public is convinced of
their necessity. One of the protests that the public remembers both in terms of
its purpose and its motive was the protest against police brutality held three
years ago over Martin Neskovski's murder. A larger group of young people
protested against police brutality for days and they set specific demands to the
MVR [Interior Ministry], part of which were fulfilled and resulted in the
14-year imprisonment of the murderer: Igor Spasov, a member of the Tigers
special unit.

Public attention was later drawn by the civic initiative AMAN's protests against
higher prices of electricity, central heating, and fuels. These protests lasted
five months, and meanwhile a civic initiative was taken to amend the Energy Law
by collecting more than 13,000 signatures, which provided the opportunity for
the AMAN demands to be debated in the Macedonian Assembly.

Initiative Must Not Abate

The currently topical protest is the students' protest against external testing
at universities. All the protests have specific demands and set goals, but civic
activism can be successful only if the public is convinced that the protests are
held over some extremely important matter and that the arguments for the protest
are justified. According to political analyst Saso Klekovski, the most important
thing is for the protesters' demands to be legitimate and for them to be able to
persuade the public that changes are required regarding the matter in question.

"The success of any protest is closely related to whether the protesters hold
their ground and convince the public that they are doing this for a reason. It
is important that the initiative should not abate after a specific goal is met,
as was the case with the AMAN's protests, once its demands were debated at the
Assembly. The mobilization should continue, but in our country initiatives most
often subdue after a while. An example of a successful civil protest was the
closure of the Veles smelter because, despite the economic interests, the public
demands were met," Klekovski says.

All Protests Are Political

Professor Jove Kekenovski says that it is obvious that Macedonian mentality
prevents the protesters from going all the way with a certain demand, which
leads to a number of unsuccessful protests in our country.

"Not a single protest thus far has ended with the meeting of all demands. Even
the large-scale protests have ended with a retreat and they have never gone all
the way. The demands are either not realized or partially realized, which
deprives the protesters of a reason to fight because some of their demands are
already met," Kekenovski says.

As for the fact that every protest acquires partisan dimensions and is
immediately libeled as being organized by a given party, Kekenovski says that
this is due to our undeveloped awareness of participative political culture.

"In our country, the leaders seek servile culture, a culture of vassals and
supporters. This is instrumentalization and an attempt to make everyone think
alike, while tarnishing the opponents as traitors. This is why, regardless of
who organizes the protests, they are always denoted as the rivals' protests,"
Kekenovski explains.

Klekovski, for his part, believe that all the protests are political, but we may
argue whether or not they are partisan.

"In my view, all the protests and other forms of civic activism, even those on
the improvement of the cycling infrastructure, are political. All of them are
civil, but in some way political, too. We are a small country, so every protest
resembles a demand of a given party. In my view, the most important thing is
whether the demands are legitimate, whether they are attainable, and whether the
public can be convinced of their necessity. It is not disputable whether there
are party activists at certain protests because we are a small country, so an
activist can certainly appear at a protest. What is important here is the core
of the protest organizers to be independent and for their arguments and demands
to be justified," Klekovski concludes,

Source: Nova Makedonija, Skopje, in Macedonian 2 Dec 14 p 2

LOAD-DATE: December 3, 2014

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                                   24*7 News

                              June 28, 2013 Friday

Is Morsi Government at brink of Army Intervention?

LENGTH: 304 words

DATELINE: Bahrain


Bahrain, June 28 -- Planned opposition protests on 30 June, the start of Ramadan
on 9 July, and ongoing fuel and power shortages are converging to produce severe
risks of violent protests in Cairo and other urban centres, in turn raising
risks of Army intervention against the Morsi government, according to IHS
assessment.

The opposition's collection of 15 million signatures against President Morsi
indicates unprecedented unity and a probable turnout of hundreds of thousands
nationwide at protests planned for 30 June. Counter-protests by tens of
thousands of Islamists and Salafis are also likely on that date, involving
severe risks of violence between protesters using Molotov cocktails, knives and
occasionally small arms. Smaller protests and counter-protests are also likely
in the run-up to 30 June.

Westerners caught up in Salafi demonstrations are at high risk of attack; during
opposition protests, Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) nationals are at highest
risk.

In Cairo, high risk locations include the Nile Corniche area; 6 October, Kasr
al-Nile and 15 May Bridges; Tahrir, Rab'a al-Adawiya, Abbasiya Squares; and the
Interior Ministry and Maspiro buildings.

"Public squares, mosques, police stations, governorate buildings, and party and
union offices are high risk areas in Suez City, Alexandria, Ismailiya, Port
Said, Luxor, Rafah, Mahalla al-Kubra, Shibeen al-Kom and other urban centres.

"The closure of the Suez Canal is very unlikely. Aviation and port worker unions
joining the Tamarrod campaign, or a resumption of customs worker strikes, would
be the main indicators for disruptions to port and airport operations."

                                 EKantipur.com

                          September 29, 2012 Saturday

Koirala not in favor of protest against govt

LENGTH: 223 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, Sept. 29 -- Nepali Congress (NC) leader Sujata Koirala has stood
against the protest programmes that the opposition parties have decided to stage
against the government .

Koirala said that there was no need of staging any protest against the
government . Opposition parties, including the NC and CPN-UML, are scheduled to
unveil their protest programmes on Monday.

Speaking at the Reporters Club in the Capital on Saturday, Koirala claimed that
Nepali citizens would not support such protest . She was of the view that the
party leadership should press for consensus rather than staging the protest .
Koirala said that the party leadership had not consulted her regarding the
protest programmes.

Koirala maintained that Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai cannot stay in the
power given that the political and constitutional deadlocks were not solved and
there was no full budget in the country.

Saying that the president should take necessary steps to extricate the country
from crisis, Koirala said that a new prime minister should be appointed by the
president as the political parties have failed to form the consensus government
. Published by HT Syndication with permission from EKantipur.com. For any query

                              The Pioneer (India)

                              May 31, 2011 Tuesday

BSP stage statewide agitation against petrol hike

LENGTH: 262  words

DATELINE: Lucknow


Lucknow, May 31 -- Initiating a political war against Congress-led UPA
Government, the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) would stage statewide agitation
against petrol hike on Tuesday, party spokesman said on Monday.

"Senior ministers, legislators and party co-ordinators would take part in the
protest that would be held at all the district headquarters.

Even ministers have been asked to attend these anti-petrol hike protest," the
spokesman said.

In state capital the protest would be led by one of the senior most ministers in
Mayawati cabinet Nasimuddin Siddiqui who will address the party workers in a
meeting in Chowk. Rural Development Minister Dadoo Prasad and Finance Minister
Lalji Verma would lead the protest in Banda and Ambedkar Nagar respectively.

The price rise protest would be held in all the 72 district headquarters. Chief
Minister Mayawati has already asked her party leaders to take part in these
protest in full strength. "Expose the anti-people and anti-dalit policies of the
Congress government," Chief Minister had told the senior party leaders while
issuing guidelines for this protest meeting.

The BSP plans to start nationwide protest against price rise. In her last karya
karta sammelan in Chandigarh she had asked party workers to get ready for
protest in Northern parts of the country. "After UP, protest will start in other
states too," party spokesman said. Published by HT Syndication with permission

                              282 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                              Daily Regional Times

                             March 28, 2011 Monday

                               The Times (London)

                             March 22, 2011 Tuesday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Thousands abandon Assad and join demos to demand freedom

BYLINE: Syria Nicholas; Hugh Tomlinson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 237 words


Anti-regime protests intensified in southern Syria yesterday as thousands of
demonstrators took to the streets of Deraa for the funeral of a young man killed
on Sunday by security forces. In the largest protests since the President,
Bashar Assad, took power 11 years ago, the crowd chanted: "God, Syria and
Freedom," a twist on the customary "God, Syria and Bashar."

Hundreds of protesters were also believed to be gathering in Jassem, also in
southern Syria, where they held a sit-in. There were unconfirmed reports of
protests in Aleppo, Syria's largest city. At least five people have been killed
by Syrian security forces in Deraa since Friday, when protests began after the
arrest of youths for writing anti-regime graffiti.

Meanwhile, Kuwaiti naval vessels arrived off Bahrain yesterday to join the Arab
taskforce supporting the Gulf kingdom in suppressing anti-Government protests.

Saudi Arabia contributed 1,000 troops to help to put down the Shia-led protests
last week. The United Arab Emirates has sent 600 police officers. Bahrain
opposition parties are demanding that the Government should expel all foreign
troops before talks can begin on a political solution to the crisis, in which at
least 16 people have been killed.

In Iran, the opposition leaders Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi have
returned home after three weeks in Tehran's Heshmatieh prison, but they and
their wives remain under house arrest.

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2011

                            Iranian Government News

                           February 5, 2011 Saturday

Anti-government protests in Morocco planned

BYLINE: Staff Reporter

LENGTH: 176 words


The IRIB has issued following news:

Moroccan authorities have okayed an anti-government protest being planned on the
popular social networking site Facebook, a media report said.

The media report said several Moroccan youth movements have announced on
Facebook that they are planning to organise an Egypt-style anti-government
protest Feb 20, a move apparently welcomed by the government.

"We intend to reassure those who are organising protests on the internet that
this is an entirely normal thing and is part of the democratic life of Morocco
," local newspaper Hespress quoted Telecommunications Minister Khaled al-Nasiri
as saying.

The protest will counter a rally planned this Sunday by government supporters,
which is also being organised on Facebook.

Anti-government protests began in Egypt last week aimed at ousting its President
Hosni Mubarak from power and mass protests have also been taking place in Yemen
against its President Ali Abdullah Saleh , who has been in power for 30 years.

                              286 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                               Belfast Telegraph

                           December 1, 2010 Wednesday
                                 Derry Edition

Queen's students protest over fees

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 340 words


STUDENTS from Queen's University were among thousands across the UK to stage
protests against plans to hike tuition fees.

Up to 60 students were involved in the demonstration outside the
vice-Chancellor's office at the south Belfast campus yesterday.

The protest organised by the pressure group FEE (Free Education for Everybody)
began at around 1pm and ended peacefully after about three hours.

The students were seeking a meeting with vice-Chancellor Peter Gregson to
discuss fears about proposals to raise student fees to £9,000 a year.

Chris Donnelly (21), a first-year history student from Dungannon, was among the
protesters.

"We had a meeting on Monday night and decided to go down the protest route
against the vice-Chancellor Peter Gregson," he said.

"We are totally opposed to the Browne Review, which is the proposals to raise
the tuition fees up to £9,000.

"We came down to highlight that students at Queen's are resolutely opposed to
the rise in tuition fees.

"It was a peaceful protest, there has been no vandalism.

"It is a stewarded protest. Security guards are not allowing people outside the
building in."

QUB Students' Union president Gareth McGreevy, however, said it was an
independent protest.

"The Students' Union acknowledges the right for peaceful protest and the choice
to do so.

"The protest was independent to any action currently ongoing by QUBSU."

And Mr McGreevy added: "We will continue their campaign, as well as negotiating
with politicians, with the university, students and all stakeholders in relation
to the current higher education funding debate."

A spokesman for QUB said the protest ended quickly.

"There was small protest by a number of young people," the spokesman revealed.

"Professor Tony Gallagher, pro-vice-Chancellor, addressed the students, listened
to their concerns, and promised to report them back to the university's
management board."

CAPTION: Students unfurl a banner outside the vice-Chancellor's office at
Queen's University yesterday during their demonstration against cuts ARTHUR
ALLISON/PACEMAKER

                                Commercial Motor

                                 April 15, 2010

Pre-election fuel protests likely, warns TransAction

BYLINE: Christopher Walton

SECTION: THIS WEEK

LENGTH: 258 words


christopher.walton@rbi.co.uk

Pressure group Trans-Action has warned that a protest over the rising cost of
fuel could be staged close to next month's general election.

According to a statement on TransAction's website, "protests against the recent
2.5p/litre fuel duty and subsequent price rises are being co-ordinated around
the country", adding that many front-line organisers from the protests in 2000
are involved.

CM understands that interest in a fuel protest has been shown by a group of
haulage contractors in the North-East, as well as Farmers for Action, and
TransAction is conducting a survey of its members about potential protest
action.

Mike Presneill, MD of Presneill Tipper Contractors and spokesman for
TransAction, says that, given the current price of fuel and the level of duty, a
protest would be more than justified.

"Whatever we do would be legal protest action," he says. "People are indicating
that they have something in mind. Whatever it is would not be a re-run of what
we saw in 2007, with firms coming down to London."

Farmers for Action was unavailable for comment.

Geoff Dunning, chief executive of the Road Haulage Association, says it is
essential that fuel duty lobbying targets the right people in the next
government and voters should have a clearer idea of where the major parties
stood.

He adds: "Labour say they will increase duty over the next couple of years,
while the Tories want to introduce a Fair Fuel Stabiliser, which seems to have
some merits, but stabilising at what price?"

     ·    See p10 for more on fuel costs.

                        Gulf News (United Arab Emirates)

                            October 19, 2008 Sunday

Ruling and opposition groups stage protests

LENGTH: 255 words


Thiruvananthapuram:  Kerala's ruling Left Democratic Front government and the
opposition United Democratic Front both staged protest sit-ins on Friday,
creating a new record of sorts in political protests.

While chief minister V.S. Achuthananandan and his cabinet ministers staged their
protest in Delhi against what they called the 'neglect of the state' by the
United Progressive Alliance at the centre, the Congress-led opposition UDF
staged their protest here, calling the LDF protest in Delhi a farce.

Opposition leader Oommen Chandy, addressing fellow Congressmen who were
protesting here, said the LDF government's protest in Delhi was nothing but 'a
political gimmick'. He said the LDF government had no moral right to stage a
protest after having increased the burden on the common man in Kerala through a
series of price hikes.

Water and power tariff, milk price, apart from the cost of daily provisions and
vegetables in the state had gone up in recent months.

The chief minister and his cabinet colleagues are, however, blaming the centre
for the current predicament of the state. The protest in Delhi is aimed at
highlighting what the LDF government feels is an apathy towards the state by the
centre, particularly in slashing power and ration rice allocations, besides not
adequately compensating the state when natural calamities strike.

While the government and opposition were both holding protests, there was also
criticism regarding the use of public money by the ministers for their trip to
Delhi to stage the protest.

                                   Irish News

                                August 09, 2003

Jail visits cancelled over roof protest;

BYLINE: By Simon Doyle

SECTION:  Pg. 9

LENGTH: 366 words


VISITS to two wings of Maghaberry prison were cancelled yesterday as four
inmates continued their rooftop protest.

The Northern Ireland Office (NIO) said prison visits to Bush and Roe houses
could not go ahead yesterday while the protests took place.

However visits to other wings in the prison went ahead as normal.

Prisoners linked to the Real IRA and Continuity IRA are now in the fourth week
of a 'dirty protest' in a bid to win segregation from other inmates.

The latest rooftop protest continued as a British government-appointed review
team visited the jail as part of its inquiries into staff and inmates' safety
concerns.

Three inmates were still on the roof of Bush House and another was on the roof
of Roe House. The three on Bush House yesterday flew banners and waved to people
in the visitors' carpark.

Marian Price, of the Irish Republican Prisoners Welfare Association (IRPWA),
said she welcomed any protest that called for segregation at the jail but added
that she did not know if any of the protesters were dissident republicans.

The IRPWA was due to stage a protest in the centre of Coalisland, Co Tyrone,
yesterday to "raise awareness of the deteriorating situation at Maghaberry".

Meanwhile parts of Belfast city centre were sealed off yesterday morning as
police negotiated with a man who claimed that he was making a rooftop protest
about conditions at Maghaberry.

Police were informed that the man had climbed on top of the roof of a
threestorey building on the corner of Gresham Street and North Street at about
1.30am yesterday.

Witnesses claimed that the man removed a number of slates from the roof of the
premises and threw them to the ground.

Large crowds gathered outside Belfast Central Library as the Fire Service,
police and ambulance crews arrived at the scene.

Harold Noblett, of Noblett's on North Street, said the incident had angered many
city centre businesses.

"This has caused so much disruption in both this street and over a wider area.

There are a lot of people angry about this, " he said.

The man came down from the roof shortly after 9am and was arrested on suspicion
of attempted burglary.

                                The Toronto Star

                    July 30, 2003 Wednesday Ontario Edition

Peaceful protest always best

SECTION: LETTER; Pg. A21

LENGTH: 214 words


200 arrested at WTO protest

July 29.

As a society, we must support protest as a healthy expression of our Canadian
democracy. There exists a difference, however, between property destruction and
peaceful protest. I work on the same street that the protests occurred.

The assertion that violence against property is justified because the Gap is a
multinational corporation that runs sweatshops is fallacious. Leaders such as
Gandhi and Martin Luther King Jr. were popular practitioners and pioneers of the
so-called non-violent resistance movement. What happened to leaders such as
these in today's various protest movements?

While no one can lay claim to the same stature as the previous leaders, one must
ask: Is the leadership of their opponents too strong? The answer is no. The
leadership of the movements are weak. When the protest organizers allow the line
to be blurred between the healthy expression of democracy and the carnage of
surrounding buildings and vehicles, they put into question the very legitimacy
of many well-reputed protest groups, such as Greenpeace and Sierra Club.

That's too bad. Apparently, the protest groups that lay claim to the higher
moral ground have sacrificed it for negative press coverage.

John Gravel, Pierrefonds, Que.

LOAD-DATE: July 30, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 2003 Toronto Star Newspapers, Ltd.

                                  Toronto Star

                     June 16, 2001 Saturday Ontario Edition

Algeria

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A20

LENGTH: 208 words


PROTEST TOLL RISES

Algerian authorities yesterday raised the death toll from a massive
anti-government protest, saying four people were killed during the rioting on
Thursday. Journalists estimated up to 1 million people took part in the march.
The dead were all hit

by a bus fleeing a depot

that had been set on fire. About 365 people were injured.


PIRATE KIDNAPPERS

Hoping to rake in huge ransoms like those reportedly paid to Muslim guerrillas
in the Philippines, pirates have attacked several vessels and taken 15
Malaysians captive in recent days. "The pirates think they can also make big
money by holding people for ransom," Jalaluddin Abdul Rahman, deputy commander
of Malaysia's marine police, said yesterday.


MAD COW DESPITE BAN

British officials yesterday confirmed a case of mad-cow disease in an animal
born after controls on feed were introduced to eradicate the illness. The cow
was born May 27, 1997, almost 10 months after mammal meat and bone products were
banned from animal feed.


'NOISY' TEEN SHOT DEAD

A 72-year-old man shot dead a 14-year-old girl and wounded another because they
were "making noise" as they played in the courtyard by his window in Rio de
Janeiro, police said yesterday.

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                          September 29, 2016 Thursday
                              Business Day Edition

The limits of protest

SECTION: OPINION & EDITORIAL

LENGTH: 181  words


The limits of protest

The universities have to deal with protesting students in much the same way as a
company would deal with striking workers. The universities are faced with a
demand they can not accede to. There is nothing more that can be done by
negotiation.

Like strikers, the students have the constitutional right to protest. The right
only extends, however, to the person making the decision to protest. No one who
decides to protest may disrupt a lecture, threaten or force someone to protest.

At the point when the protest is no longer functional, and particularly when it
has forced the management to suspend operations, then the management must issue
the protesting students with ultimatums. Management may demand that all students
return to lectures by a proposed date and cease their protest. Those who choose
not to abide by the ultimatum must leave the university campus and residences.
If they don't, they can be arrested and face charges.

There is no inalienable right to protest in any manner the individual deems fit.

Sara Gon

Research Fellow, SA Institute of Race Relations

LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2016 BDFM Publishers PTY Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                                  My Republica

                             April 22, 2016 Friday

Federal Alliance unveils protest programs

LENGTH: 303 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, April 22 -- The Federal Alliance, a loose coalition of the agitating
seven Madhes-based parties and other ethnic political parties, on Friday
unveiled its future protest programs.

According to the protest plan, the alliance will picket Singha Durbar, the main
administrative building of the country, on May 14.

The meeting of the alliance held at the Tinkune-based central party office of
the Federal Socialist Forum Nepal (FSFN) on Friday decided to resume its
protests from the last week of April and unveiled protest programs to be held
over a period of 15 days. The protests will be organized in all three
geographical regions --Tarai, Hill and Mountain.

As per the protest plan, the alliance will submit protest note on April 27 and
put up black flags at government offices on April 29.

Likewise, protest assemblies will be held in Butwal, Panchthar, Rautahat,
Birgunj, Nepalgunj, Janakpur, Palpa, Illam, Surkhet, Dhangadhi, among other
districts.

After organizing five months long protest programs in Tarai to express
dissatisfaction over the content of the new constitution, the United Democratic
Madhesi Front (UDMF) made a broader alliance with other ethnic political parties
to form the Federal Alliance and announced the nation-wide protest programs.

"It is necessary to inform people from the hills on how and why the constitution
has discriminated against the marginalized people. The UDMF has not only been
raising the issues of Madhes but also the common issues of marginalized people
whether they are from the hills or the mountains," said Upendra Yadav, the
chairman of the Federal Socialist Forum Nepal.

                                  My Republica

                            April 13, 2016 Wednesday

Fresh protests sans border blockade: Mahato

LENGTH: 189 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, April 13 -- As United Democratic Madhesi Front (UDMF) has warned of
fresh rounds of protests, one of the influential leaders of the front said that
the fresh protests will not include border blockade.

Speaking at an interaction program in the capital on Wednesday, UDMF leader
Rajendra Mahato said that the fresh protests starting this Monday sans border
blockades.

"We will not stage any protests that affects the lives of normal people ,"
Mahato added, "However, our fresh protests will be Singhadurbar-centric."

He also claimed that the fresh protests will be a nationwide not just in Madhes
districts. "The fresh protests will be focused on piling pressure on the
government not the citizens," he said.

Mahato said the earlier protests that include border blockade fail to address
people's demands but rather affected the normal lives of the people.

"We will keep on protesting unless the government heeds our demands," Mahato
warned.

                                Vanguard (Lagos)

                                 March 25, 2015

Anti-Jega Protest - Adams Defends OPC Lagos Rally

LENGTH: 281 words


LAGOS--Barely eight days, after its controversial protest in Lagos, for the
removal of Chairman, Independent National Electoral Commission, INEC, Prof.
Attahiru Jega, the Convener, Coalition of Concerned Nigerians, CCN and National
Coordinator, Oodua Peoples Congress, OPC, Otunba Gani Adams, Tuesday, fired back
at the All Progressives Congress, APC, saying his members never destroyed the
party's campaign bill boards and posters as claimed.

Since that protest which saw members of the OPC and other pro-Jonathan groups
marching from the 7up bus-stop of old toll gate along the Lagos-Ibadan
Expressway to the National Stadium in Surulere, several APC chieftains have
repeatedly accused the ruling Peoples Democratic Party, PDP, of plot to use the
OPC to forment trouble in Lagos before, during and after the March 28 and April
11 elections.

It is against this backdrop that the OPC leader, at an interactive session on
the general election, in Lagos, lashed out at the APC, saying the photograph
shown by one of the major television stations in its reportage of the protest
was a file photo of a protest rally by the Dr. Fredrick Fasehun-led OPC to
protest a threat by Boko Haram to attack the west on December 12, 2011.

Adams also described allegations that the OPC has been paid to disrupt
Saturday's election as a long list of fallacious and unsubstantiated allegations
against his person by the propaganda arm of the APC.

He said: "Our protest on March 16, 2015 was very peaceful. Against the claim by
the APC that that protest was violent, I stand here to tell you that since the
June 12, 1993 protest, that protest was one of the most peaceful protests I have
ever witnessed in Nigeria."

DATELINE: KARACHI


To show its street power, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf has announced to stage a

anti-government sit-in in front of Parliament House.

Karachi, rallies/sit-ins would be staged in Faisalabad's Zila Council Chowk,
Multan's Nawan Shehr Chowk, and Lahore to start with.

Shara-e-Faisal is one of the main thoroughfares in the metropolis and most of
the national and multinational companies' offices, schools, shopping plazas,
banks, and institutes are close to it.

                                Himalayan Times

                           October 2, 2013 Wednesday

Airline operators plan to intensify protest

BYLINE: HIMALAYAN NEWS SERVICE

LENGTH: 255  words


KATHMANDU: Airline Operators Association of Nepal (AOAN) has planned to further
intensify its protest programme as the government has failed to address its
demand to reduce the recent hike in the aviation fuel charge for domestic
airlines.

"Today is the fourth day of our protest programme and we will announce our new
protest programme on October 4," said spokesperson of AOAN Ghanshyam Acharya.
According to him, the future course of action will be more strict and it will
carry on with its protests unless the government fulfils its demand.

The Ministry of Culture, Tourism, and Civil Aviation has requested AOAN to
withdraw its protest programme. However, representatives from AOAN said that
they will not withdraw their programme and instead intensify the protest.

"The tourism ministry recently issued a formal request letter, asking AOAN to
withdraw its entire protest programme, but we are not going to withdraw our
programme unless our demands are fulfilled," said Acharya. The executive meeting
of AOAN, on September 26, had announced a series of protest programmes, which
started from September 29 at all airline operator's offices.

As part of the protest, staff of domestic airline companies have already started
wearing a black ribbon at work. According to AOAN, the tourism ministry had
failed to address the issues regarding the increase in the aviation fuel price.

On September 11, the committee had submitted a memorandum to the ministry
requesting it to take back the decision of the recent fuel price hike within 15
days.

                              300 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                            Cihan News Agency (CNA)

                              July 29, 2013 Monday

Half of Turks believe Gezi protests were aimed at creating chaos in society

LENGTH: 409  words


ISTANBUL (CIHAN)- Half of the respondents of a recent public survey said they
believe the demonstrations that began in late May in protest of government plans
to demolish Gezi Park in Istanbul's Taksim Square were intended to create
disorder in society and create trouble for the government.



The survey, conducted by the Pollmark polling company, showed that 51.2 percent
of respondents believe the goal of the demonstrations was to create chaos in
society and put the government in a difficult position, while 33.3 percent said
they think the demonstrators were exercising their democratic rights in the
protests and that they support them.

Pollmark's survey was carried out between July 9 and 18 through face-to-face
interviews with 5,135 people. The results of the survey, which were published in
the Sabah daily on Monday, were also presented to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip
Erdogan, according to the daily.

A full 51.5 percent of respondents said they believe the police did not use
excessive force against demonstrators during the protests, while 39.5 percent
disagreed with that statement.

The protests that began in Taksim spread nationwide after the police forcibly
ejected protesters from the park. Five people including a policeman were killed
and thousands of others were injured during the weeks of protests.

Among those surveyed, 48.6 percent said they were disturbed that the
demonstrators had turned protests that began out of environmental concerns into
anti-government protests, while 31,8 percent said the demonstrations had a just
cause.

When asked about their views on how the government managed the protests, 42.2
percent said the government managed the Gezi protests well and 41.2 voiced the
opposite view.

With regard to the support given by the Republican People's Party (CHP) to the
protesters, 59.4 percent said they disapprove while 26.4 percent they approve
the CHP's support for the protests.

To another question asking about the general performance of the government, 55.7
percent said they find it successful; 37.3 percent said it is not successful.

When asked for which party they would vote if general elections were held today,
51.9 percent responded that they would vote for the ruling Justice and
Development Party (AK Party), 23.5 percent said for the CHP and 13.6 percent
said for the Nationalist Movement Party (MHP), while 7.4 percent said for the
pro-Kurdish Peace and Democracy Party (BDP).

(Cihan/Today's Zaman) CIHAN

                              Herald (Goa) (India)

                           February 2, 2013 Saturday

Cavelossim protest not lodged as per GFA rules, insists Vasco

LENGTH: 793 words

DATELINE: PANJIM


PANJIM, Feb. 2 -- There is no question of upholding Cavelossim's protest against
Vasco Club on the question of fielding the alleged ineligible player in their
Goa Professional League match in November last, since the protest was not lodged
as per the official rules of the competition, divulged a Vasco club official,
here, Friday.

The GFA's Executive Committee had relied on Articles 18, 19 and 20 in deciding
that the player fielded by Vasco was not eligible to play for them. However,
Vasco pointed out that Article 18 itself states: "Protest against the
eligibility of any player(s) shall be lodged according to Articles 40 and 41 by
the protesting team with the zonal secretary/match commissioner or his duly
appointed representative or the GFA office at Panjim accompanied by a protest
fee of Rs 1000."

Vasco stressed that Cavelossim had contravened Article 40 and had instead lodged
the protest one day after the match. Article 40 - signing match report from by
teams - reads: "After the conclusion of every match in the official
competitions, the captains of both the teams or the managers of both the teams
shall sign on the referee's match report form, indicating therein whether they
intend to protest the result of the match. If the team expresses the desire to
protest the manager shall also briefly specify the reasons for lodging the
protest. When intention to protest has been expressed by a team
captain/manager/official as detailed in this Article, the referee of the match
shall take immediate steps to ensure that his match report is received by the
zonal secretary/organizing secretary/match commissioner with 24 hours from the
time of conclusion of the concerned match. Failure to do so will make the
referee liable to suspension of upto three years."

Then, Article 41 talks about lodging of protest - "Intention to protest having
been expressed under the stipulation of Article 40, the concerned team must
compulsorily follow up by submitting the protest in resume to the general
secretary, GFA/zonal secretary/organizing secretary before the closure of the
GFA office on the next day of the match. The resume shall further be confirmed
with a formal protest lodged in writing, accompanied by a protest fee of Rs 1000
and hand delivered to GFA secretariat in Panjim not later than 24 hours after
the conclusion of the concerned match.

The Vasco Club official emphasized also on Article 42 - protest null and void.
"Intention to protest not having been indicated on the referee's match report
form, or resume of protest not having been lodged within the specified time
limit, shall each jointly or severally render the protest null and void, and it
shall be rejected outright by the Executive Committee."

Since Cavelossim did not show their intention to protest in the first place,
there is no question of the protest even being entertained, argued the Vasco
Club official.

Having also indicated that one had also to go by previous judgements and
well-established precedents, the Vasco official remarked that under Article 3 -
spirit and principle - "The official competitions are governed in spirit and
principle by the laws of the game and Statutes and Rules and regulations of
FIFA, AIFF and GFA."

Doubts have also been expressed as to why the protest was referred to the
Players Status Committee as Article 19 - decision on ineligible players -
states: "Protest under Article 18 shall be decided finally by the Executive
Committee or by a sub-committee which has been appointed by the GFA under
provisions of GFA Constitution. The Players Status Committee is a duly formed
sub-committee and as such, it was asked to take up the matter. But yesterday, it
was the Executive Committee that decided on the matter at the extraordinary
meeting as the Players Status Committee decided that it was an administrative
matter.

Obviously, the matter involves legalities and one can now understand better why
every club needs to have a legal division as part of the professional
administrative set-up. Even matters concerning the contract with the players
demand a legal outlook, as it is now being pointed out that there cannot be
five-month contracts with the players.

In any case, like what the AFC has been demanding from I-League clubs, all our
local clubs will also have ultimately to follow some licencing criteria at the
State level, at least for Pro League, in as much as there cannot be a football
club without a minimum football ground/stadia with an administrative set-up at
least. That's the way for introducing professionalism in a gradual manner.
Published by HT Syndication with permission from Herald Goa. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: February 3, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2013 Herald Publications Pvt. Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                           Free Press Journal (India)

                                January 24, 2013

'Successful use of nonviolent protest not held after Gandhi, Vinoba and
Jayprakash'

BYLINE: FP NEWS SERVICE Ujjain

LENGTH: 322  words


Ujjain: Government elected through peaceful ways has right to throttle public
protest by using violent ways. Non- violence should be considered as a means in
honest public protest. We should understand the limits of nonviolent public
protest. It is required that leaders of protests should have principle
expression of non- violence.

Mass heroes should follow the principles of allegiance along with non-
violence.. This was expressed by chief guest senior journalist Shravan Garg
during the valedictory ceremony of two- day national seminar on ' Public
Protests in India and Their Limitations' organised at Gandhi Hall of Madhav
College here on Wednesday. Garg said non- violent protest could run for longer
time and one couls not fight with the state and the government with violence.

There should have right direction of protests. Maoists have been creating terror
in 83 districts of nine states of the nation. Hundreds of soldiers are
victimised by this kind of violence.

Public expects transition. Anna Hazare and Arvind Kejariwal can not bring
transition in the nation. There are Jain seers who keep fast for days more than
Anna does.

Special guest Vikas Dave said blood reloaded with feelings of public protests
runs in our veins. Movement of emergency was a massive protest after
Independence. 35 justices were directly related with this and all opposition
parties. Today we need such kind of movements.

Chairing the valedictory ceremony, Dr Satish Gaud said why we need public
protests in democratic countries? When constitutional institutions, parliament,
government, political parties, peoples' representatives are unable to fulfill
their responsibilities, then the public has to launch protests.

Seminar director Prof Brahmdeep Alune conducted the programme while Dr Mahendra
Kumar Jain proposed the vote of thanks.

Senior Journalist Shravan Garg addressing during concluding ceremony of National
Seminar in Ujjain on Wednesday.

accelerate their protest circle.

still not taken any step to regularize their services. The Laghari community

                              304 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                            BBC Monitoring Kiev Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           November 17, 2011 Thursday

Ukrainian think-tank says social protests gaining momentum

LENGTH: 423 words


Text of report by private Ukrainian news agency UNIAN

Kiev, 17 November: Socioeconomic protests in Ukraine are turning into a mass
country-wide campaign with sharp criticism of the authorities, an analytical
review received by the UNIAN news agency read.

The report read that the authorities' reaction to the protest is also changing,
according to a repressive scenario. The most popular response by the state was
detention and arrest. Court bans on rallies were also often used and police
hindered protest attempts.

At the same time, the vast majority of protests (87 per cent) over the last
month were carried out in an absolutely legal and peaceful way - in the form of
rallies, pickets, marches, demonstrations and tent cities. Compared to the data
for the first 12 months of monitoring, the share of confrontational actions
(clashes, storming [of buildings], road blocking etc) was much smaller, 7 per
cent compared to 26 per cent. Only 6 per cent of protests in October this year
could be classified as use of force (these were mostly scuffles).

The analytical review read that, while citizens most always protested in a
peaceful way, the state often used repressive measures against them. For
instance, there were 14 repressive actions per 100 protests. However, in the
first 12 months of monitoring [September 2009-September 2010] this ratio was 12
out of 100.

In response to the exacerbation of social problems in Ukraine and an increase in
antagonism between the [ruling and working] classes, the authorities resort to
use of force more frequently. "According to this litmus paper, it is not
difficult to see whose problems they are solving and the interests of which
class they are defending. Paraphrasing a well-known proverb, when the ruling
class does not take interest in the life of ordinary people, then ordinary
people take interest in the life of oligarchs," the review read.

When calculating the number of protests, every day of multi-day protests was
calculated as a separate protest. The results on the number of protests and
repression could slightly change, because the media report about some protests
with a delay.

The centre for society studies is an independent non-profit research centre for
social problems and mass protests.

The centre registered all protests since September 2009, positive or negative
reaction by the state or other objects of protests in Ukraine on the basis of
regular monitoring of about 170 national, regional and activists' media.

Source: UNIAN news agency, Kiev, in Ukrainian 1108 gmt 17 Nov 11

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                                  My Republica

                             March 15, 2016 Tuesday

15-party alliance to announce protests from mid-April

LENGTH: 150 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, March 15 -- An alliance of 15 political parties demanding
identity-based provincial demarcation has decided to launch fresh protests to
pile pressure on the government to address their demands.

A meeting of the parties held at Federal Socialist Forum Nepal (FSFN) party
office in Tinkune, decided to launch nationwide protests from mid-April, FSFN
vice chairman Rajendra Shrestha said.

The protests will be similar to People's Movement in 2006, Shrestha said.

"The protests will be named as joint protests and will appeal all Madhesi,
janajatis and ethnic communities to participate in the protests," he added.

He further said that the protests will not cover a particular region but the
whole nation.

                               Egypt Independent

                           December 16, 2014 Tuesday

Minister justifies protest law because it was 'enacted a century ago'

BYLINE: Al-Masry Al-Youm

LENGTH: 227  words


Interim Justice Minister Ibrahim al-Heneidy has expressed his approval on the
protest law arguing, "It was enforced one century ago."

In an interview on Monday aired on the privately-owned Al-Hayah TV channel, the
minister justified the protest law, saying it is similar to Western countries,
the same ones that have decried the law."Many countries like France and US have
similar laws to organize protests. Its peoples agree on them," he added.

Though France and the United States have some laws regulating protests, they are
not as sweeping as the Egyptian protest law as they do not require permission
for all protests, nor do they effectively criminalize demonstrating without
permission.

Heneidy said there was a difference between organizing protests and confiscating
the right of protesting, which will not happen.

Recommendations by the National Council for Human Rights (NCHR) over amending
the law were considered, the minister said adding that they were sent to cabinet
for approval.

The law on terrorist entities have been concluded by the ministry, he said. It
will be submitted to the State Council. The law will be applied on whoever
resort to violence to promote specific ideas. It also stipulates seizure of
assets of terrorist entities, closing its headquarters and preventing its member
from practicing policy.

Edited translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                            November 28, 2014 Friday

No police permission, but Kiss of Love will go on

SECTION: BENGALURU

LENGTH: 401 words


BENGALURU: Calling the Bengaluru police decision not allow the Kiss of Love
campaign against moral policing undemocratic, the organizers have decided to go
ahead with the protest.

"We refuse to be moral-policed about how we should carry out our protest against
moral policing. Denying us permission citing the mode and name of the protest is
questioning our right to protest," said a statement released by the campaigners
to media.

"We are moving forward with the protest, and expect every single person who
would like to express his solidarity with voices against moral policing to
gather there with us," the organizers said. They had sought permission to hold
the protest near Town Hall. They said they have been given no letter stating the
reasons for refusal of permission. Terming "baseless" the claim of the police
commissioner that details of the protest were not provided to police, they said
details about the time, date and venue were given well in advance.

They pointed out that one of the grounds for denial of permission was that Kiss
of Love sounds sensational. Kiss of Love protests have taken place in Kochi,
IIT-Bombay, Hyderabad, Calcutta, Puducherry, Delhi and Chennai.

"We refuse to the change of name of the movement. In this democratic country,
it's our right to choose the mode and form of protest and, most importantly, the
name of the protest as long as it falls within the boundaries of our
Constitution and law," the campaigners said.

The protest is against moral policing and cultural fascism, they said. "We
strongly believe that there is nothing obscene in this form of protest and would
like to keep in mind the judgments passed by the Honorable Supreme Court and the
Delhi High Court on cases pertaining to public display of affection.

"As Kiss of Love is a movement formed through a Facebook collective, and has
been organized by a group of volunteers, a single person cannot take
responsibility for the protest. We are willing and ready to take responsibility
as a group," they said.

'FOR TOLERANCE'

* This is not just a protest for the right to kiss in public places. We need to
open up spaces in this rigid society to make it tolerant towards expression of
love in public spaces, be it between siblings, lovers or parents with children.

* A single person cannot take responsibility for the protest. We are willing to
take responsibility as a group.

                              312 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              July 7, 2014 Monday

Macedonian commentary urges social media not to fuel tension after protests

LENGTH: 551 words


Text of report by Macedonian newspaper Dnevnik on 7 July

[Commentary by Igor K. Ilievski: "Protests after which everyone cries even
without teargas"]

Bloody heads, broken windows, a dozen injured, hundreds of crying people... This
is the initial outcome of the protests held over the "Monster" case ruling. This
is the overall result of the three days of larger or smaller, violent or
peaceful protests.

The organization of the protests has so far been attributed to "the social
networks." Official Tirana and Pristina have distanced themselves from the
protests, saying that they treat them "as of religious, rather than of ethnic or
national background." The Albanian and Kosovo Governments believe that the
protests were mostly Islamist because of the prevailing shouts and flags and
that the demonstrators had been abused by "elements and people of religious
background."

There is no protest that cannot be abused for whatever reasons, from filling
"the front line" with juveniles, which is the most usual and most available
"cannon fodder" during every protest, to sending out radical religious and
nationalist messages through the protesters gathered under the motto of justice
and truth.

The ruling DUI [Democratic Union for Integration - BDI in Albanian], too, has
distanced itself from the protests and has appealed to the indictees' families,
who are dissatisfied with the verdict, to resume the legal battle at the Appeals
and Supreme Courts, and even the Strasbourg court. This should be the road that
they should take to win a battle against a court ruling.

Still, this should not be done on the streets with stones, teargas, let alone
nationalist and religious ornaments. Even the demonstrators who protested in
Struga, Kicevo, and Gostivar yesterday condemned the violence of their Skopje
and Tetovo "fellow fighters."

The last thing that we currently need is a certain "Commander Panther of
the112th Brigade" to protect the Albanian nation and repeat the 2001 conflict
with even greater bloodshed.

Such protests and statements bring no good. At this point calm and cool heads
are required on "the social networks," too. There is always one side that is
dissatisfied with a verdict, but there are mechanisms to resume this process.
This is the right of every side, just as everyone has the right to protest, for
whatever reason. Still, what if those who believe that the court has reached the
right verdict use their right to protest, too, and go out to defend the court
from pressure? If the protests against the court ruling were large-scale,
imagine how large would be this protest. How would such a protest look like with
the opponent to the ruling on the one side and the court protectors on the
other, with a police buffer zone in the middle? What would be the degree of risk
under such circumstances? Is this the goal of "the social networks"?

Discontent should be expressed peacefully on the streets. Otherwise, the thing
that started as seeking justice will be transformed into something completely
different with incredibly high speed. One hot head and one stone hurled would
suffice to make the peaceful protests a battlefield. Is this the objective of
these protests?

After such protests, everyone will be crying, but not from teargas.

Source: Dnevnik, Skopje, in Macedonian 7 Jul 14 p 11

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript


                Copyright 2014 British Broadcasting Corporation
                              All Rights Reserved


                              313 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                           The Herald (South Africa)

                           September 17, 2013 Tuesday

Lack of water service delivery angers all

BYLINE: Schalk Mouton

SECTION: SOCIAL ISSUES

LENGTH: 380 words


IF there is one thing that makes South Africans stand together more than
anything else, it is the lack of water service delivery.
 As protests across the country spike, the preliminary findings of a study by
the Institute for Poverty, Land and Agrarian Studies (Plaas), show that rich,
poor, black and white all stand together in showing their dissatisfaction with
poor water management and infrastructure in the country.


 Dr Barbara Tapela, senior researcher in integrated water resources management
at Plaas, said service delivery protests related to water were becoming more
frequent and more violent, but taxpayers' dissatisfaction did not always show in
the form of protests.
 "Last year, the frequency, geographical spread and violence of social protests
in post-apartheid South Africa reached unprecedented levels," Tapela said.
"Water service delivery issues rose in prominence among various reasons cited
for violent and non- violent protests."
 Tapela said while violent protests were increasing among disadvantaged groups,
more and more taxpayers were declaring disputes with municipalities and
withholding taxes.
 "It is a vote of no confidence in their municipalities' ability to deliver
services, so they withhold their tax money and pay it into a trust to pay
private contractors for services," Tapela said.
 In 2009, 220 branches of the National Taxpayers' Union (NTU) in towns situated
in 47 municipalities, declared disputes with their respective municipalities,
with members withholding their tax money.
  The number of disputes due to poor service delivery increased to 278 towns in
the same 47 municipalities this year. "They fall into a category of non-violent
protest, where they choose to use institutionalised ways of protesting," she
said.
 According to the Service Delivery Protest Barometer, compiled by the Multilevel
Government Initiative, service delivery protests had increased exponentially
since 2008, with violent protests in the past two years increasing by more than
100% compared to 2007.
 Even in cases where the protests were not service delivery-related - like the
De Doorns farm worker protests - Tapela said like the 20 other factors that
caused the particular protest, the lack of water and sanitation was usually the
main driver of such protests.

LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: Herald


                    Copyright 2013 BDFM Publishers PTY Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              Daily Regional Times

                             June 6, 2013 Thursday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

BYLINE:  Younis Chandio and Jani Khaskheli

SECTION: Vol. VIII No. 156

LENGTH: 216  words


Different protest demonstrations were recorded by people in favor of their
demands outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Wednesday.

According to details, the employees of the Food Department Hyderabad led by
Ghulam Mustafa Memon recorded a protest demonstration against the District Food
Controller. They accused the District Food Controller of corruption and demanded
an enquiry against him. The employees of the Baldia City Hyderabad recorded a
protest demonstration for the issuance of their withheld salaries.

The students of O level recorded a protest demonstration against the authorities
of the BISE Hyderabad for conducting the papers of different subjects from them
once again. A man named Muhammad Urs Jatoi, resident of GOR Colony staged a
protest demonstration for the recovery of his cousin named Hafil Jatoi, who was
allegedly arrested by the police one month ago. The Lashari community people,
residents of Khorwah recorded a protest demonstration against the actions of
their area's landlord named Allah Dino Chandio, The activists of the MQM
Hyderabad led by Muhammad Sharif recorded a protest demonstration against the
murder of their party leaders in Karachi. The contract based employees of the
SBCA Hyderabad staged a protest demonstration for the regularization of their
services.

                              315 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                             Star of Mysore (India)

                              March 9, 2012 Friday

CITY COPS PROTEST

LENGTH: 324 words

DATELINE: Mysore


ysore, March 9 -- Perhaps for the first time in recent history, the Police
personnel, who are entrusted the responsibility of restoring peace, harmony, law
and order, registered their protest in city this morning by performing their
duties wearing black bands on their left arms.

They were protesting against the alleged assault on some cops by advocates at
the Civil Court premises in Bangalore on Mar. 2, during which a number of
Policemen were grievously injured.

Interestingly, today's protest by Policemen in city comes after a day when
families of the injured Police personnel staged a protest at Bangalore
yesterday.

Metagalli Inspector H.M. Mahadevappa, speaking to Star of Mysore, said that
their protest has been prompted by the heinous attack on Policemen in Bangalore
and maintained that the cops had no other option but to protest even while
discharging their duties.

"Just as people from other walks of life need protection, we too need
protection," he said and urged for an early solution to the issue.

Constable Revappa, who said that the protest was symbolic, wondered how the
situation would be if Police personnel resorted to protests as done by other
organisations, which would result in total chaos and lack of safety for
citizens.

Protest called off: The protest which was taken up by city Police was, however,
called off at noon following instructions from DG&IGP Shankar Bidari who
instructed the striking cops to withdraw their symbolic protest.

City advocates boycott court: A large number of justice-seeking members of the
public who had reached the city court premises to attend their cases were left
in the lurch as advocates continued to boycott the proceedings in city courts.

It is learnt that following a meeting, the office-bearers of the Mysore Bar
Association have gone to Bangalore to join in the agitation launched by
advocates in the State capital. Published by HT Syndication with permission from
Star of Mysore.

                              316 of 995 DOCUMENTS


               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                            December 30, 2011 Friday
                                National Edition

Global protests and a new lexicon

BYLINE: Megan O'Toole, National Post

SECTION: CANADA; Pg. A6

LENGTH: 504  words


From Cairo to Calgary, hordes of average citizens flooded public streets and
camped out in central squares this year. Some toppled dictators, or shed their
own blood trying. Others strummed guitars in an amorphous critique of
capitalism.

While the scope varied dramatically from the Arab Spring to Occupy Wall Street
and related protests, each movement reflected a groundswell against the status
quo.

"Protest actions this year displayed a deeper, more trenchant critique of the
failures of the global economy that separates them from more transient marches
or demonstrations," noted T.V. Reed, a professor of English and American studies
at Washington State University and author of The Art of Protest. "Occupying a
site, whether it be Tahrir Square or Zuccotti Park, symbolizes a long-term
commitment and a long-range strategy."

The cascade of political protests was touched off late last year after a
downtrodden Tunisian vegetable salesman set himself ablaze. Images of protest
soon bounced around the world in realtime.

When North Americans witnessed Arab Spring protesters willing to die for regime
change, noted Timothy McCarthy, director of the human rights and social
movements program at the Harvard Kennedy School's Carr Center for Human Rights
Policy, some responded with self-reproach: "How dare we not do the same thing?"

"The Arab Spring not only inspired us," Mr. McCarthy said, "in some cases, it
shamed us into a kind of political activism that we haven't seen in this country
really since the '60s."

The concept of seeking change by occupying public space is not new, but what was
unique in 2011 was the rapidity by which one revolution fed into another.
Protesters in the Arab world were emboldened by the perceived successes of their
neighbours, while Occupy participants took motivation from both the Spanish
Indignados' call for a new form of participatory democracy and the fierce
determination of rage-fuelled Egyptians reclaiming their streets.

Whether in Toronto or Tunis, protesters' physical encampments demanded a
response from the powers that be. "One way or the other, it's a very powerful
way of forcing attention, forcing access to the people in power. They have to do
something," said Bert Klandermans, the Amsterdam-based president of the
International Society of Political Psychology.

In some cases, most notably the falls of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali in Tunisia and
Hosni Mubarak in Egypt, protesters succeeded in achieving a singular demand. In
others, such as the Occupy encampments across Canada and the United States,
there was no obvious victory. But there was a dramatic reshaping of public
discourse, noted Megan Boler, associate chair of theory and policy studies at
the University of Toronto's Ontario Institute for Studies in Education. "The
entire vocabulary and lexicon of the public and of the news and of the media has
changed, so that slogans like 1% and 99% have a new meaning and are used
frequently," Prof. Boler said.

National Post motoole@nationalpost.com twitter.com/megan_otoole

LOAD-DATE: December 30, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2011 National Post
                              All Rights Reserved

                               The New York Times

                            March 19, 2011 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

In Syria, Crackdown After Protests

BYLINE: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 401 words


DAMASCUS, Syria -- Protests broke out in four Syrian cities on Friday, the first
large-scale demonstrations here since the pro-democracy uprisings began in the
Arab world three months ago. Brutal police crackdowns followed, leaving six
people dead and scores injured.

In the largest protests, several thousand people gathered in the center of
Dara'a, in southern Syria, chanting ''God, Syria and freedom only,'' witnesses
said. They demanded the resignation of the mayor and the leader of the local
branch of the security police. The police later opened fire on the crowd,
killing six, the witnesses said.

There were also protests in Banias, on the Mediterranean coast; in the central
city of Homs; and here, in the capital. A Facebook page, ''the Syrian revolution
2011,'' has called on people to protest against corruption and repression.

Antigovernment protests are virtually unknown in Syria, a police state where
political opposition has been brutally suppressed in the past.

Small protests in the capital on Tuesday and Wednesday were violently dispersed
by the authorities, who arrested scores of demonstrators. The state news
service, SANA, dismissed those protests as the work of outside agitators.

It reprised that explanation on Friday, saying on its Web site that after some
citizens gathered in front of the Omari Mosque in Dara'a, ''some outsiders
exploited the situation and caused chaos, damaging public and private
properties.''

The protest in Dara'a arose in part from the arrest earlier this month of about
20 youths who had written graffiti complaining about the high cost of living and
calling for more freedoms.

Videos posted on YouTube show the security services trying to disperse the crowd
with water cannons. The situation escalated later, a witness said.

''They used live ammunition immediately, no tear gas or anything else,'' said
the witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

In Damascus, a crowd at the Ummayad Mosque tried to march, chanting ''God, Syria
and Bashar only,'' but were charged and beaten by a pro-government group,
witnesses said. About 30 were arrested.

In Homs, about 2,000 protesters gathered in front of the Khaled bin al Waleed
mosque. That group too was assaulted, and arrests followed. In Banias, a similar
group numbered in the hundreds; soon afterward, all entrances to the city were
closed, said a lawyer from Banias who also spoke on condition of anonymity.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

demonstration against Habib Group Farms.

                              319 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             June 7, 2006 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

County gets 250 of 10,000 expected protests so far

BYLINE: MATT OLBERDING, Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: A; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 339 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, NE


Bulk of valuation protests usually comes at end of June, county official says.

Despite the uproar over Lancaster County property valuations, only a few hundred
protests have been filed so far.

Chief Deputy County Clerk Trish Owen said her office had received only about 250
protests as of Tuesday afternoon.

That doesn't seem like a lot, considering valuation notices have been out for a
week and the county expects 10,000 or more protests, but Owen said it's pretty
much par for the course this early in the process.

"Historically, we've always had the bulk of (the protests) the last week of
June."

Owen said there's been a steady stream of people coming into her office to pick
up the protest forms, which also can be downloaded at
www.lincoln.ne.gov/cnty/clerk/pvpform.htm.

That includes one developer who asked for 1,000 protest forms, she said.

Owen declined to name the developer, because the person hasn't filed any
protests yet.

Some people who are planning to protest may be doing research to be prepared.

County Assessor Norm Agena said that from Memorial Day through Friday, his
office's Web site had more than 1 million hits. That kind of usage was causing
the system to be unavailable often, a problem that continued Tuesday.

Agena's office also discovered a problem with the valuation notices themselves:
Because of a computer coding error, nearly 900 never got sent.

Those 897 notices have been mailed, and Agena said those property owners will
have 30 days from the day they receive them to file a valuation protest.
Everyone else must file a protest by June 30.

Among those who received valuation notices and who have filed a protest is
Lancaster County Sheriff Terry Wagner, whose south Lincoln home's value rose
$71,000.

Wagner said he was a little hesitant to file a protest because of his position
as an elected official, but he recently had a private appraisal done on his home
that produced a value considerably less than what the assessor's office
determined.

Reach Matt Olberding at 473-2647 or molberding@journalstar.com.

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                       May 28, 2004 Friday Final Edition

Lebanon: Protests turn violent, leaving five dead

SOURCE: CanWest News Service

SECTION: News; Pg. A8

LENGTH: 63 words

Demonstrators set fire to the Labour Ministry yesterday, after Lebanese soldiers
shot and killed five people and wounded 12 others during protests against the
government's economic policies, security and hospital officials said. A civil
defence firefighter also died in hospital after being hit by gunfire in what was
Lebanon's worst violence involving civilians in a decade.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                           November 9, 2016 Wednesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

World briefs: Taxi drivers protest against Uber in Brazil's capital

BYLINE:  From news services

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A25

LENGTH: 696 words


Brazilian taxi drivers protest Uber service

Taxi drivers from around Brazil staged a protest in the capital Tuesday against
the presence of Uber, demanding that it be prohibited.

More than 1,000 drivers, many in their vehicles, showed up in front of Congress
in a particularly colorful protest, with many taxis painted different colors for
various Brazilian cities.

The drivers called on Congress to ban the U.S.-based company from operating in
Latin America's largest nation. Many taxi drivers complain that Uber has led to
big drops in their incomes as customers use the Uber app to find cheaper rides
from private drivers.

Uber is currently in a handful of Brazil's largest cities, including Sao Paulo,
Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia. The company has said it views Brazil and other
parts of Latin America as growth areas.

Ebola exposure feared in Canadian lab - An employee at Canada's National Centre
for Foreign Animal Disease may have been exposed to the Ebola virus.

Dr. John Copps said Tuesday the employee was working with six infected pigs
Monday and noticed a split in the seam of his protective suit during
decontamination after working in the Level 4 lab in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

The lab director says the risk to the employee, co-workers and the community is
considered to be low.

The employee met with a doctor and was offered an experimental Ebola vaccine.
Officials, citing privacy, wouldn't say whether he received the vaccine.

The employee is in isolation and will be monitored for 21 days by local health
officials.

Gangs may be targeting police, soldiers - Authorities in El Salvador have
increased their vigilance in an effort to protect their own against gang
attacks.

Vice President Oscar Ortiz says the government has decided to raise the alert
level for all 23,000 police officers and soldiers. Members of each group have
been targeted, most often while on leave. A national police officer and a
soldier were killed in separate incidents Tuesday.

So far this year, 39 police officers, 19 soldiers and a prison guard have been
killed. Last year, gangs killed 62 police, 17 soldiers and six prison guards.

Ortiz says security forces are paying a high price in their fight against the El
Salvador's powerful gangs, but the government will continue the fight.

Bolivians take part in skull festival - Hundreds of Bolivians have carried human
skulls adorned with flowers to a cemetery in the capital city of La Paz, asking
for health, money, love and other favors.

The devotees brought skulls known as "natitas" for a short Mass at the cemetery
Tuesday. They later played music and lit candles. Others took skulls into a La
Paz home as part of the ritual celebrated a week after the Day of the Dead.

The Roman Catholic Church considers the skull festival to be pagan, but it
doesn't ban people from taking part.

Belgian called mastermind of Paris attacks - Authorities have identified a
Belgian named Oussama Atar as the possible organizer of deadly Islamic State
attacks on Paris and Brussels over the past year.

A judicial official and a security official said Tuesday that Atar's name
appears in the investigation. The judicial official said there is evidence that
Atar is the real identity of Abu Ahmed, a pseudonym of the suspected attack
coordinator. His whereabouts are unknown.

Atar's name has been circulating in Belgium for months as possibly linked to the
attacks. Belgian prosecutors would not comment Tuesday.

Investigators believe the same Islamic State cell was behind the Paris attacks
in November 2015 and the Brussels attacks in March, which together killed 162
people.

Clues sought from mass grave near Mosul - Iraqi investigators were probing a
mass grave on Tuesday that was discovered by troops advancing toward the Islamic
State-held city of Mosul.

The chilling find was the latest instance of mass graves being uncovered on
ground wrested from militants.

Footage from the site shows bones and decomposed bodies among scraps of clothing
and plastic bags dug out of the ground by a bulldozer in the town of Hamam
al-Alil.

The first officials at the site said the grave likely holds about 100 bodies,
many of them decapitated. The town lies some 19 miles from Mosul.

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                            November 6, 2016 Sunday

Protests spill over to city as venue remains deserted

BYLINE: Vaivasvat Venkat

SECTION: LUDHIANA

LENGTH: 301 words


LUDHIANA: Despite the ground opposite Vardhaman industries being allocated as
the venue for protests, the orders have not been implemented, with protests
still being conducted outside the DC office.A major protest was conducted
outside the VC office by Congress leaders on Friday. They burnt the effigy of
Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

Another protest was staged by a taxi driver and his supporters on Ferozepur
road, disrupting traffic. There was a violent protest outside Basti Jodhewal
Police Station on Thursday as well. On October 13, police commissioner Jatinder
Singh Aulakh, using his powers under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code,
fixed GLADA ground opposite Vardhaman Industries in Sector 39 A on the
Ludhiana-Chandigarh road as venue for any protest by political parties or other
organisations. The decision was taken to prevent inconvenience to the general
public because of protests by political parties and other organisations.
However, the order remained only on the paper as nothing was done for its
implementation. Protests continue to be organized on important city roads,
highways and even outside the office of the deputy commissioner. "Nothing has
been done to implement the orders and it is the general public that is at the
receiving end. This order should be implemented and offenders should be given
stringent punishment. If a place for protests can be fixed in Chandigarh, why
can't the same be done in Ludhiana," asked advocate Harjiot Singh. Police
commissioner Jatinder Singh Aulakh said, "We have registered a case with regard
to the protest carried out on Ferozepur Road on Friday. Those who violate orders
will be booked and we will implement the orders stringently. We will not allow
city residents to be harassed by protesters."
