                              323 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          What the Papers Say (Russia)

                           December 25, 2014 Thursday

MAIDAN IN KIEV SPARES THE KREMLIN SOCIAL PROTESTS

BYLINE: Olga Soloviova

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 1239

LENGTH: 447 words



HIGHLIGHT: CONSEQUENCES OF THE EUROMAIDAN IN KIEV, UKRAINE, SLOWED DOWN
PROLIFERATION OF PROTEST DISPOSITION IN RUSSIA; Informed of the devastating
consequences of the Maidan in Ukraine, the Russians hesitate to join protests.


The Ukrainian revolution is helping the Russian state machinery. Aware of what
is happening in Ukraine in the wake of the so called Euromaidan, the Russians
are less susceptible to proliferation of protest disposition. And yet, it is
economic problems that disturb the Russians more than anything else...
particularly the Russians who admit that they just might take part in protest
actions. All these assumptions are confirmed by results of the opinion polls
presented by Aleksei Kudrin's Civil Initiatives Committee, yesterday.

Devastating consequences of the Euromaidan... serve as a powerful inhibitor for
proliferation of protest disposition in Russia. Experts say that only a
sustained economic crisis will persuade the Russians to ignore the neighbors'
example.

According a the poll conducted in Moscow, Vladimir, and Gus-Khustalny (near
Vladimir), most Russians distrust the opposition and fear protests for the time
being.

Mikhail Dmitriyev said, "The Russians reevaluated the political protests that
swept through the country in 2011 and early 2012. Most of them take a negative
view of those protests now. It is the latest developments in Ukraine that
compelled the Russians to change their mind. The Maidan in Kiev cured Russia of
analogous protests."

Moreover, the respondents are as good as certain that nothing like that is
possible in Russia in general. Most Russians approached by pollsters said that
President Vladimir Putin would never permit a Maidan or its analogs in Russia.
"It follows that there are no grounds for political protests in Russia,"
Dmitriyev said.

(Nearly 20% respondents were ready to join protest actions in 2011 and 2012.
Only 4% were ready to protest in the second half of 2014.)

Dmitriyev warned, however, that the Russians' attitude toward economic protests
was changing. Interest in economic matters was flourishing. General public
experienced a dramatic shortage of objective information on the current
socioeconomic situation. "People look for it in Western media outlets, Internet,
and social networks," Dmitriyev said. "We know for example that the Russians
approve and support the country's foreign policy. At the same time, they cannot
help being disappointed by the situation in Russia itself."

Dmitriyev emphasized that these conclusions might be obsolete since the polls in
question had been conducted before the crash of the ruble.

"Protests will become more and more active in a short while. Deterioration of
the economic situation will compel general public to ask more and more questions
and demand answers to them from the powers-that-be," Ilya Yashin of RPR-PARNAS
commented.

Source: Nezavisimaya Gazeta, No 281, December 25, 2014, p. 1

LOAD-DATE: December 25, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                                Daily News Egypt

                          September 13, 2014 Saturday

647 protests in August, 370 against military rule: IDC

BYLINE: Daily News Egypt

LENGTH: 201 words


//

Egyptian riot policemen throw stones during clashes with protesters who gathered
in support of a prominent secular activist who turned himself after being
ordered detained for holding a demonstration against a new protest law, on
November 30, 2013 in Cairo.
(AFP PHOTO STR)

A Saturday report was issued by International Development Center (IDC) stating
that August witnessed 647 protests, of which the Muslim Brotherhood led 414.

Many of the protests occurred during the Rabaa Al-Adaweya and Nahda Square
sit-in dispersal anniversary.

Other protests occurred because of the electricity outages and increases in the
cost of living, the report said, followed by workers protesting against working
conditions.

Out of all protests, 370 were against military rule, 14 were calling for the
release of detainees, 12 against the war in Gaza and 10 were held against
security chaos.

According to the report, political and civil rights provided most of the reasons
for the protests.

The majority of the protests were held in Cairo, followed by Sharqeya
governorate with 12% and Giza ranking third with 9%. The lowest number of
protests was recorded in the border governorates of Marsa Matrouh, North Sinai
and South Sinai.

                               Right Vision News

                           September 2, 2014 Tuesday

Pakistan: PTI Karachi to block Shahra-e-Faisal

LENGTH: 248  words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Sept. 2 -- To show its street power, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf has
announced to stage a protest sit-in on Shara-e-Faisal, a major boulevard in
Karachi from Saturday.

"We have decided to launch a massive protest tsunami, which if the government
tried to stop, would be itself responsible for untoward consequences. We will
come out in full power tomorrow, come what may", a statement issued by the party
said.

According to sources, PTI core committee, in its meeting held, has finalized
protest demonstrations in major cities including Karachi as an extension to the
anti-government protest demonstration in Islamabad's 'Red Zone' after the party
leader Imran Khan's announcement.

"We will stage mega protest demonstrations in Lahore, Faisalabad, Multan, and
Karachi tomorrow (Saturday)", party leader Imran Khan told his workers staging
anti-government sit-in in front of Parliament House.

Laying out their protest plans, the PTI said in addition to Shara-e-Faisal
Karachi, rallies/sit-ins would be staged in Faisalabad's Zila Council Chowk,
Multan's Nawan Shehr Chowk, and Lahore to start with.

Shara-e-Faisal is one of the main thoroughfares in the metropolis and most of
the national and multinational companies' offices, schools, shopping plazas,
banks, and institutes are close to it

                               Pakistan Observer

                            November 22, 2013 Friday

500 personnel to escort protest rally; Federal capital comes under security
blanket

BYLINE:  Zubair Qureshi

SECTION: Vol. XXV No. 020

LENGTH: 340  words


Police chiefs in the federal capital spent a busy Thursday chalking out
foolproof security plan for today (Friday) protest rallies s in the city.

Some Sunni Ulema and workers of Ahl-e-Sunnat wal Jamaat have given countrywide
calls for protests against last Friday incident of arson and killings at one of
their seminaries in Rawalpindi. In Islamabad, their rally will start after
Friday prayer from Lal Masjid and end at the press club.

An office bearer of Jamat Ahl-e-Sunnat on anonymity told Pakistan Observer,
Maulana Ahmed Ludhianvi Amir of the Jamat will lead the protest rally. Leaders
of Difa-e-Pakistan Council and other religious political parties will also
participate, he said. However, he said, "We have not disclosed the number of
participants nor the magnitude of the protest. It will be a complete surprise
for police and government," he said.

An official of the Special Branch also confirmed this saying police high-ups are
not aware of the exact magnitude and intensity of the protest. "They keep saying
it will be a peaceful protest rally and very few participants will protest
against the Youm-e-Ashur killings in Pindi. However, we doubt that it will be a
small and peaceful protest," he expressed his fears.

Majlis Wahdatul Muslemeen (MWM) had also called for a similar protest rally
against attacks on their Imam Bargahs in Pindi and elsewhere.

Their rally was planned from G-6 Imam Bargah to D-Chowk after the Friday
prayers. However, according to an office bearer of the MWM, the rally has been
cancelled at the last moment. The city administration has prevailed upon the
Shia Ulemas to postpone their protest as it might lead to sectarian clashes. We
have accepted their request in the interest of peace, he said. According to a
senior official, police have been deployed a day prior to the rally outside 20
most sensitive buildings including Imam Bargahs and seminaries of the two
groups.

Likewise, more than 500 personnel will escort the protest rally and all the
measures have been taken to make it peaceful, he said.

LOAD-DATE: November 22, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2013 Hurmat Group
                              All Rights Reserved


                              327 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           November 19, 2013 Tuesday

Hawaii: Senators Introduce Bill To Tighten Guam Procurement Law

LENGTH: 645  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Pacific Islands Development, The State of Hawaii has issued the following news
release:

Senators Tom Ada and Rory Respicio have introduced Bill 224, which seeks to
clarify legal and contractual remedies in the Guam Procurement Law.

According to Ada, the bill addresses the procedures and timelines to be followed
when a protest related to a solicitation, source selection, or award of a
contract is lodged.

Both senators agree that with a good portion of government of Guam funds going
toward the acquisition of supplies and services, the timely resolution of
protests and an effective remedial scheme are essential to proper and efficient
procurement.

"The filing of a protest is an important feature of our procurement system
because it provides for 'real time' policing of the process," Respicio said. "In
other words, a participant in the procurement process is allowed to register a
protest at the time that a failure or defect in the process has occurred.
However, to be effective the protest process must be expeditious."

The current Procurement Law defines a timeline when a protest can be filed.
However, the law is silent on when the government agency receiving the protest
must respond. Bill 224, the senators said, aims to require that the protested
agency make a decision within 21 days from the date a protest is lodged. If no
decision is made within the allotted time, the protestor can petition the agency
and if a decision is still not rendered within 7 days, then the protest can be
elevated to the Office of the Public Auditor.

"Simply put, in the current law, there is no definite timeline for when an
agency must resolve a protest. Bill 224 will require that agencies respond to
and resolve protests no later than 28 days from the receipt of such protests."

Timelines

Bill 224 also seeks to provide definitive timelines on when an aggrieved
participant must take action and when government entities must respond.

"The objective of Bill 224 is to improve the efficiency and efficacy of the
administrative and judicial remedial scheme. The general structure of the
remedial scheme is sound but in need of critical changes to achieve this goal,"
Ada said.

In addition, the bill also makes changes to the process of awarding contracts
once a protest is lodged. Currently, the law is unclear in situations where a
protest is lodged after an award has been made. Bill 224 stops all further work
and awards until final resolution of a protest.

"Of course, there are provisions for exceptions in the event of declared
emergencies," Respicio qualified.

Bill 224 also clarifies who may lodge a protest, when a protest can be filed,
and under what circumstances a protest may be lodged. The bill further clarifies
who has the authority to resolve protests. The use of settlement conferences,
expedited alternative dispute resolution and debriefing are among the methods
advocated by the measure.

It also mandates that the decisions and conclusions reached at each stage of
administrative review must be in writing, detailing the basis for the
conclusions, and that the administrative review process must be exhausted prior
to seeking resolution through the judicial system.

Ada is hopeful that the introduction of Bill 224 will "enroll the good faith
participation" of private sector participants in the procurement process to
assure the efficacy and integrity of the procurement system, and to establish an
effective and expeditious resolution of disputes.

"I hope the introduction of Bill 224 will bring community stakeholders and
government procurement employees more clarity in the remedial scheme of the
government of Guam procurement law. A sound remedial scheme is an essential
component to ensuring government funds are spent efficiently, effectively and in
accordance with the law," Ada concluded.

For further information please visit: http://pidp.eastwestcenter.org/

LOAD-DATE: November 20, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                           Coventry Evening Telegraph

                           September 20, 2013 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

PROBATION PROTESTS AT PRIVATISATION;
Union members say public could be put at risk over plans to outsource work to
private firms

BYLINE: Simon Gilbert

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 402 words


PROBATION workers turned out in force to stage protests over privatisation plans
which they say could put the public at risk.

Over 100 probation staff staged demonstrations in protest over government plans
to off-load large parts of the probation service to the private sector.

Workers held lunchtime rallies between 1pm and 2pm yesterday, with staff
protesting with placards outside the justice centres in Nuneaton and Leamington.

Union members from NAPO, Unison and GMB joined forces for the protests, which
have been described by union leaders as the first stage of long term industrial
action.

The protests - which were replicated across the country - were arranged to
coincide with the date justice secretary Chris Grayling formally invited tenders
for contracts related to the Probation Service worth over £450 million.

Dave Adams, chairman of the Warwickshire Branch of NAPO, said: "I'm really
pleased with the turnout, almost 100 per cent of Warwickshire staff in work
joined in the demonstration.

"It was well received by the public, we seemed to get a positive response from
most people.

"The general public need to know about Chris Grayling's plans, but there doesn't
seem to be a clear plan for how this is going to work.

"It's like trying to build a house with no plans - he's making it up as he goes
along."

With all of Warwickshire's MPs part of the in-power Conservative party, the
protesters have vowed to work hard to convince MPs and the public that this is
not a party-political issue.

"We will be focusing on the different constituencies in the next couple of
months," said Mr Adams. "But whether you are Tory, Labour or Liberal Democrat,
you have to be worried about the dismantling of a probation service which has
performed and protected the public well for many years."

Protesters have also vowed to put particular pressure on Kenilworth & Southam MP
Jeremy Wright who is also the minister for prisons and rehabilitation.

Action is expected to take place in his constituency on Saturday, September 28
and details are due to be announced in the coming days. Workers fear cuts of up
to 30 per cent and believe job losses will be inevitable if the probation
service is sold off to a private firm.

Concerns have also been raised about the supervision of released prisoners.

Organisations such as Serco and G4S, which provided security for the London
Olympics, are believed to be among the interested parties.

                            The Daily Star (Lebanon)

                             August 23, 2013 Friday

Assir supporters vow to stage protest in Sidon

LENGTH: 194 words


Supporters of firebrand Sheikh Ahmad Assir vowed to stage a protest in Sidon
Friday despite a protest ban by authorities, said a sheikh close to the fugitive
preacher Thursday.

BEIRUT: Supporters of firebrand Sheikh Ahmad Assir vowed to stage a protest in
Sidon Friday despite a protest ban by authorities, said a sheikh close to the
fugitive preacher Thursday.

The sheikh, who declined to be identified, said worshippers from the Bilal Bin
Rabah Mosque in Abra, where Assir used to deliver sermons, would hold the
protest Friday at noon as scheduled.

"Security bodies have informed the mosque's committee of a firm decision to
crack down on any demonstration or protest outside Abra's mosque even if this
requires opening fire," he told the Central News Agency.

"But we insist on holding the protest and we hold Sidon's two MPs, its religious
and political figures first and Iran's party [Hezbollah] second responsible for
any bloodshed."

The protest aims at pressuring authorities to release Sheikh Assem Arefi and
others arrested by the Army over the Abra clashes with Assir in June.

Arefi was arrested Tuesday after he confessed to having fought the Army
alongside Assir.

Turkish mass protests enters tenth day

LENGTH: 143 words


TEHRAN, Jun. 9 (MNA) â- Tens of thousands of Turks have protested today against
the policies of Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

According to Al-Manar News, tens of thousands of Turks came to the streets again
today to protest against the policies of Prime Minister Erdogen. The largest
gathering was in Izmir, where security forces suppressed demonstrations, and
arrested the activists.
Thus, Turkish mass protests have entered into its tenth day. Meanwhile AK Party,
the ruling party has ruled out the possibility of early elections.
Widespread protests, which began ten days ago, are still continuing in many
cities of Turkey. In the first phase of the protests, people came to support the
protesters in Gezi Park in Taksim Square, and gradually became anti-government
protests, and demonstrators are now calling for the resignation of Recep Tayyip
Erdogan.

                                Daily News Egypt

                             April 28, 2013 Sunday

Labour strikes and protests double under Morsi

BYLINE: Ahmed Aboul Enein

LENGTH: 664 words


Press conference held at ECESR , where they issued their 2012 report detailing
the increasing number of labour strikes in Egypt
(Photo ECESR handout)

Labour strikes and social protests have more than doubled since President
Mohamed Morsi's election and are likely to continue doing so, a study shows.

A report published on Sunday by the Egyptian Centre for Economic and Social
Rights (ECESR) about labour movements during 2012 shows that most of the year's
3,817 labour strikes and economically motivated social protests happened
following Morsi's election.

Between January and June, the period in which the Supreme Council of the Armed
Forces ran the country, there was an average of 185 protests or strikes per
month, accounting for 29% of the whole year.

In contrast, workers staged an average of 452 monthly protests or strikes
between July and December following Morsi's inauguration, or 71% of such events
in 2012. There have been over 2,400 protests or strikes in the first quarter of
2013 alone, specifically between January and March.

"The statistics demonstrate the doubling of protest movements since July
following President Morsi's inauguration which reflects the will of workers to
have their voice reach the new president," the 70-page report noted. "Several
sectors of society tried to direct the president's attention towards their
missing rights while others demonstrated their disappointment in the president
and his government."

Most protests came from the governmental sector, which witnessed 1,355
demonstrations and strikes, accounting for 35.5% of 2012's total. Private sector
workers accounted for 10.3% with 393 protests while public sector employees made
up 5.8% with 221 protests.

Freelancers and self-employed workers held 182 protests, accounting for 5%.
Citizens protesting against rising prices, lack of fuel, electricity problems,
and other economic problems held 1,656 protests; the remaining 43.4%.

Strikes and sit-ins were the primary forms of protest used by workers and
accounted for 26.8% of protests. Workers staged 519 strikes and either held or
threatened to hold sit-ins 504 times.

Vigils, used 851 times, were the second most common form of dissent, making up
22.3% of social protests in 2012. Marches and demonstrations followed with 18.3%
while blocking of roads was 14.7%.

Hunger strikes were used 135 times, accounting for 3.5% while mob gatherings
accounted for 4.3% and detaining managers 1.3%. Shutting down and blocking
public buildings accounted for 0.6% while 13 people, accounting for 0.3%, tried
to commit suicide in protest of their living conditions.

Over 36% of labour protests, or 708, were over demands of wage increases.
Temporary workers and unemployed citizens demanding employment made up 19.3%
with 380 protests.

The rest happened in protest over mismanagement, mistreatment, corruption, or
against the closure of factories and businesses.

The report blamed Morsi's government for not issuing a law for independent
unions and syndicates despite their being a draft submitted back in 2011 by
former labour minister, Ahmed Al-Borai.

Instead of issuing the law or tasking the Shura Council with doing so, Morsi
only amended the old law regarding state-sponsored unions and syndicates so he
could replace former regime members with Muslim Brotherhood ones, the ECESR
report argued.

Furthermore the government has yet to increase the minimum wage to EGP 1,200
despite a court ordering it to in a 2011 verdict. The government is also raising
energy prices, increasing sales tax and devaluing the Egyptian pound in
accordance with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank's demands, the
report adds.

"Despite all of this the labour movement continues to defend its rights and
works to achieve the goals of the January revolution: bread, freedom, social
justice and human dignity," the ECESR report said.

Related posts:

A Tale Of Two Cairos

Sudanese representatives in Cairo for meetings on Darfur

Bakery owners cripple the Ministry of Supply

Ex-PPP minister protests against ticket denial

                                 The Irish News

                             January 7, 2013 Monday

Youths recruited by UVF at street protests

BYLINE: Allison Morris, a.morris@irishnews.com

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 256 words


The UVF has been accused of exploiting disturbances surrounding Union flag
protests to swell its youth wing's ranks.

Loyalist sources say the group has used anger in unionist communities to recruit
members to the illegal Young Citizen Volunteers (YCV).

Last night police were pelted with bricks, bottles and fireworks in east
Belfast.

The Police Federation's Northern Ireland chairman, Terry Spence, said it is
clear that "paramilitaries have hijacked this flags protest issue".

However, PUP leader Billy Hutchinson, a founding member of the YCV, said: "Show
me one shred of evidence that the UVF is orchestrating these protests. Bring me
one young person who was recruited at a protest.

"This is utter nonsense. The UVF are not orchestrating these protests. They are
the people's protests and the people should be allowed to get on with it."

Following four nights of violence in east Belfast Peter Robinson's control of
the DUP is again under question.

The first minister said the organisers of the protest movement, who include
south Armagh man Willie Frazer, were trying to "undermine the DUP as the voice
of unionism".

Mr Robinson urged unionists to move "beyond protests".

However, senior party colleague William Humphrey, who has attended protests on
Crumlin Road in north Belfast, would not rule out attending further
demonstrations.

Special courts sat on Saturday and yesterday to deal with those charged in
connection with the disturbances.

Two women and 16 men were charged with public-order offences. All but one were
remanded in custody.

                                  Ulster Star

                          September 13, 2012 Thursday

Maze protest motives questioned

LENGTH: 281  words


IN the same week the new Chairman and Board members of the Maze/Long Kesh
Development Corporation were announced, a protest has been organised opposing
the planned Peace and Reconciliation Centre at the former prison site.

William Frazer from FAIR has announced he will be holding a protest at the Maze
on Thursday afternoon. However the South Belfast UPRG have questioned the
motives behind the protest and have said that local residents are not
encouraging the protest.

The protest has been billed as a civil rights protest for Protestants, alleging
that the planned conflict resolution centre will be turned into an Irish
Republican shrine once built, however locals who reside very close to the former
prison feel that the protest itself is not something that they would encourage.

Chairman of the South Belfast UPRG, Colin Halliday said: "Locals have had no
communication with the parade organiser to tell them what is happening and in
many cases the first they heard was when social media sites advertised this.
There is a genuine fear that the prospect of hundreds of supporters being bussed
in for this event might lead to tension with the police and for such a small
closely knit rural community that is unacceptable."

Colin continued: "There has also been some confusion over the real reason for
the protest with some billing it as a civil rights protest, so if this is the
case why is it not held at Stormont and addressed to those administering
Northern Ireland? The site has been a talking point for many since the prison
closed but it is up to individuals to make up their own minds on the future use
instead of allowing themselves to be carried away with hype and myths."

                              335 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          Pretoria News (South Africa)

                            August 07, 2012 Tuesday
                                   E1 Edition

Call for calm, study shows most protests are in W Cape

BYLINE:  Babalo Ndenze Political Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 417 words


NEW RESEARCH shows the Western Cape - where the DA-led government has accused
the ANC of stoking violence - had nearly a quarter of all protests in the
country this year.

Now the ANC provincial executive committee (PEC) is calling for restraint and
asking community leaders to discourage violence.

The research, by Municipal IQ, showed protests were on the increase across the
country, with 113 so far this year, compared to two in 2006.

This year also accounted for 22 percent of all protests recorded since January
2004.

Karen Heese, economist at Municipal IQ, said "the trend of violent protests
remains a key concern", with 88 percent of protests last month turning violent.

Almost half the protests last month (46 percent) took place in informal
settlements. Heese said this highlighted "the desperation of these communities
living on the margins of local economies during the bitter winter months".

The research, "The Hotspots Monitor: major protests staged by community members
against a municipality", said protests were mostly to do with "perceived
responsibility of local government, such as councillor accountability, the
quality and pace of basic service delivery, and in metro areas, housing".

Heese said the Western Cape remained "the most protest-afflicted province in
2012", followed by the Free State.

The Western Cape accounted for 24 percent of protests, followed by the Free
State at 14 percent.

KwaZulu-Natal and Limpopo had the lowest number of protests, both accounting for
just 6 percent of the national figure. "Political and community leaders should
try to channel community grievances constructively to avoid the violence and
destruction that has typified protests during 2012," said Heese.

And the ANC has echoed this call, with provincial secretary Songezo Mjongile
calling for restraint.

"The provincial executive committee calls on community leaders to discourage
violence and damage associated with service delivery protests as this gives room
to opportunistic elements who try to demonise legitimate demands," said
Mjongile, with reference to the DA's accusation that the ANC was responsible for
the wave of violent protests in the Western Cape.

Premier Helen Zille and Cape Town Mayor Patricia de Lille have filed criminal
charges against the party.

However, Mjongile blamed the DA for community anger. "The ANC calls on the
provincial and metro governments to give the same attention to issues raised by
the communities in the same way that it does to people in the leafy suburbs."

                             May 19, 2012 Saturday

Azeris to stage week-long anti-Iranian protests in foreign countries - TV

LENGTH: 323 words


Text of report by private Azerbaijani TV station ANS on 19 May

[Presenter] Anti-Iranian protests are to start today in different parts of the
world. The goal of the protests, which will last a week, is to oppose Tehran's
anti-Azerbaijani policies.

[Correspondent] Azeris in Germany and Denmark will hold mass protests outside
Iranian embassies in these countries. They will protest against Tehran's
anti-Azerbaijani policies and the pickets organized outside the Azerbaijani
Consulate General in Tabriz against the Baku-hosted Eurovision International
Song Contest. Anti-Iran protests will be held in the Netherlands, Sweden and
Italy tomorrow, and later in France, Britain, as well as outside the Pakistani
embassy which represents Iran's interests in the USA.

[Mahmud Ali Chehregani, captioned as Iranian political emigrant, speaking in
Azeri over phone from the USA] [A protest] will be held here on 22 [May]. [The
protests] will be held all over the world, and they should be held. Azerbaijanis
should protect their state, protect their flag, protect their independence,
should support their own state, 50m Azeris should shout to the world and show to
the Iranian regime that the Azerbaijani state is not alone, that there are 50m
supporting it, and that they will never allow the Iranian regime to inflict any
damage to this state.

[Correspondent] We should note that some clerics initiated protest marches
against Azerbaijan after Friday prayers in the Iranian cities of Tabriz, Ardabil
and Tehran yesterday. Tabriz residents say that special people invited by
individual organizations attended these protests.

A similar protest was held outside the Azerbaijani Consular Office in Tabriz on
8 May.

The Azerbaijani Foreign Ministry has said that no country has the right to
interfere in Azerbaijan's internal affairs. Azerbaijan is an independent state
which decides its policies independently.

Source: ANS TV, Baku, in Azeri 1000 gmt 19 May 12

                                 Jerusalem Post

                              April 1, 2011 Friday

Photo - PROTESTING A PROTEST

BYLINE:  Melanie Lidman

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 161 words


PROTESTING A PROTEST. Uri Agnon, along with Meydad Eliyahu, Shira Inbar and
David Kriksunov, all members of the art collective KRA, created a series of
black and white drawings in an artistic protest staged at Jerusalem's Museum on
the Seam Thursday night. The performance art, part of an evening sponsored by
Ruah Hadasha (New Spirit), a group for young Jerusalemites, was called 'Tea and
Opinions'and delved into the museum's current exhibit, 'The Right to Protest,'
and the importance and meaning of political protest in Jerusalem. Members of KRA
wanted to draw attention to the fact that little had been written about the
Baramkis, an Arab family that owned the house before it became an Israeli
military position on the old border with Jordan. The group traveled to Ramallah
to meet with Prof. Gabi Baramki, who was 15 when his family evacuated the house.
The drawings were based on this meeting. The exhibit will be at the Museum on
the Seam until the end of May.

                              340 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                           January 19, 2011 Wednesday

Slideshow: Leeds students hold silent EMA protest

BYLINE: John Baronguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 178 words

ABSTRACT

Dortmund Square and The Headrow play host to latest student cuts protest in
Leeds

FULL TEXT

Students took to the streets of Leeds for a silent protest against the
government's decision to scrap the  (EMA)

In the region of 40 students and trades unionists congregated in Dortmund Square
early yesterday evening to protest against the scrapping of EMA, a weekly
payment to the poorest 16 to 18-year-olds to help them stay in education.

The students wore tape across their mouths as a symbol of their silent protest
and waved banners. From Dortmund Square they moved onto the Headrow, in front of
The Halifax, to take their protest to passing peak-time traffic. Towards the end
of the protest, students took off their tape and began chanting against
education cuts and the coalition government. to be debated in the House of
Commons today calling on the government to "rethink its decision" to scrap the
EMA, which they hope coalition MPs will back.

What do you think? Have your say in the comments section below.

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           November 27, 2010 Saturday

Iran conservative paper reports anti-war protests in London

LENGTH: 487 words


Text of commentary by Vahid Kucheh-Meshki headlined "Protests by the British
against war" published by Iranian newspaper Resalat on 24 November

Protests and demonstrations by British citizens against war-seeking approach of
the country continue in the Indian sub continent as well as in the Middle East.

British citizens have announced harsh protests several times and have asked
[David] Cameron and Nick Clegg to change their policies in this regard. However,
no reactions have been observed from the British government side.

Anti-war protests by British citizens have once again showed their anger towards
their politicians. Thousands of British people and peace -seeking activists
rushed to London streets in protest to the continuous war in Afghanistan. They
wanted to show their protest regarding the continuation of war in Afghanistan as
leaders of countries holding NATO membership gathered in Portugal [for the
summit].

Coordinators of this demonstration have said that 10,000 protesting people
gathered around in Hyde Park in Central London and marched a 2-kilometer
distance till "Traflgar" Square in order to join speeches that were made at the
square criticizing the war in Afghanistan.

This demonstration was arranged by three British organizations namely "Stop the
War Coalition", "Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament" and "Muslim Association of
Britain". "Stop the War Coalition" organization was established in September
2001 in less than two weeks after the 9/11 incident. According to the statements
by Andre Bargin, responsible for information dissemination of "Stop the War
Coalition" organization, these demonstrations had been very effective and have
drawn the attention of many British youths under 20 years of age.

This demonstration started at 1:00 p.m. [local time]. Protesters were waving
colourful banners and holding placards with slogans. They asked for the
evacuation of army from Afghanistan as well as announced their solidarity with
the people of Palestine.

Leaders of countries holding NATO membership attended a NATO gathering in
Lisbon, capital of Portugal on Friday and Saturday [19 and 20 November]. NATO
Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen evaluated this gathering as very
important for the future of military solidarity of NATO. It is expected that
NATO leaders come to an agreement on a strategy for evacuation of NATO troops
from Afghanistan by the end of 2014.

Nevertheless, Cameron and Nick Clegg cannot keep their ears blocked to these
strong shouts that ask for ending the invasion of Afghanistan and Iraq.

Tony Blair's trial, the war-seeking British prime minister, during the attack on
Afghanistan and Iraq, has turned into one of the main wishes of the British
citizens. A wish, that will come true in the near future with the follow-up of
world's nation and people like Bush, Blair and Aznar will be punished for their
war crimes.

Source: Resalat website, Tehran, in Persian 24 Nov 10

                             March 23, 2010 Tuesday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1475

LENGTH: 364  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged by the local people outside the
Hyderabad Press Club on Monday. According to details, the students of the
Faculty of Law University of Sindh Jamshoro under the leadership of Ayaz Korejo,
Mumtaz Ali and others staged a protest demonstration against the closing of the
Mitha Ram Hostel.

Members of the Kolhi community including Natho Kolhi, Paroo Kolhi and others
staged a protest demonstration for the arrest of the accused involved in
threatening them. The workers of the PPP Kotri Chapter including Muhammad Achar
and others staged a protest demonstration against an influential landlord for
occupying their land.

Members of the Talpur community including Mir Amjad Talpur, Mir Khaleel Talpur
and others staged a protest demonstration for the recovery of 2 youths of their
community namely Liaquat Talpur and Nawaz Talpur. A man namely Ali Nawaz Mochi,
resident of village Karam Khan Nizamani District Matiari staged a protest
demonstration against an influential landlord namely Jam Riaz Gahoti for
abducting his wife, 2 sons and 2 daughters.

Members of the Sindh Agriculture Forestry Workers Coordinating Organization
(SAFWCO) under the leadership of Masood Soomro, Rasheed Chandio, Niaz Junejo
staged a protest demonstration against the shortage of water in Sindh.

The women of the Bagri community including Harman Bagri, Kishni and others
staged a protest demonstration for the removal of occupation of their
residential plot. Former Nazim of UC Khaan district Mirpurkhas, Mehboob Ali
Marri staged a protest demonstration against the officials of the Auqaf
Department Sindh. PPP workers of Tando Jam chapter under the leadership of Altaf
Hussain Unar and others staged a protest demonstration against the local PPP
leadership.

The residents of City Views Plaza Latifabad No. 7 staged a protest demonstration
against the opening of a wine shop in their area. A girl namely Ayesha Soomro
along with her family members staged a protest demonstration for the recovery of
Akbar Soomro. The reinstated employees of the Sui Southern Gas Company (SSGC)
staged a protest demonstration for issuance of their withheld salaries and
posting orders.

                              343 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             April 7, 2009 Tuesday

Pundit says recurrent protests in Morocco reflect absence of social justice

LENGTH: 475 words


Al-Jazeera TV reports on 6 April that sit-ins and protests have become a daily
occurrence in Morocco. While some experts deem this phenomenon to be a
by-product of expanding freedoms and growing political awareness of Moroccans,
others believe it is the outcome of socio-economic problems and ineffective role
of unions and political parties, says Al-Jazeera.

A report from Rabat highlights the case of an employee, who has staged a sit-in
and gone a hunger strike outside the Ministry of Education in an attempt to
overturn a decision for his dismissal.

The ministry employee, Mohamed, says "I won't leave this place until the
dismissal decision is repealed. Otherwise, I will die here surrounded by these
banners."

The report looks at both arguments that explain the growing phenomenon of
protests.

A young man is shown saying "protests that occur in Rabat on a daily basis
reflect the disastrous social condition that the intellectual class wants to
highlight through protests.

The report highlights the role of unions in raising the awareness of unemployed
youths of their right to protest.

Khadija, a unionist, says "we believe that going on strike is a legitimate right
guaranteed by the constitution. It is one of the mechanisms of union's work,
which is used to pressure government and employers if they don't abide by
agreements."

Observers criticize unions for being driven by political interests rather than
the interests of the public and say unions - torn by divisions - are following
the footsteps of ineffective political parties, says the report.

Al-Jazeera TV interviews a Moroccan sociologist, Abdelrahim El Itri. He says the
view that protests reflect the absence of social justice is more objective than
the argument saying protests signal growing political freedoms in Morocco. "
Protests indicate that there is tension and public disgruntlement. This is
proven by the fact that protests are essentially staged to express
socio-economic demands. Those protests in all forms mainly demand the
redistribution of wealth and the rewriting of a new history of social justice,"
says El Itri.

He says he has done a study on protests in Morocco, which showed that they
quickly fizzle and fail to achieve economic demands and are usually met with
violence and lack of responsiveness by the authorities.

Protests in Morocco are expanding to include, along with unemployed people,
members of other groups and classes, such as villagers and women, El Itri says.

"Many protests nowadays lack political orientation in contrast to protests in
the past, which were directed by political parties. The latter seem to have
given up this role. Nowadays, there is another player; local associations are
now playing an important role in protests and taking over the role of political
parties," El Itri says.

Source: Al-Jazeera TV, Doha, in Arabic 2130 gmt 6 Apr 09

LOAD-DATE: April 7, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                     The Russian Business Monitor (Russia)

                            December 29, 2008 Monday

POLLS SHOW SOCIAL PROTEST WELL BELOW THE CRITICAL LEVEL;
Recent opinion polls show fewer than a third of respondents expecting any
increase in protest activity in Russia - and even fewer say they would be
prepared to join protests. Pollsters report a certain increase in protest moods,
but assess it as being well below a critical level. They also question the
opposition's ability to head or even strengthen the protests.

SECTION: HUMAN RESOURCES; No. 285

LENGTH: 247 words


According to the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center (VTsIOM), 30% of
respondents believe that mass protests could happen in their respective
locations in the near future; this figure was only 21% in a March poll. "These
trends never reached their peak," said VTsIOM Director Valery Fyodorov. "I
recall that 47% of respondents expected mass protests in March 2005, right after
the social benefits-to-money conversion."

"Actually, nothing extraordinary is happening in terms of protest mood changes,"
said Levada Center Director Lev Gudkov. "As far as we can tell, 23% expect mass
protests, 21% say they are ready to join them, but only about 1.5% will actually
do so. If even 15% actually resolved to join street protests, it would have been
a colossal social breakthrough. Not even rallies in Moscow in the perestroika
days would have equalled that."

Pollsters doubt that any opposition party stands a chance of heading or even
strengthening protests. Former opposition leaders (Boris Nemtsov, Gennadi
Zyuganov) "are distrusted," and younger leaders (Maria Gaidar, Ilya Yashin,
Sergei Udaltsov) "remain unknown to the masses." Gudkov added that the
opposition needs "new leaders as well as a policy program that will interest the
public. And they also lack media channels to promote such a program."

At the same time, it is common knowledge that the opposition itself prefers
contacts with the authorities to contacts with the general public.

Source: Kommersant, December 26, 2008

                              345 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                                  Korea Times

                            December 22, 2008 Monday

Police Insiders Stand for Candlelit Protests

BYLINE: By Bae Ji-sook

LENGTH: 332 words


Staff Reporter

Who was behind the candlelit protest against American beef imports that lit up
the streets of downtown Seoul and major cities nationwide? Was it the
progressive and "impure" people seeking to "overthrow" society, as police
concluded?

Some police insiders have come up with a new idea ¤Ñ the protests were pure
expressions of the general public's resentment of the government, and police
should deal with such cases with "respect" and "flexibility," they said.

Prof. Kwon Yong-cheol of the National Central Police Academy and Prof. Lim
Seung-taek of the Korea National Police University, both high ranking officials
in the police hierarchy, stood against the police's excessive suppression of the
events.

Kwon said candlelit protestors took to the streets on their own, just like the
April 19 pro-democratic movement in 1960 and March 1 Liberation Declaration
Movement in 1919 under Japanese colonial rule (1910-1945).

He said the few progressive activists, whom the police chose as agitators, lost
power during the protest movement. "They came up with theories against the free
trade agreement with the U.S. but did not lead the protests rather they followed
the crowd," he said.

Kwon stressed that police should be more open to change in society and
acknowledge that the protest was led by teenagers, women and senior citizens.

Lim said police need to guarantee ordinary citizens' rights to "hold protests
and gatherings." However, he said they have tried to restrain such gatherings by
declaring the nighttime protests illegal. "The Constitution actually allows all
kinds of protests but some police rules are hindering their spirit," he said.

Currently, chiefs of police stations approve of protests if they are "peaceful"
enough and the candlelit protests were considered near-rebellion and later
prohibited, he said.

The candlelit protests first ignited on May 2, with several Internet users
expressing their objection toward government policies. They carried on until
late August.

LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              346 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)

                           October 24, 2007 Wednesday
                                 SOONER EDITION

HOW TO PROTEST STATE CONTRACTS

BYLINE: Nicole H. King, Meyer Unkovic & Scott, nhk@muslaw.com

SECTION: BUSINESS; BUSINESS WORKSHOP; Pg. A-10

LENGTH: 204 words


To ensure equal access, state agencies award contracts through a competitive
bidding process, which begins by sending out a "request for proposal."

The law permits businesses to protest the RFP if they feel that the terms and
conditions are unfair.

If successful in lodging a protest, business owners can compel a state agency to
amend the RFP and extend the deadline for submission of proposals.

The time a business owner has to submit such a protest can vary depending on
whether the business owner is a prospective or an actual bidder. A prospective
bidder, or a business that simply receives the RFP, may protest the proposal
until the RFP deadline. But bidders have only seven days from the date they
became aware of the grounds for protest, which unfortunately, is usually
considered to be the day the business received the RFP.

This point was at the heart of a recent court decision upholding a pharmacy's
protest of an RFP. The court held the pharmacy's protest was timely because the
pharmacy did not bid on the contract. Had the pharmacy bid on the contract,
however, the court would not have upheld the pharmacy's right to protest, since
the pharmacy's protest was filed more than seven days after it received the RFP.

LOAD-DATE: October 24, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: Business workshop is a weekly feature from local experts offering tidbits
on matters affecting business.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2007 P.G. Publishing Co.


                              347 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           September 24, 2006 Sunday

Over 800 protest gatherings staged in Iran in the past year - Agency

LENGTH: 191 words


Text of report by Iranian news agency website Alborz news on 24 Sep

According to a survey conduced by Alborz news, in 1384 [year beginning 21 March
2005], there were some 838 demonstrations or protest gatherings in Iran. These
included protests by unions, political activists, workers, students, cultural
and academic activists.

Of these protest gatherings, those staged by workers and unions constituted the
highest number with 71 per cent of the total, and those staged by cultural
activists the lowest, with four per cent. Protest by political activists made up
just over seven per cent of the total.

The report adds: Of these protest gatherings, almost 574 of them were
demonstrations by workers over their work conditions. There were 86 cases of
student demonstrations, constituting 9.7 per cent of the total, and 62 reported
cases of political demonstrations, constituting 7.3 per cent of the total.

There were 62 demonstrations related to social issues, and 34 to cultural ones,
constituting 10.2 and four per cent of the total, respectively. [All figures as
published]

Source: Iranian news agency website Alborz, in Persian, 0000 gmt 24 Sep 06

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             July 11, 2006 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Valuation protests nearing record

BYLINE: Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: B; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 124 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, NE


Whether or not there will be a record number of property valuation protests this
year is still unclear.

Chief Deputy County Clerk Trish Owen said Monday morning that she didn't yet
have an exact number of protests but that the number is "pretty darn close" to
10,500.

Owen said she was pretty sure all protests that were due by the June 30 deadline
have been received by the County Clerk's office and accounted for.

But there are about 920 property owners who received late valuation notices and
have additional time to file a protest.

If 10 percent of those property owners file protests - about the same percentage
of all property owners who file a protest - the final number would likely
surpass the all-time record of 10,528 protests filed in 1987.

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           February 11, 2006 Saturday

Macedonia: Tetovo mufti's office denies role in Muhammad cartoons protest

LENGTH: 343 words


Excerpt from report by EA entitled "Due to controversial cartoon, call for
protests in Tetove" published by Macedonian Albanian-language newspaper Fakti on
10 February

Members of the Tetove [Tetovo] mufti's office have said that they are not behind
the protests, but that they support the position of the Islamic Religious
Community of Macedonia [BFIM].

A "group of students" from Tetove [Tetovo] distributed a large number of
leaflets in mosques and public locations yesterday, inviting citizens to
participate in the protest against the cartoons of Prophet Muhammad that have
been published in Denmark and other Western countries. The protest has been
scheduled to start today at 0800 gmt at the Larme mosque in Tetove.

"Hey you, who claim to be descendants of Muhammad, what has happened to you? Did
we forget Muhammad, who came as a blessing for this world and from whom we
expect mercy on Judgment Day? You must fear Almighty God," said the leaflet that
has been distributed in Tetove.

According to the organizers of the protest, "silence and failure to attend the
protest are an indication of brotherhood, cooperation and friendship with
Satan". The leaflet says that the protest organizers are a "group of students,"
without providing further explanations about who is truly behind this
invitation.

Members of the Tetove mufti's office said that they were not behind the protest,
but added that they support the position of the Islamic Religious Community of
Macedonia. On 8 February, the BFIM leaders requested that all the imams dedicate
Friday prayers in mosques on 10 and 17 February to the life and work of
Muhammad.

"We do not organize protests, but we are also unable to hamper the free will of
the citizens if they decide to support the protest. However, I appeal to those
who wish to participate in the protest that they must act in a dignified and
modern manner and protest in a democratic way," Tetove Mufti Alifekri Esati told
our paper.

[Passage omitted: Esati says protesters must not use violence]

Source: Fakti, Skopje, in Albanian 10 Feb 06 p 5

                              350 of 995 DOCUMENTS

                                 Ottawa Citizen

                    October 10, 2002 Thursday Final Edition

Quebec Crown prosecutors protest working conditions: Provincewide walkout
protests imposed working conditions

SOURCE: The Ottawa Citizen; with files from The Canadian Press

BYLINE: Jean-Francois Bertrand

SECTION: City; Pg. C9

LENGTH: 406 words

Crown prosecutors across Quebec walked off the job for a few hours yesterday to
protest government-imposed working conditions.

It was the second such protest in a week, with prosecutors saying Justice
Minister Paul Begin had broken an agreement made with the prosecutors last year
that would allow them to negotiate collective agreements.

In Gatineau, 14 prosecutors marched in front of the courthouse, wearing signs
taped to the backs of their court gowns with messages such as "Paul Begin,
minister of injustice."

The walkout, which lasted until 2 p.m., affected about 100 court cases.

Quebec's 307 Crown attorneys had expected to resume negotiations with the
government to improve work conditions and salaries.

But Mr. Begin last week unilaterally set working conditions through a
ministerial decree.

And, at a press conference in Quebec City yesterday, Mr. Begin reaffirmed the
government's intention to forbid prosecutors from going on strike.

Mr. Begin's press secretary, Claude Potvin, said the minister's decree dealt
with most of the agreed-upon issues between the prosecutors and the government.
As for the prosecutors' right to negotiate collective agreements, that will be
addressed by a bill to be presented to the National Assembly, she said.

Claude Girard, president of Quebec's association of Crown prosecutors, is angry
the prosecutors have not yet seen the contents of the proposed bill.

"The minister talks of negotiating, but he proceeds unilaterally. We were to
meet and discuss, yet Mr. Begin is imposing his views," Mr. Girard said from
Montreal.

Ms. Potvin said that talks between the Crown attorneys and the province's
treasury board will soon resume to settle the salary question.

In August, provincial mediator Gilles Ferland recommended the prosecutors'
minimum annual salary be raised to $43,500 from the current $35,500. The report
also suggested that the maximum salary be increased to $102,000 from nearly
$95,000.

But Mr. Girard said the Ferland report compared Quebec prosecutors with their
federal counterparts rather than with those from other provinces.

In Ontario, for example, provincial prosecutors earn a maximum of $165,000
annually, while a senior Crown counsel is paid about $133,000.

The prosecutors are also waiting to see the results of a study comparing their
workload and compensation with that of their colleagues in the other provinces.

LOAD-DATE: October 10, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clement Allard, The Canadian Press; Paul Begin says the Quebec
government will not allow prosecutors to have the right to strike.

                               The Jerusalem Post

                            August 20, 2001, Monday

Mayors protest budget cuts

BYLINE: David Rudge

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 382 words


More than 20 council heads from confrontation-line communities in the North
demonstrated outside the Prime Minister's Office in Jerusalem yesterday to
protest against budget cuts.

The protesters held aloft placards stating that the cuts were as bad as
Hizbullah's Katyusha rocket attacks on their communities.

According to the mayors and council leaders, funding from the Interior,
Education, and Health Ministries are being reduced by a total of NIS 50 million.

Given rising unemployment in the region, particularly in Western Galilee, the
council heads have been pressing for additional financing.

They also stressed that the threat of terror attacks from across the Lebanon
border had not abated, despite the relative quiet following the IDF's withdrawal
in May last year.

Shlomo Buhbut, chairman of the forum of heads of confrontation line communities,
stressed that successive governments had pledged to strengthen towns and
villages in the North because of the security situation.

The region also suffers from economic problems and has not managed to attract
industry and other enterprises because of its distance from the center of the
country and from the ports and rail networks.

The IDF has also ceased sending soldiers to guard communities, and guarding is
now done by local residents or by private security firms hired by the local
authorities.

At one stage, the protesting council heads threatened to break into the Prime
Minister's Office, but were stopped by police.

Buhbut, who is mayor of Ma'alot-Tarshiha in the Galilee, shouted through a
megaphone to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon that the council leaders would not
accept the budget cuts. He warned that the communities would not open schools on
September 2 and that welfare and social services would be shut down unless the
cutbacks are rescinded.

Other council heads, among them Mufeed Amar, chairman of Hurfeish local council,
said the situation is particularly bad in the Druse village and that the
municipal budget is so badly overdrawn that salaried might not be paid.

We want to ask the prime minister to return to us the money that has been cut
from our budgets because we are already finding it difficult to function
properly Amar told reporters at the demonstration.

                         Blacktown Advocate (Australia)

                             June 8, 2016 Wednesday
                               Blacktown Edition

FOUR ARRESTS AT ANTI-MULTICULTURALISM PROTEST

BYLINE: Jessica Oxford

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 301  words


FOUR men were arrested after allegedly carrying weapons during anti-Sudanese and
Middle Eastern protests at Blacktown CBD on Saturday.

Up to 20 members of the Party for Freedom gathered outside Blacktown train
station, calling for "the deportation of Sudanese and Middle Eastern gangs" and
to reinstall the White Australia policy.

"We need to abolish multiculturalism - the most failed policy of all," protest
organiser Nick Folkes said. "This policy has brought more decline and division
to Australia and all Western countries." Outside Main St's 7-Eleven shop, Antifa
Sydney organised a counter protest, the Blacktown Rally Against Racism, where
between 50 and 60 people joined the group.

Chifley Greens candidate Eliza James was part of the protest and slammed the
opposing side.

"We want to contrast the xenophobic propaganda out there," she said. "We want to
stand in solidarity with migrants and we support multiculturalism in Blacktown."
Blacktown police crime manager Detective Inspector Paul Tickner said 50 officers
were on standby to ensure the protest was a peaceful event.

A 50m buffer zone was erected between the two protests to stop brawls from
breaking out.

"It's better to be over-prepared than underprepared for any protests," Det-Insp
Tickner said.

Police allege four men left the Antifa protest and continued to David Lane where
one man lifted another up to the shops' guttering.

The 19-year-old Blacktown man allegedly removed a set of knuckle dusters and
jumped down.

Police said the knuckle dusters and another pair belonging to a 19-year-old
Lalor Park man were seized.

The men, along with a 20-year-old Greystanes man and a 22-year-old Rooty Hill
man, were arrested and charged with possessing a prohibited weapon without
permission.The men are due to appear before Blacktown Court on July 14.

                              354 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           Daily News (South Africa)

                           February 13, 2014 Thursday
                                   E1 Edition

No quick fix for protests |- study

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 269 words


Curtailing protests in South Africa required long-term economic and
institutional changes, Johannesburg University researchers said yesterday.

"There cannot be short-term fixes, there needs to be real and substantial
change," said Carin Runciman, who specialises in the politics of protests and
social movements.

Professor Peter Alexander, South African research chair in social change and
sociology, said the focus on the service delivery dimension of protests was
often misplaced.

"Protests are not just about service delivery. Community protests are more of a
rebellion of the poor."

The poor were marginalised, and frequently stigmatised, and had limited means to
make their grievances meaningfully heard.

The research was based on over 250 interviews and drew data from four media
sources, covering more than 2 000 protests since 2004. It divided protests into
three categories - peaceful, disruptive, and violent.

Runciman said there had been a general rise in protest action since 2004, with
peaks in 2009 and last year.

"There is no clear relationship between protests and elections." Just after the
2009 general elections, however, an increase was noted. A possible explanation
was that people believed President Jacob Zuma would make substantial changes to
everyday lives, but when this did not happen, people resorted to protesting.

The research indicated that most communities began by expressing their
discontent peacefully, but this was frequently met with minimal response. The
protest would then become disruptive before becoming violent. The presence of
police also sometimes exacerbated the violence. - Sapa

                            October 14, 2013 Monday

BRIEF: Georgia hosts protests against Russia's actions on constructing fences
along administrative border

BYLINE: N. Kirtzkhalia, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 221 words


Oct. 14--TBILISI, Georgia -- Seven cities of Georgia held protests against
Russia's actions on constructing fences.

Citizens lined up in a human chain during the protests.

Protests started simultaneously at 15:00 on the central streets of Tbilisi,
Rustavi, Kutaisi, Telavi, Gori, Batumi, and Zugdidi. Young people lined up in a
human chain for 15 minutes.

Starting from the May of this year, Russian border guards have been actively
setting barbed wire along the administrative border of the Tskhinvali region
(the so-called South Ossetia) According to the Georgian Ministry of Foreign
Affairs, in some areas the line goes deeper into Georgian territory.The same
processes are observed at the administrative border with Abkhazia.

Large scale military action was launched in South Ossetia on August 8, 2008.
Later, Russian troops occupied Tskhinvali and expelled the Georgian military.

Russia recognised the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia in late August.
In response, Tbilisi ended diplomatic relations with Moscow and has called the
two unrecognised republics of Abkhazia and South Ossetia occupied territories.

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                             June 6, 2012 Wednesday
                              Business Day Edition

Western Cape hit hardest by service-delivery protests

BYLINE: SETUMO STONE

SECTION: SOCIAL ISSUES

LENGTH: 442  words


Western Cape hit hardest by service-delivery protests

SA EXPERIENCED a phenomenal rise in service-delivery protests last month, with
the Western Cape being the most protest-afflicted province, according to the
Municipal IQ's Hotspots Monitor, which records major protests staged against
local government.

The report indicates that the number of service delivery protests this year is
likely to eclipse the peaks of 2009 and 2010, with last month recording more
protests than any month since 2004.

Last weekend five violent protests were reported in Siyahlala informal
settlement in Philippi near Gugulethu, Cape Town, with residents demanding that
electricity be installed in their shacks.

Municipal IQ's Karen Heese said that protests last month included demands for
housing in Cape Town to a cluster of North West protests for tarred roads. & The
worrying theme was that they were violent and demonstrated high levels of
frustration,& said Ms Heese.

This comes as critics have cautioned that the African National Congress' (ANC's)
latest march against a painting depicting President Jacob Zuma's genitals might
set a precedent that could overwhelm the party and government.

However, the Democratic Alliance-led government in the Western Cape seems to be
at the receiving end of the protest action, despite reports of widespread
dissatisfaction with the performance of the ANC across the country.

According to the Hotspot Monitor, the ANC-led government in Gauteng province saw
a fall in protest activity, which Municipal IQ MD Kevin Allen attributed to a &
policing solution& quot;A policing solution to contain violence and destruction
of property is certainly relevant, but it is important for local government,
especially councillors, to acknowledge protests (without justifying violence)
and to be seen to be acting on the valid grievances of protestors,& he said.

Halfway through this year, 67 major protests were recorded, with the highest
record standing at 111 in 2010 - which were mostly linked to inter- and
intra-party political contestation ahead of the local government elections last
year.

Political analyst Steven Friedman said while the Municipal IQ study relied on
media reports, the actual numbers could be higher than reported.

& What we know is that we continue to have a high level of protests since 2004,
mostly because there is a widespread feeling among people in townships and
informal settlements that local government workers do not listen.& Spokesman for
Western Cape Premier Zak Mbhele said the provincial government was continuously
trying to engage communities over developments but public participation remained
low.

stones@bdfm.co.za

against the US jury's verdict then it would be the final verdict.Another protest

protest and demanded that Dr Aafia Siddiqui was innocent therefore she should be
released as soon as possible.The students have also held a protest rally in

to support Dr Aafia Siddiqui and put pressure on US government for the release

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              June 8, 2009 Monday

Journalists of closed Egyptian opposition weekly launch protest

LENGTH: 350 words


[Unattributed report: "the journalists of al-Sha'b newspaper launch an open
protest requesting the fulfilment of their demands."]

Cairo al-Sha'b WWW-Text in Arabic, weekly newspaper, affiliated with the
opposition Labour Party of Egypt, on 08 June 2009, carries an unattributed
1,200-word report entitled: "the journalists of al-Sha'b newspaper launch an
open protest, saying that they will continue the protest until their demands are
met."

The report says that the journalists of the newspaper al-Sha'b "launched a
protest in front of the premises of the Supreme Press Council," adding: "the
protest started at 1200 hours and ended at 1900 hours on 06 June 2009."

The report explains that the protest was staged after Chairman of the Supreme
Press Council, Safwat al-Sharif, "refused to receive the journalists."

The protesting journalists said that they will "escalate the protest until all
their demands are met," adding: "they would escalate the protest to the point of
entering into a hunger strike until death if their demands are not met."

The journalists denounced the failure of the concerned institutions to pay their
insurance dues, and noted that the "continued closure of the newspaper al-Sha'b
was an infringement on the constitution and law."

The protesting journalists denounced the government inaction concerning their
loss of jobs for the tenth consecutive year without trying to find a solution
for their problem. They pointed out that they continued to receive the same
salaries fixed in May 2000 when the newspaper was closed.

The report adds that the Editor-In-Chief of the al-Sha'b electronic newspaper,
Khalid Yusuf. Submitted two memos to the National Council of Human Rights. It
explained that one of the memos dealt with the salaries and benefits of the
suspended newspaper al-Sha'b while the other memo said that 14 court rulings
were issued since the newspaper's closure in May 2009 by the Supreme
Administrative Court revoking the decision suspending the newspaper, but no
action was taken to allow the republication of the newspaper.

Source: Al-Sha'b, Cairo, in Arabic 8 Jun 09

                          What the Papers Say (Russia)

                            December 26, 2008 Friday

PUBLIC DOUBT

BYLINE: Victor Khamrayev

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 255

LENGTH: 325 words



HIGHLIGHT: SOCIOLOGISTS REPORT A GROWTH OF PROTEST MENTALITY BUT ESTIMATE IT AS
WELL BEYOND THE CRITICAL LEVEL; Few Russians seem to be of the mind to join
protests.


Every third Russian (or less) expects any increase in activeness of protests in
the country and even less than that are prepared to join protests. Sociologists
report a certain growth of protest mentality in Russia but estimate it as well
beyond the critical level. They also doubt the abilities of the opposition to
head or even strengthen the protests.

According to the All-Russian Public Opinion Research Center (VTsIOM), 30% of the
respondents allow for the possibility of mass protests in their respective
cities or towns in the near future. This March, VTsIOM sociologists reported
this possibility allowed for by only 21%. "These trends never reached their
peak," VTsIOM Director General Valery Fyodorov said. "I recall that 47%
respondents expected mass protests in March 2005, right after the so called
social benefits-to-money conversion."

"Actually, nothing extraordinary is happening in terms of protest mentality
changes," Levada-Center Director Lev Gudkov said. "As far as we can judge, 23%
expect mass protests, 21% pledge readiness to join them, but only about 1.5%
will actually do so."

"Had it been even 15% actually resolved to join street protests, it would have
been a colossal social breakthrough," Gudkov said. "Not even rallies in Moscow
in the perestroika days would have paralleled them."

Sociologists meanwhile doubt that any opposition party stands a chance to head
or even strengthen the protests. Former opposition leaders (Boris Nemtsov,
Gennadi Zyuganov) "are distrusted", and younger ones (Maria Gaidar, Ilya Yashin,
Sergei Udaltsov) "remain unknown to the masses". Gudkov added that the
opposition needed "new leaders as well as a program that will interest society.
And they lack information channels to promote this program as well."

At the same time, it is common knowledge that the opposition itself prefers
contacts with the authorities to those with the population.

Source: Kommersant, No 237, December 26, 2008, p. 3

LOAD-DATE: December 26, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                            March 11, 2003, Tuesday

STUDENTS MARCH IN ANTI-WAR PROTEST

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 176 words


MORE than 50 students from Cardiff University walked out of their lectures to
take part in a protest against a war in Iraq. The protest yesterday afternoon
was intended to keep up the momentum after the national anti-war protest in
London last month.

The protest was a practice run for the intended protest at the Aneurin Bevan
statue in Queen Street on the first day of war.

The group turned shoppers' heads in Queen Street as they carried banners and
chanted anti-war slogans.

Some of the protesters felt the march would have little effect.

Francis McInally, a third-year geography student from Cardiff, said: "Blair and
Bush will go ahead with war despite public opinion."

# Meanwhile, an American couple are in Cardiff this week as part of a year-long
trip around the world to promote peace.

Dan and Diana Geiger, from Montana, are members of the Baha'i faith and will be
in South Wales until this Wednesd ay.

                           The New Age (South Africa)

                             May 27, 2015 Wednesday

Social protests on the rise

BYLINE: LERATO DIALE

LENGTH: 175 words


SOUTH Africa has experienced a 96% increase in social protests since 2010,
according to the Institute of Race Relations (IRR). Using figures from the SAPS
2013-14 annual report, the institute says during the last two years there were
11668 peaceful crowd-related incidents, 1907 unrest-related incidents, and 1691
incidents of public violence.

These included major service delivery protests, industrial action, demarcation
issues, and conflict between political parties.

IRR research analyst Gabriela Mackay says the social protests occurred mainly in
areas where there had been wasteful government expenditure.

"The trend for major protests shows that there is a greater rate of occurrence
in areas with high levels of fruitless and wasteful government expenditure."

There were 176 major service delivery protests last year.  Multiple factors
played a role in service delivery protests as the Western Cape had the lowest
level of fruitless and wasteful expenditure, but 14% of major service delivery
protests occurred in the province, Mackay said.
