                            Staffordshire Newsletter

                          September 17, 2014 Wednesday

SECTION: NEWS:PEOPLE; Pg. 2-3

LENGTH: 501  words


AROUND 300 Support Stafford Hospital campaigners marched on health bosses this
week in the latest phase of their campaign to keep maternity and children's
services.

And there were angry scenes at the annual meeting of the Stafford and Surrounds
Clinical Commissioning Group.

One member of the public called for a vote of no confidence in the health body,
made up of local GPs who commission services from hospitals and health
providers.

And another shouted: "How do we get rid of you?"

Campaigner Karen Howells claimed that moving the children's ward and
consultant-led maternity services out of Stafford was "a disaster waiting to
happen".

Mrs Howells, who is planning to fight the Stafford parliamentary seat for the
National Health Action Party, said other hospitals across the area were already
working at full capacity, with no slack in the system to take on Stafford
patients.

"This is highly dangerous," she said. "Stop the transfer of services before
lives are lost."

And she told CCG board members: "You are not listening to what local people
want. We want our maternity, paediatrics and A&E services to stay."

Jan Kelly, from Hixon, raised concerns about delays at the University Hospital
of North Staffordshire's A&E department, where she said patients were left
waiting on trolleys.

"I do not have confidence in UHNS and I do not have confidence in your choices
for me," she told the board.

Campaigner Julian Porter, from Brocton, queried the cost of moving services out
of Stafford, which he said amounted to over £300 million in its impact on other
hospitals.

"It seems to me you are spending £320 million to solve a £9 million CCG
deficit," he said.

Stafford borough councillor Rowan Draper challenged the CCG to provide evidence
that patients were consulted, and called for more input from health
professionals into decision-making.

"The CCG should remove voting members who are not clinical professionals," he
said.

"We need to get clinicians and other health staff in there making the
decisions."

CCG chief executive Andy Donald denied that it was decomissioning a
"significant" amount of services at Stafford.

"We are still paying for these services, though they will be provided
elsewhere," he said. "And we are proposing to commission enhanced services at
Stafford."

He said patients were consulted in all decision-making, and the CCG put quality
and safety at the heart of its work.

"We are more invasive than most CCGs in checking on health trusts and we are
absolutely focused on ensuring patients are safe," he said. "The CCG supports
Stafford Hospital. We support it in actions, in words and in resources."

But he said the organisation, which has a cumulative £18 m deficit to repay over
the next few years, faced pressures from rising patient expectations,
constraints on public spending, and the challenge of reshaping services for
future needs.

"We are not unique in that," Mr Donald said. "Similar problems of money and
clinical sustainability exist in places as diverse as Leeds, London and Sussex."

LOAD-DATE: September 17, 2014

want change."

suppression of freedom of speech.

                              371 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           October 17, 2013 Thursday

Egypt's Tamarrud movement denounces draft protest bill

LENGTH: 251 words


Text of report by Egyptian state-run news agency MENA

Cairo, 17 October: Tamrrud Movement, that spearheaded the 30 June protest that
helped topple Muhammad Morsi, denounced the protest bill approved by the
government, saying it restricts the right of peaceful assembly, an important
gain of 25 January revolution.

Non-peaceful assembly should be addressed by law without taking any step to
tight the noose on peaceful protesters, Muhammad Abd-al-Aziz, the movement's
political liaison official [said].

A number of political forces and rights groups have also criticized the draft
that was referred by the government to interim President Adli Mansur for review.

Under the 21-article bill, citizens have the right to organize and join
meetings, parades and demonstrations under certain conditions but bans using
places of worship as gathering points for protests. Demonstrators are also
banned from possessing weapons, ammunition, fireworks and face-covering masks.

To organize a protest, organizers should request permission from the police
station responsible for the intended site of protest 24 hours in advance. Such
permission should include the location and the pathway of the protest, start and
end time, the issue which the protest is concerned with, its demands and the
names of the organizers of the protest.

The law obliges the minister of interior to address the authorities concerned
with the demands of the protest to try to find solutions.

Source: MENA news agency, Cairo, in English 0542gmt 17 Oct 13

crackdown on their protest camp on Mall Road. The police claimed protests could
not be held in the area due to the imposition of Section 144. Later, those
arrested were released and they continued their protest on Mall Road. The
protest ended when party leadership decided to continue it from Monday

                             The Advocate (Burnie)

                            February 1, 2013 Friday

Tarkine protest battle looming

BYLINE: Sean Ford

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 316 words


DEVELOPMENT of a controversial iron ore mine in the Tarkine is moving closer,
and so are protests for and against it.

Shree Minerals Ltd has told the Australian Stock Exchange it will take steps to
finalise contracts, plans and processes to start project development at Nelson
Bay River in the far west of Circular Head during the current quarter.

It aims to start production in mid-2013, according to its December quarterly
report, released on Tuesday.

Environmentalists have foreshadowed on-ground protests in an attempt to stop the
mine, and mine supporters plan counter- protests.

Wilderness Society Tasmanian campaign director Vica Bayley said protests could
be expected if the mine development went ahead.

``People have declared their intentions," Mr Bayley said

He said the campaign against the mine had been building at community level and
much had been done informing and mobilising people.

``Nobody wants to protest; people want this issue off the agenda and proper
heritage listing," he said.

``Clearly, people value the Tarkine, want to protect the Tarkine and the Tarkine
has a long history of people emerging to defend it.

``It is an area that has got identified world heritage values and is partly in
an existing conservation reserve.

``You can expect protests at a range of levels."

Circular Head Mayor Daryl Quilliam expected protests against the protesters.

``The protests will be about the right to work and the right for people to go
and get jobs," Mr Quilliam said.

He was expecting the council leadership team to meet Shree around mid- February
to talk about the company's time frame and the counter-protests.

He stressed the counter- protests must not involve violence.

Shree gained Commonwealth approval for the mine in the December quarter and has
all the approvals it needs to develop it.

The first stage of the mine plan involves mining ore for direct shipping for the
first two years.

                               The Frontier Post

                           September 24, 2012 Monday

Protests and role of media houses

BYLINE:  Hafiz Muhammad Noman - Karachi

SECTION: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR Vol. XXVII No. 444

LENGTH: 610  words


The whole world is facing the huge protests by the Muslims against a US-made
anti-Islam and blasphemous film. The protests by the Muslims along with the
elements of violence in the protests are increasing day by day and surely it is
the expression of love with the last Prophet Mohammad (Peace Be Upon Him) for
whom, the Muslims are always ready to sacrifice their lives and can never bear
any kind of blasphemy with him but with all the prophets as the Muslims believe
in and respect all the prophets of the universe.

On this occasion, the Pakistani media is also responsible to perform its real
duty in order to promote, support and co-operate the protests but the Pakistani
media must be in favour of the protests by the Muslims so that US, its allies
and all the infidels should realize that everyone here is united on this issue
and cannot bear such blasphemous film or any kind of blasphemy and if someone to
do so, the Muslims would show severe reaction.

Unfortunately, the role of some media houses in Pakistan is very shameful as it
is reported that the US government is funding them in order to give a little
coverage to the protests against the blasphemous film or cause to alleviate the
intensity of the protests. Such media houses are shamefully exaggerating minor
torchings or flaming untoward incidents, which indeed shows that the American
agenda is being accomplished or acted on successfully.

Although the protests in civilized countries get more raged when the governments
hinder or prevent the protesters from their protests, hence every sensible
person can clearly gauge that some of the Pakistani media houses are serving for
the US government and supporting their stance by highlighting the element of
violence in the protests against anti-Islam and blasphemous film.

All the stress of some media houses in Pakistan seems to be spending on
criticizing the protesters' behaviour whereas some of our media houses do not
even seem ready to speak against cursed filmmakers, cursed French magazines'
editors and the governments that support them. Such media houses are not ready
to annoy those governments which are funding them.

Recently a French magazine published some nude photos of the princess of Britain
and what happened then, perhaps everybody knows! The government of Britain
immediately reacted and the French magazine was banned after this issue though
the magazine had no concern with the Britain. If Pakistan government and big
Islamic countries take some effective measures which send a message to the
Muslims that the Muslim governments are really annoyed on the blasphemous issue
and are taking some serious and extraordinary steps to legislate universal law
on the blasphemy of all the prophets as the Jews made a punishment law for the
opposition of their holocaust, then there was no reason that the protesters
adopted violence. When nothing takes place so, the protesters will adopt not
only violence but the element of flaming untoward incidents will also take place
as it happened in Libya and other countries.

It is not hidden now and everybody knows that in Islamic countries, the
diplomats from US and its allied governments keep busy in sabotaging strategies
rather than diplomatic activities and the clear example of this is our own
country Pakistan where America on the one hand claims to have good friendship
with Pakistan but on the other hand, Pakistan's sovereignty is being violated
openly. If the government in this situation wants to avoid any unpleasant
incident, some serious steps must be taken which represent rightly for their
sentiments because to control sentiments on blasphemy of any prophet is
impossible!

                   Globes [online] - Israel's Business Arena

                              July 1, 2012 Sunday

Thousands march to protest in Tel Aviv;
Protesters marched from Habima Square to the Tel Aviv Museum. A second protest
was held in Jerusalem.

BYLINE: Globes' correspondent

LENGTH: 384 words


A new social protest march was held in Tel Aviv on Saturday, a week after the
violent confrontation between activists and the police in the previous protest
and a riot in which several bank windows were broken. Last night's protest was
particularly tense, as the demonstrators marched from Habima Square to the Tel
Aviv Museum.

A protest march was also held in Jerusalem by several hundred social activists.
The demonstrators marched from Paris Square along King George Street to Horse
Square. Some protesters tried to disrupt the Jerusalem light rail.

In Tel Aviv, hundreds of people marched from Habima Square to the Tel Aviv
Museum, where they held the main demonstration. The organizers estimated the
number of protesters at several thousand. The police kept their distance. The
Forum for Social Justice said that the protest march had police approval, and
was fully coordinated with the security forces.

The police closed the streets along the march to traffic, but some protestors
demonstrated opposite the government compound in Tel Aviv, and, earlier in the
evening, others disrupted traffic on Namir Road and Shaul Hamelekh Street. The
police did not intervene.

At the Tel Aviv Museum, retired Police Major General Zeev Even-Chen, the father
of one of the victims of the Carmel fire, gave a speech in which he accused
government officials of failing to take responsibility for what was happening in
the country. "Everyone says it was not me; it's nothing but a kindergarten
headed by the prime minister The people who call you anarchists are themselves
anarchists. Not us."

In a statement today, the Forum for Social Justice said, "It has been almost a
year since we came out on to the streets with very clear demands from the
Israeli government. The government's attempts to say it doesn't understand shows
obtuseness and blindness. Today, we are telling the Israeli government, 'Open
your eyes. We are demanding increased investment in people. We are the people
who are bearing this country on our shoulders. The money that you will take in
the next harvest is not yours, but belongs to the citizens. You are only
responsible for its fair distribution."

Published by Globes [online], Israel business news - www.globes-online.com - on
July 1, 2012

© Copyright of Globes Publisher Itonut (1983) Ltd. 2012

                             The Northlines (India)

                          December 28, 2011 Wednesday

ReTs hold district level protests across the state

LENGTH: 307 words

DATELINE: JAMMU


JAMMU, Dec. 28 -- A large number of Rehbar-e-Taleem teachers held a protest
demonstration rally here on Wednesday to supporting the district level protest
here on Wednesday to press their pending demands. Meanwhile such protest also
held in Udhampur under the leadership of Vinod Sharma in support of their
consistently ignoring their genuine demands. As a part of the state wide protest
by the RET teachers forum, a protest demonstration and rally was also organized
in Poonch led by Najam Jafri, the state general secretary of the forum. A
Protest rally was also taken out from Parade ground to DDC office Poonch via
Main Bazar and Qila

Najam Jafri said if their genuine demands are not fulfilled, forum will start a
chain hunger strike during the forthcoming assembly session. A memorandum
submitted to DDC Poonch for CM. Others who spoke on the occasion included Shamim
Ansari, Sartaj Chowdhory, Arif Rathor, Badar Din, Manjeet Sharma, Shafiq Ahmed,
Niaz Kirmani, Muzaffar Ahmed, Kafeel Ahmed.

Similar protests were represented from other districts such as Samba, Kathua,
Rajouri, Udhampur, Doda, Ramban and Kishtwar where the protestors raised slogans
projecting their demands.

In Vijaypur too, a protest demonstration was organized by ReTs lead by Zonal
President of ReT body, Rinku Sha who repeated their demands included
regularization of the EVs who have completed the seven year service, enhancement
of wages of the RET, inclusion of rendered period of RET for promotion benefits,
rationalization of transfer policy in case of regularised RET teachers. Sharma
alleged that govt. is not in the mood to listen the genuine demands of ReT.

                              377 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                  Moscow News

                            December 12, 2011 Monday

State-owned TV acknowledge protests

SECTION: POLITICS

LENGTH: 466 words


Russian federal television stations showed Saturday's protest -- the first time
that federal television covered any Moscow protests against the election
results. Daily rallies have been held since Monday, the day after the election,
and more than 1,000 people were detained in the capital alone during rallies
since then.

Federal television channels ignored the run-up to the protest, but could not
stay silent as tens of thousands of Russians gathered on Bolotnaya Ploshchad on
Saturday to protests against elections violations and vote rigging.

Journalists wanted to report on protests

There were rumours on Saturday that NTV's news anchor Alexei Pivovarov refused
to go live with the 7 o'clock evening news if the protests were not mentioned,
Kommersant reported.

The channel denied these rumours, but opened their news program with repots of
the biggest protest in Moscow since the 90s.

On Dec. 5, up to 8,000 people gathered at Chistiye Prudy in an anti-election
protest, yet neither Channel One nor Rossiya 1, the two main state channels,
mentioned them, while NTV showed only a few seconds at 11:15 pm news.

However, TV channel employees on all levels, from top management to journalists,
were not happy to keep quiet about the rally on Dec.10, sources told Kommersant.

Protests on the news

First reports of the rally on Bolotnaya Ploshchad, which started at 2 pm, were
on air at 4 pm, with video, and were the first item on the news on NTV, Channel
One, and Rossiya 1.

The stories were 6-10 minutes, and not just seconds of footage, with interviews.
Rallies in other cities were also mentioned, even though evaluation of how many
people turned up were lower than some estimates.

Both state-owned Rossiya 1 and Channel One identified the protesters' claims:
against the results of the election and a desire to dismiss the head of the
Central Election Committee, Vladimir Churov. Not a single channel, including NTV
and Ren TV, showed any slogans and chants of the protesters against Vladimir
Putin. NTV, however, added that the protesters demanded a 'change of political
institutions in the country.'

NTV showed a protester on Bolotnaya saying 'I came here because I am sick of
everything. How much longer can people be cheated and treated like cattle.'

Kremlin ban

Many TV journalists told the Kommersant informally that the ban on reporting the
rallies came from the Kremlin, who did not comment.

Yesterday, a source familiar with the situation said the Kremlin was less than
pleased. 'Well, no one thanked them [the channels] for it,' he told Kommersant.

Sources in the Kremlin also told Gazeta.ru that it was President Dmitry
Medvedev's order that made the TV channels show the rallies and ensured that the
police was polite, and not a single person was arrested.

LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                           Copyright 2011 RIA Novosti
                              All Rights Reserved

                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                            March 23, 2011 Wednesday
                                  1 - Edition

Syrians protest despite threat

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 225  words


THOUSANDS of Syrians yesterday braved security forces and marched in the
southern town of Daraa after the funeral of a protester killed in the previous
day's unrest.

Witnesses said protests also spread to the nearby towns of Jasim and Enkhel.

"There was a massive deployment of security forces to block protests but
thousands gathered anyway," a witness said.

They used tear gas to break up the crowd and "arrested several people" on the
fourth day of unrest.

Daraa has become the unexpected nerve centre of anti-regime protests in Syria,
with protesters holding daily demonstrations since last week despite a huge
deployment of security forces and a heavy-handed crackdown on protests that left
five dead.

Demonstrators marched from a cemetery towards a mosque after the burial of Raed
Akrad, who was killed by security forces when they opened fire to disperse a
protest. They chanted "Just God, Syria and Freedom" and "Revolution,
revolution", and an activist said demonstrators would keep up their protests
"until all the demands were met".

The protesters, who have been inspired by regimechanging revolts in Tunisia and
Egypt, are demanding freedom and an end to 48 years of emergency laws in Syria
under President Bashar al-Assad.

Demonstrators set Daraa's courthouse ablaze on Monday after clashes with police
that left one person dead and 100 wounded.

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             March 14, 2011 Monday

Azeri police cordon off Baku university fearing fresh youth protests

LENGTH: 147 words


Police have cordoned off the area around Baku State University (BSU) fearing
renewed protests by young activists, the Azerbaijani Turan news agency reported
on 14 March.

A student protest was advertised on social networks to be held at the university
at 1400 (1000 gmt) as the continuation of the protests held in Baku on 11 and 12
March. However, there was no protest at 1445, the agency said.

The university management has decided to end classes earlier, and all students
have been warned against attending protests, Turan said.

In the meantime, APA news agency said police had obtained information that a
group of BSU students was planning an unauthorized protest outside the
university. Police have been deployed to the area to prevent the protest, the
agency added.

Sources: Turan news agency, Baku, in Russian 1055 gmt 14 Mar 11; APA news
agency, Baku, in Azeri 1008 gmt 14 Mar 11

                              382 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                          What the Papers Say (Russia)

                            August 20, 2009 Thursday

WEARY OF CRISIS

BYLINE: Tatiana Frolovskaya

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 156

LENGTH: 344 words



HIGHLIGHT: SOCIOLOGISTS: 25% RUSSIANS ARE PREPARED TO SUPPORT PROTESTS;
Specialists say that the Russians will adapt to the crisis rather than protest.


Twenty-five percent Russians are prepared to support mass protests. The opinion
poll conducted by the Russian Public Opinion Research Center (VTsIOM) shows that
the spring/summer lull is over and the number of the Russians sufficiently
desperate to support street protests increases again. Not that the Russians'
financial standing took a dramatic turn for the worst over the last month or so.
Sociologists ascribe the changes to depletion of the population's trust in
effectiveness of the anti-crisis measures taken by the authorities. In other
words, it is absence of changes for the better that encourages protest
mentality.

Protest mentality was showing a steady decline in Russia over the years
preceding the crisis. VTsIOM sociologists detected and reported reversal of the
trend in autumn 2008. The situation hovered on relative stability between April
and June this year but the latest opinion poll dispelled all optimistic
expectations. The number of the Russians prepared to support protest actions
increased from 21% in June to 25% a month later. The number of whoever flatly
refused to participate in protests in the meantime dropped from 74% to 66%. The
majority of respondents actually dismiss mass protests as quite unlikely but
even they show a decline from 71% to 67%.

And yet, sociologists refuse to entertain the idea that the increase in protest
disposition may make trouble for the authorities this autumn. "The situation
shows no improvement but that only foments pessimism, uncertainty, and a slight
increase in protest mentality," Denis Volkov from Levada-Center announced.
"There will be no mass protests, mark my words. The population will adapt to the
crisis rather than protest."

"People are weary of the crisis which is only natural," Igor Nikolayev of FBK
agreed. "Considering the relative stability of the ruble, this weariness does
not manifest."

Sociologists say that the Russians' negative moods (protests) peaked in the
period of smooth devaluation of the ruble in late 2008 and early 2009.

Source: RBC Daily, No 149, August 20, 2009, p. 2

LOAD-DATE: August 20, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                           Copyright 2009 Agency WPS
                              All Rights Reserved

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              March 2, 2007 Friday

Kosovo's Self-Determination refuses to reveal 3 March protest scenario to police

LENGTH: 279 words


Text of report in English by independent internet news agency KosovaLive

Prishtina [Pristina], 1 March: Although, the protest of the Self-Determination
Movement, which will take place on 3 March, is announced to be peaceful, the
activists of this movement say that it is possible that protestors will take
bottles with paint, whereas the Kosova [Kosovo] Police Service [ShPK] voiced
confident that the violence of 10 February will not be repeated.

This protest aims to show the dissatisfactions of the people of Kosova with [UN
special envoy] Martti Ahtisaari's package.

ShPK officials and activists of the Self-Determination Movement told KosovaLive
that the protest of 3 March will begin at 1400 [1300 gmt]. The protestors will
move from the Self-Determination Movement headquarters and will stop at the OSCE
headquarters.

The spokesperson for the ShPK, Veton Elshani, told KosovaLive that the activists
of Self-Determination Movement did not brief them about the scenario of the
protest.

"We had a friendly meeting with the activists of the Self-Determination
Movement, but they were not ready to tell us the scenario of the protest,"
Elshani said.

Elshani said that the ShPK together with UNMIK [UN Interim Administration
Mission in Kosovo] police are preparing an operative plan, which will be used if
the protest escalates and becomes violent.

On the other hand, the activist of the Self-Determination Movement, Xhelal
Sfecla, told KosovaLive that the scenario of this protest will be the same as it
was on the protest of 28 November last year.

He also said that, during the protest, they will have some short speeches.

Source: KosovaLive website, Pristina, in English 1 Mar 07

                                  Toronto Star

                    November 16, 2001 Friday Ontario Edition

CBC-TV reporter arrested in Tehran, footage erased

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A21

LENGTH: 200 words

CBC-TV reporter Neil Macdonald and his camera crew were arrested in Iran and
detained for four hours yesterday after shooting footage of a protest.

"They were covering an anti-government protest at a soccer stadium in Tehran
when they were apprehended, taken to a police station and questioned," said CBC
spokesperson Ruth-Ellen Soles.

"They were forced to play their taped material, then their material was erased,"
she said, adding, "But everyone was released and everyone's fine."

Macdonald, the network's Middle East correspondent, was arrested along with an
Australian reporter, his crew and two locals.

They weren't charged with any crimes, Soles said, and no one was hurt.

"But I'm sure it was very nerve-racking for everyone involved," Soles said.

Foreign Affairs spokesperson Reynald Doiron confirmed the incident yesterday
afternoon from Ottawa.

He said the Canadian embassy in Tehran was alerted to the incident and went to
the police station.

The group was subsequently released.

"They apparently had film footage not allowed in Tehran. They erased their
footage," he said.

"He was released and no charges were laid," the Foreign Affairs spokesperson
said.


LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                             July 23, 2016 Saturday
                                Regional Edition

The Dallas protests remained peaceful

SECTION: EDITORIAL COPY; Pg. A15

LENGTH: 222 words


The headline on the July 9 front-page article "Peaceful protests turn into
mayhem " was misleading. Only by reading most of the article did one realize the
error. The article made clear that the Dallas sniper was not part of the
peaceful protests, that he disrupted the peaceful protests and that he did not
change the nature of the protests. A more accurate headline would have read:
"Peaceful protest disrupted by shooter." No protesting person was reported to
have been moved to violence. The headline wrongly implied that the protesters
went from peaceful to violent. (Mayhem is violence.) Although I do not believe
this sloppiness was intentional, it contributes to the lack of understanding,
lack of identification and connectedness,  and lack of carefulness in speech
that are some of the conditions that increase violence in the United States.

We need healing, and we need to directly and honestly address not only what is
happening (which the headline failed to do) but also what happened in the past
that we find ourselves at this point. Kevin B. Blackistone's July 10 news
column, "White America's ongoing worry: The aggrieved black man," was a perfect
example of the type of reportage and opinion that are critical for us to face
our demons together and survive as a culture. Please be more careful.

Jeanine Hull , Washington

LOAD-DATE: July 23, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: Every Zone

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


     Copyright 2016 Washingtonpost.Newsweek Interactive Company, LLC d/b/a
                            Washington Post Digital
                              All Rights Reserved


                              386 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                               Egypt Independent

                             April 17, 2016 Sunday

Protesters insulted police seeking provocation: former deputy minister

BYLINE: Al-Masry Al-Youm

LENGTH: 451  words


Former Deputy Interior Minister Mohamed Nour Eddin said in a TV interview
broadcast on Saturday that the ministry has never rejected any requests to hold
public protests, denying accusations that political protests are routinely
dissallowed in Egypt.

"All requests submitted to the ministry was approved including permissions on
protests against the policies adopted by the ministry and the Minister Magdy
abdel Ghaffar himself," Nour Eddin said during a talk show on Al-Ghad news
channel.

He made the comments in the wake of protests across Egypt against the official
transfer for two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabian control, a move that has
provoked angry reactions within Egypt. At least 100 people were reportedly
arrested in various locations on Friday, as some protesters clashed with police.


Defending Egypt's system for regulating political protests, Nour Eddin said all
countries in the world have rules that regulate public protests, and the system
in Egypt is no different.

He said that groups who accompany the Egyptian president on his foreign tours
have to get permission to protest in support of Egypt during those visits. The
permissions includes specific hours and locations, as well as prior approval of
the slogans, so as to avoid insulting officials or inciting hatred.

The legislation regarding protests in Egypt does not ban them, but rather
regulatest their conduct, said the former ministry official.

He said, those people who protested on Friday were merely expressing their
concerns about the future of their country, and the police allowed them to
continue with their protests so long as they remained peaceful and did not
damage to property, use fireworks or flammable materials, or assault the police.

"When I conducted a tour of some places that saw protests, I didn't come across
one situation that didn't involve insults aimed at provoking the policemen," he
said, refering to the protests on Friday.

Among the protests on Friday, was one large gathering outside the Journalists
Syndicate, located in downtown Cairo. Security forces attempted to disperse the
protesters, leading to clashes.

On April 8, Egypt and Saudi Arabia signed an agreement clarifying the
demarcation of maritime borders between the two nations, just one of several
deals signed during the visit to Egypt of Saudi King Salman bin Abdel Aziz.

In a statement last week, the Egyptian Cabinet said that the agreement places
the two islands of Tiran and Sanafir within Saudi territorial waters, although
the agreement will need to be reviewed by parliament before it is ratified.

The two islands are of great strategic importance, being located at the entrance
to the Gulf of Aqaba

Edited translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm

LOAD-DATE: April 17, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              387 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           Daily Independent (Lagos)

                               February 08, 2016

Workers Protest Against 45 Percent Electricity Tariff Hike

LENGTH: 296 words


Workers under the aegis of the Nigeria Labour Congress and the Trade Union
Congress have started a nationwide protest against the recent increase in
electricity tariffs in the country.

The NLC had called for the protest after repeatedly calling on the Nigeria
Electricity Regulatory Commission to suspend the recent increase in tariffs.

The NLC President, Ayuba Wabba, who described the tariff hike as outrageous,
said it was the fifth in a row since 2012 and unacceptable.

In a statement calling for the protest Wabba said, "It is a nationwide protest,
meaning that the 36 states of the Federation including Abuja will be involved in
this action.

"Our members have been sufficiently mobilised and are ready to go. If you are an
electricity consumer and you are not happy with the bills electricity companies
serve you every month, you are invited to join this protest rally."

Civil society groups and activists also expressed support for the protest and
mobilised their members for it.

In Abuja, protesters could be seen carrying placards expressing their disdain
for the tariff increase with some bearing such inscriptions as "We won't pay
more for darkness".

Some of the workers came out as early as 7am for the protest, which started at
the Labour House in the Central Business District Abuja.

The workers are expected to protest at NERC offices and in the case of Abuja,
the protest will extend to the National Assembly.

The NERC had introduced the new power tariff regime in December, outlining the
various rates of increase in energy charges for consumers across the country.

It also announced the removal fixed electricity charges for all classes of
electricity consumers and noted that power users would only pay for what they
consume.

The new tariffs became effective February 1.

LOAD-DATE: February 9, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2016 AllAfrica Global Media.
                              All Rights Reserved

                          Daily Independent (Nigeria)

                            February 8, 2016 Monday

Workers Protest Against 45% Electricity Tariff Hike

LENGTH: 306  words

various rates of increase in energy charges for consumers across the country.

It also announced the removal fixed electricity charges for all classes of
electricity consumers and noted that power users would only pay for what they
consume.

The new tariffs became effective February 1.

                              389 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                          September 10, 2015 Thursday

Washington: Blog: Small Business Size and Status Protests Are Better Late Than
Never

LENGTH: 479 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Olympia: Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association, The State of
Washington has issued the following news release:



 Many small businesses have encountered set-aside competitions where they either
strongly believe, or know for certain, that a competitor has misrepresented its
size or status. Some feel that agencies sometimes look the other way, or even
purposely sidestep the small business rules, to allow favored firms of
questionable size to compete for these contracts.





 Although the small business size protest is an available remedy, the five-day
deadline for filing a well supported, "non-speculative" size protest often
presents a barrier for small companies. It is very challenging to research and
draft a quality size protest in just five working days. Also, what if the
company does not learn that the competitor is large or ineligible until after
the five-day deadline? What can be done in that situation?



 Two little known contracting regulations could come to the rescue. The first
rule is that there is no time limit on size or status protests filed by the
Small Business Administration (SBA) itself. The second rule is that the
contracting officer is required to transmit every size protest, filed within the
five-day window or not, to the SBA. So even if a small business is past the
five-day window, if it has actionable information, it still may file a size
protest. Accordingly, the contracting officer is required to send it to the SBA
for review. The SBA receives these "untimely" protests because the SBA can
choose to adopt the protest as its own without regard to the time limits that
apply to contractor size protests. The SBA will dismiss the contractor's
protest, but if the SBA chooses to take the ball, the protesting contractor
actually can end up with a stronger advocate than its own firm.



 Filing late is only a fallback strategy. Filing on time is much preferred
because the contract award can be prevented, and review by the SBA is required.
On a late protest, review is discretionary, and obtaining relief is not a high
probability. On the other hand, if the late protest is strong enough, the
contracting officer might even terminate the existing contract.



 So, if a company has information suggesting that a competitor who received an
award was not eligible because of size or status, it may be better to file a
late size or status protest than none at all&mdash;if the claim is
strong&mdash;because there is at least a chance for relief if the SBA itself
adopts the protest as its own.



 Finally, a size protest is not the only recourse. In some situations, it may be
possible to file a Qui Tam whistleblower case and recover a share of the
contract revenues the misrepresenting contractor has improperly received.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusme.com

LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                          September 10, 2015 Thursday

Washington: Blog: Small Business Size and Status Protests Are Better Late Than
Never

LENGTH: 479 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Olympia: Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association, The State of
Washington has issued the following news release:



 Many small businesses have encountered set-aside competitions where they either
strongly believe, or know for certain, that a competitor has misrepresented its
size or status. Some feel that agencies sometimes look the other way, or even
purposely sidestep the small business rules, to allow favored firms of
questionable size to compete for these contracts.





 Although the small business size protest is an available remedy, the five-day
deadline for filing a well supported, "non-speculative" size protest often
presents a barrier for small companies. It is very challenging to research and
draft a quality size protest in just five working days. Also, what if the
company does not learn that the competitor is large or ineligible until after
the five-day deadline? What can be done in that situation?

actually can end up with a stronger advocate than its own firm.

because the contract award can be prevented, and review by the SBA is required.
On a late protest, review is discretionary, and obtaining relief is not a high
probability. On the other hand, if the late protest is strong enough, the
contracting officer might even terminate the existing contract.



 So, if a company has information suggesting that a competitor who received an
award was not eligible because of size or status, it may be better to file a
late size or status protest than none at all&mdash;if the claim is
strong&mdash;because there is at least a chance for relief if the SBA itself
adopts the protest as its own.



 Finally, a size protest is not the only recourse. In some situations, it may be
possible to file a Qui Tam whistleblower case and recover a share of the
contract revenues the misrepresenting contractor has improperly received.

                               Egypt Independent

                            April 8, 2015 Wednesday

Report: security responsible for 70% of violence in universities during first
semseter

BYLINE: Egypt Independent,Nehal Mostafa

LENGTH: 309  words


Security services were involved in 70 percent of violence witnessed at
universities, while students were responsible for 20 percent of the violence
between October 2014 and January 2015, according to the Democracy Index report,
which also showed 820 students were arrested, 650 were imprisoned, while 440
students were dismissed, though no official accurate estimates were provided
about the security crackdown.Issued on Wednesday, the report said that 572
protests were staged by students, of those 521 were staged by university
students. At the top was Cairo University, then Alexandria then Helwan then Ain
Shams, then Zagazig, Menoufia, Mansoura and other governmental universities.

Eleven protests were staged by privately-owned universities and other 12
protests were staged by students of higher institutions.Sixty-nine percent of
the demonstrations demanded release and return of detained and dismissed
students, 12 Percent of protests were staged against court verdict clearing
former President Hosni Mubarak on charges of killing protesters, 18 protests
were staged against security crackdown on students, 14 protests were against
against the death of classmates caused at the hands of security forces, 17
protests were staged against violence and terrorism, whereas 15 percent of
protests were against administrative problems and demands of enhancing
educational services.Ninety-four percent of the protests were peaceful, while
5.5 percent were violent through blocking roads and sieging offices of
officials.Seventy protests were forcibly dispersed, despite being peaceful.
Thirty-four clashes erupted between protesting students and security upon the
violent dispersal of protests. Eleven bombs were found, while three stun
grenades exploded on university campuses, despite the high security
measures.Edited translation from Al-Masry Al-Youm

                               The Frontier Post

                             April 18, 2014 Friday

Countrywide MQM protest against workers' killing, arrest today

SECTION: Vol. XXVII No. 906

LENGTH: 483  words


The Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM) is all set to stage a country-wide protest
demonstration against 'extra judicial killings and forced disappearances of its
workers' on Friday, Local TV reported. MQM leaders said on Thursday if the
government, army and police could not provide party workers and leaders with
adequate security and protection, they should step aside and the MQM would come
forward for its own protection.

The MQM declared that a series of protests and sit-ins would continue to be
staged all over the country if extra-judicial killings were not stopped and
kidnapped party workers were not recovered.

The party leaders warned of this while addressing a protest rally organised at
the Karachi Press Club (KPC) as the first step in their series of protests. They
claimed that today's rally would be a big one and the more protests would
continue in the country if the law enforcement agencies did not stop their
'illegal and unconstitutional activities' against the MQM.

Carrying placards and banners, the participants of the rally raised slogan
against what they termed the extra-judicial killings and disappearances of party
workers. The affected families were also carrying portraits of their missing
family members and demanded the prime minister take steps for the recovery of
kidnapped activists.

Addressing the protest rally, Dr Farooq Sattar said that it was the MQM's
demand, and warning as well, to the federal and provincial government and
law-enforcement agencies to stop the violations of the Constitution and illegal
activities. He said that the MQM could deal with the plainclothes men itself if
the government and law enforcement agencies allowed the party to deal with them.

Farooq Sattar said: "Don't test our patience otherwise the scenes of deprivation
could be converted into scenes of destruction." He said that Thursday's protest
was a 'trailer' while Friday's protest would be 'the full film' and protests and
sit-ins would continue in the country till the unlawful activities of the
law-enforcement agencies stopped.

He said the articles 4,9,10 and 14 were being violated by the law-enforcement
agencies and the MQM was trying to draw the attention of the rulers and
responsible forces to stop these unconstitutional acts and avoid using unethical
and inhuman methods with the MQM workers.

The parliamentary party leader in the National Assembly Dr Farooq Sattar asked
the present regime not to create the Balochistan like situation in Sindh.
Addressing the rally the party leaders Haider Abbas Rizvi, Khawaja Izharul Hasan
and Ashfaq Mangi also warned the law enforcement agencies not to enforce the PPO
against the MQM otherwise the people would resist and rulers would be
responsible for the situation.

The participants got emotional when the mothers of two missing workers Farooq
and Irshad and daughter of Farhan spoke and shared the miseries of their
families.

                           The New Age (South Africa)

                            February 28, 2014 Friday

Protest slammed

BYLINE: FRANCE NYAKA

LENGTH: 389 words


THE ANC in the Bohlabela region near Bushbuckridge has condemned the recent
violent protests against alleged corruption in the Bushbuckridge local
municipality.

The condemnation follows the protest by residents and apparently ANC members who
barricaded the R40 road between Marite and Hazyview with rocks and other objects
this week.

The protesters demanded the removal of ANC regional chairperson Mandla Ndlovu
and other senior comrades.

They claimed that the municipality's tender system was under the control of
Ndlovu and his party colleagues, which only awarded their friends and relatives.

During the protest, a bus belonging to the Great North Transport was damaged and
motorists were prevented from using the road.

Schools and businesses in the area also came to a halt because of the volatile
situation.

The protest took place a week after a task team was established by the ANC's
provincial executive committee (PEC). It was tasked to investigate whether the
protests in the province were politically motivated.

ANC regional spokesperson Lydia Morewane said the party was shocked at the
violent protests, which undermined the rights of those who going to work and to
school.

"We condemn the protest which ended up undermining other people's rights.
Violent protests are against the country's Constitution," Morewane said.

She said ANC members were elected democratically and could only be removed in
that way, so people needed to submit their complaints peacefully to the ANC.

"We still need to confirm if some of the protesters are legitimate ANC members
or not.

"It is well known that ANC members are always disciplined and following the
right channels (in voicing any grievances)," Morewane said.

Municipal spokesperson Zondi Mkhabela said the allegations against it were
unfounded.

"We distance ourselves from the allegations, no political party or individual
can control our tender system.

"We are bound by the prescripts of the Municipal Finance Management Act when we
award contracts, so the allegations are baseless," Mkhabela said.

Bushbuckridge police spokesperson Lt Ndlovukazi Mashele said a charge of public
violence was being laid, but no arrests had been made as yet.

The police crowd control unit and tactical response team were now monitoring the
situation, he said.

francen@thenewage.co.za

                                Daily News Egypt

                           September 20, 2013 Friday

Morsi supporters set out to protest Friday

BYLINE: Mostafa Salem

LENGTH: 253 words


A number of protests was announced within Cairo and in certain governorates on
Friday as part of the "youth are pillars of the revolution" Friday.

Members of the Muslim Brotherhood and supporters of ousted President Mohamed
Morsi march through Cairo's Maadi Neighborhood on September 6, 2013.
(AFP Photo)

Protests set out after Friday prayers from different mosques in Cairo and Giza,
setting out from Al Iman mosque in Nasr City, Al Rian mosque in Maadi, Al
Istiqama mosque in Giza.

Several other governorates are also witnessing protests, including Alexandria,
Port Said, Sharqia and Minya.

The protests came after the National Coalition for Legitimacy, the Muslim
Brotherhood youth and the Anti-Coup Youth Movement called for mass protests
denouncing the Raba'a dispersal and the 30 June "coup".

Unconfirmed reports claim that several of the Cairo protests will be heading
towards Mostafa Mahmoud square in Mohandessin.

Protests  also broke out on Friday in the Giza village of Kerdasa, which is host
to a massive security operation that started on Thursday.

The Anti-Coup Youth Movement released a statement on Monday, 16  September,
appealing to the people to carry out civil disobedience on Sunday by refraining
from going to work: "We call on the people to go out to demonstrate in all the
streets of Egypt and assemble in the main squares since early morning Sunday."

                                Himalayan Times

                           January 26, 2013 Saturday

Khanal warns government to mend ways

BYLINE: Himalayan News Service

LENGTH: 239  words


Parbat: Taking the government's threat head-on, CPN-UML Chairman Jhala Nath
Khanal today warned that the opposition's parties would launch street protests
if the Unified CPN-Maoist and its coalition partners do the same.

Speaking at the press meet organised by Press Chautari, in Kushma, Perbat,
Khanal said all opposition parties of the country would jointly launch street
protests against of UCPN-M and its coalition partners if they obstructed their
protests. "The opposition parties have the right to protest," Khanal added.

However, he said his party was ready to hold talks with the government to iron
out the differences. "The opposition parties," he said, "have no interest to
protest but it has become a compulsion since the government has been doing
running the day-to-day affairs in an authoritarian manner."

He made it clear that the protest would not stop until the government mends its
way and puts an end to authoritarianism in the country. "Protest programmes
would be peaceful and maximum mobilisation would be provided to the people,"
Khanal said.

He accused that Unified CPN-Maoist of imposing dictatorship in the country.
"They like to prolong their stay in power, and at the same time come to streets
in protest," he said. He pointed that it was a kind of Panchayati system to
protest by the ruling party. Khanal went on to say that protests will continue
until a national consensus government was formed in the country.

                                 Target series

                                October 31, 2012

85 people sign up to support anti-immigration protest in Boston

SECTION: Pg. 5

LENGTH: 307  words


Eighty-five people have confirmed their support for Boston's anti-immigration
protest on Sunday, November 18.

Campaigner Dean Everitt has organised the demonstration by the Ingram Memorial
from 2pm to 3pm.

The decision to protest was made following the publication of a report from
Boston Borough Council into the social impact of population change in Boston.

The report made recommendations to try to deal with issues stemming from an
increase in population over the last 10 years, but Mr Everitt and other
campaigners said it fell short of tackling the real problems.

He said: "We are holding this to raise awareness to the ever increasing   issues
caused by uncontrolled mass immigration.

"We are hoping for a peaceful protest and would like many people to come on the
day to show their support for something everyone is moaning about in the town -
immigration."

The protest, which has attracted many people to its Facebook site, was set to
go-ahead last year but was cancelled.

Lincolnshire Police are fully aware of the planned protest.

Boston Police Station's community policing inspector Dave Rimmer said: "We are
working closely with the organiser  to ensure that the protest remains a
peaceful one with the minimum of disruption possible for the community of
Boston.

"Before, during and after the event the police will be engaged in ensuring that
anyone seeking to turn this protest into anything other than the peaceful
protest planned, will be dealt with according to the circumstances and existing
legislation.

"The organiser has a right in law to hold a peaceful protest, part of the
planning by the police is to ensure that we have the ability to respond against
a number of contingencies, to maximise the safety of everyone concerned, and to
this end there will be an appropriate and proportionate number of officers on
duty on the day."

                                   UMCI News

                            February 17, 2012 Friday

Students keep Algeria protests warm

LENGTH: 579 words


As weekly anti-government protests are planned in Algeria each Saturday,
students around the country keep the movement warm during weekdays, organising
strikes, sit-ins and protests.

As weekly anti-government protests are  planned in Algeria each Saturday,
students around the country keep the  movement warm during weekdays, organising
strikes, sit-ins and protests. The student protests in Algeria started  already
on 8 February, almost a week before the pro-democracy protests,  and were
sparked by unpopular reforms in the qualification system and  poor quality of
teaching at Algerian universities. But a loose  connection to the regional
anti-regime protest wave was soon noted.

Since the Saturday anti-government protests in Algiers, which was  brutally
dispersed by a large number of police troops, the pro-democracy  movement mostly
has staid off the streets, rather concentrating on  setting up a nation-wide
organisation to head the protests each  Saturday.

But meanwhile, the student protests are going on, spreading and reaching  new
heights. All over the country and during the entire week,  university students
have organised strikes, sit-ins and manifestations.

Ten days ago, some 500 students at the University of Algiers started  boycotting
classes. More student joined in a protest march the day after  as an "indefinite
strike" was declared. Then, students in thecites of  Oran, Tlemcen and Annaba
followed up with strikes and manifestations.

This week, the more politicised students have even widened their action.  In the
city of M'sila, the "indefinite" student strike was announced on  Monday.
Yesterday, an estimated 15,000 students took to the streets of  M'sila, mostly
shouting slogans against Algeria's education policies.  The protests were
peaceful.

Also yesterday, students from several cities, including Boumerdes, Blida  and
Oran, streamed into the capital, Algiers, establishing a protest  camp in front
of the Ministry of Higher Education. Students spent the  night in front of the
Ministry, demanding that a decree reforming the  qualification system be called
back.

Algeria's independent and usually well-informed daily 'El Watan' reports  from
the protest camp in front of the Ministry that protesters' numbers  were around
thousand. A student spokesperson told the newspaper that  "we are in contact
with 38 universities," all having joined the protest  movement.

Government so far has not reacted to these peaceful protests and  security
forces have not interfered with the students. Student leaders  in statements
have made sure only to focus on issues relative to  education policies, although
students' sympathies with the pro-democracy  movement have been demonstrated at
several occasions.

While government is not interfering with the striking students,  government
media are not mentioning the student protests. Independent  Algerian media,
which have a considerable market position, however give  the protests an ample
coverage.

While the Algerian student protest movement is increasing its pressure  on
government from day to day, also a wave of strikes is hitting the  country.
Hospital workers have been on strike, engineers and agronomists  have followed
and an education sector strike has been announced.

Also the striking groups maintain their mass action is connected to  working
conditions and salaries and is not in connection with the  mounting
pro-democracy movement. Popular belief in Algeria however says  otherwise.

LOAD-DATE: February 16, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 36


     Copyright 2012 UMCI News - United Mediterranean Council of Industries
                         Syndigate.info, Al bawaba.com
                              All Rights Reserved

                              New Vision (Kampala)

                             August 14, 2011 Sunday

Tour Operators Speak Out On Riots

BYLINE: Steven Candia

LENGTH: 375  words


TOUR operators have condemned the planned resumption of the walk-to-work
campaign, saying the protests will further hurt the industry and the economy.

The operators under the Association of Uganda Tour Operators (AUTO) said the
industry and the economy had taken a huge knock from the April-May protests that
were characterised by violence.

Amos Wekesa, the AUTO president, told an annual general meeting last week that
the resumption of the protests would turn away tourists and worsen the scarcity
of dollars.

Tourism is one of Uganda's top foreign exchange earners.

Wekesa noted that the industry and the economy had been battered by the earlier
protests and could not stand another wave.

"Tourism is the second largest foreign exchange earner. Any resumption of the
protests is likely to hurt the industry and consequently the national economy,"
he pointed out.

"Whatever happens affects both the industry and the economy negatively.
Something must be done. We condemn the protests," Wekesa said drawing a
thunderous applause.

Boniface Byamukama, the AUTO chairman, said there was need to avert the
walk-to-work protests because it is peak season.

The operators asked the Government and opposition leaders to resolve the matter
amicably. They said disruptions would hit the economy given the losses suffered
by the tourism and hotel industry in the previous protests.

"In the last protests, the tourism industry lost about 30% (about $340,000) of
the bookings, while the hotel industry lost 70% of its booking. If this happens
again, the economy will suffer. We condemn the walk-to-work protests," he said.

The tour operators disclosed that some of them have had to refund advance
payments by tourists who were forced to call off their trips following the
earlier protests.

Opposition parties last week announced that they would resume the walk-to-work
campaign in protest of the soaring cost commodity prices.

Kampala courts have dismissed several cases against party leaders in connection
with the May protests.

The tour operators also blamed the Government's violent reaction to the
protesters.

They argued that though the current economic situation was largely due to the
global economic crisis, it was partly so because of the after effects of the
protests.

                            June 16, 2010 Wednesday

Different protests demonstrations staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1560

LENGTH: 195  words


Different protest demonstrations were recorded by the people in favour of their
demands outside the Sukkur Press Club on favour of their demands on Tuesday.
According to details, the residents of Workers Colony staged a protest
demonstration against the stealing of furniture and transformer of their local
area school.

The members of the All Sindh Disabled Forum under the leadership of Chairman
Hafiz Aslam Hussaini, Dr Saiqa Mangi, Mubashir Sehto and others recorded a
protest demonstration for the provision of jobs and other facilities to the
disabled persons. The people of Jona community recorded a protest demonstration
for the recovery of their community girl Samina, who was allegedly kidnapped by
ASI Owais Lashari and his compliances.

A youth namely Ghulam Rasool Bhatti and his sister Lal Bibi, residents of ADC
Colony staged a protest demonstration for the provision of jobs to them. The
leaders of Sukkur Small Traders recorded a protest demonstration against the
several hours of unannounced load shedding. The members of a social welfare
organization SPO staged a protest demonstration against the worsening law and
order situation in interior of Sindh.

                            August 30, 2007 Thursday

Students join protests in Burma

LENGTH: 386 words


Excerpt from report by Norway-based Burmese Democratic Voice of Burma website on
29 August

According to the latest news at hand, we understand that at least 50 people
demonstrated in Tavoy, capital of Tenasserim Division or Coastal Region, from
1130 to 1230 today.

A resident said the protestors were on motorcycles.

[Begin unidentified male recording] An estimated 50 people, about 20 of them on
motorcycles, demonstrated in Tavoy from 1130 to 1230 today to protest high
commodity prices. [End recording]

That was a report about the protest in Tavoy. We have not been able to receive
details of the protest yet. Residents in the city seem to be afraid and are
reluctant to speak to the media.

The military has tightened security in the city and we understand there were no
arrests but further details could not be obtained yet.

That was the only protest today. Although earlier reports indicate that there
was another protest in Sittwe again today, it was not true because the resident
of Sittwe we spoke to was reporting about the protest yesterday.

We also do not have any news about the situation in Taungup and Kyaukpyu yet.

Security has been tightened in many other cities and residents say that it was
not easy to stage protests at the moment.

Meanwhile in Mandalay where many monks are residing, residents report that some
movement could be seen among monks who were gathering in small groups. [Passage
omitted on protests in Arakan State's Sittwe and Rangoon's Hledan yesterday]

Yesterday's protest at Hledan was led by Ma Su Su Nway and at least 11 youths
were arrested after members of the Union Solidarity and Development Association
and Swan Ahr Shin intervened.

Names and addresses of those arrested were: Ko Kyaw Soe Win, Ko Thant Zin Myo,
Ma San San Win, Ko Than Zaw Myint and Pho Hla Pye of Hlaingthaya; Ko Ye Naing
Thein of Chauk; Ko Aye Naing, Ko Mya Hlaing, Ko San Win, Ko Thant Zin Oo, and Ko
Nay Dun of Insein.

We understand they are currently being detained at the Kyaikkasan Interrogation
Centre in Rangoon.

This latest round of arrest if added to the list of detainees announced by the
Assistance Association for Political Prisoners [based in Thailand] would bring
the total of people arrested, including Min Ko Naing, to over 100.

Source: Democratic Voice of Burma website, Oslo, in Burmese 1430 gmt 29 Aug 07

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                           September 11, 2006 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Protest tense at sex offender's house;
Parsonfield residents exchange words with the men helping Joseph J. Tellier move
in.

BYLINE: ELBERT AULL Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 237 words


A protest near the new home of a convicted sex offender became heated early
Sunday afternoon in Parsonfield, a protest organizer said.

No one was arrested, and there were no violent incidents at the protest, where a
few dozen local residents picketed in opposition to sex offender Joseph J.
Tellier's presence at 26 Road Between the Ponds. But they exchanged tense words
with some men who helped Tellier move into his home during the protest, said
Parsonsfield resident Lars Fossum.

York County sheriff's deputies were on the scene monitoring the protest.

Tellier was convicted in 1989 of kidnapping, raping and beating a 10-year-old
girl, and has been the focus of protests in York County communities since he was
released from prison in 2004.

The latest round of protest erupted in July, when Tellier moved to a home in
Waterboro within 1,000 feet of two schools. He has moved three times since then
amid protest from residents.

Fossum said residents oppose Tellier's presence because his home is a short
distance from a school bus stop. He said protesters want to create a
neighborhood watch organization with members who would escort children to the
bus stop.

A public forum on Tellier is scheduled for 7 p.m. Thursday at South Hiram
Elementary School in Hiram. Chief Deputy Maurice Ouellette of the York County
Sheriff's Office and Department of Corrections Commissioner Martin Magnusson are
scheduled to attend, Fossum said.

                                   Irish News

                                  May 20, 2005

Groups call for protest against G8;

BYLINE: Barry McCaffrey

SECTION:  Pg. 11

LENGTH: 222 words


A coalition of Belfast-based pressure groups are calling on people to join in
protests against the world's super-powers later this summer.

The Belfast coalition is planning to take part in a series of protests in
Edinburgh in July when the eight richest countries in the world, known as the
G8, are to hold a summit to discuss poverty in Africa and global warming.

In the past, G8 summits have been the target of regular protests by a wide range
of pressure groups.

Some protests have been marred by violence carried out by extremist groups.

But speaking ahead of this summer's protests in Edinburgh, 'Grassroots against
G8' spokeswoman Ann Patterson insisted that a wide range of local groups would
take part in peaceful protests in Scotland in July.

"There is a misconception that only radicals and fascists are involved in the
protests against the G8 group," she said.

"It is totally untrue. I am a 50-something, pacifist who works for the Quaker
movement.

"Our group is made up of trade unions, Church people, community groups,
environmentalists and people who believe that it is wrong for the richest
countries to be robbing and pillaging from the poorest."

Mrs Patterson said that around 500 local people have already signed up to travel
to the Edinburgh demonstration in early July.

LOAD-DATE: May 20, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Copyright 2005 The Irish News Limited


                              408 of 995 DOCUMENTS

                                  Western Mail

                            March 25, 2004, Thursday

MORE TO STUDENT LIFE THAN PROTESTS

SECTION: First Edition; NEWS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 304 words


Three-quarters of first-year university students are not interested in taking
part in political protests, while two-thirds believe that student protest isn't
effective and doesn't make any difference, according to the Lloyds TSB/Financial
Mail on Sunday Student Panel.

Only a quarter of the panel, made up of first-year students at universities
across the UK, decided to take part in the recent 'day of action'.

Of those who did, the main reasons for taking part were the desire to try to
make a difference, the belief that protest could be effective as long as it was
well publicised and gained media attention, and that protest raised awareness
about educational policy among the general population.

Of those saying that student protest were not effective, the key reasons given
were, concerns about the image it presented of students just wanting an easy
life; claims that fellow students used protest days as an excuse to take a day
off studying; student strikes are ineffective as they don't withdraw an
essential service from the public; few of those taking part would go on to use
their vote at a local or general election; the Government wouldn't listen to
protests anyway.

Louise Williams, head of student banking, Lloyds TSB, said, 'Given that this is
the student population facing top-up fees and student loans, the views expressed
by our panel initially come as a surprise.

'However, as students are under more pressure to perform and get real value from
their education now than ever before, you can understand why protesting and
political activism have slipped further down their agenda.'

Students themselves acknowledge that they are not as politically fired as
previous generations - only a third believe that the current student population
is more active than their predecessors.

                             The News International

                           August 17, 2016 Wednesday

PAT to start protests from 20th

SECTION: Vol. 26 No. 165

LENGTH: 304  words


The Central Core Committee of Pakistan Awami Tehreek (PAT) in a meeting on
Tuesday announced the schedule for protest demonstrations from August 20 till
August 30.The meeting was chaired by its Chairman Dr Tahirul Qadri who declared
that "Qisas and National Solidarity Movement" would start from the 20th of this
month. He said that protest demonstrations and sit-ins would be held in Lahore,
Peshawar, Hyderabad, Faisalabad, Sibi, Kohat, Dera Murad Jamali, Mansehra,
Sukkur, Dera Ismail Khan and 71 other cities.

On the 21st, Gujranwala, Sialkot, Narowal, Hafizabad, Mandi Bahauddin, Gujrat
and 21 other cities will witness protest demonstrations and sit-in. On the 25th,
protest demonstrations will be held in DG Khan, Layyah, Rajanpur, Muzaffarabad
and 11 other cities. On the 27th, protest demonstrations will be held in
Bahawalpur, Lodhran, Bahawalnagar, Rahimyar Khan. On the 28th, protest
demonstrations and sit-ins will be held in Rawalpindi, Quetta, Karachi, Jhelum,
Chakwal, Haripur and 20 other cities.

Dr Tahirul Qadri said the second phase of "Qisas and National Solidarity
Movement" would start with a big protest demonstration and sit-in in Islamabad.
All the protest demonstration will be addressed by Dr Tahirul Qadri through a
video link.

Addressing the core committee meeting, the PAT chief said "our protests and
sit-ins are to get 'Qisas' for the Model Town killings and for country's
economic condition and rid the country of terrorists and extremists."

Dr Tahirul Qadri said the time was not far when the families of the Model Town
martyrs would get justice and the whole world would see. He said the revelations
made by the Panama Leaks were just a drop of water from a sea of corruption that
had been committed by rulers. He said a country filled with natural resources
was being looted with both hands.

                       Dorking and Leatherhead Advertiser

                              June 24, 2016 Friday

Nine cleared of obstruction at protest

SECTION: NEWS:LETTERS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 281  words



NINE people have been found not guilty of obstruction at  protests close to the
Horse Hill drill site, near Horley, earlier this year.

They  had all been arrested and charged with willful obstruction of the highway
after the demonstrations,  near the  site, where flow tests were taking place,
during February and March.

But, following a trial at Redhill Magistrates' Court last week, all of them have
been found not guilty.

District judge William Ashworth concluded the defendants were all walking at a
"reasonable" speed, and that their method of protest was not unreasonable nor
disproportionate.

Mr  Ashworth said: "By and large the protest at Horse Hill can be characterised
as a dignified and peaceful protest."

One of the defendants, Paddy Horne, said: "I am very happy. The fight goes on.
It is very important to nip any infringements [of human rights] in the bud."

Sarah Finch, from Frack Free Surrey, said: "The 'not guilty' verdicts are a huge
relief for the people involved, and a vindication of the right to peaceful
protest.

"Across the UK, people power is keeping the threat of unconventional oil and gas
drilling at bay.

"We will continue to use our right to peaceful protest to oppose further
drilling at Horse Hill."

Millions of barrels of oil were discovered below  the site last year.

Stephen Sanderson, executive chairman of UK Oil and Gas, which owns a large
stake in the firm doing  the drilling, said earlier this year: "I would like to
reiterate for the umpteenth time, that we are not fracking at Horse Hill."

The cleared defendants were: Isabelle Bish, Thomas Burke, Paddy Horne, Stephen
Jackson, Neil Lamonby, David Powter, Daniel Nye, George Stubbs and one other.

The October 1st democracy protests in Hong Kong were the largest since the
student protests in Beijing in 1989. Here's a look at how the events unfolded,
in video.

The Evolution of Joshua Wong | At age 17 he can't vote, but Hong Kong activist
Joshua Wong is leading a student movement for democracy.

Voices from Hong Kong's Protest | Hong Kong residents reflect on the recent days
of protests.

In Hong Kong, Protesters' Demands Denied | Outside of government offices,
tensions ran high as Hong Kong's leader refused to resign.

Scenes of Chaos in Hong Kong | Violent skirmishes broke out between
pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong and the men who tore down their
encampments on Friday in the neighborhood of Mong Kok.

Hong Kong, One Week Later | Pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong held one of
the largest rallies of their campaign Saturday evening, a gesture of defiance
following attacks on their occupied areas.

In Hong Kong, Deflated Hopes for Change | As the pro-democracy protests in Hong
Kong recede, one young woman reflects on the inevitable outcome and how it
forced her to confront the glaring inequities that she faces every day.

                                Himalayan Times

                              July 14, 2014 Monday

Women right activists' protest continues

BYLINE: HIMALAYAN NEWS SERVICE

LENGTH: 235  words


KATHMANDU: The women right activists continued their protest today in front of
the Constituent Assembly for the seventh time today to remind the government of
their demands.

The women rights activists had begun their sit-in protest in front of the CA
building after ending an their earlier protest in the capital from April 29.
They changed their form of protest on June 2.

The National Alliance of Women Human Right Defenders, which is leading the
protest, had said they were changing the form of protest after the government
assured them of addressing their demands.

According to the activists, even though the government was positive about
addressing their demands, no action has been initiated. They have been staging
sit-ins in front of the CA building every Monday to remind the government of
their demands.

The activists have been demanding amendment to existing rape laws, a fast-track
court for prompt verdict delivery on rape cases, fresh directives for Nepal
Police to make the investigation process related to rape cases sensitive and
effective, implementation of the provision of penalty for the perpetrators and
ensuring rape and sexual violence victims' right to study and health services.

Their other demands include promulgating laws to recognise discrimination
against rape victims as social offence and a high level committee to investigate
rape cases that took place during the time of conflict.
