                              414 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                 Aswat Masriya

                           October 2, 2013 Wednesday

Egypt saw 969 protests in September - Democracy Index

BYLINE: Aswat Masriya

LENGTH: 223  words


Egypt saw at least 969 demonstrations during September, 80 percent of which were
staged for political reasons, according to a Democracy Index report issued on
Wednesday.



The report cited that around 42 percent of the protests were arranged by the
Muslim Brotherhood, who staged 408 demonstrations in September.

The Cairo-based index added that most of the protests took place on Friday,
which "indicates that the Brotherhood used Friday prayers to mobilize a large
number of protesters."

"An observer would see a significant statistical decline in the Brotherhood's
organizational ability; as the first week in September saw 68 protests, which
decreased to 60 protests by the second week and 49 protests by the third,"
according to the Democracy Index that works under the International Development
Centre.

Supporters of deposed Islamist President Mohamed Mursi and the Brotherhood,
which he hails from, have repeatedly protested against what they call a "coup
against legitimacy" since the military ousted him on July 3 following mass
protests against his rule.

The protests climaxed following the government's crackdown on the two Cairo
sit-ins in mid-August where at least a thousand people were killed.

The report said that students represent the second largest group to stage
protests in September as they held 259 demonstrations this month.

against sacrilegious film.The police in federal capital is still on red alert,

Lahore.

against the blasphemous movie.

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          February 22, 2012 Wednesday

Protest rally held in Odessa in connection with 20th anniversary of Khojaly
genocide

BYLINE: E.Mehdiyev, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 535 words


Feb. 22--The 20th anniversary of the Khojaly genocide was marked by protest
march in the Ukrainian city of Odessa.

Representatives of the Ukrainian, Moldavian, Jewish, Turkish and Tatar youth
took part in a protest march, organized jointly by the Association of the
Azerbaijani Youth of Ukraine and the Youth Forum of the Organization of Islamic
Cooperation, the Association told Trend on Tuesday.

"Activists of the association, who organized protest march in the central
streets and squares of Odessa under the slogan "The Armenians have to answer to
history for the atrocities committed in Khojaly", members of youth organizations
of Turkish, Tatar, Jewish, Ukrainian and other nationalities distributed among
the local population booklets with information on the atrocities committed by
the Armenians in Khojaly.

Despite the frosty weather, the youth fell to the ground, forming the number
"613" -- such number of people became victims of the Khojaly genocide. Then 613
black balloons were released to the air, on which words "Justice for Khojaly"
were written, which was a call for justice, addressed to the world community and
international organizations.

Then, with the participation of the Diaspora representatives of number of people
living in the Odessa district, local and foreign students a ceremony of
remembrance of victims of Khojaly genocide was held. Speaking at the remembrance
ceremony the President of the Association Anar Tahirov and chairman of the
Association's Odessa organization Samir Aliyev brought the facts of numerous
crimes, genocide, ethnic cleansing and aggression of Armenia against Azerbaijan,
stressing that they can be traced over the past two centuries.

The event participants watched a documentary on Khojaly genocide, telling about
the atrocities the Armenians committed against children, women and elderly
people in frosty February night.

After watching the film Consul General of Turkey in Odessa Argan Hussein said
"Official Yerevan and the current leadership of Armenia directly involved in the
Khojaly genocide must be held before an international court".

Chairman of the All-Ukrainian Youth Organization Anton Daritchenko, Chairman of
the Moldovan youth organization Andrew Tetyu and others who spoke called the
historical injustice that after 20 years the international community has not
given the legal and political assessment of this tragedy.

At the end of the event for the legal and political assessment of the genocide
committed by Armenians against Azerbaijanis in Khojaly, an appeal to the
Parliament of Ukraine and international organizations was adopted.

The Armenian military forces committed genocide in Khojaly on Feb. 26, 1992.
Some 613 people were killed, including 63 children, 106 women and 70 old men. A
total of 1,000 civilians were disabled during the genocide. Eight families were
annihilated, 130 children lost one parent, and 25 lost both. Additionally, 1,275
peaceful residents were taken hostage, while the fate of 150 remains unknown.

Do you have any feedback? Contact our journalist at agency@trend.az

___ (c)2012 Trend News Agency (Baku, Azerbaijan) Visit Trend News Agency (Baku,
Azerbaijan) at en.trend.az Distributed by MCT Information Services

                            January 23, 2012 Monday

Kosovo movement ends protest at one of two border checkpoints

LENGTH: 262 words


Text of report in English by Pristina-based weekly Self-Determination Movement
website on 23 January

[News: "Protest at Dheu i Bardhe Terminated"]

On January 14, the government tried to violently suppress peaceful protest,
whereas on January 22, the government chose other methods to make impossible the
sustainability of the protest. The Kosova [Kosovo] Government continued this
special war throughout the day. The police obstructed the transport of all
logistical material necessary to assist protestors to survive extremely low
temperatures, such as tents, wood for heat, reflectors, generators, food and
drink.

Due to the logistical restrictions made by police which made impossible the
secure continuation of the protest at Dheu i Bardhe [Bela Zemlja],
representatives of Levizja VETEVENDOSJE! [Self-Determination Movement] in a
responsible manner ended today's protest at Dheu i Bardhe. A number of
protestors went on to join the protest at Merdare.

About 22.00 [ 2100 GMT], after declaring the ending of the protest there was a
problem between various protestors, but not for political reasons. It was
personal and isolated. The police are dealing with it and it is not related to
the ending of the protest.

At Dheu i Bardhe and at Merdare, leaders of Levizja VETEVENDOSJE! continually
called on protestors to be calm and measured [restrained]. They stated that
anyone who did not respect the peaceful plan for the protest would not be
considered part of our movement and unwelcome to stay amongst the protestors.

Source: Vetevendosje website, Pristina, in English 23 Jan 12

                              419 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                   Arab News

                             March 13, 2011 Sunday

Protests or no protests

LENGTH: 276 words


For weeks since the contagious uprisings took to the streets and squares of many
cities in the Arab world, we have been hearing rumors about protests and
"Fridays of Rage," we received calls from friends and heard some reports about
demonstrations and protests in Riyadh and other cities in Saudi Arabia. When
asked about these reports, our answer always was: "Where are you getting all
these stories from?"

By NASSER SALTI | ARAB NEWS

My wife and I were sipping coffee Thursday morning when I asked her about the
talk among women in the neighborhood and, what their take was on the would-to-be
protests.

She told me that one lady asked her son what is he going to do after Friday
prayer. The young man, in his early twenties, replied jocularly: "I do not know
exactly but I would probably join my friends in the protest." She asked him,
"What protest?"  dripping sarcasm, "For not letting you sleep until noon
throughout the week."

She said I know you are joking because just three weeks ago you and thousands of
young people rallied throughout the city celebrating the king's safe return
following his treatment in the US.

But the city was waiting whether it would be protests or no protests. Those who
have lived in Riyadh long enough know that the city has an instinct, and Riyadh,
unlike what some Orientalists may think, has no mysteries and no secrets. That's
why people here until now never have taken the protest stories seriously. Friday
night as the dust storm was sweeping over the city, my friend said, "I think God
is on the side of the government, nobody will enjoy a protest in a dust storm".

- Nasser Salti can be reached at nassersalti@hotmail.com

                              420 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           Cape Argus (South Africa)

                           January 12, 2011 Wednesday
                                   E1 Edition

Study says protests will escalate

BYLINE:  ELLA SMOOK Metro Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 453 words


South African politicians are to blame for "incentivising" violent service
delivery protests because of the way they react to such incidents, says a top
international researcher.

Hirsh Jain, a Harvard Law School researcher and visiting fellow at the
University of the Western Cape's Community Law Centre, recently published a
paper on his research into community protests nationwide between 2007 and the
middle of 2010.

Jain found that protest action in South Africa had become increasingly violent
since 2007, and that communities felt the only way to hold politicians to
account was to take aggressively to the streets.

Derek Powell, a senior researcher at the Community Law Centre, said one of the
questions raised by Jain's research was whether the increase in protests would
translate into different voting behaviour in the upcoming local government
elections, with angry communities ejecting non-performing political parties.

"Earlier research undertaken by Professor Susan Booysen of the University of the
Witwatersrand suggests that protesting communities actually return the incumbent
political party to office," he said.

"If this occurs in the 2011 election, it will be a signal that protests, not
elections, are the main mechanism for calling elected local officials to
account, and hence that local democracy is not maturing."

Jain's research shows that protests have "increased substantially" over the
course of the past two years, with an average of 8.7 protests a month during
2007 rising modestly to 9.83 during 2008 but shooting to 19.18 a month during
2009.

Protests remained a frequent occurrence during the first half of 2010, with an
average of 16.33 protests a month across the country. Protests have also become
more violent.

During 2007, about 41.6 percent of protests were violent, with people being
intentionally hurt, houses and other structures burnt, shops looted, rocks
thrown at passing motorists, tyres burnt or roads blocked.

By 2010, 54.08 percent of protests included elements of |violence.

Gauteng was "overwhelmingly the predominant site of |protests", with a third of
all action on its soil during the period of measurement.

The Western Cape came in second with 16 percent of the protests, followed by the
North West and the Eastern Cape.

Standing head and shoulders above other reasons for protesting, housing was
cited twice as often as electricity, water and generally poor service delivery.

Jain said the authorities had to evaluate the effectiveness of their current
approaches to community protests because, although they consistently condemned
violent protests, "much of what the state does, starting at the highest levels,
seems to incentivise engaging in flagrant displays of violence".

LOAD-DATE: January 12, 2011

                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

Albanian opposition decides to resume protests in October 2010

LENGTH: 635 words


Text of report by Albanian leading national independent newspaper Shekulli, on
23 September

[Report by Denis Dedej: "Opposition Decides To Resume Protests in October"]

Even though it did not announce any specific deadline, the opposition implied
that it would wait until the end of the current month for its election
transparency demand [to be met] and, if this demand is not met, the opposition
would begin protests in October. This was the decision made by the left-wing
coalition yesterday.

Taking part in the meeting were PS [Socialist Party] Chairman Edi Rama, PDS
[Social Democracy Party] Chairman Paskal Milo, PBDNj [Human Rights Union]
Chairman Vangjel Dule, PDK [Christian Democrat Party] Chairman Nard Ndoka, PLD
[Party for Freedom and Justice] Chairman Spartak Ngjela, and G99 [Group99]
Chairman Erion Veliaj.

During the 60-minute meeting in one of Tirana's most renowned restaurants on the
Deshmoret e Kombit Boulevard, the opposition parties discussed the options about
the future political course, including that of the protests. The discussions
ended with the agreement on the resumption of the protests at a date and with an
agenda to be set in the coming days.

Meeting

Sources in the opposition meeting told Shekulli that the parties agreed that
after failing to capitalize on the big chance offered by the European Parliament
for a solution to the country's political crisis, the only way to bring an end
to this situation was by organizing massive protests throughout the country.

At the meeting the opposition leaders accused Prime Minister Berisha of lacking
the will to give his consensus for the 2009 Assembly election transparency by
reopening the ballot boxes. Under these circumstances the opposition decided to
resume the protests on a continuous basis.

The same sources said that the protests throughout Albania would resume in a new
situation created after the failure to take advantage of the chance offered by
the European Parliament. It was also agreed that the deadline and the dates for
beginning the protests would be discussed at a later date, on the basis of the
opinion provided by the PS.

The opposition leaders agreed to start preparations for democratic protests and
create the right atmosphere for them. They exchanged opinions about the sequence
of the protests. However, it was agreed that the decision on this issue should
be made by the PS forums, since the PS leaders are the opposition leaders.

Nevertheless, the scheme will be the same as the one used in the protests of
previous months, that is, the protests will be first held in towns all over the
country and then they will culminate with a major protest [in Tirana].

Stance

PLD Chairman Spartak Ngjela, speaking in the name of the opposition, declared
that the meeting had decided on the resumption of massive protests.

"We undertook to lead the people in the protests, because a people whose rights
have been violated and who still fail to protest, is destined to have no future.
The protests will begin all over Albania in October. We will later decide the
day the protest will be held in Tirana," declared Spartak Ngjela.

He said that the vote manipulation, the economic degradation, the moral decline
of the Albanians and the entire society, the loss of the perspective, and the
major confusion stemming from a loss of confidence in this government of
corruption, theft, and abuse all obliged the opposition to stand up and assume
its moral responsibility.

"Albania wants protests and we will, certainly, lead the people, with
responsibility, until this government is removed from office, until the current
prime minister resigns, until this government resigns from the political scene
for all the reasons I just mentioned before," declared the opposition
representative.

Source: Shekulli, Tirana, in Albanian 23 Sep 10

Different protests staged in Hyderabad

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1472

LENGTH: 266  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged by the local people in Hyderabad on
Friday.  According to details, the activists of the JSQM under the leadership of
Abdul Fateh Channa, Haji Anwar Mallah and others staged protest for the recovery
of their arrested party leaders namely Akash Mallah and Noor Muhammad Khaskheli.
Members of the Ahl-e-Sunnat Wal Jamaat under the leadership of Maulana Abdul
Majeed, Muhammadullah Qureshi, Abdul Ghaffar Shakir and others staged a protest
demonstration for the arrest of the killers of Shaheed Moulana Abdul Ghafoor
Nadeem.

The activists of the Awami Tehreek Tando Allahyar chapter under the leadership
of Farid Kalhoro, Dhani Bux Khaskheli and others staged a protest demonstration
for the arrest of the killers of Siyani Khaskheli. The people of the Khoso
community, residents of district Matiari staged a protest demonstration against
the atrocities of an influential landlord namely Ferozuddin Shah. The people of
the Oad community staged a protest demonstration for the arrest of the killers
of their community youth namely Ameer Gul Oad.

A man namely Sultan Mughal along with his family members, residents of Latifabad
No. 8 staged a protest demonstration against his brothers for ejecting him from
the house.  The PPP workers of Chambar district Tando Allahyar staged a protest
demonstration against the local party leadership for neglecting them. The
activists of the Jamaat-e-Islami under the leadership of Maulana Abdul Waheed
Qureshi, Shaikh Shaukat Ali and others staged a protest demonstration against
the proposed razing of Masjid-e-Aqsa.

                              Daily the Pak Banker

                            February 5, 2010 Friday

Pakistan: Protest rallies observed across Pakistan in favour of Dr Aafia

LENGTH: 390  words

DATELINE: Pakistan


Pakistan, Feb. 05 -- ISLAMABAD, The Pakistan Professional Forum has observed
protest rally in favor of Dr Aafia Siddiqui after convicting her by the US
jury.The protest rally was started from Blue Area to China Chowk, addressing the
protest rally the Naib Ameer of Jamat-e-Islami Punjab Mian Muhammad Aslam has
said that the people of Pakistan could not accept the US jury verdict because Dr
Aafia was innocent and time was not far when she would be released.He also urged
President Asif Ali Zardari and Prime Minister Syed Yusuf Raza Gilani to bring
Pervez Musharraf to face the court. The central leader of Jamat-e-Islami Asif
Luqman Qazi said that if Dr Aafia Siddiqui was not released, the serial of
rallies would continue until her release.He said that if Aafia Siddiqui had
committed any crime then her trial should have been held in Pakistani's court.

He said that Pakistan should quit from the so called US alliance and war against
terror.Earlier President Asif Ali Zardari has directed the government to
establish contact with Dr Aafia Siddiqui's family.Meanwhile the protest rallies
were observed in all over the country against the US jury's judgment convicted
Dr Afiya Siddiqui.According to a private TV channels, several organizations in
all cities of Pakistan held protest rallies while a huge rally was observed in
Quetta to show sympathy with Dr Aafia Siddiqui.Talking to a protest rally Dr
Fauzia Siddiqui, the sister of Dr Aafia Siddiqui has appealed the people of
Pakistan to stand against US jury's verdict and convey the message to US
government.Talking to a private TV channel, Dr Farogh Naseem, a famous lawyer
has said that if any appeal was not registered against the US jury's verdict
then it would be the final verdict.Another protest rally was held in Karachi
organized by PASBAN where hundreds of people observed protest and demanded that
Dr Aafia Siddiqui was innocent therefore she should be released as soon as
possible.The students have also held a protest rally in Gujranwala and the
participants of the rally demanded from Pakistani government to support Dr Aafia
Siddiqui and put pressure on US government for the release of Dr Aafia.

Jerusalem's haredi neighborhood of Mea She'arim protest the detention of a
yeshiva student who failed to appear at the IDF enlistment center last month.
The student was expected to be in detention until after Succot, but in the face
of mounting protests, authorities decided to release him tomorrow, ahead of Yom
Kippur.

                             Kashmir Times (India)

                           September 11, 2015 Friday

Clashes, protests against court decision

LENGTH: 415 words

DATELINE: SRINAGAR


SRINAGAR, Sept. 11 -- Clashes and protest demonstrations were held at several
places in response to protest call given by separatists against the high court
ban on beef ban.

The police fired smoke shells and resorted to lathi to disperse the post Friday
protest at several places against the beef ban. Senior separatist leaders Syed
Ali Shah Geelani, Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, Mohammad Yasin Malik and Shabir Ahmad
others were either places under house arrest or detained by police.

The day begun with tension over the beef ban, soon after the Friday prayers
large number of youths took to streets at Nowhatta in old Srinagar and tried to
held a protest demonstration against the beef ban. The policemen deployed there
prevented them from holding the protest.

Police used tear smoke shells to disperse the angry protesters .The youths also
pelted stones towards the security forces. In Sopore town clashed erupted in the
township after police prevented them from holding the protest demonstration.

Police resorted to aerial firing to disperse the protesters who alleged hurled
stones on the government forces in Pulwama. Protest demonstration was also held
after Friday prayers outside Masjid Hamza Amirakadal. Amid slogans the
protesters tried to march towards clock tower Lal Chowk, however, police swung
into action and detained number of protesters.

Anti-beef ban protests rocked Kashmir University as well where hundreds of
students and scholars amid pro-freedom, pro-Geelani and anti-India, anti- BJP,
RSS slogans marched on the campus of the varsity.

Protest march was taken out in Central Kashmir's Ganderbal district that was
headed by Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front leader Noor Muhammad Kalwal. Reports
said that the march was taken out form Markazi Jamia Masjid Beehama and
culminated peacefully amid pro-freedom and pro-Islamic slogans. Peaceful protest
march was also taken out in Kangan and Lar town of the district.

In Budgam district witnessed scores of protest marches shortly after Friday
prayers. A police official said that these protest marches culminated peacefully
and police did not use any force on the protesters. The protest marches against
the beef ban were taken out from main market Budgam, Krimshora, Khansahab,
Shamsabad, Aarigam, Raithan, Dreygam, Kanira and other places.

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 8, 2014 Wednesday

Turkish interior ministry urges to cease protests

BYLINE: Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 340 words


Oct. 08--Turkish Interior Minister Efkan Ala urged the population of Diyarbakir,
Mardin, Siirt, Mus, Van and Batman provinces to stop the riots and protests, as
they are becoming dangerous, Turkish newspaper Milliyet reported Oct. 8.

"No question can be resolved through the riots and protests," he said.

In early October the Kurds-populated Syrian town of Kobani, was taken under
control by the IS. The move triggered mass protests among the Kurds in six
provinces of Turkey. Some 15 people were killed during the protests. Following
the protests, a curfew was declared in the provinces of Diyarbakir, Mardin,
Siirt, Mus, Van, Batman.

On Oct. 2, 2014, the Turkish parliament adopted a mandate that gave permission
for the country's armed forces to participate in the military operations abroad.

Turkish PM Davutoglu said the country would do anything possible to protect
Kobani, adding that Turkey will take part in ground operations against the IS in
Syria only if the airspace of Syria is declared a no-fly zone.

The terrorist organization known as the 'Islamic State' (IS, formerly ISIL or
ISIS) was created in 2003 in Iraq. Between 2004 and 2006, the organization was
led by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, and consisted of 11 radical Islamist groups, which
had close ties to the terrorist organization Al-Qaeda.

Following the start of military confrontation in Syria in 2013 between the armed
opposition and the government forces, the IS penetrated the country. The
organization said at the time it refuses to take the oath of Al-Qaeda and
declared 'a holy war' against all groups in Iraq and Syria, as well as the
Syrian government forces.

In late June of 2014, the IS announced about the creation of the 'Islamic
Caliphate' on the territories under its control in Iraq and Syria. In turn,
Iraqi authorities asked the international community for help in fighting the IS.

                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                            February 07, 2014 Friday
                                   E1 Edition

Up In Flames Protests becoming increasingly violent

BYLINE:  Caryn Dolley

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 326 words


There has been a surge in violent protests across the country as elections loom,
with nine people dying, allegedly at the hands of police, in five weeks.

This death toll is equal to the total number of people killed during protests
throughout last year, according to statistics from the South African Institute
of Race Relations.

There are at least five protests a day in South Africa, says the Institute for
Security Studies.

This week a number of protests erupted around the country, with the East London
city hall being petrol bombed during one flare-up and in another, a man being
shot dead in Sebokeng, south of Joburg.

Yesterday in the Western Cape there were protests in Sir Lowry's Village and in
Kuyasa, Khayelitsha. Roads were closed and protesters targeted journalists.

These protests come days after President Jacob Zuma called on the public to act
within the law and police to exercise restraint.

Race relations institute figures show there have been four deaths in the North
West, three in Limpopo and two in Gauteng.

Police ministry spokesman Zweli Mnisi said: "We are concerned, not only from the
viewpoint that police might have shot (protesters). Any loss of life at a public
protest is unacceptable."

He said the police respected the right of people to protest, but expected them
to do so within the law.

"What we're seeing of late is criminality, police being attacked," Mnisi said.

Gareth Newham, the Institute for Security Studies' governance, crime and justice
division head, had expected to see an increase in protests this year as had
happened before the last provincial and national elections in 2009.

During electioneering campaigns, residents believed that holding protests could
get the attention of politicians.

Newham said the deaths this year were "a new dynamic" in protests and it was not
clear what was behind this.

He said it could be as a result of protests being more violent or because police
involved were not properly trained. 8P2

                              429 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                         Intellinews - Turkey This Week

                                August 12, 2013

Turkish PM Erdogan vows crackdown on anti-government demonstrations if protests
flare again.

LENGTH: 146  words


Turkey's PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the country's security forces would be
ready to respond to any anti-government protests if they flared again after
summer holidays.

The protests have nothing to do with freedoms, Erdogan said. Deputy PM Bulent
Arinc recently said that the government had intelligence reports suggesting that
there would be more anti-government protests this autumn.

The anti-government protests engulfed Turkey's major cities, including Istanbul
and the capital Ankara, in June after police cracked down on demonstrators
seeking to save a park in Istanbul. The clashes between the protesters and
security forces left five people dead and thousands people were injured and
arrested.

The police crackdown on the park protesters angered many Turks and the initial
Gezi park occupation transformed into a nationwide political movement against
the AKP government.

BRIEF: Employees of Iranian Hamadan Telecom protest due to working hours, salary
cuts

BYLINE: S. Isayev and T. Jafarov, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 123 words


Oct. 24--Employees of Iran's Hamadan Telecommunication company have staged a
protest in front of company's headquarters, ILNA reported.

This is the second time this year that the employees of Hamadan Telecom are
staging protests because of small pay.

Reportedly, the employees' working hours and salary both were cut in half, which
was the reason for protests.

Currently the employees are working 4 hours a day, while receiving salary which
is not enough, because of high prices in the country.

                                 Jerusalem Post

                          September 13, 2012 Thursday

Palestinians call for Friday protests to demand end to Oslo Accords

BYLINE: KHALED ABU TOAMEH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 346 words


Palestinian activists have called for mass demonstrations in the West Bank on
Friday to demand an end to the Oslo Accords and other agreements signed between
the PLO and Israel.

The call came as public transportation workers and social activists announced
that they have suspended their protests against the high cost of living until
Sunday.

The decision to suspend the protests came despite calls from many youth groups
to continue demonstrating against Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Salam
Fayyad.

Some activists said they have come under heavy pressure from the PA leadership
to suspend the protests that swept through the West Bank in the past 10 days.

The activists said that the PA leadership was worried that "outside elements"
were taking advantage of the protests to incite against PA President Mahmoud
Abbas.

PA leaders were also concerned that the protests could plunge the West Bank into
anarchy and lawlessness and "benefit the Palestinians' enemies."

The protests were initially directed only against Fayyad and his government's
economic policies.

But in the past few days Palestinians also started demanding the resignation of
Abbas and the cancellation of the Oslo Accords.

On Wednesday, an anti-corruption group in the West Bank issued a call for mass
demonstrations to demand an end to the Oslo Accords.

Signed by the Coordinating Committees of the Palestinian Revolution Against
Corruption and Dependency, a statement published in Ramallah said that the
demonstrations would be held under the motto "The Friday of National Dignity."

The group said that it was also demanding the cancellation of the Paris
Protocol, which regulates economic ties between the PA and Israel.

In his weekly radio address to Palestinians, Fayyad renewed his appeal to Arab
countries and Western donors to provide the PA with urgent financial aid to ease
the economic hardships.

He said the PA has been suffering over the past two years from a severe
financial crisis because of lack of international aid and that the current
crisis was the worst since the establishment of the PA in 1994.

                               The Frontier Post

                             June 21, 2012 Thursday

Murree Road be declared 'protests free'

BYLINE:  F. P. Report

SECTION: Vol. XXVII No. 351

LENGTH: 195  words


Due to increasing protests demonstrations, the city district government
Rawalpindi has failed to declare Murree Road protests free which cause immense
inconvenience and problems to citizens while travelling on the busiest road of
the district.

In the most recent protest against prolonged power outages on Murree Road,
hundreds of violent protesters damaged public property and traffic remained
suspended for all kinds of traffic for several hours but police remained
helpless to control the situation as protesters outnumbered security personnel.

Former Commissioner Rawalpindi Zahid Saeed had started efforts to make Murree
Road protest free exactly like ban of staging protest demonstrations on Mall
Road Lahore. Moreover, traders, people from various sectors of life and social
organizations had also initiated movement to declare Murree Road protest free.

After the transfer of former Commissioner Zahid Saeed, his successor
commissioner Rawalpindi Israrullah Bosal could not continue efforts in this
connection.

Citizens demanded concerned authorities to take effective steps to make Murree
Road protest free as increasing protests and rallies cause inconvenience to
them.

                              435 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                            Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)

                              June 24, 2011 Friday

WASL protest allegedly stopped by Army

LENGTH: 477  words

DATELINE: Sri Lanka


Sri Lanka, June 24 -- Parents of missing and disappeared Tamil youth staged a
protest in the Killinochchi town yesterday to urge the authorities to release
information of the whereabouts of their children.

The protest, which was organized by the 'We Are Sri Lankans' organization, was
allegedly stopped by military personnel in the area who had allegedly explained
to them that staging protests in the area was not permitted. The protesting
parents held placards and photographs of their missing children and shouted
slogans urging the authorities to release information about their children who
had gone missing during the war.

"These youth went missing at a time when a very different political situation
existed in the country. But now that the war was over, it is vital to tell these
parents where their children are so that they could go back to living their
lives again in peace," WASL Executive Committee member and former Inter
University Students Federation (IUSF) Convener Udul Premaratne said, speaking at
the protest held yesterday. He urged the government to ensure that the
democratic rights of these people were secured. "If the government took measures
to release the information of the missing youth, Sri Lanka wouldn't be
experiencing interference from other countries," Premaratne added.

Meanwhile, Premaratne also alleges that two individuals attached to WASL -
Sinnathurei Rajendran and Lalith Kumar Weeraraju, who assisted in organizing the
protest, had been detained at a military camp from Wednesday and had only been
released after the protest was stopped yesterday. He also alleged that military
personnel had visited several homes in Killinochchi on Wednesday and told the
people to forget about the protest.

Similar protests had been organized in the Trincomalee and Vavuniya districts
earlier for the same cause by WASL.

Army denies involvement

The Army denied that military personnel had been involved in obstructing a
protest that was carried out yesterday by the parents of missing and disappeared
Tamil youth in Killinochchi yesterday.

The 'we are Sri Lankans' organization which had organized the protest said that
the military had intervened to scuttle the protest claiming that people were not
allowed to carry out protests in the area. Their Executive Director, Udul
Premaratne said that more than 200 military personnel had tried to stop the
protest from taking place.

However Military Spokesman, Major General Ubaya Medawala said that there had
been no military involvement. No military assistance was requested as it was a
peaceful protest which did not require any military presence," Major General
Medawala further said. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily
Mirror Sri Lanka. For any query with respect to this article or any other
content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             April 25, 2011 Monday

Al-Jazeera highlights protests in Iraqi cities calling for US forces pullout

LENGTH: 380 words


Protests in Iraq

Doha Al-Jazeera Satellite Channel Television in Arabic at 1535 gmt on 24 April
carried the following announcer-read report: "Iraqi protesters in Iraq have
urged all Iraqi governorates to stage protests and sits-in aimed at driving the
US occupation forces out of Iraq and releasing detainees. In the meantime, a
number of Al-Ramadi people staged an open-ended sit-in calling for the
withdrawal of the occupation forces from Iraq."

Immediately afterward, the channel carried a video report highlighting the call
by the people of Mosul on all Iraqi governorates to stage protests, since they
"share the same suffering." The video added: "The protesters started quoting the
slogans of the Tunisian and Egyptian revolutions. With one voice they say: The
people want the regime to fall."

The video added that the people of Tikrit responded to the call by protesting,
"but the security forces convinced them to end the sit-in for a few days until
they obtain the required permission." It added that the protesters told the
police that they would "protest a few days later."

He went on to say: "People in the city of Al-Ramadi staged protests in the
centre of the city, but the security forces refused to allow this and designated
a place at an entrance of the city where they could protest." He continued by
saying that "people began protesting and hoped that they would be able to reach
the city centre some day and protest there."

The video continued by saying: "It seems that protests are contagious, as they
spread from one city to another. Protests were staged in Al-Sulaymaniyah
Governorate in northern Iraq, and lasted for many days. Then, the Kurdish
Peshmerga forces intervened and raided the location of the sit-in.

"In Baghdad, preparations are under way to launch a massive protest once the
100-day deadline, set by Iraqi Prime Minister Al-Maliki, expires. But the
situation in Baghdad is very unstable. There is a gap between the stance of some
politicians on protesting in support of Bahrain, to extend support on a specific
political issue, and the stance of protesters in the Al-Tahrir Square in
Baghdad, who chant slogans in support of Iraq and want a united Iraq, away from
sectarianism and corruption."

Source: Al-Jazeera TV, Doha, in Arabic 1535 gmt 24 Apr 11

                            Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)

                               May 7, 2010 Friday

IUSF complains to Inspector General of Police

LENGTH: 275  words

DATELINE: Sri Lanka


Sri Lanka, May 7 -- The Inter-University Student Federation (IUSF) yesterday
lodged a complaint with the Inspector General of Police, Mahinda Balasooriya
against an attack on them by the police when they held a protest march in
Colombo recently.

IUSF spokesman, Udul Premaratne said on May 4 the protest commenced near the
Vihara Maha Devi Park at 11.00am and police intervened and tried to put a stop
to the protest.

"Initially when we started the protest the police came and intervened in the
matter. They told us not to carry out the protest. We asked him which law gave
them the authority to stop us from carrying out a protest? They accepted they
had no right to do so and allowed us to proceed with the protest," he said.

Premaratne said after the student had walked about a kilometre, the police had
barricaded their path and refused them space to proceed with their protest. He
said within a short space of time union members were assaulted. Five had been
wounded and one who was seriously wounded had to be hospitalised.

"It is completely unacceptable. They have no authority to do such a thing. It is
usually common for the police to fire tear gas when situations get very intense.
However we had just begun the protest. There was no need for them to harass us
in the way they did," he said.

The IUSF carried number of protests this week against amendments to be made by
the University Grants Commission to reduce the duration of the nursing degree
from four to three years. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily
Mirror Sri Lanka. For more information on news feed please contact Sarabjit
Jagirdar at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement,
please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              443 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                  Moscow News

                           February 25, 2010 Thursday

Protests at utility hikes spread across Russia

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 491 words


Anna Arutunyan After a spate of protest rallies rocked Russian cities over the
long weekend, experts and sociologists expect more to come. And a key trend in
the streets is that once-marginalised groups are uniting with the established
opposition, under a combination of both social and political demands.

The axis of the protests, however, has switched from Moscow and St. Petersburg
to outlying areas of the country. After an unprecedented 10,000-strong protest
in Kaliningrad last month over a hike in transport tariffs, up to 2,000 people
rallied in the far northern city of Arkhangelsk on Saturday, protesting an 18
per cent utilities hike. Over 500 protested in Samara against a similar hike,
and smaller rallies were held in Siberia's Kemerovo region.

Unresolved social and economic issues are driving these rallies and spilling
over into political protest, with some activists openly calling for Prime
Minister Vladimir Putin's dismissal. Labour-related conflicts grew nearly
threefold from 2008 to 2009, according to the Centre for Social and Labor
Rights, with 272 disputes and strikes in 2009 - up from 93 in 2008.

"General protests are increasing, and this is logical," said Pyotr Bizyukov, an
expert at the centre. "When labour disputes are not resolved, protests involving
a wider range of civic issues increase. Labour problems can turn into civil
problems, and you get [situations] like those we have seen in Kaliningrad and
Arkhangelsk."

While tariff hikes alone provoke protests every year and are not necessarily an
indicator, this year they became the last straw after other problems had
accumulated during the economic crisis, said Carine Clement of the Institute for
Collective Action, an organisation that brings together various left-leaning
groups.

"There is a trend towards more involvement in protest organisation since the
monetisation protests in 2005," Clement said, referring to massive rallies
against state reforms of the benefit and welfare system.

The protests in 2009, taken as a whole, outnumber the protests from 2005, said
Mikhail Delyagin, an economist at the Institute for Globalization Studies. "A
total of 5 million people were involved in protests in 2009, while in 2005 there
were about 3 million."

Social protests are increasing, he said, and they could have an impact on the
2012 elections. "A systemic [political] crisis in the country can't be ruled
out."

Vyacheslav Nikonov, head of the Politika think tank, dismissed such talk.
"Obviously, when a protest against something is organized, the authorities are
blamed," he said of the linkage between social and political demands in
Kaliningrad and elsewhere.

The real political battles are being waged over the regional Duma elections that
will take place on March 14, Delyagin said. There, tensions are comparable to a
"civil war", as various political figures struggle to maintain their standing
and their business interests, he said.

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                           Copyright 2010 RIA Novosti
                              All Rights Reserved

Students of International Islamic University Islamabad (IIUI) staged a protest

According to details students residing in the University Hostels became agitated
over two suicide blasts in the university campus and staged a protest rally in
the varsity and also staged protests demonstration for evacuating the students
from University Hostels.

Later when federal Interior Minister A. Rehman Malik visited IIUI, the students
of the university were staging protest demonstration and he urged on the
students to observe unity and directed the police deployed at Campus not to
restrict the students from venting their emotions.

Students also chanted anti-America slogans during the protest and some students
wept bitterly at the loss of lives of their fellow students and friends and told
the Minister that security arrangements in the university were not better and
appealed to the Minister to punish the responsible elements.

                        BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             March 27, 2009 Friday

Kyrgyz opposition leader happy with protest results

LENGTH: 363 words


Excerpt from report by privately-owned Kyrgyz AKIpress news agency website

Bishkek, 27 March: "The indefinite protests, scheduled for 20 April, will be a
constituent part of the election campaign," the leader of the [opposition]
Ata-Meken party, Omurbek Tekebayev, said at the end of the peaceful protest,
which was held in the Kyrgyz capital's Gorkiy Park today.

He said that the scheduled protests were held across Kyrgyzstan in difficult
weather conditions, particularly in the south of the country where heavy rain
had continued since the morning. He said that the rain was preceded by the
authorities' crippling threats against activists and protesters.

"The activists, who were invited to the protests particularly in Bishkek, were
arrested every day without explaining any reasons for this and held them at
detention centres of the National Security Service and the police. Students and
civil servants were threatened with expulsion and dismissal," he said.

"However, despite this, the protests were held in all places. We had said that
3,000 people would take part in the peaceful protest in Bishkek, but, according
to our estimates, over 6,000 people took part," he said.

[Passage omitted: the protesters put forward several political demands to the
president]

The party leader said that the resolution would be sent to the president.

"We are happy that we did not give in. We are banded together and determined to
bring about the change of power," the opposition leader said at the end of the
opposition protest today.

"The United People's Movement intends to prepare both for the presidential
election and the indefinite protests, which are scheduled for 20 April,
simultaneously. The indefinite protests will become a constituent part of the
election campaign," Tekebayev said in conclusion.

[Passage omitted: ex-defence minister Ismail Isakov said the indefinite protests
would begin on 20 April unless the authorities met opposition demands by this
time]

According to different estimates, including that of the law-enforcement
agencies, from 400 to 1,000 people took part in the protest in Bishkek.

Source: AKIpress news agency website, Bishkek, in Russian 0956 gmt 27 Mar 09

                          Hindustan Times (New Delhi)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 6, 2009 Tuesday

Protest continue over Pashupatinath priests appointments

BYLINE: Anirban Roy, Hindustan Times, New Delhi

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 408 words


Jan. 6--KATHMANDU -- Even after the ban on protests and rallies around
Pashupatinath temple, people on Tuesday continued with demonstrations close to
the holiest Hindu shrine of Nepal.

The Pashupati Area Development Trust (PDAT) on Monday evening had announced ban
on protests and rallies in and around the 17th century shrine as the disapproval
over the appointment of two Nepali priests had resulted in a violent protest.

The Bhandaris (junior priests) of the shrine have also reportedly extended
support to the protests on Tuesday, which interrupted vehicular movement in
Gaushala and Chahabil areas.

The protesters shouted slogans against the Maoist-led government and demanded
resignation of Prime Minister Prachanda. "Why is he (the Prime Minister) not
respecting the orders of the Supreme Court?" Ranjan Bhandari, one of the
protesters said.

The apex court on January 1 had asked the PDAT to put on hold the appointment of
the Nepali priests. The devotees are angry as the PDAT on Monday had filed a
writ petition at the Supreme Court claiming that the court's order was "unjust
and unfair".

However, the matter became intricate as PM on Monday had told that the
government would accept the SC verdict regarding the appointment of Bhattas in
Pashupatinath shrine.

Moreover, Information Minister Krishna Bahadur Mahara on Tuesday added more to
the controversy when he claimed that the Nepali priests were appointed to manage
the Bheti (offerings of devotees) at the temple.

Speaking to journalists at Dang, Mahara, who is also the spokesman of the
government, said that they wanted the offerings to be used primarily for social
welfare.

Meanwhile, Head priest (Mul Bhatta) of the Pashupatinath Temple Mahabaleswor
Bhatta told Hindustan Times that he is not a party to the controversy and wanted
to leave Nepal immediately.

"I want to leave as soon possible. I hope the devotees will help me to find ways
to go back home," the head priest, who hails from Karnataka, said. He has served
in Pashupatinath shrine for more than 15 years.

To see more of the Hindustan Times or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.hindustantimes.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Hindustan Times, New Delhi
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                   What the Papers Say Weekly Review (Russia)

                             March 31, 2008 Monday

NO EXTREMISTS

BYLINE: Yevgenia Zubchenko

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 4

LENGTH: 245 words



HIGHLIGHT: SIXTY-TWO PERCENT DENOUNCE ANY INTENTION TO PARTICIPATE IN PROTEST
ACTIONS; Protest moods in Russia are at a low level at this point.


Levada-Center sociologists asked the Russians if they viewed opposition
activists as extremists. As it turned out, most Russians regard Eduard Limonov's
banned National Bolshevik Party as an extremist organization. Thirty-four
percent respondents called NBP an extremist organization and 28% said it was
anything but. Grigori Yavlinsky's Yabloko and the Union of Right Forces are
viewed as extremist organizations by 8% respondents (each). Nine percent branded
Mikhail Kasianov's People's Democratic Union and 10% Garry Kasparov's United
Civil Front as extremist.

It may be added that all these political structures arrange protest actions on a
more or less regular basis. Yabloko activists picketed in front of the
Prosecutor General's Office and Interior Ministry earlier this month demanding
Maxim Reznik's release from the detention cell in St.Petersburg.

Sociologists say in the meantime that few respondents admit readiness to join
protests. Sixty-two percent Russians denounce any intention to participate in
protest actions. Only 22% will protest to defend their rights and freedoms, and
16% are undecided.

"Protests are always the lot of the active minority," political scientist
Alexander Kynev said. "The majority never participates in protests and not only
in Russia... On the other hand, even 5-6% of the population are sufficient to
carry out revolutionary changes."

(The opinion poll was conducted this March.)

Source: Novye Izvestia, No 53, March 28, 2008, p. 2

LOAD-DATE: March 31, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                                October 08, 2007
                              Business Day Edition

Violent protests

BYLINE: D Wolpert

SECTION: OPINION & EDITORIAL; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 124  words


Violent protests

I was stunned to read Phillimon Mnisi's letter stating violent protests such as
those at Wits University are likely to continue because of the "arrogant
attitude of management", Protests at Wits (October 5).

What claptrap!

Do we therefore infer that due to our president's arrogant approach to many
issues, we should give ourselves the right to engage in violent and destructive
forms of protest?

My suggestion is that while students have every right to democratic protest,
they are obviously in need of a proper education and should at least devote
ample time to their studies. However, we are approaching examination time and,
predictably, those who are ill prepared are once again vandalising their
learning institutions.

Rivonia

LOAD-DATE: October 8, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                           November 5, 2016 Saturday

Protests spill over to city as venue remains deserted

SECTION: CHANDIGARH

LENGTH: 306 words


Vaivasvat.Venkat@timesgroup.comLudhiana: Despite the ground opposite Vardhaman
industries being allocated as the venue for protests, the orders have not been
implemented, with protests still being conducted outside the DC office.A major
protest was conducted outside the VC office by Congress leaders on Friday. They
burnt the effigy of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Another protest was staged by
a taxi driver and his supporters on Ferozepur road, disrupting traffic.

There was a violent protest outside Basti Jodhewal Police Station on Thursday as
well. On October 13, police commissioner Jatinder Singh Aulakh, using his powers
under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code, fixed GLADA ground opposite
Vardhaman Industries in Sector 39 A on the Ludhiana-Chandigarh road as venue for
any protest by political parties or other organisations. The decision was taken
to prevent inconvenience to the general public because of protests by political
parties and other organisations. However, the order remained only on the paper
as nothing was done for its implementation. Protests continue to be organized on
important city roads, highways and even outside the office of the deputy
commissioner. "Nothing has been done to implement the orders and it is the
general public that is at the receiving end. This order should be implemented
and offenders should be given stringent punishment. If a place for protests can
be fixed in Chandigarh, why can't the same be done in Ludhiana," asked advocate
Harjiot Singh. Police commissioner Jatinder Singh Aulakh said, "We have
registered a case with regard to the protest carried out on Ferozepur Road on
Friday. Those who violate orders will be booked and we will implement the orders
stringently. We will not allow city residents to be harassed by protesters."

                              451 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                               The Economic Times

                            July 13, 2016 Wednesday

Kashmir violence: Protests or no protests, forces to go full steam against
terror

BYLINE: Bharti Jain

SECTION: DEFENCE

LENGTH: 368 words


NEW DELHI: Unfazed by violent protests in south Kashmir in the wake of Hizbul
Mujahideen terrorist Burhan Wani 's killing, the security establishment will
continue to go full-steam in its fight against terror. The encounter in Handwara
and the foiling of an infiltration bid in Keran on Monday exhibit the security
establishment's resolve to deal firmly with those who pick up arms and indulge
in violence.

According to a top officer of the security establishment, protests or no
protests, there would be no compromise on crushing terror with armed action.
Stating that J&K has witnessed several cycles of violence in the past, including
the protests over Amarnath in 2008 and the stone-pelting attacks that killed 150
civilians in 2010, the officer said the violent protests following Wani's
killing were another phase that would pass.

"Angry mobs will not distract us from our goal to neutralise terrorists who
endorse violence and hit our police and security forces. While we will ensure
judicious use of force to deal with local civilians, a terrorist who dares to
hit the state and indulges in mindless violence will have to face the
consequences, including death as the security forces challenge him," said an
officer.

Whether Wani's killing would spur a fresh round of local recruitment, the
security establishment on Monday said any such fallout will be prevented by
pushing a slew of welfare measures aimed at gainfully engaging the J&K youth and
boosting local industries like tourism and handicrafts. "The prime minister's
announcement of 80,000 crore package for J&K last year was a step in that
direction. The welfare schemes and initiatives covered in the package will start
rolling out soon, helping to generate employment in the Valley. This will reduce
terror recruitment," said a government official.

According to intelligence agencies, Wani's killing may have acted as a trigger
for outpouring of locals' angst against the state government, lack of jobs, etc.
"The violence was not an isolated reaction to Wani's killing," said an
intelligence officer.

A top officer of the security establishment said that signs of return to
normalcy were visible on Monday.

                             May 19, 2016 Thursday

Sanghiya Gathabandhan to stage protest assembly in Mangalbazar

Kathmandu, May 19 -- The agitating Sanghiya Gathabandhan, which decided to

Madhes movement once again. Their second phase of protest announced on Wednesday
includes holding protest assemblies in three district of Kathmandu
valley-Kathmandu, Lalitpur, Bhaktapur-and major cities like Pokhara and Birgunj
outside valley.

BRIEF: Four policemen injured in Turkey protests

Turkey's Mersin province, Turkish Milliyet newspaper reported on Oct.9.

The protestors burned the building where the headquarters of the Peoples'
Democratic Party of Turkey was located.

In early October the Kurds-populated Syrian town of Kobani, was taken under
control by the IS. The move triggered mass protests among the Kurds in
Diyarbakir, Mardin, Siirt, Mus, Van and Batman provinces of Turkey on Oct.8.
against Turkey's policy of non-interference.

Some 22 people were killed during the protests. Following the protests, a curfew
was declared in the provinces of Diyarbakir, Mardin, Siirt, Mus, Van and Batman.

The school lessons were suspended in the Diyarbakir, Hakkari, Van, Batman and
Tunceli provinces of the country on Oct.8.

Additionally, Turkey canceled all of flights of Turkish Airlines to Diyarbakir
province on Oct.8 due to deterioration of the situation in the south-east of the
country.

                              454 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            October 2, 2014 Thursday

Middle East Arabic press provide minimal coverage of Hong Kong protests

LENGTH: 483 words


Middle East press on 2 October continues to largely ignore the pro-democracy
protests that have been taking place in Hong Kong for five days against China's
plans to vet candidates for the 2017 elections.

The UAE's pro-government Al-Ittihad newspaper even reports on its front page the
country's congratulations to China on its national day, which falls on 1
October, without any mention of the demonstrations in Hong Kong.

Egypt's privately-owned daily Al-Misri al-Yawm, however, adopts a different
editorial line and highlights the protests on its front page. "The 'umbrella
protests' in Hong Kong defy the Chinese dragon," the paper declares, while
adding that the protests "overshadowed the celebrations of China's national
day".

Hong Kong's rallies have been known in the media as the "umbrella protests" as
both the weather and teargas forced protesters to use their umbrellas as a
shield.

Taking a stronger stance on the protests, Abdallah al-Madani of the Qatari
pro-government daily Al-Watan says that "Hong Kong is China's award and
headache" at the same time.

"Beijing's rulers thought that restoring control over Hong Kong peacefully in
1997 after 150 years of British rule is a victory for them and an end to a
problem that used to annoy them," he says.

"At the time they mistakenly thought that the mere change of educational
curricula will create a new generation of obedient Hong Kong inhabitants," he
adds. "But16 years after that event, the former British colony and its
inhabitants, who are different in their culture and lifestyle from their fellow
citizens in mainland China, remain a headache to the regime in Beijing," he
says.

"Return Yemen"

Meanwhile, the Gulf papers are preoccupied with the situation in Yemen, where
the Shi'i Huthi group seized key parts of the capital, Sanaa.

Most papers highlight the outcome of a meeting for the ministers of interior of
the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries on Wednesday where they discussed
the recent developments in Yemen.

"Gulf countries will not stand still before the sectarian foreign interferences
in Yemen; Sanaa's security is part and parcel of our security," reads the main
headline of Saudi Arab nationalist daily Al-Jazirah.

A similar statement features on the front page of UAE's pro-government Al-Bayan,
while Qatar's Al-Watan carries a less defiant tone with a headline saying: "Gulf
to 'Huthis': Return Yemen."

"Iraq's sovereignty red line"

Iraqi papers, for their part, highlight Foreign Minister Ibrahim al-Ja'fari
statements that the country's sovereignty is a "red line".

In a news conference the previous day, Al-Ja'fari said that Iraq does not need
foreign basis or troops rather it needs equipment and arms.

Al-Ja'fari's statements feature on both state-owned and privately-owned dailies,
which headline his remarks about Iraq's sovereignty.

Source: Middle East Arabic press review from BBC Monitoring in Arabic 02 Oct 14

LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                            October 2, 2014 Thursday

BRIEF: Females in Turkey protest against country's participation in Iraq, Syria
conflicts

BYLINE: Rufiz Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 168 words


Oct. 02--Females of Istanbul protest against the parliament's adoption of
mandate, which will allow the Turkish Armed Forces to participate in operations
against the militants of the terrorist organization "Islamic state" in Iraq and
Syria, the Turkish newspaper "Milliyet" said Oct.2.

More than 200 women blocked the traffic on the bridge, which connects the
European and Asian side of Istanbul in protest against the mandate.

Istanbul police detained 16 females during the protests.

Turkey's parliament is currently discussing the mandate.

The opposition People's Republican Party (CHP) and the pro-Kurdish People's
Democratic Party (HDP) in Turkey are in favor of the adoption of the mandate.

The National Action Party (MHP) and the ruling Justice and Development Party of
the country also advocate for the adoption of the mandate.

                                  Daily Times

                               May 9, 2014 Friday

PTI allowed to hold protest

BYLINE:  Asim Qadeer Rana

SECTION: Vol. XIII No. 127

LENGTH: 295  words


Addressing a press conference on Thursday, Nisar said, "Approval to hold the
protest will be granted by Thursday, late night."

Nisar criticised the "new tradition" of holding sit-ins and protests. "This
newfound tradition of holding protests and sit-ins isn't good, not just for
Pakistan, but for any country," he asserted.

Nisar also laid down a few conditions for the PTI's protest, which included a
ban on the use of firearms or any kind of harmful weapons, including batons.

"Use of firearms or any harmful weapon will not be permitted. If any vehicle is
transporting a weapon, it will be seized and will not be allowed to pass
through," Nisar said. Use of containers would not be allowed, except for those
provided by the government, and "no infants are allowed".

"It's not fair for children to be dragged to these protests in this heat," the
interior minister said. "The only reason why we've decided to allow this protest
to go through is because the PTI and Imran Khan have been extremely determined,"
he said.

The minister said that no one would be allowed to carry ammunition in the
protest rally, and if any protester was found carrying a weapon, he would not be
allowed to enter Islamabad. "Police, Rangers and Frontier Corps personnel will
be deputed for the security of the resident of the twin cities."

He said the government would also not allow any protesters to enter the Red Zone
of Islamabad.

Nisar said that after the May 11 rally of the PTI, politicians should evolve a
consensus on holding protests without disturbing the routine life. The Islamabad
Capital Territory Administration would not create any hurdle in the way of
peaceful protests, he said. "A non-violent protest is the democratic right of
the opposition, and government respects such rights."

                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                            March 15, 2014 Saturday

Rawalpindi nurses protest Lahore incident

SECTION: Vol. LXVIII No. 73

LENGTH: 349  words


The nurses of the garrison city on Friday staged a protest on the premises of
Benazir Bhutto Hospital against what they said brutal use of force by the Punjab
Police against their counterparts in Lahore.

The protesters claimed that the baton charge and torture had left two nurses
dead. The Lahore nurses have been protesting for the renewal of their services
for the last many days.

When the news of the killing came, all the nurses of Benazir Bhutto Hospital,
Holy Family Hospital, District Headquarters (DHQ) Hospital stopped work and
gathered at emergency department of Benazir Hospital.

They staged a peaceful demonstration to press the government for holding
impartial inquiry into the incident and bringing the killers to book.

More than 50 nurses, carrying placards inscribed with their demands, were
chanting slogans against the Punjab government and the police.

While talking to Dawn, Nurses representative Shamshad Nazir said that the nurses
staged token protest and if the killers were not arrested then they would launch
province-wide protest.

She said their protests did not affect the work in emergency wards and Intensive
Care Unit (ICU) as the nurses on duty in these wards were not invited to join
the protest.

She said that the protest was only for an hour to record our protest and they
would not want to create problems for the patients.

Gul Naz Jabeen and Huma Asif, nurses from Holy Family Hospital, said that
working condition was already not good for the nurses and job insecurity forced
the nurses in Lahore to protest.

They declined to buy the government's claim that they had not sent police to
disperse the peaceful protest of nurses.

"It is wrong because without the government consent, the police cannot take such
action," they said.

BBH Medical Superintendent Dr. Asif Qadir Mir told Dawn that the protest did not
create problem for the patients as few nurses staged a protest.

He said special arrangements had been made for the care of the patients and the
nurses had been requested to remain clam as the government would investigate the
matter and listen to their problems.

                                 The Irish News

                            February 4, 2014 Tuesday

£7 million for Twaddell protest policing

BYLINE: David Young

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 267 words


The cost of policing a long-standing protest at a north Belfast community
interface is approaching £7 million, latest figures have indicated.

Violence flared in the unionist Woodvale area last summer when Orangemen were
banned from parading past the adjacent nationalist Ardoyne on the Twelfth of
July.

Loyalist demonstrators have maintained a continuous presence at a protest camp
at the interface at Twaddell Avenue ever since.

Justice minister David Ford yesterday revealed the cost of policing the Twaddell
protest had reached £5.45m by the end of December.

With police now estimating the daily cost of the operation at £40,696, the total
bill is now thought to be around £6.8 million.

As well as providing an update on the Twaddell protest, the minister confirmed
the total cost of policing last year's loyalist Union flag protests was almost
£22m.

Those demonstrations were triggered when Belfast City Council voted in December
2012 to limit the flying of the flag on top of City Hall. A number of the
protests descended into serious violence.

Police published the financial implications of the flag protests last year but
Mr Ford yesterday confirmed the PSNI bill from 3 December 2012 to 31 March 2013
was £21.9m.

Mr Ford, said around £250,000 had also so far been paid in criminal damage
compensation linked to the flag protests, with that sum set to increase.

Referring to the cost of policing both the flag protests and Twaddell the
minister said: "The flag protests and civil unrest have placed, and continue to
place, a financial, and indeed a more general, burden or cost on many different
sectors."

                            The Star (South Africa)

                           February 12, 2013 Tuesday
                                   E1 Edition

Cosatu to stage more road protests against e-tolling

BYLINE:  Mogomotsi Magome

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 433 words


Cosatu has warned of more drive-slow protests against e-tolling on Gauteng
highways after what it considered a "very successful" protest yesterday.

The labour federation and some of its affiliates embarked on a drive-slow
protest against e-tolling, which it says will be detrimental to the working
class if implemented by the government.

The protest, which started with a handful of cars driving slowly in the Pretoria
city centre, caused massive traffic delays, as was intended by the organisers.

The convoy, led by nearly 30 cars belonging to Cosatu members and branded with
the labour federation's posters and slogans, brought traffic to a near
standstill on the N1 and R21 highways.

Many motorists, especially those who were unaware of the planned protests,
appeared frustrated after being caught up in the massive traffic backlog.

The Tshwane metro police deployed more than 60 officers on motorbikes, and metro
police vehicles to marshal the traffic.

An officer was injured when his motorbike collided with a car taking part in the
protest.

Metro police spokesman Isaac Mahamba said the accident was the only incident
during the protest.

"The accident took place on the N1 direction south but both the officer and the
Cosatu motorist were taken to hospital and were stable.

"The officer did a U-turn as he was helping to control the traffic but the
motorist did not see him," said Mahamba.

He said though many motorists had been frustrated by the traffic, they appeared
to support Cosatu's stance and eventually accepted they would be stuck in
traffic for a while.

"Most of them were hooting in approval and showing their support," he said.

Cosatu's Gauteng provincial secretary, Dumisani Dakile, said they were
organising more drive-slow protests around the province.

"There will be more drive-slow protests because we want to make our point about
the e-tolls, which is that the public is against them.

"We've had a very successful protest today, even though the turn-out was very
little in the beginning. As the day progressed, you could see that many people
were supporting the protest.

"There are more drive-slow protests being organised and we know they will be as
successful as what you saw here today," he said.

Dakile said it was still too early to say whether the protests would make the
government change its tune on the implementation of the e-tolls.

"It's too early to tell, but with the many other protests that we are planning,
we hope to make a serious impact, and the more support we get from people, the
higher the chances of having this e-tolling scrapped.

"We are not backing down," said Dakile.

                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           January 16, 2013 Wednesday

Third day of Pakistan anti-government protests top story on Iran's Press TV

LENGTH: 305 words


The third day of anti-government protests in Pakistan and growing "pressure" on
the country's government to resign was the top story in the 0500, 0600 and 0700
gmt news bulletins on Iran's English-language Press TV on 16 January.

The TV said that "pressuring is piling up" on the Pakistani government as
anti-government protests entered their third day in Islamabad. It described the
protests as the "largest political demonstration seen for years in the capital".
Press TV quoted "anti-government cleric" and protest leader Tahir-ul Qadri as
saying that he blamed Pakistan's "corrupt and incompetent leaders for the
country's woes".

Press TV reported that the Non-Aligned Movement, currently headed by Iran,
criticized the West's "double standards" at a recent UN Security Council debate
on terrorism, adding that "not much seems likely to be done about the global
issue". It said that the Security Council's failure to mention US drone strikes
amounted to "hypocrisy". Press TV's correspondent accused some Security Council
members of being the "world's greatest practitioners of state terrorism".

The TV went on to report that Syria's envoy to the UN had slammed the 15 January
bombing at Aleppo University as a "cowardly terrorist attack", accusing
"foreign-backed" rebels of being behind the blast. In a separate report, Press
TV described Turkish Prime Minister Erdogan's decision to appoint a special
governor for Syrian refugees in Turkey as "blatant interference in [Syria's]
internal affairs".

Press TV also highlighted the following reports in its bulletins: "Surge" in US
gun violence after shootings in two states; IAEA delegation arrives in Iran to
finalize framework agreement with Iran; NATO "enters" Mali as France deploys
ground troops and six allies pledge support.

Source: Press TV, Tehran, in English 0700gmt 16 Jan 13

                                 Final Edition

Iranians protest as hunger striker dies

BYLINE: Deutsche Presse-Agentur

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 129  words

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran


Protests were held Sunday - the second anniversary of Iran's disputed
presidential elections - by opposition supporters who clashed with police and
security forces.

The protests were overshadowed by the sudden death of Iranian dissident and
journalist Reza Hoda Saber, reportedly of a heart attack, while he was on a
hunger strike.

The opposition had called for silent protests against the government, their
websites reported. Demonstrations were planned in central and northern Tehran
but designed to avoid provoking confrontations with police.

The reports could not be independently verified because the government has
prohibited Western media from covering the opposition protests. President
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was re-elected on June 12, 2009, despite accusations of
fraud.
