                              467 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                     BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           December 28, 2010 Tuesday

Tunisian social protests are "not political but popular uprising", expert says

LENGTH: 343 words


Social protests that erupted in Sidi Bouzid province and spread to other
Tunisian cities represent another example of a "spontaneous uprising" with
people helped by local union activists setting the tone and steering them away
from any political agenda, a Tunisian historian told Al-Jazeera TV on 27
December.

"This movement is similar to all major [social protest] movements that took
place in Tunisia's contemporary history in terms of spontaneity and spread,"
said Adnan Massar, who is a specialist in the history of Tunisian trade unions.

The current social protests "are very much like protests that happened in 1978
in terms of the role of labour unions in giving these protests a framework," he
said.

"People who took to the streets saw in labour unions the only thing that brought
them together," he argues.

"This provides so many lessons to political parties that have been active for
decades but have been unable to have a foothold in those events and could not
understand them and predict them," Massar opined.

"The Tunisian General Labour Union had never before led any of the social
protests except under pressure from its middle ranks, that is, regional unions
and local union activists. This is what is happening now," he said.

"The main union has its own considerations and calculations. But it is under
pressure from regional unions," Massar explained.

"It is the middle ranks that are in direct contact with people. They have won
popular trust and taken control of organizing these events and expressing
people's aspirations," he said.

"Giving a political framework to these protests would create problems instead of
offering solutions. The strength of these events may be undermined if other
groupings were to take control of them," Massar noted.

"As serious as they are, these protests would not sustain any structure that
would be set by any of the existing political parties whether they are legal or
illegal," he said.

"Statistically, these parties do not count for anything," Massar said.

Source: Al-Jazeera TV, Doha, in Arabic 2100 gmt 27 Dec 10

LOAD-DATE: December 28, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Transcript

                              All Rights Reserved

                              470 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             June 9, 2010 Wednesday

Armenian opposition sit-in demands release of arrested activist - paper

LENGTH: 234 words


The youth branch of the opposition Armenian National Congress (ANC) and
non-partisan citizens held a sit-in protest in the Armenian capital Yerevan on 4
June demanding the release of an ANC activist, the pro-opposition Aravot daily
reported on 5 June. The Armenian police did not hinder the protest this time,
the paper said.

The protesters chanted "Davit, we are with you" during the two-hour sit-in
protest on Yerevan's central Liberty Square, Aravot said. Davit Kiramijyan, who
is accused of hooliganism, was detained on 31 May during an opposition protest
and was arrested for two months on 3 June. The police suppressed opposition
protests in Yerevan on 29-31 May.

The police did not disperse the protest on 4 June but told the protesters they
were violating public order when chanting slogans, Aravot reported. One of the
protesters, Patvakan Hovakimyan, told the paper they would be holding protests
on Liberty Square until Kiramijyan was released.

The protest was also attended by an ANC activist, Sargis Gevorgyan, and his
sister, Ani Gevorgyan, a journalist of the pro-opposition Haykakan Zhamanak
daily, who were detained during the 31 May opposition protest and released on 3
June. An ANC activists, Tigran Arakelyan, told Aravot that the protesters would
resume their traditional Friday marches which had not been held over the past
two months.

Source: Aravot, Yerevan, in Armenian 5 Jun 10, p 3

                             April 23, 2007 Monday

OPP TO PROTEST OUTSIDE SC DURING CJ'S HEARING TODAY

LENGTH: 199 words


ISLAMABAD: Opposition Members of National Assembly (NA) will again stage protest
demonstration outside Supreme Court on the occasion of Presidential Hearing of
Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry on Tuesday (today). On account of
starting of NA session, all the Members of opposition Parties have been directed
to participate in protest demonstration outside the Supreme Court.

On the other hand, Members of PML (N) MMA, PPP and others have arrived in
Federal Capital to participate in protest demo. The leadership of the opposition
Parties have directed the members to strongly protest during the hearing on
Tuesday. It is expected that Opposition's protest demonstration will be quite
big as they will once again be ably supported with Lawyers Community.  MMA's
President Qazi Hussain Ahmed will lead the protest demonstration with the able
support of other opposition leaders including Imran Khan, Chaudhry Nisar Ali
Khan, Khawaja Saad Rafiq, PPPP's Raja Pervez Ashraf, Khurshid Shah and others
outside Supreme Court under amid security conditions. Meanwhile Interior
Ministry has directed Police and Law Enforcement Agencies to be on a high alert
in view, to avoid any untoward incident.

                              474 of 995 DOCUMENTS

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

                      March 28, 2003 Friday Final Edition

Violent Protest

SOURCE: The Gazette

SECTION: Editorial / Op-ed; Pg. A26

LENGTH: 177 words

Until last Saturday's peace protest, we were very proud to be part of one of the
communities that joined together to promote peace worldwide. However, the more
we get informed, the more out of place we feel at the rallies.

We were in shock to see the American flag set afire at the protest and even more
so to hear the people around us cheering. Does the irony of this action being
committed at a peace protest strike only us? In which way does violence advance
the cause of peaceful protest?

Furthermore, when people hold an entire country accountable for the decisions of
an essentially unelected president, it makes all genuinely peaceful protesters
lose all credibility. Why should world leaders like George W. Bush and Tony
Blair care what we think if in the process of getting our message across we use
the same methods we are denouncing: violence.

We were also disturbed to see fellow protesters bearing anti-Israeli posters.
Has peace become an idea that people like to believe in but fail to act upon?

Kate Searle

Elsa Kelly-Rheaume

Montreal

LOAD-DATE: March 28, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Protesters light U.S. flag.

TYPE: Letter

               Copyright 2003 CanWest Interactive, a division of
                      CanWest Global Communications Corp.
                              All Rights Reserved

Crowd held for meter protest

ABOUT 22 people, mainly youths, were arrested and later released on bail after
they allegedly blocked roads with rocks in a protest against the installation of
water meters in Siyabuswa, Mpumalanga, last weekend.

They were charged with public violence and will appear in a local magistrate's
court on March 12.

                               The Jerusalem Post

                           October 30, 2001, Tuesday

News in brief

BYLINE: David Rudge Gil Hoffman Ap Margot Dudkevitch

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 648 words


Israeli Arab leaders protest policy on Palestinians

Arab MKs and several local council heads staged a protest rally opposite the
Prime Minister's Office in Jerusalem yesterday against what they described as
the aggressive and destructive policies of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's
government regarding the Palestinians.

The demonstrators held placards and banners with slogans charging "Occupation is
Terror and calling for an end to the massacre of the Palestinian people and
their leaders."

"We stressed that there cannot be real peace stability and security without the
establishment of an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel which would
have its capital in Jerusalem said Abed Inbitawi, spokesman for the Israeli Arab
leadership's monitoring committee, the rally's organizers. David Rudge

Israeli Arab leaders protest policy on Palestinians

Arab MKs and several local council heads staged a protest rally opposite the
Prime Minister's Office in Jerusalem yesterday against what they described as
the aggressive and destructive policies of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's
government regarding the Palestinians.

The demonstrators held placards and banners with slogans charging Occupation is
Terror and calling for an end to the massacre of the Palestinian people and
their leaders."

"We stressed that there cannot be real peace stability and security without the
establishment of an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel which would
have its capital in Jerusalem said Abed Inbitawi, spokesman for the Israeli Arab
leadership's monitoring committee, the rally's organizers. David Rudge

Anti-Sharon meeting in Likud tonight

Several groups in the Likud that oppose Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's policies
will meet tonight at Likud headquarters to decide how to coordinate their
efforts.

The Likud activists will declare officially that they have enough signatures to
convene the Likud Central Committee to discuss Sharon's statements supporting
the establishment of a Palestinian state.

Internal Security Minister Uzi Landau will convene the Likud bureau Thursday to
discuss whether the pro- Palestinian state comments violate the Likud
platform.Gil Hoffman

Mubarak echoes bin Laden

CAIRO (AP) - Terrorism will end only after a peaceful solution to the
Palestinian problem is found, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said yesterday.

Mubarak, in a speech to Muslim clerics broadcast live on state television, also
said Palestinians fighting Israel could not be called terrorist and declared
Islam a religion of peace.

We must not couple violence with Islam and I don't see any connection between
violence and Islam Mubarak said to a room full of clerics wearing the long gray
coats and red-and-white turbans of graduates of Al-Azhar University, one of the
most respected institutions in the Sunni Muslim world.

The situation in the Middle East is something else he continued. People have
reached a state of frustration and feeling of injustice which leads to more
violence between the Palestinians and the Israelis."

Shooting last night after quiet day

There were a number of violent incidents in the West Bank and Gaza last night
following a day of calm.

An Israeli citizen was lightly injured from stones thrown at his car near Yakir
in the early evening. He was treated at the site and did not require
hospitalization. Late yesterday afternoon and last night Palestinians shot a
number of times at soldiers deployed on the western outskirts of Kalkilya. A
bomb exploded near an IDF convoy travelling near Sanur south of Jenin. No one
was injured and no damage reported.

In Gaza three mortar shells were fired last night one landing near an IDF base
in Gush Katif and two in the community of Kfar Darom. Palestinians also threw
grenades at soldiers deployed near Rafah. Margot Dudkevitch

LOAD-DATE: October 26, 2001

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              May 17, 2016 Tuesday

Nepal arrests UK citizen over alleged participation in anti-government protest

LENGTH: 293 words


Text of report published by Nepalese newspaper Kathmandu Post website on 16 May

Nepal Police on Monday [16 May] arrested a British national for 'participating'
in a protest programme carried out by Madeshi and Janajati.

Martin Travers, 44, a British passport holder, was arrested on Monday afternoon
during a protest outside Singha Durbar, Kathmandu, while he was partcipating in
the protest, according to police.

But Martin refuted the police version. He told the post that he was merely
taking pictures of the protest when somebody came up from behind and put a
protest band on his forehead. He insisted that he was not part of the protest.

The arrest comes a day after reports and pictures of foreigners taking part in
the anti-government protest by Madhesi and Janjati groups splashed the media. He
is a mural painter and paints people's faces, his aides said after the arrest.

Chief District Officer of Kathmandu District, Ram Krishna Saubedi, confirmed the
arrest of British national who, he said, showed up among protestors carrying
flags and donning red band in his forehead during Sunday's protest.

Martin, a mural painter, held an exhibition titled 'Of Struggles and Dreams -
Homage to the People Of Nepal' in Siddhartha Art Gallery in August 2015. The
exhibition was inaugurated by British ambassador John Rankin. He was also an
artist with Book Bus, a USAID mobile library in Nepal.

He sold his paintings to support art workshop in various schools in the country,
including Kanti Ishwari School, Pyafal and Jagat Sundar, Chagall.

Martin, 44, who had actively involved in relief distribution in Rasuwa, came
back to Nepal on the anniversary of earthquake to continue his relief programme.

Source: The Kathmandu Post website, Kathmandu, in English 16 May 16

                                Kashmir Observer

                             April 24, 2015 Friday

Protests After Friday Prayers

LENGTH: 351  words


SRINAGAR: Protest marches  were taken out in different parts of Kashmir Valley
after Friday  prayers against the detention of separatist leader Masarat Alam.

Chairman  of Hurriyat Conference (G) Syed Ali Geelani had Thursday called for
peaceful protest after Friday prayers against the detention of Alam  under the
Public Safety Act (PSA) and his shifting to Kotbalwal jail  Jammu.

Reports said that soon after Friday prayers scores of  people protested in
different parts of Srinagar city including  Habakadal, Hyderpora, Amira Kadal.
Muslim League supporters staged a  protest amid pro-freedom slogans in Haba
Kadal area. The protest was led  by Muslim League spokesperson Muhammad Rafiq
Ganaie. Peaceful protest  was also held at Amira Kadal and Hyderpora after
Friday prayers. Scores  of youth pelted stones on police and CRPF personnel at
Gojwara and  Nowhata, however police exercised maximum restraint and did not use
any  force to disperse the protesters. Traffic was disrupted while  shopkeepers
downed their shutters after stone-hurling incidents.

In  North Kashmir's Anantnag town, protest was held at Sherbagh while in
Pulwama a large number of people staged a peaceful protest against the
detention of Masrat Aalam. Peaceful protest was also held at Qaimou  Kulgam.

Protesters resorted to stone-pelting in South Kashmir's  Tral town where a large
number of people took to streets against the  detention of Muslim League leader
Masrat Aalam. Police used tear-smoke  shells to disperse the angry protesters.
The clashes according to  eyewinesses continued for hours.

Stone-pelting incidents were  also reported from Sopore and Narbal area's of
North and Central  Kashmir. Separatist leader Nayeem Ahmed Khan addressed a
gathering in  Narbal where protesters unfurled Pakistani flags and clashed with
police  and CRPF. Green flags were also unfurled during a peacful rally that
was addressed by Mirwaiz Umar Farooq at Imambarah Budgam.

A  police official told CNS that the situation all across Kashmir Valley
remained peaceful and no major incident of violence was reported from  any part
of Valley.

                                 EKantipur.com

                          February 25, 2015 Wednesday

Protest called off in simara

LENGTH: 226 words

DATELINE: BARA


BARA, Feb. 25 -- The protests against the government's move to roll back its
decision to set up units of land revenue and survey offices in Simara was called
off on Tuesday.

After 10-day agitation, life in the area gradually returned to normalcy, with
the resumption of transport service, reopening of market places and educational
institutions.

Simara Malpot Sthapana Sarokar Samiti, a committee that led the agitation, said
in a statement that it decided to call off the protest after the authorities
expressed commitment to address its demands. The committee had demanded
treatment for the victims who sustained injuries during the protest, provide
compensation and immediate release of those arrested during demonstrations.

However, the UCPN (Maoist) expressed dissatisfaction over the decision to call
off the protest. "The ruling parties have politicised the movement of the local
people. It is an all-party protest. So the announcement of some parties to
postpone the protest is meaningless," said Ajurna Chimoriya, who represents the
Maoists in the committee.

Local people, business community and party activists are up in arms against the
Cabinet decision.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from EKantipur.com. For any query
with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact
Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              Daily The Pak Banker

                           November 27, 2014 Thursday

JUI-F to organize protest rallies against attacks on its chief

LENGTH: 245  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


Central Majlis e Shoora of Jamiat
Ulema-e-Islam Fazl on Wednesday decided to organize rallies across
the country from Dec 5, to protest against suicide attack on its
chief Maulana Fazl-ur-Rehman last month.


      Addressing a press conference, Secretary General JUI-F Maulana
Abdul Ghafoor Haideri said Majlis-e-Shoora has approved a series of
protest rallies from Dec 5 in four provincial capitals.
      While giving detail of protest schedule, he informed that on
Dec 9 protest rallies would be organized on district level, January
2 on Tehsil level, Jan 16 and 30 countrywide and on February 27
protest rally would be organized in Islamabad.
      He said that this is our constitutional right to register
protest against violence on our party workers and suicide attacks on
our party leadership including JUI-F Chief Maulana Fazl ur Rehman.
      He said that the whole family of Maulana Fazlur Rehman was
being targetted by the unknown elements. In last few months it was
third attack on Maulana followed by attacks on his brother, son and
his house.
      Expressing dissatisfaction on investigations of attacks, he
said his party wants to know real facts and motives behind attack on
Maulana and family.
      He said Balochistan government did not inform the party about
any progress in investigations of Quetta suicide attack on Maulana.
      JUI-F leaders including Maulana Amjad Khan, Malik Sikandar,
Aslam Ghauri, Qari Usman, Haji Qayyum and others were also present
on the occasion.

                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             July 15, 2014 Tuesday

Protests against Israeli air-strikes on Gaza to be held across Maldives

LENGTH: 261 words


Text of report by Abdul Latheef headlined "Maldivians to protest against Israeli
aggression in Palestine" published by Maldivian daily Miadhu website on 15

The organizers of the protest, to be held in Maldives, against the Israeli
aggression in Palestine have stated that the protest will be held tonight.

The protest will begin at 9:30 [local time] tonight near the Social Center. It
is scheduled to be a march which will conclude all the way from the main
Majeedhee Magu to Ameenee Magu and Boduthakurufaanu Magu near Stadium.

A special supplication will be made near the Stadium. In addition to this
information will be shared regarding the events of Gaza and Palestine.

Similar protests will be held in Addu City and other islands.

Although this event is organized by some of the youth, political parties have
also expressed their support for the protest and announced their participation.

Maldivians has always been in solidarity with the Palestinians. Maldivians
empathize with the suffering that our Palestinian brothers and sisters are
enduring during the holy month of Ramadan.

Maldives has also called for an immediate cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza.

The Government of Maldives has earlier expresses alarm at the rising death toll
in Gaza, and the possible escalation, and reiterates its call to bring an
immediate cease to the violence. The Maldives believes that it is only through
negotiations that a conducive environment could be created where both Palestine
and Israel could live side by side in peace.

Source: Miadhu News website, Male, in English 15 Jul 14

                           Free Press Journal (India)

                                October 28, 2013

CM hopes clean sweep in Indore dist

BYLINE: OUR STAFF REPORTER

LENGTH: 578  words


Faces protests at three places

Indore: Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chauhan is eyeing for all the nine seats in
Indore district and even demanding people to elect BJP candidate. But the
protestors at three places have made it clear that if the CM wants his wish to
be fulfilled, then he shall honour the sentiments of the people as well.

The Jan Ashirwad atra faced protests basically at three places - Sanwer, Indore-
I and Indore- IV constituencies. The atra entered the district through Sanver
though a few hours late. The protests began from here itself when the people
localites expressed their protest against the outside candidate in this
constituency.

It is noteworthy that BJP had lost Sanver seat in the last assembly elections as
well. The outside candidates who are probable for getting the ticket include
Rajesh Sonkar, Sawan Sonkar and Nisha Sonkar, none of whom are natives of
Sanver. The local people are demanding for a native candidate in the
constituency.

Sources claimed that MP Sumitra Mahajan is playing behind the scenes by inciting
the protest against the outside candidate as she has a local candidate whom she
is supporting. Thus, through the protests, she is pushing for her own candidate.
Placards were shown to the CM in the protests.

The atra further faced protests in Indore- I, but this time, the intensity was
far higher since it was about Sudarshan Gupta. It seemed as if people just hate
sitting MLA Sudarshan Gupta. It looks for now as if he is definite to get the
ticket, however, protests and discontent has increased against him and it was
clearly evident with mass protest during the CM's visit. It is claimed that
sitting MLA Ramesh Mendola ( Indore II) is playing behind the scenes and
extending his support to the protestors. As the atra moved toward assembly
constituency Indore- IV, Sindhi Colony residents

residents expressed its ire against the nepotism being shown by giving tickets
only to the Gaur clan and nobody else is being even considered. The increasing
dissatisfaction among public over the muscle power dominance in the region has
become a cause of concern for the politicians in the assembly elections. It is
claimed that BJP city president Shankar Lalwani is playing behind the scenes in
this constituency and is extending his support to the protestors.

Yatra arrives late

Chief Miniser Shivraj Singh Chauhan reached district Indore a few hours behind
the schedule. He was expected to reach in Sanwer at around 11 am on Sunday. He
reached here around 1.30 PM. Then he moved to city via Chandragupt Maurya statue
junction. Here he addressed a gathering form his Rath ( special open vehicle)
itself. From here, he moved toward Pardeshipura via Sawaria Sweets, Khatipura
village, Gori Nagar and Damaru Ustaad Chauraha. At Pardeshipura he held a "
Nukkad Sabha" and stayed in his open vehicle for addressing the audience.

Further, he moved to Malwa Mill in constituency- V via Atal Dwar, Nehru Nagar
and Pancham Ki Phel. At Malwa Mills, he addressed the people. Then, he proceeded
to Imali Bazaar Chauraha in constituency- III via Chimanbaag, Khatipura chuaraha
and Sanskrit College. Then he moved toward Bada Ganpati in constituency- I via
Badwali Chauki, Shastri Colony and Jinsi Chauraha where he addressed a public
gathering. Chauhan's rath then moved toward constituency- IV at Mhownaka, via
Lohar Patti, Malganj Chauraha and Chhatripura Thana. He concluded his atra in
constituency Rau at Vaishali Nagar ( Dutt Mandir).

                                 EKantipur.com

                            August 29, 2013 Thursday

Govt deaf to peaceful protests: Kakre Bihar protestors

LENGTH: 306 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, Aug. 29 -- The Kakre Bihar Joint Struggle Committee, which is up in
arms demanding permission to build a Buddha shrine in Kakre Bihar in Surkhet,
organised a broader rally and corner meeting in the Capital on Thursday.

The agitating Buddhist community and various religious and ethnic organisations
gathered at Basantapur for the rally that marched through New Road, Jamal,
Ratnapark, Bagbazaar, Putalisadak, Padmodayamod before converging into a corner
meeting at exhibition road.

Addressing the assembly, President of Nepal Federation of Indigenous
Nationalities (NEFIN), Nagendra Kumar Kumal, despised the government for being
apathetic towards the Kakre Bihar issue. He accused the government of ignoring
their peaceful protests and said they would announce the fourth phase of their
protests. "The fourth phase of our protests would be intense and coercive.

The struggle committee's third phase of protests ended on Thursday.

More intense protests are on the cards bound to happen shortly said the Vice
Chairman of Buddhist Community Yukten Zigdol said they are unveiling more
intense protest programmes.

He added that the increasing turnout of attendants indicates the public support
for the cause. "The government didn't take note of the peaceful rally, hence
forth our protests will be more intense which must fall into the authority's
ear," said Zigdol.

The Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities (Nefin), in association with
the Buddhist community, announced the third round of protests on August 18 to
press for their demand.

The Kakre Bihar Joint Struggle Committee have been holding continuous protests
since early May.

                            Kashmir Monitor (India)

                             June 29, 2013 Saturday

JCC announces fresh protest calendar

LENGTH: 375 words

DATELINE: SRINAGAR


SRINAGAR, June 29 -- Joint Consultative Committee (JCC), an amalgam of several
employees unions Friday announced a fresh protest calendar by calling
Secretariat ghero on July-8 and lock-out of government offices on the same day
across the state.

The leaders of JCC held a meeting on Thursday, in which they decide that they
would hold protest demonstrations on July-8 outside the Civil Secretariat
Srinagar. However, they announced fresh protest calendar at a press conference
here on Friday.

While as, in a significant development, the Civil Secretariat Non-Gazetted
Employees Union extended its support to the JCC programme. The Civil Secretariat
Non-Gazetted Employees Union had not participated in the previous protest
programmes of JCC. However, its leaders said they would give full support to JCC
and will hold protest demonstration inside the premises of Civil Secretariat on
July-8.

"On July-8, employees will hold protest outside Civil Secretariat while as
non-gazetted employees of Civil Secretariat will hold inside its premises. The
employees of Jammu will hold protest outside office of Divisional Commissioner
Jammu and will also submit memorandum to him," the JCC leaders said at a press
conference here.

They said employees of Leh and Kargil would hold protest outside District
Development Commissioners of their respective districts.Those who participated
in the press conference included senior JCC leaders, Abdul Qayoom Wani, Muntizer
Mohideen, Gafoor Ahmad Dar.

The JCC leaders said there would be complete shutdown of government offices
across the Valley on this date.The government employees are demanding
enhancement of retirement age from 58 to 60 years, removal of pay anomalies and
regularization of daily wagers.

Earlier, the employees Rajbhavan chalo was foiled on June-22.

Employees said they had negotiated with the government and gave them time which
they asked for. "Even agreements were signed between the government and
employees' leadership but so far they backtracked from their commitments," the
JCC leaders claimed.

DATELINE: KARACHI


Peaceful protests were staged across Karachi and other cities of Sindh on
Saturday to express solidarity with MQM chief Altaf Hussain.

The protests were held a day after the Supreme Court issued a contempt notice to
Altaf Hussain for his criticism of judges.

A large number of people attended the protests.

Residents of Shah Faisal Colony took to the streets and held a peaceful protest
in favour of Altaf Hussain.

Similarly, protests were staged in Gulshan-e-Iqbal, Nipa Chowrangi and
Liaquatabad, attended by large numbers of women and children.

Demonstrators said that they would stand by MQM chief.

Later, all rallies culminated peacefully.

Apart from Karachi, protests were held in different cities of Sindh.

Unknown persons set tires on fire and staged sits-in in Hyderabad, Mirpur Khas,
Nawabshah and Sukkur.

In Hyderabad, protest demonstrations were held in Hyder Chowk

                            South China Morning Post

                              May 28, 2012 Monday

We have the right to loud protests

SECTION: YOUNGPOST; Star letter; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 300 words


Many people in Hong Kong say rowdy public protests are ineffective and cause
danger and disturbance to the public. They say protesters should be polite.

That argument has merit. Yet we live in a world where making a public scene
draws attention. This is a world of the media. If the media doesn't take notice,
some issues may never get the publicity they deserve. If you want your voice to
be heard, shouting loudly may be the only option.

In any event, protests in Hong Kong are rarely violent. Look at Europe.
Protesters there burn cars, smash windows, and even loot stores at times.

Here people only use their voice to protest. There's little damage to public
property. Fights with police officers rarely happen. Most protests in Hong Kong
are quite creative and peaceful. Even if you are unhappy with the protests in
Hong Kong, you should still think twice before pointing the finger at
protesters.

Alex Siu, SKH Lam Kau Mow Secondary School

From the Editor

Thank you for your pointed and passionate letter, Alex. You make many good
points, which apply to protests all around the world.

Protests serve to bring people's attention to an issue. Locals do seem to be
able to carry them out with very little violence.

With Hong Kong being a very crowded city, any type of protest is bound to cause
disruption to someone. Also, if it is a big protest, people can be squeezed or
bruised in the process, and if they haven't brought enough water, they might
suffer dehydration.

For their part, the police are tasked with protecting property and people. They
cannot stand by and do nothing while protesters run wild, and so they tend to
act before things become bad.

It is a testament not only to the people of Hong Kong but also to our police
force that there haven't been more violent protests.

Susan, Editor

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2012 South China Morning Post Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              491 of 995 DOCUMENTS

SAUDI ARABIA

Protests started March 10

King Abdullah's continuing popularity has contributed to relative calm, as
protests by Shiites and women's rights advocates have failed to gain a foothold.

GOVERNMENTSTATUS

STABLE

SYRIA

Protests started Feb. 4

At least 5,000 people have died in the months of protests against President
Bashar al-Assad. Although President Obama and other world leaders have called
for Assad to step down, there has been no indication that foreign governments
might intervene in the conflict.

GOVERNMENTSTATUS

TEETERING

TUNISIA

Protests started Dec. 17, 2010

With elections in October, Tunisia has moved quickly toward democracy after the
sustained protests that led to the ouster of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali
in January and ignited the broader upheaval.

GOVERNMENTSTATUS

TOPPLED

YEMEN

Protests started Jan. 22

President Ali Abdullah Saleh has pledged to step down, ending his 33-year-long
rule, but the timing and pace of any change remain in doubt.

                            July 20, 2011 Wednesday

Students step up housing price protests;
Jerusalem tent protesters will hold a protest march this evening to the Kfar
David luxury neighborhood.

BYLINE: Ori Chudy

LENGTH: 153 words


Following yesterday's promise to intensify the struggle, students today
announced that the Jerusalem tent protesters will hold a protest march this
evening to the Kfar David luxury neighborhood. Protesters in the Jerusalem
encampment have received support from the leader of another recent protest -
Yitzhak Alrov, who led the cottage cheese protest just a few weeks ago and
received tremendous public support.

Student protests in northern Israel are also expected to intensify, as
representatives of the Tel-Hai College Student Union plan to block traffic at
the Sinai intersection in Kiryat Shmona.

The National Student Union reported that this is only a first step in the
intensification of the struggle, and that they intend to follow up soon with
additional measures.

                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                            February 21, 2011 Monday
                                   E2 Edition

'Jasmine Revolution'| calls worry China

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 355 words


BEIJING: Jittery Chinese authorities staged a show of force yesterday to squelch
a mysterious online call for a "Jasmine Revolution" apparently modelled after
pro-democracy demonstrations sweeping the Middle East.

Authorities detained activists, increased the number of police on the streets
and censored online calls to stage protests in Beijing, Shanghai and 11 other
major cities. Citizens were urged to shout "We want food, we want work, we want
housing, we want fairness" - a slogan that highlights common complaints among
ordinary Chinese.

Many activists said they did not know who was behind the campaign and were not
sure what to make of the call to protest, which was first posted on the US-based
Chinese-language advocacy website Boxun.com.

China's authoritarian government has appeared unnerved by recent protests in
Egypt, Tunisia, Bahrain, Yemen, Algeria and Libya. It has limited media reports
about them, stressing the instability caused by protests in Egypt, and
restricted internet searches to keep people uninformed.

The call to protest in China did not seem to garner much appeal among citizens.
In Beijing, 25-year-old Liu Xiaobai was stopped by police after he placed a
white jasmine flower in front of a McDonald's restaurant that was the planned
protest site and took some pictures with his cellphone.

Ahead of the planned protests, more than 100 activists in cities across China
were taken away by police, confined to their homes or were missing, the Hong
Kong-based group Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said.

Yesterday, searches for "jasmine" were blocked on China's largest Twitter-like
microblog, and status updates with the word on popular Chinese social networking
site Renren.com were met with an error message.

The call for a Jasmine Revolution came as President Hu Jintao gave a speech to
top leaders on Saturday, asking them to "solve prominent problems which might
harm the harmony and stability of the society".

Hu told the senior politicians and officials to improve management of
information on the internet "to guide public opinion", the official Xinhua News
Agency reported. - Sapa-AP

                              498 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           The Advertiser (Australia)

                           August 22, 2007 Wednesday
                                 State Edition

Mass protest to hit Sydney

BYLINE: KARA LAWRENCE, JOE HILDEBRAND, SYDNEY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 355  words


A WEEK of mayhem, involving every major protest group in the city, will cause
mass disruption to Sydney at next month's APEC summit.

Revelations of radical plans came yesterday as police issued a warning to
parents they could not guarantee the safety of their children caught up in the
protests.

APEC organisers are bracing for protests from radical groups, which are
recruiting high school students to take part.

The groups, which aim to clog up Sydney for 11 days leading up to and including
the summit, include radical protest groups Resistance and the Socialist
Alliance.

Also planning protests are the Maritime Union of Australia, Amnesty
International, the Greens, Vietnamese and Chinese groups and Critical Mass with
its monthly bike ride.

Friday, September 7 and Saturday, September 8, the peak of APEC leaders' week,
have emerged as the most popular for radical protest groups.

On the Saturday, at least 15,000 protesters are expected to clog the heart of
Sydney. The biggest protest, at 10am, is expected to be the 10,000strong Stop
Bush Stop Howard rally and march from Sydney Town Hall to Hyde Park North.

Hundreds of students from at least five Sydney high schools are expected to walk
out of school in a student strike at 1pm on Wednesday, September 5, for a
Belmore Park protest. Resistance organiser Simon Cunich yesterday said hundreds,
possibly thousands, of students were expected to take part.

He said Resistance had visited 20 Sydney private and public high schools to
recruit students.

Mr Cunich insisted the protest, involving children from Year 9 up, would be
peaceful. ''We've called a peaceful protest and we're not looking for a
confrontation. We'd call on police not to use violence in the protests,'' he
said.

Assistant Commissioner Dave Owens, who is heading the police APEC response, said
school students who attended protests put themselves at risk. ''These kids might
get caught up in a violent protest but as police we cannot guarantee their
safety if they do,'' he said.

He said police were well-briefed on plans for a student walkout and said ''the
same rules apply to them as anyone else''.

                              499 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                                  My Republica

                            April 6, 2016 Wednesday

New Madhes protest to be Singha Durbar-centric: Mahato

LENGTH: 265 words

DATELINE: BIRGUNJ


BIRGUNJ, April 6 -- The upcoming protests to be launched by Madhes-based parties
will be centered on picketing Singha Durbar in the Capital, according to
Sadbhawana Party (SP) Chair Rajendra Mahato.

Interacting with media in Birgunj on Wednesday, Mahato said the protests would
not be border-centric as their last protests only troubled the general people
while failing to pressurize the government.

The upcoming protests in mid-April would not affect people, according to him.

"Currently we're busy in the preparations for the upcoming protest programs,
which will be Singha Durbar-centric and affect the government much," he said.

Mahato clarified that the Madhes movement has neither had its miscarriage nor
has it ended; but its nature has changed.

The United Democratic Madhesi Front (UDMF) has recently decided about the new
modality of its protest.

"Despite UDMF's utmost flexibility, the government seems to have failed to
address the issue of Madhes," he said. "But the next round of protests will be
decisive in getting the Madhes issues resolved."

According to him, UDMF leaders are currently engaged in building the alliance's
strength through awareness campaign from Mechi to Mahakali.

He also criticized the government for terming the recent advice of European
Union as interference.

Mahato also claimed that all the constituents of UDMF stand together and that
there was no dispute among them.

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Republica. For any query with
respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor
at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: April 6, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Times of India (Electronic Edition)

                           October 29, 2015 Thursday
                                Kolkata Edition

CAUTION CALL Voice of reason from Muslim thinkers

SECTION: TIMES CITY

LENGTH: 392 words


If it is protests, Bengal is never far behind. From chief minister Mamata
Banerjee to young poet Mandakranta Sen, luminaries from the state have joined
the outcry against rising intolerance in the country . But one such protest -a
public beef party organized by the Leftleaning Bhasha Chetana Samity at
Dharamtalla on Wednesday -triggered a backlash from Muslim academics and
intellectuals.

Professor Maqbool Islam, dean of student affairs at Kalyani University , said:
"I strongly

agree on the need to protest. But I do not support its form. Openly eating beef
cannot be a mode of protest."

Islam found support in Professor Amzed Hossain, Aliya University's English
department head. "This is less of a protest more of exhibitionism. It will do
more harm than good," he said. Quari Maulana Fazlur Rehman, the senior cleric
who leads the Red Road Eid namaz, felt, "This is akin to teasing. It is
important that we protest, make ourselves heard, but this can't be the manner."

Bhasha Chetana Samity , comprising artists, poets and civil society members, had
planned the protests to lend its voice against the

growing incidents of intolerance nation-wide.Samity secretary Emmanuel Haque
argues it will be a symbolic protest. "We have sent out invites to many people
to join this public beef eating. In our view, this requires the strongest
voice," he said. Haque says the protest is aimed at demolishing several myths
and falsehoods.

Academic Miratoon Nahar finds nothing wrong in protesting against intolerance.
"To protest is their right. But the question is whether such protests yield any
result. I declined the invite (for Friday's protest). I have my reasons," she
said. Faruque Ahamed editor-publisher of

'Udar Akash' -a peer reviewed research journal that takes up issues on
minorities -does not

support such a protest rally as "it might incite communal and religious
sentiments."

Maulana Rehman said, "Protests to me should be so that people feel for my cause.
I shouldn't end up antagonizing or alienating them. This is like teasing or
taunting people.What I eat is behind the closed doors of my home, what point
will I make by doing it openly?" Professor Islam said, "In the 19th century , in
the Young Bengal protests, radical Bengali free thinkers who were Brahmins ate
beef to prove their liberal beliefs. But this didn't find acceptance in
society."

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              Daily Regional Times

                             March 30, 2015 Monday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

BYLINE: Younis Chandio and Jani Khaskheli

SECTION: Vol. VIII No. 806

LENGTH: 213  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged by people in favor of their demands
outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Sunday.

According to details, the SSGC employees led by Mohammad Ali Shah, Abid Mirani,
Kashif Malik and others staged a protest demonstration for the provision of
different facilities to them. They also demanded of the concerned authorities to
issue their withheld salaries. The APCA members under the leadership of Ashraf
Bozai, Noor Mohammad Shaikh and others recorded a protest demonstration for the
provision of promotions and other facilities to the clerical staff in Sindh. The
activists of the Sindh National Party led by Akhtar Sindhi, Khadim Baloch and
others recorded a protest demonstration against the administration of a cotton
factory for sacking the laborers. On the occasion, they demanded of the
concerned authorities to reinstate the sacked employees, otherwise they have
threatened to accelerate their protest circle. The contract based employees of
the National Bank of Pakistan continued their protest demonstration for the
regularization of their services. The senior workers of the PML-N Hyderabad also
continued their protest demonstration against their local party leaders for
ignoring them in the provision of jobs and other facilities.

                       BBC Monitoring Trans Caucasus Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                          November 26, 2014 Wednesday

Azeri pressure group holds protest outside UN office

LENGTH: 296 words


Text of report by private Azerbaijani news agency APA

Baku, 26 November: The Karabakh Liberation Organization (KLO) has held a protest
outside the Azerbaijan representative office of the UN  [in Baku] over
[Azerbaijani citizens] Sahbaz Quliyev and Dilqam Asgarov, who were taken captive
by Armenian troops in Kalbacar District [in July 2014].

In addition to the KLO members, Asgarov and Quliyev's family members and
relatives attended the protest.

Police thwarted the protest, which started in the form of a march from Martyrs'
Avenue. Only four protesters were allowed access to the [protest] site outside
the representative office.

The protest aimed to draw attention to the indifferent approach displayed by the
UN and other international organizations to the fate of our captive citizens.
The protesters chanted slogans "Down with the UN", "Down with the [OSCE] Minsk
Group" and others.

In the end, the protesters presented a statement to the UN Baku office.

[BBCM note: Azerbaijani citizens Dilqam Asgarov (Dilgam Asgarov) and Sahbaz
Quliyev (Shahbaz Guliyev) are charged with murder and espionage. The two are
natives of the Armenian-controlled Kalbacar District of Azerbaijan and were
detained by the separatist authorities in that district on 10 and 14 July 2014
respectively. Yerevan described them as "saboteurs", while Baku said they were
civilians.

Baku and Yerevan are locked in a conflict over Azerbaijan's Nagornyy Karabakh
region, which along with seven surrounding districts came under the control of
ethnic Armenian forces in the early 1990s. The OSCE Minsk Group, co-chaired by
Russia, France, and the United States, mediates between Azerbaijan and Armenia
to hammer out a peaceful solution to the conflict.]

Source: APA news agency, Baku, in Azeri 0843 gmt 26 Nov 14

                              503 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                Al-Ahram Weekly

                                  May 8, 2014

Protests continue

LENGTH: 773  words


Worsening economic conditions led to a series of protests and industrial actions
in the first four months of 2014, writes Nesma Nowar

Despite the fact that Egypt has seen two revolutions aiming at achieving social
justice and better living conditions, people are still struggling to make ends
meet amid worsening economic conditions and soaring inflation rates.

Industrial action and workers' strikes are still dragging on, with workers
asking for the same things that they were after the ouster of former president
Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

A recent paper by the Egyptian Centre for Economic and Social Rights (ECESR), an
NGO, showed that there were some 354 protests in the first quarter of 2014, of
which 249 were industrial actions.

The paper said that workers' living conditions had worsened as a result of a
decline in wages strained by high inflation rates and soaring prices, in
addition to the unfair implementation of the minimum wage of LE1,200 which came
into force this year.

The minimum wage excluded a big chunk of public-sector workers by covering only
those directly employed in the government's administrative apparatus. The paper
added that the workers' deteriorating situation could get even worse as the
result of the recently announced plans to cut subsidies, which will involve
price increases across the board.

"The persistent tough conditions have caused industrial action to escalate in
the first three months of 2014 despite the issuing of the notorious protest law
last November," the paper said.

It classified the protests according to reasons, places and forms of protest. It
found that industrial action topped the protests that took place this year, with
24 protests, followed by socially motivated protests, at 71, and then
economically motivated protests, at 34.

Cairo came first as the governorate that saw the majority of the protests, with
the paper attributing this to the fact that Cairo is the biggest governorate in
terms of hosting factories, companies and hospitals and it was where public
transportation workers are based.

Some 71 protests occurred in Cairo in the first three months of the year,
representing 19.8 per cent of all protests, with the highest number taking place
in February. Cairo was followed by Suez (31), Gharbiya (29), Menoufiya (27), and
Beheira (21).

The paper said that rallies were the workers' favourite form of protest,
representing more than 52 per cent of the protests in Egypt during the first
three months of the year. These were followed by strikes (15 per cent) and
sit-ins (10 per cent).

The public sector was where the majority of the protests took place, followed by
the public business sector and then the private sector, shedding light on the
problems facing the country's public sector.

Public business sector and private-sector workers have been protesting against a
delay in receiving their financial dues, including wages, and the hiring of
temporary workers.

"The workers' ongoing protests came as no surprise, given that their demands are
still unmet," said Farag Abdel-Fattah, a professor of economics at Cairo
University, who added that the legal situation of workers and their worsening
economic conditions were the main reasons that had prompted the protests.

Abdel-Fattah said that the economic polices followed for the past 30 years had
increased poverty rates and led to price increases, which in turn had caused
many workers to plunge into poverty. "In such an economic climate, it's very
logical to see protests through which labour expresses its grievances," he said.

Though Abdel-Fattah stated that the labour protests were justified, he also said
that it was important to reinforce the legal context to regulate such protests.
"There should be strong labour unions that decide on the protests and there
should be good reasons behind the protests," he said.

"The period of the protests should also be defined, and they should not harm
business 0activities."

Labour protests have been prominent in Egypt since the 25 January Revolution.
Workers have protested over wages, the employment of temporary workers,
mismanagement, mistreatment, corruption, and against the closure of factories
and businesses.

However the current protests are fewer than during the first two years of the
revolution. There were over 2,400 protests or strikes in the first quarter of
2013 alone, specifically between January and March, while in 2012 the figure
reached 3,817.

The decline stems from several agreements between the trade unions and both
prime ministers Hazem Al-Beblawi's and Ibrahim Mehleb's governments, which have
tried to tame the protests until economic conditions improve.

                               Leicester Mercury

                             March 17, 2014 Monday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Protest at 'corruption' in Turkey

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 143 words


SCORES of people gathered at the weekend for a protest directed at the Turkish
government. The protest, at Leicester Clock Tower on Saturday afternoon, was
sparked by the death of 15-year-old Berkin Elvan, who had been in a coma for
nine months.

Berkin was hit on the head by a police gas cannister during anti-government
protests in Istanbul last summer.

Leicester protest organiser Burcu Erdogan, 24, of Beaumont Leys, said: "We
wanted to show our support for the family of the young boy who died and raise
awareness of what's going on back home.

"We want to stop the dictatorship and fascism.

"We are here to show our support for our country and to make it clear that we
want change."

The protesters said they were campaigning against government corruption and the
suppression of freedom of speech.

                            Cihan News Agency (CNA)

                            March 13, 2014 Thursday

Nationwide protests held for slain Gezi victim continue

LENGTH: 226  words


ISTANBUL (CIHAN)- Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets on Tuesday and
Wednesday throughout the country to protest the death of Berkin Elvan, a
15-year-old boy who died on Tuesday after being in a coma for nine months after
being hit on the head by a tear gas canister during last summer's Gezi Park
protests.



Elvan was buried amid tears in an Istanbul cemetery on Wednesday afternoon with
participation of thousands of people.

Protests still continue in many cities of the country. On Wednesday, thousands
of people flocked to Istanbul's Taksim Square to protest the government. People
shouted slogans against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and the ruling
Justice and Development Party (AK Party). Riot police set up barricades and
positioned water cannons at the entrance of Istiklal Street to prevent
protesters from gathering in Taksim Square. Police fired tear gas and water
cannons to disperse the crowd. Large numbers of people were taken into custody
during the protest.

Erdogan has said during Gezi Park protest that he "gave the orders" to police
for their intervention in the protests.

Protests were also staged in provinces of Ankara, Mersin, Hatay, Izmir, Çorum
and Kütahya.

                              506 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                           The Mercury (South Africa)

                           February 13, 2014 Thursday
                                   E1 Edition

'No quick| fixes for| protests'

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 450 words


Curtailing protests in South Africa required long-term economic and
institutional changes, Johannesburg University researchers said yesterday.

"There cannot be short-term fixes, there needs to be real and substantial
change," said Carin Runciman, who specialises in the politics of protests and
social movements.

Professor Peter Alexander, South African research chair in social change and
sociology, said the focus on the service delivery dimension of protests was
often misplaced.

"Protests are not just about service delivery. Community protests are more of a
rebellion of the poor."

The poor were marginalised, and frequently stigmatised, and had limited means to
make their grievances meaningfully heard.

The research was based on more than 250 interviews and drew data from four media
sources, covering more than 2 000 protests since 2004. The research divided
protests into three categories - peaceful, disruptive and violent.

Runciman said there had been a general rise in protest action since 2004, with
peaks in 2009 and 2013. There were also generally more protests during winter.

"There is no clear relationship between protests and elections."

Just after the 2009 general elections, however, an increase was noted. One of
the possible explanations for this was that people believed President Jacob Zuma
would make substantial changes to people's everyday lives once in office, but
when this did not immediately happen people resorted to protesting.

People were not only concerned about the levels of service delivery they
received, but also about the quality of democracy they experienced.

Doctoral student Trevor |Ngwane said people often resorted to protesting,
frequently targeting ward councillors or mayors. This was because once these
officials were voted in there was no means of removing them if they failed to
deliver.

Discontent

Alexander said the fact that councillors often earned substantially more than
their constituents led to a social gap, which often led to discontent.

The research indicated that most communities began by expressing their
discontent peacefully, but this was frequently met with minimal response. The
protest would then become disruptive including blocking roads and burning tyres
before becoming violent, where property was damaged and people injured or
killed. The presence of police also sometimes exacerbated the violence of
protests.

Alexander said of controlling protests: "Repression won't work. It will
intensify |bitterness."

The growing number of protests in South Africa were also part of an
international trend.

"It's been a ticking time bomb in South Africa. Protests will continue unless
authorities listen and act positively, not bureaucratically." - Sapa

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          Pretoria News (South Africa)

                           February 13, 2014 Thursday
                                   E1 Edition

Protests reveal disillusionment of poor, study shows

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 320 words


Curtailing protests in South Africa required long-term economic and
institutional changes, Johannesburg University researchers said yesterday.

"There cannot be short-term fixes," said Carin Runciman, who specialises in the
politics of protests and social movements.

Professor Peter Alexander, the South African research chairman in social change
and sociology, said the focus on the service dimension of protests was often
misplaced.

"Protests are not just about|service delivery. Community protests are more of a
rebellion of the poor," he said.

The poor were marginalised and had limited means to make their grievances
meaningfully heard.

The research was based on more than 250 interviews and drew data from four media
sources, covering more than 2 000 protests since 2004. It divided protests into

Runciman said there had been a general rise in protest action since 2004, with

"There is no clear relationship between protests and elections," she said.

                              508 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                 Daily The Post

                            December 16, 2013 Monday

CNG sector, transporters start protests in Punjab

LENGTH: 522  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


All Pakistan CNG Association (APCNGA) and transporters will start protest
demonstrations in all cities of Punjab, including the twin cities of Rawalpindi
and Islamabad, from Monday (today). Thousands of jobless workers employed with
the compressed natural gas (CNG) business and transporters along with their
families plan come out on the roads against gas disconnection.



The protest demonstrations will be staged in Rawalpindi, Gujranwala, Sialkot,
Lahore, Faisalabad, Wazirabad, Gujrat, Multan, Sahiwal and several other cities
of Punjab on Monday (today).

Chairman Supreme Council APCNGA Ghiyas Abdullah Paracha on Sunday said that in
first phase of protest, we would stage protest demonstrations in Rawalpindi,
Gujranwala, Sialkot, Lahore, Faisalabad, Wazirabad, Gujrat, Sahiwal and Multan
on a regular basis. In the second phase protest demonstrations would be held in
the other cities of the province. We will continue our protest till the
acceptance of our demands, he warned.

He said the SNGPL has suspended the supply of natural gas to the CNG sector in
Punjab for indefinite period without the approval of the government and despite
stiff opposition from the Planning Commission of Pakistan, which is illegal and
unconstitutional. The unilateral and ill-timed decision has disturbed the daily
life of million of people while posing serious threat to Rs450 billion
investments in the CNG sector, he said.

He said that unlike others the CNG sector is the only sector, which has no
alternative to the natural gas and it shuts down completely when gas supply is
suspended. The government and the CNG operators have signed an agreement for
supply of gas around the year, which is being violated, he said.

Ghiyas Paracha said that all other sectors using natural gas have option to run
on furnace oil or electricity but the government's axe falls on the CNG sector
if it decides to suspend gas supply. He said that load management means
reduction in supply and that the CNG operators will not allow complete closure
in the name of management.

The SNGPL's 'one-sided' and flawed decision, he said, has hiked the transport
fares, disturbed the daily life, encouraged black marketing of petrol and hiked
the LPG prices by Rs40 per kg.

On the one hand, he said, the government is introducing employment schemes and,
on the other, it is taking decision that will result in massive unemployment and
non-serviceability of tens of thousands

of commercial and private

vehicles.

Other leaders of the association said that our filling stations are closed all
across Punjab and there is reduced pressure in the provinces of Sindh and Khyber
Pakhtoonkhwa but the domestic consumers are still not

getting gas.

Paracha also said the CNG sector has been paying the highest tariff and maximum
taxes but it is subjected to injustices. Gas suspension has left CNG owners
unable to pay gas bills and salaries.

He said that suspension orders should be reversed, gas should be supplied to CNG
stations from 9 am to 7 pm without interruption, cases be registered against
those responsible for gas crisis and the government should honour its
agreements.

                        Gulf News (United Arab Emirates)

                            November 29, 2013 Friday

Topless protest in Palestine

BYLINE: Nasouh Nazzal Correspondent

LENGTH: 518 words


Ramallah: Topless feminist activists will hold protests at the community garden
of the Church of Nativity in Bethlehem on December 24, but intend to delay
announcing the aim of the protest until the protest occurs.

Femen, the topless feminist protest group, is coming to Bethlehem in the West
Bank next month to participate in Christmas celebrations and the group's
possible visit to the Palestinian territories has raised high concerns among
Palestinians and Muslim parties.

A number of international sources have recently revealed that several topless
feminist activists will arrive in Bethlehem next month during the Christmas
season to organise a topless protests at the community garden of the Nativity
Church. These sources claim the protest will be against violence and unfairness
and to highlight the activists' "right" to demonstrate and express opinions.

The possible visit of Femen activists to Palestine has provoked Islamist
Palestinian parties which have announced that such a visit to Palestine for such
a protest "will not be possible and will never happen".

"Palestine is a holy and blessed area which will never be sullied by those
atheist women," the Muslim activist told Gulf News. "This issue should not be
discussed in the first place. There is no room for those women in Palestine.
This should be realised and taken as a matter of fact."

Islamic factions in northern areas of the West Bank have already addressed this
issue with their colleagues in southern areas of the West Bank including
Bethlehem and Hebron. The official stressed that the protest remains so far a
rumour and that the parties in Palestine do not want to make it an issue.

"If the visit is confirmed and the women arrive in Palestine, action against
this visit will be taken," he said.

Vera Baboun, mayor of Bethlehem, has categorically rejected any kind of protests
by topless feminist activists in the city. "Any protest that does not observe
Palestinian customs and traditions and which violates public decency is
unwelcome," she said in a statement.

"Any protest to be organised in Bethlehem needs an official permit," she
stressed.

Femen is an exhibitionist feminist protest group based in Paris that originated
in Ukraine, having been founded there in 2008. Femen activists claim their nude
protests allegedly fight against patriarchy and gender inequality.

Baboun said that activists from the Femen group will visit the Palestinian
territories next month to organize topless protests on December 24, and that
will coincide with the Christmas celebrations. She said that Femen will announce
the cause of the protest in Palestine during the protest itself.

A senior official at the Palestinian security apparatus said the Palestinian
security in Bethlehem has not received the relevant instructions about the
possible visit.

"Our final opinion about this is that we can not allow such topless protests in
Palestine. If any such protest was organised, the security organisations will be
held responsible from the Palestinian public perspective," he told Gulf News.

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 10, 2013 Tuesday

BRIEF: One person killed during protests in Turkey

BYLINE: A. Taghiyeva, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 140 words


Sept. 10--Protest actions of those dissatisfied with the policy of the ruling
Justice and Development Party took place in Antakya district of Turkish Hatay
province last night, Hürriyet newspaper reported on Tuesday.

During the fray there were clashes between the country's security forces and
demonstrators. One person was killed and several injured as a result of clashes.

Protests took place in Turkey for three weeks from late May. According to the
authorities, the protests were of an anti-government character.

As a result of the unrest in Turkey, nearly 4000 people were injured, five died
and 4900 were detained by the police.

                                 EKantipur.com

                           August 21, 2013 Wednesday

GJM concerned over Gorkhaland protests in Ktm

LENGTH: 304 words

DATELINE: KAKADBHITTA


KAKADBHITTA, Aug. 21 -- Gorkha Janamukti Morcha, which has been spearheading
protests in Darjeeling Hills of India demanding a separate state, has expressed
reservations over the protests that took place in Kathmandu three days ago,
supporting the Gorkhaland movement.

GJM alleged that the recent protests calling for a separate Gorkhaland state in
Darjeeling hills outside the Indian Embassy in Kathmandu has incited the
'elements' which are against the idea of separate Gorkhaland state.

"We are totally unaware about the protests that occurred in Kathmandu ," said
GJM General Secretary Roshan Giri," We don't even know why the protests took
place in Kathmandu ." He speculated that the protests were orchestrated at the
behest of those who do not want Gorkhaland .

GJM leader Giri made it clear that Darjeeling does not need financial or moral
support of any of the foreign countries. "We have been facing criticisms even
without taking any support," he said," I wonder what will be the situation if we
move ahead taking foreign support."

Sources claimed that the Indian Defense Ministry too has been concerned
regarding the protests in Kathmandu .

GJM has been launching protests in Darjeeling since August 3 demanding separate
state of Gorkhaland in Darjeeling . The strike has paralysed normal life in the
region.

Mamata Banerjee visiting Darjeeling

Meanwhile, West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee is scheduled to visit
Darjeeling in the first week of September, to participate in a programme.
Banerjee's visit is being viewed with keen interests as it comes in the wake of
intensified campaigns by Gorkhaland supporters.

                        BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             April 9, 2013 Tuesday

Protest in Tajik capital organized by pro-government groups - opposition

LENGTH: 302 words


Text of report by website of state-run Iranian radio external service from
Mashhad on 7 April

Some Tajik experts and media outlets have said that the protest rally held by a
group of Tajik youth in [the Tajik capital] Dushanbe city was organized by
pro-government groups.

A member of parliament and deputy chairman of the [opposition] Islamic Rebirth
Party of Tajikistan, Saidumar Husayni, mentioned that the city municipality had
refused a request by the party in the past to hold a protest demonstration to
condemn the killing of women and children in Gaza by the Zionist regime. He
added: "It is not clear for us how did the youth get permission to hold the
demonstration spontaneously?"

Shokirjon Hakimov, prominent lawyer and deputy chairman of the [opposition]
Social Democratic Party of Tajikistan, described the protest demonstration of
the Tajik youth at the US embassy as a false and unsuccessful scenario of the
government. He said: "While the municipality has repeatedly refused requests by
political organizations and parties to hold public protests why did it keep
silence over the protest of a group of the youth?" He believes it is absolutely
clear that the protest rally was held with a green light of official Dushanbe.

Over 100 Tajik youth on Friday afternoon [5 April] organized a protest rally in
front of the US embassy in Dushanbe, the capital of the country, and called for
handing former Tajik prime minister Abdumalik Abdullojonov over to court.

The accused prime minister of Tajikistan, who has a political refugee status in
the USA, was released from a remand centre in Kiev, Ukraine, at the
recommendation of the US authorities and request of some international
organizations on Thursday, 4 April.

Source: Voice of the Islamic Republic of Iran website, Mashhad, in Persian 1149
gmt 7 Apr 13

                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                             March 11, 2013 Monday

Christian community holds countrywide protests

SECTION: Vol. XXXVII No. 69

LENGTH: 347  words


The Christian community is holding protests throughout the country against
Badami Bagh, Lahore, incident.

In Lahore' the protestors completely destroyed Yuhana Abad Metro Bus Station and
set ablaze electric transformer.

Police used tear gas and rounded up some miscreants.

PPP Minority Wing also held a protest rally in front of Punjab Assembly against
Badami Bagh incident.

On the other hand 5 policemen were injured in tone pelting by the protestors at
Ferozepur road.

Christian community also held a protest demonstration at Faizabad interchange
Rawalpindi against the incident.

In Faisalabad' the District Aman Committee protested against the Lahore
incident.

Local Islamic clerics, students and people from various walks of life also
attended the protest demonstration.

Police resorted to tear gas shelling and aerial firing in front of Press Club to
disperse the protest rally in Karachi. The demonstrators turned violent and
torched some of the vehicles and pelted stones at police.

Protests were also reported in Mandi Bahauddin, Sargodha, Gojra, Dera Ismail
Khan, Peshawar and Gujranwala.

In Sind, Christian communities held protest demonstrations in Karachi and
Sukkur.

The protesters demanded to immediately arrest the miscreants.

PPP member of Punjab Assembly and President of Punjab PPP Minorities Wing'
Pervez Rafiq has resigned in protest against Badami Bagh incident.

Meanwhile' Chief Minister Punjab Shahbaz Sharif visited the Josef Colony and
directed authorities to swiftly address the grievances of the people.

He said Badami Bagh incident is an attempt to mutilate the image of Pakistan. He
said culprits will be brought to justice.

Pakistan Qaumi Masiha Party and Pakistan Minorities League staged a protest
outside Lahore Press Club on Sunday.

Meanwhile, Chief Justice of Pakistan Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry has
taken suo-moto notice of Joseph Colony' Badami Bagh' Lahore incident and hearing
will be held today (Monday).

On March 9, over 150 homes of the Christian community were ransacked and set on
fire by an angry mob over alleged blasphemy committed by Sawan Masih.

                                Himalayan Times

                            January 22, 2013 Tuesday

Oppn parties declare protest programmes

BYLINE: HIMALAYAN NEWS SERVICE

LENGTH: 243  words


BIRATNAGAR: Nine opposition parties have announced 10-day protest programmes in
Biratnagar today against Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai starting from January
25.

Organising a press conference, opposition parties declared protest programme to
topple the Bhattarai-led government through street protests as he has been
refusing to put in his papers. They have even formed the Protest Coordination
Committee comprising district chiefs of all the nine parties.

According to the protest programme schedule, they will stage joint protest rally
and meet in Biratnagar's Janaandolan Chowk on January 25. A motorcycle rally
would be staged in front of stadium at 1 pm on January 29. Similarly, the
political parties would organise horn rally on January 31 and February 1.
Finally, a public meeting with more than 50,000 participants will be held on
February 20 in Biratnagar.

The parties have even warned that if Bhattarai fails to resign by then, they
would continue their protests on the same day on February 20. Speaking at a
press meet, Congress' Amod Prasad Upadhaya clarified that the protest programmes
are not intended for the PM chair but to get back the kidnapped democracy.

Similarly, UML Morang chairperson Mahesh Regmi said the objective of the
opposition was not only to make a way for the government but also to stop the
illegal activities carried out by the government that are against peoples'
interest and to hold polls by institutionalising democracy.

                              515 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                                 Jerusalem Post

                             April 3, 2012 Tuesday

Summer protests will return and be more political, says organizer

BYLINE: BEN HARTMAN

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 394 words


Last year's social justice protests will return to Israel this summer, just with
more focus, anger and specific demands, and without the tent cities that defined
the summer of 2011, a leader of one of the groups looking to reignite the
protests said Sunday.

Idan Miller, a 40-year-old Tel Aviv hi-tech worker and one of the founders of
the group "the joint camp" (hamahaneh hameshutaf), said that the summer's
protest will also be political, a marked divergence from the oft-repeated
refrains of last year's protest leaders, who characterized the demonstrations as
a sort of apolitical, pan-Israeli awakening of overburdened citizens.

"This summer's protests will be much more political, because we realize that the
changes happen in the political realm," Miller said. "Those who hold the keys
are those politicians who are trying to be the prime minister."

Miller added that they "won't just be about shouting social justice and saying
'I'm not political.' This time we'll say we are political and the only way to
change things is at the ballot box."

Saturday night's protest against rising gas and electricity prices brought
together several hundred people and was the largest street demonstration since
the "March of the Million" held last September. While it was similar to last
summer's rallies - protesters shouted for revolution, red flags were on display
and there was a half-hearted attempt to block a major city thoroughfare - Miller
said it also showed how this summer's protests will be different.

"The protest this summer will be much more focused on very specific issues, like
last night's protest, which was focused on two specific issues: gas and
electricity. There are a number of concrete issues and we will try and force the
system to focus on them," he said.

Miller said he believes that the protests will only kick off in earnest in May,
with the opening of the Knesset summer session, but when it will, it will not
include tent cities and the urban Woodstock vibe of last summer.

Around a half dozen protest groups are planning demonstrations in the coming
months, with most talk focusing on reigniting the protests this summer. They
appear to be on fertile ground, at least according to a survey released by the
College of Academic Management Studies last week, which stated that 78 percent
of Israelis feel the cost of living protests should continue.

LOAD-DATE: April 5, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: Idan Miller (Credit: Channel 2)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2012 The Jerusalem Post
                              All Rights Reserved
