                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           February 25, 2012 Saturday

Programme summary of Afghan Ariana TV news in Dari 1530 gmt 25 Feb 12

LENGTH: 821 words


A. Home News

B. News Headlines

1. 0050 The Ministry of Interior has reported in a statement that two foreign
advisors were killed in an armed clash in the command centre of the ministry. It
has been said that the two foreigners were American advisors and the Taleban
have claimed that the attack was conducted in reaction to the Koran burning. A
Taleban spokesman has said four foreign advisers were killed by one of their
associate who was working in the Interior Ministry. Video archive shows some
foreign soldiers.

2. 0240 The Afghan government introduced nine ministers-designate to parliament
to get a vote of confidence from the MPs. The ministers were introduced by the
Second Vice-president Karim Khalili at a ceremony today. Speaking during the
ceremony, Mr Khalili said that peace is a need of the Afghans, but the peace
process must be led by Afghans. He has said that the achievements of the past 10
years must not be lost and the Afghan constitution should be respected in the
peace process. Video shows Khalili addressing a parliamentary session.

3. 0510 Four people were killed and 50 others were wounded in today's violent
protest in Konduz Province. Reportedly, over 20 others were wounded in a similar
protest in Laghman Province. The provincial officials said 17 suspects were also
detained in connection with violent protests in Laghman Province. Another report
from Nangarhar Province says four people were killed and three others were
wounded in today's protests in two districts of this province but the provincial
officials did not confirm the report on casualties. Report adds that peaceful
protest was held in Sar-e Pol Province. Video shows protests in various
provinces of the country.

4. 0730 A Statement by the United Nations Assistance Mission for Afghanistan
(UNAMA) condemns violent protests in northern Konduz Province which involved
attack against the provincial office of UNAMA in the mentioned province. The
statement says some opportunists try to take advantage of the situation and
attack government and non-government properties which is not to the benefit of
Afghans and their country. Video shows archive footage of the protests in the
province.

5. 0810 Adverts

6. 0920 Some religious scholars in northern Baghlan Province denounce violent
protests which results in killing of civilians and destruction of government or
private buildings. Speaking on issue, some religious scholars said the violent
protests only harm Afghans and does not resolve the problems. They called on
people in the province to stage only peaceful protests and prove their bravery
and love for Koran. Video shows some religious scholars talking on the issue,
archive footage of violent protests.

7. 1050 Some religious scholars meet President Karzai and discuss burning of the
Holy Koran and actions so far taken for the punishment of the perpetrators. The
president also voiced concern over the issue and violent protests in the country
and said new measures will be taken to avoid such incidents in future. The
scholars also condemned burning of the Holy Koran and called on the president to
take a guarantee from foreign forces not to repeat such acts. No video.

8. 1120 Bayat Foundation distributes winter assistance to hundreds of vulnerable
people in northern Baghlan Province. Speaking on the issue, some people thanked
Bayat Foundation for the assistance. Video shows distribution of assistance to
some people, some officials talking on the issue.

9. 1430 Dr Burna Asefi, a man widely credited as one of the founders of
contemporary mental health services in Afghanistan, passed away in London today.
No video. (See separate report)

10. 1500 Commercials

D. Foreign News

11. 1810 Reports say that nearly 100 people have been killed and dozens of
others have been wounded in Homs; Abdorabo Mansur Hadi has taken an oath as the
new President of Yemen.

12. 1850 The IAEA has said that Iran has accelerated enriching uranium and has
enriched over 100 kilograms of uranium so far.

E. Economics News

13. 1920 Report on launch of a number of projects in central Ghazni Province.
The projects are part of the efforts for introducing the province as the capital
of Islamic countries in 2013. Video shows part of the province, some officials
talking on the issue.

14. 2010 Officials in Konar Province have said that reopening of the Nawapas
transit route in the province will increase economic growth in the province.
Meanwhile, the foundation of a custom house was laid in the province. Video
archive shows parts of Konar.

15. 2130 Afghan Chamber of Commerce and Interior Ministry distribute winter
assistance to over 700 families in various parts of Kabul. The assistance
included fuel, blankets and foodstuffs which were mainly distributed to the
internally displaced people in the outskirts of Kabul. Video shows distribution
of assistance to some people.

G. Weather forecast:

Source: Ariana TV, Kabul, in Dari 1530 gmt 25 Feb 12

                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                           February 16, 2012 Thursday

Regulate demos, LHC orders govt

BYLINE:  Our Staff Reporter

SECTION: Vol. XXV No. 367

LENGTH: 286  words


The Lahore High Court on Wednesday sought reply from the Punjab Government on a
plea seeking policy to regulate demonstrations and protests in the province
especially in Lahore, and some administrative actions against Paramedical
Alliance President over the death of an old lady during the demo before PIC.

Petitioner-Lawyer Mian Asad Mahmud said that Punjab Paramedical Alliance (PPA)
on Feb 8 had staged a protest before the Punjab Institute of Cardiology (PIC)
demanding professional allowance, revision of service structure for lower grad
employees and pay protection.

He submitted that such kinds of protests and blocking the traffic were causing
disturbance for the public at large and during the protest of PPA an old lady
Saleema Bibi, en-rout to PIC for emergency medical treatment, lost her life.

Petitioner contended that PPA's style of protest was not in professional way as
they have a right to protest but they don't have right to stop any ambulance
carrying patients.

He pointed out that protests were increasing day by day and the city is
witnessing at least two to three protests daily which were causing problems for
the commuters and disturbing routine life of masses.

He requested for directions to Punjab government to devise a strategy to
regulate the protests. Petitioner also prayed to penalise the PPA President
Malik Munir for his neglecting act of causing a loss of an old lady by adopting
illegal way of protest.

After recording initial arguments, Justice Manzoor Ahmad Malik issued notices to
Punjab government, Secretary Health and PPA president for Feb 17.

The court also directed the petitioner to make party to Capital City Police
Officer, Lahore and other police officers in the petition.

                             Kashmir Images (India)

                           September 8, 2011 Thursday

Secretariat employees chart new course of protests

LENGTH: 424 words

DATELINE: Srinagar


Srinagar, Sept. 8 -- In what could be described as a novel way of protest,
employees of the Civil Secretariat here after performing their duties in the day
chose to protest during the night right within the secretariat premises. They
were intermittently shouting slogans in favour of employees' demands and then
chatting over the outcome of their strike.Moreover, some Cabinet ministers
including Peerzada Mohammad Syeed, and Chief Secretary Madhav Lal and many a
commissioner secretaries were also compelled to stay put in the secretariat for
the night.

"Let's work so that common people are not troubled but at the same time we
should also register our protest," goes the idea behind this new way of protest,
the protesting secretariat employees said. "This really is a unique way to
protest given the history of protest demonstrations in the state. We thought
that people should not suffer when we press for our genuine demands," Rauf Ahmad
Bhat, president Civil Secretariat Non-Gazetted Employees Union (CSNGEU) told
'Kashmir Images'.Even when many of their colleagues were protesting in the
premises and at the gate, some employees were directed to continue work during
the night."We took permission from chief secretary in writing so that pending
RTI and litigation files are completed during the night amid protest. We don't
want to follow age-old tradition of creating inconvenience to the common people
by our strikes," says Subhash Koul, secretary CSNGEU.Asked as to how they
thought of this 'out of box' idea of protest, Bhat told said, "See in 1947, we
used to cook food on the fire in an open hearth, but times have changed; now we
just have to press a button and food is ready. So, age-old ways of protest will
do no more in the modern age as human mind is constantly evolving."Employees
were all joy about introduction the novel way in the protest history of Kashmir
as it does in no way harm the interests of the common people. "It is a great
privilege to be part of a protest that harms none and at the same time speaks
about the discontent of the local employees," exuded an employee of General
Administration Department.However, he feels sorry that "State government is
sanctioning arrears of non-local IAS and IPS officers in one go, but claims
there are no resources when it comes to paying the local employees of the
state." Published by HT Syndication with permission from Kashmir Images. For any
query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                     The News Herald (Panama City, Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 6, 2010 Sunday

Muslims protest Israeli raid: Counter protesters across street say Jewish nation
has right to defend itself

BYLINE: Sarah Owen, The News Herald, Panama City, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 466 words


Jun. 6--PANAMA CITY -- Activists on one side of the street waved Israeli flags,
while those across the intersection carried Palestinian banners. Both sides held
American flags and both sides prayed.

About 150 Panama City Muslims and their friends and families gathered Saturday
to protest the Israeli blockade of Gaza, which resulted Monday in the deaths of
nine people after troops raided a flotilla laden with supplies.

Another crowd of about 50 stood on the opposite corner of 23rd Street and State
77 to protest the protest.

Vivian Mohamed, a member of Bay County Islamic Society, said the event wasn't
about religion and it wasn't about politics; it was about basic human rights.

"Bottom line, we're humans first," Mohamed said. "That flotilla was strictly
humanitarian aid. They were doing a good thing; they were innocent, and they
were killed."

Supporters carried signs that read "Peace for all," "Stop hate" and "Honk for
human rights." They chanted "USA, USA" and "Hugs, not bullets."

Mohamed said her goal in organizing the rally was to help educate the community
about the blockade and about the "underlying tones" of the conflict.

"When they think Jerusalem and Palestine, they think Jewish and Muslim," she
said. "They see us, Muslims, as foreigners. Well, I'm American -- I was born and
raised in Ohio."

Across the street, someone shouted, "Go back to the Middle East; go back home."

Ron Kimbal agreed the issue wasn't religion, but said it was political. He
carried a sign that read, "I support Israel."

"Basically, Israel is standing up to these flotillas -- they're defending their
rights to defend themselves," Kimbal said. "These flotillas could be bringing
weapons into the country. Israel has a right to defend herself from terror."

John Nichol, a former member of the Air Force, echoed fears of weaponry slipping
through the blockade.

"They shouldn't have to have rockets imported in on their heads," Nichol said.
"And I'm not a Jew; I'm a Christian."

Protesters on his side of the street sang Christian hymns while Judy Mullikin
and Marian Nickel weaved through crowds on the opposite side of the road handing
out candy bars and fliers.

"We understand that Jesus loves everyone and God has a covenant with both of the
peoples, Arabs and Jews," Nickel said. "These people have told me they love
America; they love me. We just want them to know we're all God's children."

To see more of The News Herald or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.newsherald.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The News Herald, Panama City,
Fla. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

Different protests staged in Sukkur

BYLINE:  Kamran Shaikh

SECTION: Vol. III No. 1462

LENGTH: 314  words


Local people staged different protest demonstration in Sukkur in favour of their
demands on Tuesday.

According to details, the people of the Shaikh Community under the leadership of
Allah Dino, Saeeda, Zahida and Lal Khatoon staged a protest demonstration
against the kidnapping of their girl namely Shabiran. Talking to newsmen, they
alleged that the armed men including Amjad Mirani, Amjad Shaikh and others had
kidnapped their girl ten days ago and despite passage of ten days the police
have not recovered their girl. They demanded for the immediate recovery of their
girl. Another protest was staged by the people of the Pathan Community,
demanding for action against the police officials, involved in cutting throat of
a youth of their community namely Munawar Khan. They were led by Advocate
Maulana Amir Khan, Mir Dadan Khan, Shahbaz Pathan.

The third protest was staged by the traders of Sukkur against the robbery from
the shop of Dr Sunil Kumar. The leaders of the Anjuman-e-Tajiran including Syed
Muhammad Shah, Haroon Shaikh and others led the protest. The activists of the
Sindh Taraqqi Pasand Party chapter Sukkur staged a protest demonstration in
favour of the demands of the employees of NPIW. They demanded of the government
of Sindh to take notice of the matter and regularize the services of the NPIW
employees.

The fourth protest was staged by the people of the Gopang Community, residents
of Kandiaro against the abduction of their youth. Talking to newsmen, they said
that a few influential persons of their area namely Shahzado Gopang, Nawab
Gopang, Murtaza Gopang and others had kidnapped a youth of their community
namely Riaz Gopang on 5th of March and added that the SHO Kandiaro, Aslam
Laghari is supporting the above mentioned accused. They demanded for the
immediate recovery of the abducted youth and action against the accused persons
and SHO Kandiaro.

Students in Pakistan tribal area protest Afghan, Iran "interference"

LENGTH: 202 words


Excerpt from report by staff reporter headlined "Kurram students protest foreign
interference" published by Pakistan newspaper Daily Times website on 14 August

Peshawar: People from different areas recorded their protest by staging protest
demonstrations and addressing news conferences and issued warnings to the
government for redressing their grievances here on Wednesday [13 August].

The first such protest demonstration was staged by students from Kurram Agency,
who asked the government to take notice of interference by Afghanistan and Iran
in their areas.

The students chanted slogans against the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation
(NATO) forces in Afghanistan for their alleged bombing of the Sunni Muslim
population in Kurram Agency.

Carrying banners and placards, the students were stopped by policemen when they
tried to stage protest demonstrations in front of the Afghan and Iranian
consulates.

They alleged the governments of Afghanistan and Iran were openly involved in the
sectarian fighting in Kurram Agency, which had so far claimed hundred of lives
and dislodged thousands others from their houses since November last year.

                              523 of 995 DOCUMENTS


                       BBC Monitoring Europe - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             July 29, 2008 Tuesday

Serbian "nationalist organizations" protest Karadzic arrest for 7th straight day

LENGTH: 313 words


Text of report by Serbian independent news agency Beta

["Nationalist Organizations Hold Protest" - BETA headline]

Belgrade, 28 July - A protest against the arrest of war crimes indictee Radovan
Karadzic was held in Belgrade again today, for the seventh day in a row.

The protest, organized by the Serbian Radical Party [SRS] and the nationalist
organizations Obraz [Dignity] and 1389 [year of the Battle of Kosovo], was
incident-free.

Several hundred protesters gathered just after 1700 hours [ 1500 gmt] in Trg
Republike Square and set off on a protest march along Decanska Street, across
Trg Nikole Pasica Square, along Kneza Milosa and Kralja Milana Streets, and back
to Trg Republike, where the protest ended an hour later.

While marching, they shouted familiar slogans from similar gatherings and
chanted support for Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic.

At the protest, SRS official Natasa Jovanovic urged people to turn out for the
Radicals' rally in Belgrade tomorrow and said she expects the protest to be
attended by 1 million people.

A strong police presence was securing state institutions along the protesters'
route, as well as the McDonalds' restaurant and the Belgrade headquarters of the
Democratic Party in central Terazije Square.

It was noticed that there were more reporters at today's rally than at the
protests held at the weekend.

During protests over the past few days, several reporters, cameramen, and news
photographers were attacked, prompting a decision by media houses to scale down
coverage of rallies.

During the past three days, police have been perceived to be protecting
reporters and preventing their contact with demonstrators during protest
marches.

Radovan Karadzic was arrested in Belgrade on Monday, 21 July, which triggered
daily protests staged by a number of nationalist organizations.

Source: Beta news agency, Belgrade, in Serbian 1646 gmt 28 Jul 08

                           December 6, 2007 Thursday

Journalists continue protest for press freedom

LENGTH: 291 words


ISLAMABAD: Journalists community continued their protest demonstration against
the ban on media and to show sympathy with deposed judges.  The protest was
organized by Rawalpindi Islamabad Union of Journalists here outside the
Islamabad Press Club. President RIUJ, Afzal Butt was leading the protest
demonstration.

The participants of the rally were holding banners and placards inscribed with
the slogans of freedom of speech and restoration of deposed Judge.  While
addressing the protest rally he vowed to continue the struggle for the freedom
of speech, which had started some months back. He said that Journalists and
lawyers were harassed and handcuffed in Karachi which is the worst example in
the history.  He further said that with the beginning of journalists protest
demonstration all the channels were banned.  But now, government has open few
channels ostensibly after imposing heavy restrictions.

However, Geo News, Aag, Geo Sports, Royal TV and FM-99 are still shutdown.
Therefore, government must restore the transmission of all these channels, he
demanded.  Secretary General PFUJ, Mazhar Abbas in his address said that
historic struggle of the journalists, lawyers and member of civil societies is
continuing and the number of the protestors is increasing day by day which would
further strengthen the movement.  He demanded from the government to lift ban
from all channels immediately. He also demanded release of the all the arrested
lawyers.

Members of the civil societies and workers of political parties also expressed
their views on the occasion. Jamil Abbasi, Sardar Naseem (PML-N), Ishtiaq Assi,
Hamayun Mirza, former secretary Interior, Rodad Khan, J. Salik and Raja Hanif
Advocate were also present on the occasion.

                               The Jerusalem Post

                          September 6, 2007, Thursday

Sderot parents call on Olmert to resign in Jerusalem protest. 'We live in a war
zone'

BYLINE: Rory Kress

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 531 words


Sderot residents gathered outside the Knesset on Wednesday afternoon to protest
the government's poor security provisions after another week of heavy Kassam
attacks and no military response.

Parents were calling for Prime Minister Ehud Olmert's resignation and carrying
hand-painted signs saying The Knesset never gets hit by Kassams. They fed their
young children popsicles before allowing them to climb atop mounds of
construction rubble to shout towards Olmert's office that they no longer want
him or the rockets.

The protest was organized by the Committee for a Secure Sderot - an apolitical
group that lobbies for improved security in Sderot and provides services to the
community.

The protest included a boycott of the Sderot municipality's educational system
following a Kassam attack near a busy nursery school on Monday.

" Hamas is accurate enough to hit our preschool over and over again...they're
targeting our children said Dov Dalin, 24, a student at Sapir College who lives
in Sderot.  I sleep on the floor instead of in my bed. I don't live a normal
life. I live in a war zone."

Gilad Sabag 18 attends high school in Sderot. This past Sunday he should have
returned to school like the rest of students across the country but instead he
recalled a very different scene.

"From 5 a.m. the Kassams were falling without stop he recalled. People were
screaming and running - but nobody cared. I was afraid to get hit. My school
isn't secure; I feel it and I know it."

Though school has been in session for five days Sderot students have attended
less than one full day of classes Sderot Municipality spokesman Yosef Pinhas
Cohen told The Jerusalem Post during the demonstration.

According to Cohen seven Kassams struck Sderot during the Monday morning
commute. "We had small children on the way to school and they didn't know what
to do. It's impossible to learn Cohen said. He echoed a common sentiment among
Sderot parents that the actual security of the school buildings is not the main
issue; rather, it is the fact that the children must leave the relative safety
of their homes to go to school.

When asked if schools would reopen on Thursday, Cohen could only reply Maybe yes
maybe no and explained that most parents were trying to take their children out
of the city altogether.

Chana Melul, a Sderot mother of three young children, should have seen her
oldest child attend his first day of first grade on Sunday.

It's a very very sad thing for me. All of my enthusiasm for taking him to his
first day of school is gone. I missed it sighed Melul.

Instead, she and her children awoke at 5: 30 in the morning to the sound of the
Tzeva Adom (Color Red) Kassam warning siren.

Usually I am awake to take care of my kids but this time I was awake because of
the Kassams. My youngest child said to me 'Mommy now I need water because I have
to relax after the siren.' It's not normal. They haven't been on a playground in
more than a year lamented Melul.

When Sderot schools reopen, Melul believes she will allow her child to go. I
will take him because I want him to feel like he has a routine life she said.

LOAD-DATE: September 11, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: SDEROT RESIDENTS protest in front of the Prime Minister's Office
in Jerusalem yesterday refusing to send their children to school and demanding
the government stop the constant Kassam rocket attacks. (Credit: Sebastian
Scheiner/Ap)

                             Herald Sun (Australia)

                          November 22, 2006 Wednesday
                                 FIRST Edition

The right and wrong way to protest

SECTION: LETTERS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 336  words


THE two protests held in Melbourne over the past few days could not have been
further apart in how they were held and the effect they had in getting their
messages across.

The message of the G20 protest was completely obscured by the violent behaviour
of a relatively few idiots who were there only to disrupt and destroy.

Monday's ''bush'' protest on the other hand was dignified and peaceful, as a
protest should be.

Bob Williams, Croydon Hills

GOOD to see the farmers didn't ride their horses into McDonald's or the Nike
store, but instead, marched peacefully. Then, again, they were all hard-working
Aussies, not like the trash on the weekend.

Clint Brown, Burnie, Tas


TWO methods of protest:

1: Smashing property, abusing police and screaming slogans.

2: A street march by hundreds of country Victorians making a peaceful point.

I too will protest this Saturday. I will protest by supporting a country-based
political party. I will not give my support to metropolitan controlled political
parties with no inkling of the damage they have caused rural Victoria over the
past 25 years.

If Messrs Bracks and Baillieu cannot recognise that there are people living past
Dandenong, they should get re-educated.

John Cribbes, Sale


THE cattlemen claim continuing use of national parks because of seven
generations of access.

Will they support Aboriginal access to all of Australia because of something
like 1500 generations of access?

These cattlemen want something for nothing.

Lawry Twining, Northcote


THE Liberal Party's support for cattle grazing in the Alpine National Park
contradicts the party's loud calls for water conservation and healthy national
parks.

Alpine grazing was wrecking the headwaters of major water catchments and sending
native species to the brink of extinction.

Political parties should be protecting public lands and catchments, not
virtually giving them away to private grazing interests. A healthy environment
and alpine grazing simply don't mix.

Charlie Sherwin, director, Victorian National Parks Association

                               New Indian Express

                            July 20, 2016 Wednesday

UoH students object to designated protest spots

LENGTH: 291 words

DATELINE: HYDERABAD


HYDERABAD, July 20 -- Student groups of University of Hyderabad said that they
are against the decision to identify one or two areas in the campus for staging
protests or demonstrations.

"It was resolved to constitute a committee with the Dean Students' Welfare and a
member of the executive council to identify one or two areas on the campus for
staging protests/demonstrations in a democratic manner," as mentioned in a
document titled 'Minutes of the 169th meeting of the Executive Council held at 3
P.M, on June 28, 2016'.

"Protests are not programmes, they do not have boundaries. If there is an issue
at mess or hostel, we will protest there but not at designated sites," said
Gurajada Garikapati, spokesperson of ABVP-UoH.

Member of Ambedkar Students' Association (ASA), Dontha Prashant expressed a
similar opinion. "If there is a problem in finance department, I will stage a
protest there but not in a forest," he said.

Officials from the university said that the designated protest sites have not
been decided yet. As of today, the student groups stage protests at Shopping
Complex of UoH, administration building, before main gate and other places. Of
all the places, the shopping complex, where Rohit Vemula stayed in Velivada till
his death, is ground zero for protests from January. In the document, it was
also mentioned that disciplinary action would be taken for blockade of entry
into campus or administration building. Earlier, in some of the protests that
were organised staff were not allowed into the administration building.

                             May 12, 2016 Thursday

Different protests staged outside the Hyderabad Press Club

SECTION: Vol. 09 No. 133

LENGTH: 249  words


<Text>

Different protest demonstrations were staged by people in favor of their demands
outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Wednesday. According to the details, the
activists of the Sindh Small Industries Corporation Employees' Union including
President Noor Mohammad Khoso and others staged a protest in favor of their
demands. The protestors said that due to wrong policies of the government
hundreds of employees have been deprived of their salaries and pensions since
past 8 months. A man namely Ghulam Mustafa, resident of Kotri staged a protest
demonstration against the mill manager, who has sacked him from the service. A
man namely Zameer Hussain staged a protest demonstration against his stepmother
Surya Nisar Khokhar. A woman namely Parveen, resident of Paretabad staged a
protest demonstration against her husband Safeer Mohammad.

She accused her husband of subjecting her to torture. A woman namely Shahnaz
Mangi w/o Barkat Mangi, resident of Kotri staged a protest against her husband
for forcing her to prostitution. The residents of Tando Adam including Zubair
Ahmed, Raza Mohammad and others staged a protest demonstration against HESCO
Subdivision Tando Adam for surplus charges on electricity bills. The residents
of Maitari including Mohammad Bachal Mallah and others staged a protest
demonstration against the local landlord Mir Mohammad Shah for occupying their
houses and issuing them dire threats.  They all urged the concerned authorities
to resolve their problems.

                                Dawn (Pakistan)

                             March 21, 2016 Monday

PPP groups protest, but separately

BYLINE: AAMIR YASIN

SECTION: Vol. 70 No. 81

LENGTH: 391  words


The divided PPP in the Rawalpindi city on Sunday responded positively to the
call of party chairman Bilawal Bhutto Zardari to protest against the PML-N
government for allowing Pervez Musharraf to go abroad.

Two separate protest gatherings were held in the garrison city by the PPP
workers and supporters against the government decision. Over 250 people turned
up at both the protests.

One of the groups staged a protest at Liaquat Bagh in front of Benazir Bhutto's
monument. The divisional coordinator of the party, Raja Imran Ashraf, PPP city
president Amir Fida Paracha and Shujaat Haider Naqvi led the protest.

More than 100 party workers and supporters took part in the protest. The
participants were carrying placards inscribed with slogans against the PML-N
leadership.

Both groups were responding to Bilawal's call to protest Musharraf's exit

The speakers said the government allowed Musharraf, an accused in the Benazir
murder case, to leave the country as it wanted to give him an amnesty in the
case.

They said in difficult times, Nawaz Sharif sought help from the PPP but he
changed his attitude later. They said Mr Sharif gave a safe passage to the
former president without any justification.

They said the PPP would continue its struggle to strengthen democracy and
parliament without the PML-N which always danced to the tunes of others. They
said the days of the PML-N government were numbered and the PPP had started an
agitation against its wrong polices.

On the other hand, more than 150 PPP workers and supporters gathered at Siddiqui
Chowk on Saidpur Road led by Babar Jadoon, Khalid Nawaz Bobi and Chaudhry
Banaras.

'Go Nawaz Go' slogans were chanted by the protesters. They blocked the road for
an hour and dispersed peacefully.

The speakers stressed the need for bringing Musharraf back to face the law.
Musharraf will never come back during the tenure of Nawaz Sharif as he (Sharif)
assured Musharraf's friends that no action would be taken against him even in
the Benazir murder case, claimed Babar Jadoon.

When contacted, PPP city chapter spokesman Shujaat Haider Naqvi said the party
had invited all the workers and local leaders to Liaquat Bagh but the other
group did not turn up as it wanted to maintain its own identity.

However, Babar Jadoon added that old party workers were not informed about the
programme at Liaquat Bagh.

                        BBC Monitoring Central Asia Unit
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                             March 14, 2016 Monday

Opposition protest ends in Kyrgyz south

LENGTH: 173 words


Text of report by privately-owned daily Kyrgyz newspaper Vecherniy Bishkek on 14
March

The protest in the town of Kerben in Aksy District has ended. VB [Vecherniy
Bishkek] learnt this from the leader of the political movement Jany Muun, Timur
Saralayev.

According to him, the protest was attended by around 500 people. It lasted for
two hours. According to the organisers, there were provocations by authorities.
Athletic men attempted to foil the holding of the protest. They jostled and
tried to provoke the participants to violate the law.

However, the police department for Dzhalal-Abad Region denied reports concerning
the number of participants in the protest. Members of the police told VB that
only 70 people from among locals had gathered in Kerben and around 100
protesters in Dzhalal-Abad.

At the moment the situation is stable. No violations by participants in the
protest have been registered. According to the law-enforcement agencies, the
protest ended at 1330 [0730 GMT].

Source: Vecherniy Bishkek, Bishkek, in Russian 14 Mar 16

                           Hobart Mercury (Australia)

                           January 21, 2016 Thursday
                                 Hobart Edition

Arrests first under new protest law

BYLINE: BLAIR RICHARDS State Political Reporter

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 202  words


TASMANIA'S Resources Minister says the State Government's anti-protest laws are
working as they should, following a further arrest at a community forest protest
in the North-West.

A 35-year-old Lutana woman participating in the Lap-oinya protest was yesterday
arrested and charged for failing to comply with a police direction to leave the
area.

The woman was the second person to be arrested at the protest after a
66-year-old ana-esthetist from Wynyard was arrested on Tuesday.

They were the first people to be charged under the Liberals' anti-protest laws,
designed to protect forestry businesses from being disrupted.

"The Government is a strong supporter of free speech and the right to protest.
But we also unashamedly support the rights of people to earn a lawful living,"
Resources Minister Paul Harriss said. The Government's political opponents say
while the unrest at Lapoinya may suit the Liberals politically, it will damage
the forest industry by making Forestry Tasmania's quest to gain environmental
certification even harder. Opposition leader Bryan Green said Mr Harriss " wants
the forest wars to continue for his own political interests". "That can only
mean the demise of Forestry Tasmania," he said.

                          What the Papers Say (Russia)

                            November 2, 2015 Monday

PROTESTS POSTPONED

BYLINE: Alexei Gorbachev, Daria Garmonenko

SECTION: PRESS EXTRACTS; No. 1428

LENGTH: 602 words



HIGHLIGHT: PROTEST ACTION IN MOSCOW MIGHT TAKE PLACE ON DECEMBER 1 AND NOT ON
NOVEMBER 15; The opposition decided to postpone the protest action in Moscow.


Insiders claim that the protest action the opposition is planning in Moscow
might take place in the middle of December and not on November 15 as it was
initially scheduled. Organizers of the march cannot reach an agreement on the
agenda. RPR-PARNAS wants the protest action to be thoroughly political. Yabloko
insists on an emphasis on protests against investment of new powers in security
structures. Preliminary reports indicate that the protest action will probably
take place on December 12, the Constitution Day in Russia.

Sergei Sharov-Delone, member of the Protest Committee, said that the march was
postponed give the opposition additional time to organize things better. "We
want this action to be associated with a maximum specific message... and that
takes time," he said.

Sharov-Deloine said that the March of Changes was going to retain its name and
its central idea. "What we need is a sharp turn in the course Russia is
following. Human rights issues are a part of the package - release of political
prisoners, economic matters, political affairs, no more wars in Syria and
Ukraine, freedom of expression, and no more laws that expand the powers wielded
by secret services."

"Organization of previous protest marches was easier because we merely responded
to the current events. Not this time when we mean to formulate the agenda,"
Sharov-Delone said.

What information is available to this newspaper indicates that it is with
RPR-PARNAS and Democratic Coalition in general that the Protest Committee cannot
reach an agreement.

"Our colleagues within the Protest Committee claim that elections legitimize the
regime and thus should be boycotted. PARNAS in the meantime intends to
participate in the future federal parliamentary campaign. It insists therefore
that the matter be made a part of the agenda at the protest action," said a
source within RPR-PARNAS.

RPR-PARNAS Assistant Chairman Konstantin Merzlikin pointed out that genuine
protests required a broader spectrum of participants. It is known in the
meantime that Anaxei Navalny's Progress Party intends to take no part in the
future protest action. Its representatives say that the municipal authorities
will never permit a protest action in central Moscow whereas protesting in the
outskirts will be pointless.

Yabloko leader Sergei Mitrokhin said that it was necessary to protest against
the "inhuman laws" that invested new powers in law-enforcement agencies. "Our
colleagues are obsessed with vague slogans on the necessity of a new regime and
so on. We believe that it is wrong and that it is necessary to be more specific
and precise in protests. Say, protests ought to be organized against the new law
on the policy that are about to be permitted to open up on people without
sufficient grounds."

Sergei Davidis, one of the December 5 Party leaders and Protest Committee
member, said that the rally might take place on December 12.

Konstantin Kalachev of the Political Expert Group pointed out that the date of
the protest was going to have no effect on the turnout. "Dedicated participants
in democratic rallies will turn up in any event on any day. As for the rest,
they are unlikely to come."

The expert backed the idea to focus the protest action on the forthcoming
federal parliamentary campaign as "quite reasonable".

National Strategy Council General Director Valery Khomyakov said that December
12 was a good choice for the protest. "The Constitution is ignored or this is
what the opposition claims. It is logical therefore to organize a protest right
on the Constitution Day."

Source: Nezavisimaya Gazeta, No 237, November 2, 2015, p. 1

LOAD-DATE: November 2, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ORIGINAL-LANGUAGE: RUSSIA; RUSSIAN

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               Eastbourne Herald

                           October 14, 2015 Wednesday

Anti-fracking activists protest against Eastbourne bank

LENGTH: 425  words


A group of climate activists held a protest against fracking outside a branch of
Barclays Bank in Eastbourne on Saturday (October 10).

Activists from Eastbourne and District Friends of the Earth invited members of
the public in Terminus Road to sign a petition asking the bank to stop funding
exploratory shale gas drilling in the UK.

The group held its protest as the bank owns 97 per cent of Third Energy, a
company linked to fracking in North Yorkshire.

The protest came as part of a wave of protests outside branches of Barclays
organised by Friends of the Earth groups across the UK to recognise Climate Day
of Action.

A spokesman for the group said, "The protest, and the petition, was well
received by the public and is indicative of a greater general awareness of what
fracking is and what the risks are for the environment and for public health.

"There is the risk of extra carbon emissions from fracking contributing to a
worsening of climate change."

At the end of the protest the group personally delivered letters from Eastbourne
residents asking the bank to cut its fracking ties.

"This protest marks the beginning of a period of intense activity by climate
campaigners globally, and many activists from Eastbourne and District Friends of
the Earth, and other local community groups, will be on the People's Climate
March in London on November 29," added the spokesman.

"They will also be in Paris on the final weekend of the crucial UN climate talks
on December 12 and 13.

"The main message on both occasions will be that all politicians and government
leaders should take urgent action to mitigate climate change, primarily by
keeping most of our fossil fuel reserves in the ground rather than extracting
and burning them."

                             Kashmir Images (India)

                             April 24, 2015 Friday

People protest after Friday prayers against Alam's detention

LENGTH: 157 words

DATELINE: Srinagar


Srinagar, April 24 -- Peaceful protests were held at various places after Friday
prayers against the detention of Hurriyat leader Masarat Alam Bhat.

Chairman of Hurriyat-G Syed Ali Shah Geelani had Thursday called for peaceful
protest after Friday prayers to protest the detention of Alam under the Public
Safety Act (PSA) and his shifting to Kotbalwal jail in Jammu.

Peaceful protests were held at Habba AKdal, Amira Kadal and other few places of
Srinagar city. Protests were also held in Nowhatta area of downtown Srinagar,
where there were also minor stone-pelting clashes.

Reports of protests were also received from other districts of Valley.

Meanwhile, authorities had placed some senior separatist leaders including
Geelani under house-arrest

                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                           January 7, 2015 Wednesday

Rise Of The Far-Right

SECTION: Vol. XXVIII No. 306

LENGTH: 404  words


In Dresden, the state capital of Saxony, Germany, almost 18,000 protesters
gathered to protest the 'Islamisation' of Europe, chanting nationalistic and
xenophobic slogans. The protests are organised by the group, Patriotic Europeans
Against the Islamisation of the Occident (PEGIDA), a populist movement that is
gaining momentum and spreading to other parts of Germany, incorporating neoNazis
and football hooligans along the way. Ostensibly, the movement aims to protect
the "JudeoChristian" culture of Europe, but the movement's true objection is
with the perceived loose immigration and asylum seeker laws in Germany, and
therefore all active measures proposed by the group is along those lines.
Antiimmigrant movements are not exclusive to Germany, or even this age; in times
of economic crises, discontent against the state latches on to the only visible
manifestation of lost economic opportunity: a migrant who holds the job that a
native might have held.

Throughout history, rise of the farright, antiimmigrant, nationalistic politics
has coincided with economic breakdowns. The Nazi party emerged from the shell of
Germany after the First World War just as the farright is resurfacing after the
European economic crisis. Golden Dawn in Greece, National Front in France,
United Kingdom Independence Party in the UK and the Swedish Democrats in Sweden
are all born of the same complaint, and have the same agenda. Islam just happens
to be the touchstone, the easily identifiable foe, against which protests can be
mobilised.

It is encouraging to see how the rest of Germany has responded to these
protests; antiPEGIDA protests have dwarfed the antiIslam protests. Chancellor
Angela Merkel, along with the senior leadership have come out to condemn the
"racist and xenophobic" protests. In Cologne, the city's landmark cathedral
dimmed its lights to mark its protest against PEGIDA. While majority of Germany,
and Europe for that matter views these protests as racist, they are nonetheless
gaining steam, and condemnation alone will not solve this. The solution lies in
fixing the broken international refugee regime under the International
Convention on the Rights of Refuges, which sees some countries, such as Germany,
take on more than its share of the burden. The conflict in the Middle East has
led to an outpour of refugees, and unless a fair system is developed, the
farright will continue gaining ammunition.

LOAD-DATE: January 7, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                 Copyright 2015 Nawai Waqt Group of Newspapers
                              All Rights Reserved


                              536 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                              Daily The Pak Banker

                            August 30, 2014 Saturday

PTI Karachi to block Shara-e-Faisal today

LENGTH: 380  words

DATELINE: KARACHI


In a bid to show its street power, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf has announced to
stage a protest sit-in today on Shara-e-Faisal, a major boulevard in Karachi.

"We have decided to launch a massive protest tsunami, which if the government
tried to stop, would be itself responsible for untoward consequences. We will
come out in full power tomorrow, come what may", a statement issued by the party
said.

According to sources, PTI core committee, in its meeting held, has finalized
protest demonstrations in major cities including Karachi as an extension to the
anti-government protest demonstration in Islamabad's 'Red Zone' after the party
leader Imran Khan's announcement.

"We will stage mega protest demonstrations in Lahore, Faisalabad, Multan, and
Karachi tomorrow (Saturday)", party leader Imran Khan told his workers staging
anti-government sit-in in front of Parliament House.

Laying out their protest plans, the PTI said in addition to Shara-e-Faisal
Karachi, rallies/sit-ins would be staged in Faisalabad's Zila Council Chowk,
Multan's Nawan Shehr Chowk, and Lahore to start with.

Shara-e-Faisal is one of the main thoroughfares in the metropolis and most of
the national and multinational companies' offices, schools, shopping plazas,
banks, and institutes are close to it.

Thousands of demonstrators led by Khan and Pakistan Awami Tehreek's (PAT) Dr
Tahir-ul-Qadri are camped outside the parliament building in Islamabad demanding
the prime minister step down.

More than a week of government efforts to negotiate an end to the standoff made
little headway, with Khan adamant the Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif must resign.

Khan, who had last night refused to compromise on his foremost demand of Prime
Minister Nawaz Sharif's resignation in a meeting with country's powerful army
chief, said he was absolutely incredulous of former's 'assurances'.

"I don't even have an iota of trust in Nawaz Sharif's promises as he has never
been a man of his word", Khan said.

Chairman PTI  said now it was a do-or-die struggle for him as there was no
turning back from this point.

"I have made up my mind. I have only two options: 'Independence or death'. There
are no two ways about it", Khan said.

Khan also underscored that he didn't want to give this government any 'breather'
by easing his stance.

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                            December 20, 2013 Friday

RSP too sore over Cliff House protest; LDF meet today

SECTION: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM

LENGTH: 363 words


THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The LDF state committee meeting to be held on Thursday will
review the ongoing Cliff House blockade protest launched by the LDF seeking the
resignation of chief minister Oommen Chandy. The meeting assumes significance as
the CPI and the RSP have made public their dissent to the mode of strike.

The CPM, however, is learnt to be adamant in continuing the protest. To
emphasize on the mode of protest and to counter charges that the common man is
at the receiving end of the protest, the CPM has organized a special blockade on
Thursday which will have women at the forefront. Women LDF volunteers from
different parts of the district will stage a blockade in front of the Cliff
House on Thursday. As if to give a strong message to dissenting LDF partners,
CPM state secretary Pinarayi Vijayan himself will reach Nanthancode to
inaugurate the day's protest. Wednesday's protest was inaugurated by CPI leader
Binoy Viswom.

Sources in the LDF said the CPI and the RSP will formally demand a change in the
ongoing mode of protest. On Tuesday, the CPI state secretariat decided to demand
a change of the protest venue as the party felt there was no point in blocking
the main road at Nanthancode in the name of blocking the Cliff House when the
chief minister roamed around freely.

On Wednesday, RSP general secretary T J Chandrachoodan came up with a stronger
criticism against the Cliff House siege. Chandrachoodan said there was no point
in insisting that one should stop the movement of others for conveying one's
demands. Commenting on how a single person could defame a massive struggle by
the LD, Chandrachoodan said, "The times have changed. There is no point in
sticking on to protests that extend for months. New modes of protests should be
devised at the age of social media", he suggested.

However, other constituents in the LDF are yet to take a decision on how to go
ahead with the protest. The Janata Dal (S) is also against the current protest
but it is not clear whether the party would raise any objection in the LDF
meeting. Other partners, Kerala Congress and Congress(S) would support whatever
stance the CPM takes.

                               Right Vision News

                           December 17, 2013 Tuesday

Pakistan: CNG sector, transporters start protests in Punjab

LENGTH: 557  words

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD


ISLAMABAD, Dec. 17 -- All Pakistan CNG Association (APCNGA) and transporters
will start protest demonstrations in all cities of Punjab, including the twin
cities of Rawalpindi and Islamabad, from Monday (today). Thousands of jobless
workers employed with the compressed natural gas (CNG) business and transporters
along with their families plan come out on the roads against gas disconnection.

The protest demonstrations will be staged in Rawalpindi, Gujranwala, Sialkot,
Lahore, Faisalabad, Wazirabad, Gujrat, Multan, Sahiwal and several other cities
of Punjab on Monday (today).

Chairman Supreme Council APCNGA Ghiyas Abdullah Paracha on Sunday said that in
first phase of protest, we would stage protest demonstrations in Rawalpindi,
Gujranwala, Sialkot, Lahore, Faisalabad, Wazirabad, Gujrat, Sahiwal and Multan
on a regular basis. In the second phase protest demonstrations would be held in
the other cities of the province. We will continue our protest till the
acceptance of our demands, he warned.

He said the SNGPL has suspended the supply of natural gas to the CNG sector in
Punjab for indefinite period without the approval of the government and despite
stiff opposition from the Planning Commission of Pakistan, which is illegal and
unconstitutional. The unilateral and ill-timed decision has disturbed the daily
life of million of people while posing serious threat to Rs450 billion
investments in the CNG sector, he said.

He said that unlike others the CNG sector is the only sector, which has no
alternative to the natural gas and it shuts down completely when gas supply is
suspended. The government and the CNG operators have signed an agreement for
supply of gas around the year, which is being violated, he said.

Ghiyas Paracha said that all other sectors using natural gas have option to run
on furnace oil or electricity but the government's axe falls on the CNG sector
if it decides to suspend gas supply. He said that load management means
reduction in supply and that the CNG operators will not allow complete closure
in the name of management.

The SNGPL's 'one-sided' and flawed decision, he said, has hiked the transport
fares, disturbed the daily life, encouraged black marketing of petrol and hiked
the LPG prices by Rs40 per kg.

On the one hand, he said, the government is introducing employment schemes and,
on the other, it is taking decision that will result in massive unemployment and
non-serviceability of tens of thousands

of commercial and private

vehicles.

Other leaders of the association said that our filling stations are closed all
across Punjab and there is reduced pressure in the provinces of Sindh and Khyber
Pakhtoonkhwa but the domestic consumers are still not

getting gas.

Paracha also said the CNG sector has been paying the highest tariff and maximum
taxes but it is subjected to injustices. Gas suspension has left CNG owners
unable to pay gas bills and salaries.

He said that suspension orders should be reversed, gas should be supplied to CNG
stations from 9 am to 7 pm without interruption, cases be registered against
those responsible for gas crisis and the government should honour its agreements

Published by HT Syndication with permission from Right Vision News. For any

contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                      Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 10, 2013 Tuesday

BRIEF: 255 participants of mass protests indicted in Turkey

BYLINE: Rufiz Hafizoglu, Trend News Agency, Baku, Azerbaijan

SECTION: NATIONAL POLITICAL NEWS

LENGTH: 194 words


Dec. 10--Around 255 participants of the mass protests in Turkey have been
indicted, Turkish Sabah newspaper reported on Dec.10 citing the sources at the
country's Prosecutor's Office.

There are seven foreign citizens among those who were accused of participation
in mass protests in various cities of Turkey, according to the newspaper.

The citizenship of the accused foreign citizens hasn't been mentioned, the
newspaper said.

Protests had been taking place in Turkey for nearly three weeks since the end of
May 2013. According to the authorities they were anti-government.

The Turkish oppositional parties accuse the police of using excessive force
against protestors.

In total, around 2.5 million people from 79 Turkish provinces participated in
protest actions during three weeks, the Turkish Interior Ministry said earlier.

As a result of the unrest in Turkey nearly 4,000 people were injured with
varying severity, 4,900 were detained by the police.

                                 The Messenger

                             March 10, 2013 Sunday

Christian community holds countrywide protests

SECTION: Vol. V No. 68

LENGTH: 269  words


The Christian community is holding protests throughout the country against
Badami Bagh, Lahore, incident. In Lahore, the protestors completely destroyed
Yuhana Abad Metro Bus Station and set ablaze electric transformer.

Police used tear gas and rounded up some miscreants. PPP Minority Wing also held
a protest rally in front of Punjab Assembly against Badami Bagh incident.

On the other hand 5 policemen were injured in tone pelting by the protestors at
Ferozepur road. Christian community also held a protest demonstration at
Faizabad interchange Rawalpindi against the incident.

In Faisalabad, the District Aman Committee protested against the Lahore
incident. Local Islamic clerics, students and people from various walks of life
also attended the protest   demonstration. Police resorted to tear gas shelling
and aerial firing in front of Press Club to disperse the protest rally in
Karachi. The demonstrators turned violent and torched some of the vehicles and
pelted stones at police.

Protests were also reported in Mandi Bahaudin, Sargodha, Gojra, Dera Ismail
Khan, Peshawar and Gujranwala. In Sindh, Christian communities held protest
demonstrations in Karachi and Sukkur. The protesters demanded to immediately
arrest  miscreants. Meanwhile, Chief Minister Punjab Shahbaz Sharif visited the
Josef Colony and directed authorities to swiftly address the grievances of the
people.

He said Badami Bagh incident is an attempt to mutilate the image of Pakistan. He
said culprits will be brought to justice. Pakistan Qaumi Masiha Party and
Pakistan Minorities League staged a protest outside Lahore Press Club on Sunday.

                                 Target series

                               November 21, 2012

Immigration protest group plan event in Spalding after 'success' in Boston

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 261  words


More than 300 people have attended a static protest against what they claim are
high-levels of immigration in Boston.

The Boston Protest Group claimed the "peaceful demonstration" was aimed at
highlighting the pressure put on local services by migrant workers.

Protest organiser Dean Everitt said he was pleased with the turnout: "It was a
peaceful protest. There was no trouble at all. We even had a migrant worker in
the crowd talking to the protestors. It was a really good atmosphere.

"We had a really good turnout of between 300 and 350 people.

"The council need to go back to the drawing board and rethink this."

Protestors held banners ranging from "Free Us From The Shackles of Europe" to
"Get Back Our Country.

Mr Everitt is now planning another protest in Spalding after Christmas.

The protest march was planned for last year but was cancelled after the borough
council agreed to set up a task force.

A report on population change was published as a result, but campaigners said it
had not gone 'far enough' and the Government still needed to listen.

Boston and Skegness MP Mark Simmonds said: "Freedom of speech and the right to
protest are important aspects of our society and culture. I am encouraged that
Sunday's protest remained peaceful and that attendees were able to exercise
their rights without hindrance."

The protest was organised after the publication of Boston Borough Council's
report on population change

The Social Impact of Population Change report was approved at a meeting of the
council on Monday.

It looks at issues surrounding migration in Boston.

                             October 8, 2012 Monday

Different protests staged in Hyderabad

SECTION: Vol. VII No. 411

LENGTH: 413  words


Different protest demonstrations were staged by people in favor of their demands
outside the Hyderabad Press Club on Sunday.

According to details, the civil society of Hyderabad continued its hunger strike
against the LG Bill passed by the Sindh Assembly for the fourth consecutive day.
While talking to newsmen, the leaders including Punhal Sario, Zulfiqar Halepoto,
Mukhtiar Abbasi and others said that the PPP has imposed black law in Sindh to
prolong its tenure with the support of its coalition party.

They said that despite the protests by entire Sindh, the government is not ready
to amend or abolish the bill which is a sign of their insincerity towards the
people of Sindh. They said that the people of Sindh would not let anyone to
divide their motherland. Meanwhile, the activists of Labor Party Sindh led by
Comrade Mubarak Jatoi, Faiz Keerio and others recorded a protest demonstration
against the Local Government Bill 2012. Their protest was followed by another
demonstration by the social welfare organization known as the Youths' Network
for Human Rights led by Abdul Nabi Mallah and others.

They also demanded of the government to immediately abolish the LG Bill,
otherwise they have threatened to accelerate their protest circle. The residents
of Doctors' Colony Hyderabad protested against the attack on Shoukat Magsi's
house in Darzi Goth Karachi. A woman namely Farzana alias Arbab Zadi, resident
of village Tharo Khan Marri staged a protest demonstration against the
kidnapping of her husband Abdul Sattar and three children.

A woman namely Zeenat along with her son Nadir Khoso protested against the
Pabban Police for arresting Ghulam Nabi Khoso without any case. A woman namely
Bhag Bhari, resident of Shaheed Benazirabad recorded a protest demonstration
against the actions of the influential men, who have occupied her home. A woman
namely Azizan, resident of Shah Latif Colony staged a protest demonstration for
the recovery of her abducted brother Liaquat Ali. Activists of JSQM Wehdat
Colony led by Irshad Ali Junejo and others recorded a protest demonstration
against registrations of alleged fake cases against party leader Ghulam Haider
Dharejo.

Wistro community people, residents of Naushehro Feroze led by Qamaruddin Wistro
and others recorded a protest demonstration against the actions of the local
police for torching their homes. The activists of Jamaat-e-Islami led by Abdul
Waheed Qureshi and others protested against the poor sanitary system.

                              544 of 995 DOCUMENTS



                                  Moscow News

                            August 2, 2012 Thursday

Analysts disagree over protest poll

SECTION: POLITICS

LENGTH: 445 words


Political analysts cannot agree on the meaning of a recent poll showing both
growing support and discontent with protests.

The latest poll by Levada Center showed that 42 percent of respondents support
the rallies that have been going on since December. It is 11 percent more than
in March and close to December's numbers, when 44 percent supported the
protests. Forty-seven percent said they were against the protests, and 11
percent could not say.

Economic problems

Some experts stress that raising tariffs, utility payments and alcohol prices
could lead to a new wave of protests, while the majority did not notice the
government's actions against the opposition.

Discontent is growing with two groups of people - one is unhappy about rising
prices, the other is unhappy about the new repressive laws, deputy head of
Levada Center Alexei Grazhdankin told Kommersant.

Grazhdankin is referring to the law that allows for the blocking of blacklisted
Internet web sites and another law that strengthens punishments for
participating in and organizing unsanctioned rallies.

People are fed up with protests

However, the figures for protests are still a bit lower than those in December,
at the peak of Russian protest activity, director general of the Institute of
Priority Regional   Projects, Nikolai Mironov, told RIA Novosti.

He argued that the population has no reason to protest because the reforms
demanded by the protesters in the end of 2011 have been implemented.

'Of course, there are a lot of unsolved problems that demand further action,
corruption, for example. But as we can see, in general in Russia these problems
do not cause protests. But the effective work of public organizations is
ongoing: demands are made, laws are written, conferences are held. Public
activity is not falling.'

He added that while there could be a rise in protest activity in September,
there would be a steady decline after that.

Higher School of Economics professor and political analyst Oleg Matveichev,
however, stressed that the number of people opposing the protests rose together
with the number of supporters, which means that the protest movement has no
future.

'I think those who say that they support it will not go to the rallies
themselves, because they are sick of going 10 times, considering the new laws
and dangers on their way,' he said.

He argued that the protests were the result of singular events - the elections
and the inauguration.

'The society is tired of protests: everyone is fed up with everybody walking
around and destabilizing the situation in the country. This is why there are
more people with a negative view of it,' he said.
